review_body: This is the best hotel coffeeshop in Tokyo but with some drawbacks. In normal times, a reservation is necessary and for a hotel coffeeshop that is a bother. Regretfully the pricing is ridiculous for most items on the menu but if that is the price I have o pay to keep it, as it is, then, ok, I will. Still it seems not difficult to understand that instead of asking nearly 2000 yen for a glass of champagne it is better to sell a bottle at 12,000 to 15000 of, for example ,Bollinger or Taittinger as you might actually sell them. Service is nice but slow, but that is ok, when I go there, I am not in a hurry.

First, if you have any concerns, this is a luxury hotel with impeccable staff and service. The location is outstanding making it a very convenient trip from Nartita. Don't hesitate to request ahead of time to be met at your train by staff as navigating the trip from the train to the hotel is challenging for any seasoned traveler. It's just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the outstanding service provided by the concierge team. As a guest we were afforded access to the health club onsite for a nominal charge. The facility is luxury as well. Our lunch in the main floor exceeded it's already stellar reputation. The luxury, staff and service made this a highlight of our trip to Hong Kong, Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka. Even after checking out and leaving for Kyoto, on the way back through Tokyo Station, staff met us at our train and took our luggage to the Narita Express. Their is no way we could have navigated the train station in time to make our connection. REMEMBER, WE HAD ALREADY CHECKED OUT OF OUR HOTEL A WEEK PRIOR when they contacted us asking what train we were on from Kyoto, to make sure they met us at the train car. They also assisted us in purchasing tickets to Kyoto after we checked out. Just as when we arrived, they carried our luggage and gleefully engaged us in conversation and delivered us to our destination. At this point, I want to make the special effort to acknowledge the lead Chief Concierge Marie Antoinette Mori and one member of her staff, Miyuki Saito.

We had a wonderful few days here. The staff were absolutely charming and could not have been more helpful - including helping us with our luggage to the platform for Shinkansen & Narita Express. Rooms have recently been renovated, everything is tip top.

Their prominent breakfast buffet had to be stopped and replaced with fixed set menu, but the hotel was trying their best to cope with the current situation. Staffs were quite nice, ideal location, the walk to the front desk from the room is a little pain as the hotel is stretched horizontal to the train station. As a tourist, I asked few questions at the concierge getting around Tokyo and was astonished when asked “don’t you have a cell phone,” as if I should do my own research. Typical of the service targeted for non-Japanese tourist but they could do better.

We loved our stay. The hotel itself is beautiful and luxurious. The staff are so kind and pleasant. The lounge downstairs is a very relaxing place to have a drink and listen to the harpist. The rooms are small but super comfortable. The view from the windows is an added touch. The bathrooms are massive and loved the shower head. We would stay here again for sure. Great location too.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is full of rich heritage. If the walls could talk!!! This hotel was once the offices of the railway station. Check in as smooth a silk and I was guided to my room. Heritage brochure given on arrival and walls full of paintings, prints and photographs of the buildings former life. The hotel has a wonderful selection of restaurants - I chose Camellia for dinner which is a bar / restaurant, which was an excellent choice - sausages and onion rings - delicious with some Japanese whisky. Bar staff speak excellent English which is so for all the hotel. To the Lobby Lounge for a nightcap - not my intention but I heard the harp music being played with such angelic talent my attention was lost in absorbing attraction. If I had known I would have arrived much earlier.Breakfast the following morning - my, what a selection in the Dome. I didn’t know where to start but I went around several times to sample a little of each on offer. I was suitably impressed with this restaurant also. As I was leaving the waiter gave me a cookie and crisp bread to take away as I told him I was taking a train from Tokyo later that morning. This is a hotel that mixes the arts and heritage. It is inspirational for its history. The concierge were helpful though they chose to check museum opening by the internet rather than calling (it being the weekend of the introduction of limitation of opening caused by Covid 19), and hence I was misinformed. Front desk super efficient and looked after my bags until I returned four days later. The only downside of this hotel is the size of some of the rooms - my cupola room was just 30 Sq meters. I understand that the shape and size is dictated much by the nature and shape of the building. Notwithstanding, I didn’t spend too much time in my room so no big issues. The proximity to the station is one very positive element to staying here. All platforms within walking distance.A great hotel and a wonderful experience, especially for rail enthusiasts. I love my stay here!

My first visit to Tokyo, so lucky to have been recommended to this hotel. Reading the history of the hotel and it's transformation into what it is today is really interesting. The hotel is in a small group of hotels which i would not hesitate to stay at again. The attention to detail, the service by the staff, quality of the food, decor and cleanliness are exceptional a truly wonderful stay, well done to all involved. The location is great, its part of the station, whether you are travelling locally or further afield by the "Bullet" its all minutes away. Also a short walk from the Imperial Palace, close to numerous restaurants and shops a perfect location to see Tokyo from.

Beautiful hotel! We contacted them ahead of time to arrange meeting us at the train station to help us with our luggage and we were greeted by 2 staff members right at our train car. The room was a bit small but lovely. Gorgeous rainwater shower. Great location to the train and an easy walk to the Imperial Gardens. I did find it strange that they would allow you to use the computer in the business center for 10 minutes with a charge of 100 Yen. All of the hotels I’ve stayed at had a business room with computers with no time limit or charge. It’s just bizarre that a hotel of this caliber would do this. I still loved the hotel and would highly recommend it!

Back again for a second stay and it was still very pleasant. The location is unbeatable for taking trains all around and to Narita. Service is still good. The hotel is really elegant. This time round my room faced the direction of the palace and that makes it nicer than the dome facing room in my opinion.

Loved staying in this beautiful hotel at the train station. The location is awesome and the hotel is very elegant. The staff were super kind , attentive, knowledgeable, spoke perfect English for those who do not speak Japanese. Our room super clean and very comfortable with great amenities, very quiet as well. The staff stored our luggage on our check out day. They also escorted us all the way down to the Narita Express platform, assisting with our luggage. That was such a kind gesture, possibly they sensed I was concerned about not missing the train. Very lovely, polished, kind staff. They were also very genuine, asked why we chose their hotel and loved hearing our responses. I want to go back!

What a beautiful hotel with wonderful staff. Japan is renowned for its expensive hotels and sometimes you don’t necessarily get value for money but here this bucks the trend. This is a stunning renovated hotel In the confines of the magnificent architecture of Tokyo station. You are wonderfully greeted by passionate and caring staff and the decor is modern chic with a lovely finish. The food is great too and all the rooms have high ceilings due to the renovation of the old station. A must stay if you can. Location excellent, staff excellent, room excellent! We WILL return!!!!!

I have been to Tokyo 4 times in the last 5 years.The combination of rich cultural diversity, kind/helpful people,safety,efficient transportation system and quality of foodis second to none.If you want to take advantage of what Tokyo has to offer Tokyo Station Hotel is the place to stay.Access to hundreds of restaurant, stores,and transportation is literally right under your feet.The Imperial Palace, fashionable Ginza and Nihonbashi are within walking distance.Rooms are spacious, immaculate with very comfortable bed and pillows and a large bathroom with a rain shower to die for.Both Japanese and western breakfast are sumptuous. However,service is what defines Tokyo Station Hotel.Japanese hospitality at its best! The best Concierge Service in Tokyo helmed by Ms.Marie Antionette Mori and assisted by Ms.Miyuki Saito will open the door not only to the most difficult Michellin starred restaurant but also guide you to the the best pizza, ramen,tea,pokemon/yukata store and cutlery nearby. There is nothing better!We will certainly be back after the Olympics.

This should be ‘big’ luxe in CBD Tokyo. Impeccable service during 3 night stay for work. Staff are highly attentive with the best hospitality. The location is superb for both work and play. We got a huge room which looks into the square with awesome view of the Palace in the horizon. Breakfast at the Atrium was splendid - loved the special crab omelette and salmon avo egg benny. Espresso at the Atrium must be the best in town. Highly recommended

I visited this wonderful hotel twice on my most recent trip to Tokyo, and it was just the same old wonderful Tokyo Station Hotel as I have known each and every time I’ve visited Japan. Its luxurious ambiance, friendly staff and comfortable amenities make it the only hotel in which I will EVER stay in Tokyo, and I heartily recommend it to any traveler coming here. The Duty Manager, Yoshiki Kamata, couldn’t be nicer, more helpful or more pleasant. If you miss staying here you’re making a BIG mistake! My HIGHEST recommendation!

We are leaving this Hotel today. We are a family of 4 from HONOLULU HAWAII. Our kids are 4 and 14. This hotel is formal and its layout it like a football field long. The layout of the hotel stays true to the original 1915 building, but its cramped, has 14' high ceilings and very small rooms. They required us to buy 2 rooms to house the family. I wanted to buy a $1200 2 floor room with ample sq footage, but even that was not allowed (meaning occupancy by more than 2). So they are very much a luxury type hotel but for us (being from Hawaii, but totally used to travel all over the world) the rules were a burden, and detracted from our stay. The elevator to the spa was 60 yards down a hall tot he first floor, then get off and walk to another elevator to get to the basement. Nothing FLOWS here. We are on a wing and the logical entrances are blocked off (meaning not open) so we have to walk 60 yards to the main are, then down, and 60 yards back to the same location to get 2 floors down outside. Totally inconvenient and abnormal considering it being a luxury hotel. We were given 1 key for each room. To get into the hallway you need a key. To power up the room you need a key. So this meant figuring our who could go where and when, as when I asked for another key (for a total of 2 per room) it was advised it was not policy, and then met with confusion. They sent a bellman with another key. Thanks! but this made the original key unusable! So we still had only 1 key. So I went down the 60 yard hall to the main check in area to get a second key for each room. More language confusion ensued. AHHHH. My overall impression is that the PEOPLE here are so humble, kind and helpful. The rules are not flexible even to common sense. And this recipe makes it a place I wouldn't recommend unless you're a seasoned Japanese traveler. We had another episode trying house the spa. Down the 60 yard hell. Advised that we should NOT be wearing robes in the hotel common area. Looked at in shock. We went all the way back to change into normal clothes, bringing our swim suites with us this time. back down he 60 yard hall, only to find out the spa is gender separate, and no kids allowed. (of course) So by now we've walked this place so may times without getting anything done its soured us. Again. Not the people. Its the Policies. The 2020 Olympics are coming here. Id imagine these luxury hotels might want to get a little Flexible and stop with the unbending rules or it'll make for some unhappy guests. Japan. We love your culture in general. But this formality is a burden! With respect. Mahalo!

A pleasant enough hotel in a wonderfully restored building, The Tokyo Station Hotel may be a little too focused on serving the well-healed commuters and office workers that stream past its doors each day. Hotel residents are left to squeeze into any space left by office workers in the bar, lounge and other public areas. Our room was fine - well maintained and with a decent amount of space. We were facing the station, so the view from our window was of…..the exterior of the station I guess. I really great touch is the in-room mini-tablet that has free internet access via the mobile phone network. You can take it on your travels around Tokyo, with all the attendant benefits of internet access without roaming charges. The Tokyo Station Hotel was the least-best of the four hotels that accommodated us during repeated visits to Tokyo. There’s nothing wrong with The Tokyo Station Hotel as such – we just had a nicer stay at our other Tokyo hotels.

The place is very conducive in meeting friends especially on its open park.I was just lucky & happy to visit the place and take a glimpse of it.Japanese is an advanced country having the Tokyo Station Building & beside it is THE TOKYO STATION HOTEL.

I visited this hotel on beginning of December 2019. I was so impress with the reservation service’s help for me as early arrival guests. Their help was much appreciate! I also impressed with the concierge team who helps in arranging suggesting and reserving my trip also help about traveling within Tokyo to my destinations. This made me have a perfect trip! I was so enjoy staying here with very nice and clean room with superb location.

I would like to endorse all of the great reviews on this special hotel in Tokyo. It has been a terrific base for a wonderful first trip to Tokyo for our family of four. I would like to thank Miyuki and Marie (Concierges) especially who have been exceptionally helpful with their assistance with recommendations and bookings for wonderful restaurants, museums and our outbound train travel. They really went above and beyond. We especially enjoyed Ginza Kyubey restaurant and Mori Borderless Art Museum. Thank you!

The Tokyo Station Hotel has been in the Tokyo station since 1915. One of JR East Japan Group, big Japanese company. The nobel Prize-winning author, Yasunari Kawabata (my high school senior) stayed here to write his works. Another famous writers like Seicho Matsumoto stayed to write their works. The Tokyo Station Hotel had an academic ambience, but the location is very convenient. Yes. it is in the station, but very quiet, clean and an upscale boutique hotel. I stayed at the Duplex type room, with a king size bed. Very comfortable. During my staying, I spent quiet and romantic night in my room and at Oak Bar. Next morning after good sleep, I enjoyed very delicious breakfast. Perfect staying!

In a country where hospitality is already highly valued, the Tokyo Station Hotel stands out for service, warmth, and grace. The room was very quiet despite its location in a busy transit hub. The concierge was extremely helpful. We plan to stay at Tokyo Station the next time we are in Tokyo.

I had a great stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel from 16 – 20 Dec 2019. The hotel staff were very friendly and efficient. They speak English well and we had no problem in communications. We were greeted as soon as we arrived the lobby. Since we arrived in the morning, they managed to check us in early. The check in was super quick and staff sent our luggage to room. The room (we stayed in a family room) was very clean and spacious. Overall, the decoration of the hotel looks elegant. The staff are very helpful. I would like to specifically thank Ms Hakuro (Hope I got her name right). She spent quite some time to help me book the Airport Limousine bus. I will recommend the Tokyo Station Hotel to spend a lovely holiday in Tokyo.

What is good about this hotel: beautifully furnished with nearly every amentity in the rooms. Outstanding, obliging and fast service. Breakfasts to die for. Great location if you are arriving by train from the airport[s], as it is part of Tokyo Central Station - it even has its own private entrance from the Station. Located in the Marunouchi area, a good district for shopping and dining out.What it lacks: spacious and convenient public rooms. Handy public washrooms.The drawback: owing to its shape, running the length of the station, it is very long and accordingly you might have to walk as much as 150 metres to reach your room. You will have baggage service, but this could be a disadvantage for elderly people.Do not be put off by the fact that this hotel is on a Station - you will not be aware of the trains or any noise whatsoever!

I spent four nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel. The hotel continues to impress me, having last stayed here a couple of years ago.Great location - right inside Tokyo Station making it very convenient for transpiration, and a short walk to the Imperial Palace. Staff are all courteous and professional.Breakfast is fantastic - really enjoyed the Japanese selection.The room is pretty small, but the bathroom is well-sized with excellent water pressure.The one downside: the gym! It only opens at 7am during the week (and even later in the weekend), which isn’t ideal if you’re here for work and want to do a workout before meetings in the morning. There’s also very limited AC in the gym, which means that it gets stuffy very quickly (I understand that this appears to be a cultural thing though). Great technogym equipment though.

A wonderful hotel at an excellent location in the heart of Marunochi. Have stayed here over my past five visits to Tokyo and it is still remains so well maintained and beautiful. Room was very clean, nice and so comfortable. The hotel concierge was extremely helpful in assisting me in all of my restaurant reservations and planned them so detailed and well. Other hotel service staff were also very helpful to my other requests and needs. A real top-notch hotel with outstanding service.

I stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel with a group of friends while visiting Japan for a holiday, and the experience was nothing short of impeccable. The staff were friendly, helpful, and willing to go above and beyond to accommodate us and ensure our stay was pleasant. The levels of service we received was nothing short of world-class. The location was also fantastic, we were ideally situated to explore the best that Japan has to offer. I would also like to mention the Chief Concierge, Marie Antoinette Mori, who is an exceptional asset to the team. It was a pleasure to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel and I will be recommending this hotel to friends and family who are travelling to Japan.

This was our first visit to Japan. We flew into Haneda airport, then took the monorail to Hammamatsucho Station followed by the local train to Tokyo Station. Our total journey time was around 40 minutes.The Tokyo Station Hotel is part of the station building, but you must be careful to exit through the correct ticket barrier so you don’t end up on the wrong side (it’s a very big station and you can’t walk through without a valid ticket).It is a beautiful small hotel, with luxurious bedrooms and bathrooms including, of course, the Japanese state-of-the-art electronic bidet-toilet! We were tired from our flight so except for venturing out to a local pizzeria we stayed in our room to rest. We had a pleasant view onto the large square in front of the station.The bed was big and comfortable with beautiful bedding, and the room was quiet, so perfect for a good night’s rest.Breakfast was served upstairs in the conservatory and was a huge buffet selection of both Western and Japanese breakfast items. It was delicious, and as we were leaving the restaurant the staff gave us a gift of a wrapped rice cake to eat later on our journey. (It was also delicious, we ate it later on the Bullet Train).The Reception staff were extremely helpful, polite and efficient. Check-in was seamless and a young lady accompanied us to our room to show us around and answer any questions. They lent us umbrellas when we ventured out for a morning walk in the rain.On our departure a young man accompanied us into the train station, wheeling both of our suitcases, and took us all the way to the platform gate where we would board our Bullet Train. We felt this service went above and beyond our expectations.Overall this hotel was a fabulous introduction to Tokyo and Japan, and our only regret was we did not stay longer. We would definitely stay here again if we ever return to Tokyo.

My husband, daughter and I spent three nights at the hotel earlier this month. The service was outstanding as was the cleanliness of the hotel. The rooms were very comfortable and well appointed and immaculate and the bathrooms were updated and lovely. We were greeted cheerfully by staff as we left and arrived at the hotel each day.

This is a very unique property with its location right above Tokyo Station. I stayed here with my wife and we were very impressed by the quality and professionalism of the concierge team. Would recommend for anyone staying in Tokyo without hesitation.

Loved to stay at this iconic place with the homely feel. Despite it being right in the busiest spot of Tokyo Station, this luxury place provide very cosy private setting for limited number of guests. Turn right out of the serene hotel door is Shinkansen ticket office with lots of commuters, quite a convenient contrast. You can get to anyway so easily by all transportation types. Breakfast was outstanding and worth to highlight, with both variety and quality. It’s only served to hotel guests in a beautiful high ceiling loft of the Tokyo Station building. Comfortable stay beginning to end..

This recently renovated hotel is located adjacent to the main Tokyo Station. Yet the rooms are sound proofed so you would never know this.It is especially convenient if you fly into Narita airport and take the Narita Express to Tokyo Station.With an advanced request, the hotel staff will meet you at the Narita Express platform at the sprawling, multilevel Tokyo Train Station. You need to let them know which NEX train you are on. The rooms in the 100 year old hotel are small but have very high ceilings so you do not feel cramped. The rooms have many modern lighting features and other electronic features desired by modern travelers. The bed was very comfortable and I slept well. The bathroom was amazing and very well-equipped, with plenty of hot water and pressure. The automatic Toto toilet was something I will miss here in the USA – yes, amazing. The hotel even provides cotton sleeping wear, in a nightstand drawe and slippers in the closet..I booked a package that included their guest-only buffet breakfast in their Atrium dining room. The selection and quality of the food was superb, with both Japanese and Western options. It is well worth the upgrade.The staff was very professional – attentive yet friendly. Maid and laundry service accommodating and responsive. The Concierge was supportive with restaurant and tourist information. language was not an issue.The hotel common areas are somewhat limited, with a small public lobby. There is a lobby lounge with an evening harpist, where drinks and light food is served. The other common areas are refined and very well-maintained. The hotel also has some world class restaurants and a small gift shop. The neighborhood is filled mainly with high-rise office buildings which also have some excellent restaurants, but the Imperial Palace is a short walk away. Of course, Tokyo station is full of more quick grab very affordable food choices as well.Hard to beat the location because it is a transportation hub with the subways, taxis and trains as very easy access.

This hotel is stunning from an architectural perspective and everything is first class. The rooms are very well appointed with every amenity you could think of. All of the staff members are extremely helpful and friendly, both before and during our stay. The location is ideal for getting around as it is very centrally located. We took a bullet train and since the hotel is attached to the central Tokyo rail station we just needed to figure out which exit to use and head upstairs.

This was a relaxing, delightful stay, in the absolute heart of Tokyo, a short walk from the imperial palace, Ginza, and of course directly above Tokyo Station. My goal was to stay there for 1.5 days (two nights) to rest, work, and acclimate to the Japanese time zone prior to an important business meeting in northern Japan. Mission accomplished! The room was exquisitely furnished, with beautiful, highly variable lighting (something I particularly appreciate) the bed was very comfortable, and despite being near a street, their was absolute silence in the room due to the super insulated windows. The spa (an extra $18 or 2000 yen) was a highlight. A carbonated hot tub, with two other tubs of various temperatures, sauna, steam, and all meticulously clean and relaxing. A truly memorable stay, but at ~$500/night, obviously a splurge!

There are many expensive hotels, plenty of nice ones but only a few that combine such detailed, personal service and room appointments as well at the Tokyo Station hotel. Service included an escort from reception to the adjacent railway station down a series of passaged and escalators for the airport train, help with ticketing and an email enquiry before arrival about the sort of things I might want. The room was beautiful - high-ceilinged, quiet and peaceful - lighting and bathroom controls straightforward, everything where it should be. In-room massage was wonderful. This isn't a big hotel so its relatively easy to find your way around the lovely 100 y.o building. Willl stay here again!

This was my first trip to Japan, so I decided to indulge myself with a hotel that was very close to the main Tokyo Station. I predicted that after a long-haul flight from DFW to NRT, I would be ready to quickly settle in at the first stop of the Narita Express (N’EX). Great decision and choice on several accounts.With an advanced request, the hotel staff will meet you at the Narita Express platform at the sprawling, multilevel Tokyo Train Station. You need to let them know which NEX train you are on. I was unable to provide them with the needed NEX information upon arrival due to my jet lag, but I made it nonetheless. The hotel Concierge was heartfeltly concerned that I had not communicated with the hotel but relieved that I still made it work. This set the stage and tone for a wonderful, albeit only two-night stay.Yes, my king-bed room was small but impeccably furnished. The bed was firm but luxurious, and the bathroom was immaculate and very well-equipped, with plenty of hot water and pressure. The Toto toilet was amazing – yes, amazing. The hotel even provides cotton sleeping wear, in a nightstand drawer.I booked a package that included their guest-only buffet breakfast in their Atrium dining room. The selection and quality of the food was superb, with both Japanese and Western options. It is well worth the upgrade.The staff was very professional – attentive yet friendly. The Concierge walked with me to the nearby JR East ticket counter to assist me in purchasing my JR Hokuriku Shinkansen train ticket to my business meeting in Karuizawa. He also helped my buy a Suica card for the metro/subway, for when I return to Tokyo.The hotel common areas are somewhat limited, with no public lobby per se but a lobby lounge, where drinks and light food is served. The other common areas are refined and very well-maintained. There are a myriad of restaurants and shops in the Tokyo Station. The neighborhood is filled mainly with high-rise office buildings, but the Imperial Palace is a short walk away.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel at the start of our recent trip to Japan. This is a very good hotel with wonderful service, ideally sitautyed in the Marunouchi area near the Imperial Palace. The immediate surroundings also offer a more relaxed feel to other parts of Tokyo, yet are within easy striking distance. Rooms are very comfortable, a good size and the service from all team members is excellent.

The hotel is beautiful and very well located. Being in the train station makes it very easy to do day trip around Tokyo. The rooms are large and very well appointed. They are also very quiet. The breakfast had lots of choices and was very good. The concierge was excellent. She arranged for someone to escort my daughter to the train platform with all her luggage to make sure she got on the Narita Express with out any problems. The service overall at the hotel is impeccable. I look forward to staying here again when I return to Tokyo!

Very good location and room, the concierge-team before and during my visit was a real highlight. I had many, sometimes difficult and complicated, reservation request and they always came back in incredible detail. Will gladly return.

The location of this magnificent hotel was the perfect spot for my first visit to this wonderful city. From the moment we arrived, we felt most welcome and pampered. The staff was accommodating and helpful. Loved the understated ambiance. The room (Twin) with a view toward the Imperial Palace was quite spacious & beautifully appointed. The bathroom amenities ("Est. 1915") were a special perk. The breakfast room with an incredible skylight and a delicious assortment of food was a perfect start to the day. My hotel of choice for my next trip to Tokyo.

This is our second time staying at the Tokyo Station Hotel. The first time in 2017 impressed us so much that we had to stay here again. The location was excellent, room was very clean, the amenities were well appointed and the service was tops!When we checked in, the front desk noticed that my birthday was just past so they arranged for a special souvenir photograph which they presented to me upon checkout. Also, on checkout day, we did a day trip to Kawagoe and we did not have much time between our arriving train from Kawagoe and departing train to Tokyo that evening. When I mentioned this to the hotel, they arranged for someone to bring our luggage to the shinkansen platform so that we would not have to run up to the hotel to retrieve luggage and miss our departing train to Tokyo. That was really some service! The front desk manager Kamata-san and his staff were very helpful.Needless to say, we will be staying at this hotel the next time we are in Tokyo.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel for three great days in October 2019. We had never been to Japan and it was difficult to decide where to stay. The main purpose of our trip was to enjoy the fine dining and culture of Japan. The hotel is perfect. It is on top of Tokyo Station and located central to Japan with good access throughout by subway and rail. It is also a short walk to Ginza and the Imperial Palace. The hotel was recently remodeled and just as nice as the Ritz Carlton's and Four Season's that we have recently stayed at. In addition, while expensive, it probably is the fairest priced for the high end hotels. The hotel is smaller than the photos look because it is in Tokyo Station with probably about 100-200 rooms. The breakfast was also amazing with both Japanese and Western breakfasts available. The highlight of our stay there was the dining that the concierge's arranged. I had asked them several months ahead of time to try to book several of the top end restaurants in Tokyo. We asked to dine at Sukiyabashi Jiro, Sushi Yoshitake and Tempura Fukamachi and they were able to arrange all three and they were truly amazing. There is no way we could reserve any restaurants there. They also gave us some wonderful places for Ramen and other restaurants. When we return to Tokyo we will certainly return to the Tokyo Station Hotel.

The hotel exceeded my expectations. I loved my room (Maranouchi-side Twin), and it was much larger than I was expecting for a central Tokyo hotel. It was very clean and had every amenity I could ask for in a luxury property---I loved the in-house pajamas! Staff were beyond friendly and helpful. The Concierge team, especially, went above and beyond for me, and I appreciated their efforts in bookings they made. I loved my stay, would love to stay again, and would not hesitate to recommend this wonderful hotel.

After a 12 hour flight what a relief to be greeted ( free meet and greet) at the train station after we caught the narita express in - our guy was amazing. Grabbed our bags and negotiated the maze of elevators etc while we followed him faithfully back to this incredible hotel. So beautiful and calm oasis after a busy 24 hours / lovely upgrade was appreciated. It should be noted that twin rooms are so much better than a double as the beds are huge and can be pushed together Lovely linen too and views from the window overlooking the plaza and RWC amazing signage. Thank you for a fabulous welcome first night to Japan

Room was clean and the location was great. Nothing particularly special about the room (it was entry level category though). Fantastic service from the lady who showed me to my room. All the ladies at the concierge ‘/ front door were super helpful while the gentlemen at the concierge / guest relations were offhand . Overall a pleasant stay.

This was my second visit to this wonderful hotel. The rooms are great; the location is fantastic; and the breakfast is probably the best anywhere in the world. However, the service this time was quite uneven. (1) The person at the Concierge had a slight attitude. (2) The man at Guest Relations had an attitude. (3) The man at the Check In desk did not let me check in at 2PM when other guests were led to their rooms, and I had an Amex special booking. Also, he did not give me a room upgrade when my special booking allowed for one. While the service on my first was unbelievably good, on my second visit, I regret to say that it was so uneven that I will try another hotel next time I'm in Tokyo. Maybe the new Okura or the Palace Hotel might have better service.

I'll first echo what most reviewers have said...The hotel is beautiful and clean. The rooms are large for Japan, and the bathrooms huge. The staff are incredibly friendly and helpful. The breakfast has a large assortment of delicious options. The location was very convenient.Some new points...While I found the gym ordinary, I didn't find the staff to be a nuisance as done have written. They were always around and ready to offer help when needed (e.g. helping to add weights, spotting, clean equipment). I was surprised to find a hyperbaric chamber which was fun to try. It was also inexpensive to use the gym as a long-stay guest; 1000¥ gave day access, with use of spa, and exercise gear.Overall had a wonderful time staying at the hotel.

Having travelled from the UK we arrived at the hotel at c1.30pm. We were aware that our room would not be ready until 3pm - however, we were amazed that the hotelcouldn’t offer us a coffee or a glass of water while we waited - as their coffee shop was full. This was just the beginning - as we then found that we had been allocated a twin room instead of a double. Not acceptable and no other rooms available. Very poor.

First, the obvious. The Tokyo Station Hotel is very convenient for Tokyo station. So convenient, in fact, that it’s possible to have a room looking directly onto the station concourse. This historic building was sympathetically restored a few years ago. The staff are absolutely outstanding; when my husband thought he had dropped his watch outside the hotel, the bellboy who had shown us to our room went personally to the nearest police box to see if it had been handed in. When we somewhat sheepishly reported that we had found it in the room, they couldn’t have been nicer. The rooms are snug, as in most Tokyo hotels, but the bathroom is big. Breakfast is on offer at the 4th floor atrium, a light and airy room, and is only open to residents. It is a real treat - a veritable feast of hot and cold, Western and Japanese, much of it with labels explaining where it has been sourced from. In an age of luxury chain hotels, the Tokyo Station Hotel stands out for its individuality, the professionalism of its staff and its sheer class.

A beautiful early 1900's brick building that sits astride the massive transportation hub of Tokyo Station. Impeccably appointed rooms and seamless professional service. This hotel is a calm quiet oasis just a step away from one of Japan's busiest transportation hubs. The rooms are spacious and comfortable, with huge bathrooms and any service just a call away. Our porter even gave us a short history of the hotel and station while escorting us to our room. Luxury accommodations nestled in a historic setting.

The location of this hotel is perfect, it’s right at the Tokyo train station, and if you requested the “meet and greet” service in advance, they will pick you up at the platform of the train station. I also like they provide “handy” which is a smartphone device you can use wifi and make phone calls for free. Breakfasts was very good, they used high-quality ingredients and everything was delicious. The concierge is amazing, they booked “Sukiyabashi Jiro” for us, which we tried to book through other ways and got rejected. This is THE place to stay in Tokyo.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel for 5 nights in September. The location can’t be beat. It is literally steps from the train station. So easy to catch a train or a subway. Notwithstanding the proximity to the train station this beautifully designed hotel is an oasis of serenity. The rooms are quiet, spacious & elegantly decorated. Our room overlooked the main plaza. We dined at the hotel on two evenings. Our meal in the Camellia bar was outstanding. The staff are amazing & so gracious. In particular all 3 of the concierge staff that I dealt with on numerous occasions went over & above to help me out. They were incredible! Great shopping & restaurants are literally across the streets. The hotel is within walking distance of the Imperial Palace. This is a fabulous hotel

Just book it! Dome rooms overlooking the actual goings on in the beautiful train station are awesome and unique (and completely soundproof). The hotel is immaculate and gorgeous. What a treat! Luxury, service and a unique setting. Not to mention an incredible location to tour all of Tokyo. If that isn’t enough, the staff is truly special. Marie Antoinette Mori, the lead concierge went way above the call of duty and scored us coveted (but not expensive!) baseball tickets for our travels to Hiroshima. When we checked in, she personally came to welcome and greet us. Other staff escorted us to taxis;And all were just polished, helpful, and friendly. I would (and will) return to Tokyo in part just to spend some more time enjoying the hotel, the tea room, bar, etc. I debated between this hotel and the Ritz and am so happy we ended up choosing the Tokyo Station. Perfect in every way!

The Tokyo Station Hotel is a building of Japanese national importance and a hotel of immaculate hospitality. After a moment of personal forgetfulness on my part within 2 hours of arriving in Japan in August, the staff at the hotel literally saved my entire vacation. Service and attention to detail at The Tokyo Station Hotel come from a very high level of commitment to warmth and hospitality. In terms of transportation, the hotel's location cannot be beat, while nearby dining, shopping, and sightseeing options are numerous and convenient. Rooms with very high ceilings are stylish in western/European decor. DO NOT MISS breakfast in the hotel's Atrium venue - for hotel guests only, this breakfast is reason enough to book a room. Treat yourself at The Tokyo Station Hotel. You will be glad you did.

We had our first taste of The Tokyo Station Hotel three months ago, and boy did it leave an impression. As luck would have it, we found our way back for another stay, one which validates all the good memories from the last stay and then some. Here is a recap of what makes the Tokyo Station Hotel stand out from the pack.LocationIn a word, perfect. You will not find another hotel with a better location. There is simply none. This majestic hotel sits directly at the most iconic train station in the country and in the very heart of the city. From this starting point, you can be pretty much anywhere in Tokyo within 20 mins (including Haneda airport). Ginza and the Imperial Palace grounds are within walking distance while Osaka and Kyoto are but a direct seamless 2-hour bullet train ride away.The train station is itself a food and shopping paradise. Big malls, shops (both high-end and wallet-friendly boutiques), and restaurants surround the station, including beneath it. It is worth a day of exploring on its own. Grab a map of the place and tap on Ms Mori's excellent concierge team for advice, otherwise getting lost is a real probability. Rooms Gorgeous and classy in every way. You will love how tastefully the rooms have been put together. There are a wide array of rooms, with some categories offering unique features. The Dome side rooms (which we stayed this time) for instance looks into the interiors of the Tokyo station. From there, one can observe the thousands of commuters that go about their day from the calm and tranquility of the room. The Palace view rooms offer a majestic vista of the Imperial Palace grounds.The entry rooms are compact but never claustrophobic, thanks to the high ceilings and good layout. The mid-level Superior rooms are amongst the largest in Tokyo and would be our recommendation. A lot of attention is placed on the bathroom area so those who enjoy a nice shower or a hot soak in the tub will absolutely love what the hotel has done. In short, these are rooms you will want to spend time in, so don't just use the hotel merely as a convenient base to travel. It is so much more than that.ServiceWarm, attentive, and efficient, with good command of English to boot. They will be there for you, attending to every need. In our case, this care extends after checkout where the guest relations team found a quiet area for us to rest while waiting for a late flight home. This is Japanese hospitality at its finest. The service is so good, you may well regard them as friends and not just hotel staff, just as we did.Food In my earlier review, I wrote about the breakfast at the Level 4 Atrium as something not to be missed because of the huge spread and lovely setting. This remains very much the case. Do have breakfast included in your room rate. It is well worth it.I will now add the Lobby Lounge to the list of must-dos. The place combines a warm refined ambience, soothing live music from the resident harpist, and an extensive menu of drinks and light bites. The perpetual long queues attest to the quality. Go for their signature french toast with a pot of royal milk tea. We can't think of a more delectable way to enjoy a summer afternoon.Overall value-for-moneyThe Tokyo Station Hotel offers compelling value, especially when considering its incomparable location, classy interiors, top-notch service, and storied heritage. This hotel has all the qualities to compete with the best luxury hotels in the city, at prices that are more reasonable due to the good diversity of room types. Members of the Small Luxury Hotels (SLH) collection or World of Hyatt can additionally look forward to enjoying additional perks like early check-ins/late checkouts, breakfast and possibly even room upgrades. Do therefore consider enrolling for the membership if planning a major stay here.

What can be said about this hotel that has not already been said. The service is incredible; the hotel, elegant. We stayed there twice in August. Once we had a queen sized bed in a palace view room; once we had a king bed in a dome room. I preferred the first despite the smaller bed. The rooms seemed equally small but the queen room was better laid out. They do manage to squeeze a lot in a small space. The bathroom is large and there is a closet. I liked the view better in the palace side room, too. The beds were comfortable as were the pillows. The food was expensive; we did not eat there. There are plenty of places to eat around there. If you plan to eat in the station, be aware there are few eat-in restaurants there. The proximity to the station was the major reason we stayed there. We took the Narita Express in and nothing could have been easier. We took the Shinkasen to Kyoto-- again, easily. Trains around the city. It is great for that. The service in the hotel was great. They were able to order my tickets to Kyoto and charge them to the room. Then they had not one but two women guide us to the train, helping us with luggage. We appreciated that. The female concierge there is efficient and professional; we did not deal with the males, so I can't speak to them. It's just a great place to stay.

It is not cheap but the service is excellent from the arrival till the departure (inclusive an escort service to the Narittta express). The breakfast was great with a Japense part and a continental part. They have rooms with connecting doors which makes it easy if you travel with children. The hotel is very well located (near to shops, public transport, restaurants, ...). As said not cheap, but you get value in return.

This hotel is so perfectly located, right at the Tokyo station. Getting here from haneda took 20 mins.All the major corporates are in the same area /place, so you can walk to most of the meetings and then it was easy to take a train back to the airport, Narita or haneda.The rooms are nice and luxurious and quite comfortable. Service was goodDon't understand why we need to pay extra for using the gym but it was a small thing

I've now stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel 3 times along with a number of other top notch hotels in Tokyo. In my experience, this hotel is the best.Service, as expected with any upscale Japanese hotel is excellent. The location couldn't be better. The hotel is near the Ginza and the Imperial Palace but is also connected to the Tokyo Station which makes travel anywhere else incredibly convenient. The look of the hotel borrows from European architecture and there is basically a full block of open park-like space in front of the hotel, beyond which is a plethora of department stores and restaurants. The hotel itself features a wonderful breakfast in their atrium and rooms are ultra clean sharing modern features with a traditional feel. Totally recommend this hotel.

This hotel is a really great location if you plan to catch the train or subway to travel to sites and other places. It is truly a beautiful property. My room was a nice size with comfortable beds. It was very clean and had nice amenities as you would expect at a luxury hotel. The staff was extremely attentive and available for anything you needed.

Thousands of people have passed through Tokyo Station without noticing this wonderful hotel. As befitting such a landmark building, the Tokyo Station Hotel is elegant, yet discrete. The rooms are spacious and beautifully decorated, even if the hotel’s best feature might be its direct access to the Shinkansen terminal. The facilities are mostly impeccable, except for a slightly crowded fitness centre. The buffet breakfast is spectacular, both in presentation and taste. In summary, a highly distinctive property in perfect location.

This is an amazing hotel. I had stayed in Park Hyatt and this is better. Location is perfect for JR trains. Concierge was very helpful. They even take your luggage to bullet train platform. Attentive service. Bar had good cocktails. Had an amazing experience

The Tokyo Station Hotel is such a historic and elegant hotel. It’s in the perfect location, so convenient for all sorts of transportation. Our room was very spacious, comfortable, quiet, and beautifully decorated. The bathroom was huge, full of amenities. We had a rain shower in our bathroom and it was amazing. The hotel also has a fantastic breakfast spread in a beautiful atrium. It was such a great way to start each day of our stay.All that is well and good, but the biggest and most impressive takeaway from our stay was the exceptional level of hospitality given to us by the staff. Everyone was so courteous, welcoming, and helpful. They are true professionals and you can tell that they are perfectionists who take great pride in their work. Prior to our arrival, we had contacted the hotel a number of times with various questions and have always gotten quick, courteous, and helpful responses.We chose to stay here because of the impeccable reputation of Ms. Mori and her concierge team. We were not disappointed. She secured the reservation we wanted and even made arrangements for us that we didn’t think to ask for, such as when she had a member of the hotel staff escort us to the train platform after we had already checked out of the hotel. That was much appreciated, as the station is so huge and complex. It saved us a lot of time from wandering around trying to figure out which way to go while carrying a bunch of luggages. Ms. Mori is very personable and considerate. We really enjoyed our conversation with her. There are so many nice hotels, but the staff is what makes a place. And the entire staff at the Tokyo Station Hotel is first class in every way. I normally like to try different hotels when I travel but I would certainly be a repeat guest here.
user_name:
teeism
New York City, New York

review_body: Service, room and the location all are top notch. We were hesitant to book bc we have two rowdy, very loud kids but we like nice hotels . The rooms are truly soundproof and spacious enough. We usually book suites for the kids to have space but we didn’t need it here. And they had kids Pjs, slippers and toothbrushing cups! The hotel also allows kids under 12 to share a bed with an adult. We were thankful for that since it’s not very common in Japan. The twin beds are also big enough to share.Service also above and beyond. For example we asked at the beginning of our stay about the hotel to hotel luggage delivery service. We would need it to send our luggage to our next hotel. When we went back a couple days later to book it they had already filled out the forms with the receiving hotel information.

Service at The Tokyo Station Hotel continues to surpass itself! On our most recent visit, the bellhop actually walked us through Tokyo Station, helped us purchase multi-line tickets, and even took our luggage up the escalators to the platform. On this same visit, our family celebrated two wedding anniversaries, and the Hotel took and then provided printed, celebratory photos for all of us. A birthday was another occasion for our stay, and the concierge was able to get us all baseball tickets in Tokyo Dome (which had proven impossible via internet from home). Every aspect of our stay was perfect, from the exceedingly comfortable and unique dome-side rooms to the ever changing, but consistently superior, breakfast. Truly a phenomenal hotel!

The service was absolutely amazing. Being my first trip to Japan, I needed a lot of assistance to getting around and finding the correct trains. The staff at The Tokyo Train station was incredible. They helped me purchase tickets, even walked me to the train to be sure I boarded the correct car. It’s the best place to stay.

Got a palace view king room. You'll be hard pressed to find a room with tall ceilings and more than comfortable size as this in Tokyo at a reasonable price. Try the breakfast buffet at least once as it is quite a treat.

We stayed at the Ritz in Osaka, Hotel Gracery and Cross Hotel. They were all great properties but they didn’t measure up to this hotel. It started the moment yo7 walked in, the attention to detail, high level of respect from everyone. We were escorted to our rooms and had the staff following with our luggage. The rooms were magnificent, roomy for Japan and very elegant. Shower and tub were perfect, AC was perfect, as cold as you wanted it. If you encountered any staff in the hall, they immediately stepped aside and waited for you to pass, speaking and bowing. It was just amazing the level of respect from every single person. Beds were comfortable (for Japan), large pillows and large towels. This is a great place to stay in Tokyo.

We cannot recommend this place enough! My girlfriend and I had an absolutely fantastic stay here. The service was unbeatable. Their concierge helped us get into many of the best restaurants we hoped to visit and they provided directions and an itinerary for each one. The building has so much historic character and such a cool vibe about it. You can certainly find fancier hotels with bigger rooms; but this place is truly unique and beautiful in every sense. It's 100+ years old, built into the Tokyo Station train depot, and offers views into the train station from the hotel. Somehow it's completely quiet, though, and you feel miles away from the city and station. I'm a light sleeper and staying here was the best sleep I got in Japan.

I stayed in Tokyo Station Hotel for 7 nights on a recent business trip. I enjoyed the stay tremendously. In a city of modern buildings and architecture, hotel stands out for its traditional looks and old school charm. My room was comfortable and well appointed. Hotel breakfast was fantastic, and really a great way to start the day. Location is top notch, and particularly so for a business trip.Hotel service was above all expectations. On site bars and restaurants were plentiful and beautiful, and food choices excellent. In short, highly recommended.

My partner and I visited Japan for a 2 week holiday in late March/early April, and got to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel for 3 nights. This was by far our favourite hotel. The staff are incredibly attentive and kind, and the spa downstairs was amazing. The bed was the most comfortable bed we slept on in any hotel we've ever stayed at to date. The rooms are very clean and filled with all the amenities you can think of. The hotel lobby is welcoming and chic, and we couldn't ask to be better located to explore not only Tokyo but also surrounding areas. Absolutely recommend if you want to stay somewhere extremely welcoming, well kept, conveniently located, and not so over the top!

Tokyo station hotel is an excellent hotel in many senses. The location is right at the top of the Tokyo train station. However Tokyo train station is a huge station so make sure your find the M1 exit and the hotel is in front of you. The hotel has a long tradition and the building is very pretty so many tourists come to the outside of the hotel to take pictures. The breakfast is very tasty, has many choices and surprises. The room is modern and pretty though a bit small but you are in the centre of Tokyo so what can you expect? All staff are very polite, their services are excellent and they can speak good English. A little surprise is the ball pen in the hotel. When you use it, you will like it and it is so good that I have to buy one from its gift shop. Lots of shopping areas and restaurants nearby and make sure you have a deep pocket as they are expensive.

Everything perfect. They take attention to every detail. Always smiling staff .;Location of the rooms ; best location away from the railway station.Staff, food, location and rooms, all amazing. We love this hotel!

Great, little, luxury hotel steps away from the Imperial Palace. It has a super convenient location since it's a part of Tokyo Station. Rooms are luxurious and super quiet. Make sure to explore the below ground areas since they contain many, many food and apparel shops. Service is at the end of the already great Japanese service reputation!

We stayed here just one night after arriving from the US, before our train ride to Kyoto. The staff was friendly and the hotel sparkling clean. Despite its historic roots, our rooms were quite large with lots of glass and comfortable beds. The staff even showed me the hallway for direct access to the train station without going outside!The breakfast buffet (included in the room price for us) was excellent. It had a broad variety of mostly Japanese-style breakfast foods, including blowfish dumplings (tastes like shrimp)! They also had very high-quality pastries, like pain au chocolat and apricot Danish. I liked their coffee. It’s hard to go wrong here if you need to catch a train the next morning.

Be it leisure or business, the Tokyo Station Hotel is THE hotel in Tokyo. Full amenities (including pyjamas!), great service and price is very reasonable, considering its rich history. The hotel is housed within a beautiful building, which has been designated as Culture Property of Japan. On top of its already many accolades, Tokyo Station Hotel's concierge team (Ms Mori and team) is truly the best in Tokyo! They will do their utmost to get you the most coveted reservation.

On arrival, I was dropped at the concourse entry. I had to take my bags in myself as there was no porter/doorman outside. I arrived early at 12.30pm and I was recommended to catch the train and go to Harajuku. Unfortunately I spent 3 hours battling crowds and long queues. There was no ability to actually see anything meaningful. Once back at the hotel my room turned out to have only internal views- when it said it was in the dome with concourse views, I expected the external concourse views not inside the train station. I ordered room service and what a disappointment it was. Pate turned out to be terrine- big difference. After a hot nights sleep I had breakfast in the atrium. Also a mistake. I arrived in the last hour of service. The room was incredibly hot. I had to find my own table and then had to chase staff for orange juice which was empty and coffee which they didn't ask me abut when I sat down, I was then trying to quickly eat as they appeared to be packing up. The eggs Benedict that were sitting on the hot buffet were rubbery and semi warm. On check out- I paid the very expensive price and then asked about leaving my bags for a few hours. That was facilitated promptly and with no problem. When I returned to get my bags they were provided to me and I asked about a taxi to the airport and was directed to a taxi stand outside the train station. So, I lugged my bags myself to the taxi stand. Very poor service, particularly when I was travelling alone.

The family stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel and we loved it. The room itself was not big, but it had everything we needed. And the bathroom was very good. The staff was exceptionally helpful and friendly.

Fantastic stay. The hotel is truly a luxurious stay in Tokyo. It is centrally located in the Financial District and is connected to (on top of and part of) Tokyo Railway station. From those perspectives, it is an ultra convenient location. The palace is a short walk away. I always enjoy a hotel that is historic, yet has been largely rebuilt and is modern on the inside (or at least in the rooms). This hotel does not disappoint. Grand and glorious from the outside. A constant wave of photo takers out front given the majesty and beauty. The room is actually quite large by Tokyo and European standards. The bathroom is perfect - very large shower. One of the better rooms for a business traveler I have stayed in this year. The service was impeccable. They are ready to help at every turn and many speak very good English. Deserving of 5* hotel status. I enjoyed my stay.

We had a delightful stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel. All was perfect (situation, staff, breakfast, room, wifi). Amazing to be in the station without any noise. A really unique place we will remember in a great neighborhood. A big special thank you to the concierge who booked excellent tables and was so kind (vive les clés d'or)! She really made a difference.

Ideal location, spacious room, great staff and wonderful breakfast. All you want for a hotel is there except one downside is that the fitness is open only at 7 AM which is usually later than other hotels I have gone to. That is kinda late. Except that, it is perfect.

Spent our last night in Japan at the hotel above Tokyo Station. So very happy we did! Staff were amazing and accommodating- even walked us right to the train platform to ensure we found our way to the Narita Express for our flight home. Slightly higher cost but so so SO worth it!

The Tokyo Station Hotel is simply the best. The standard by which I measure all other luxury hotels. And the location is ideal. The bathroom was to die for. Just a perfect hotel. I am an old woman, it might be too tranquil for some one younger.

What a lovely hotel this is. It is recently renovated, absolutely immaculate, and the greeting you get on arrival is fit for a king. If you’re planning on training down through the main island then it’s a great place to start - particularly as it’s basically in the train station. The bathroom is packed with all the freebies you will need. The only criticism I could lay is that the basic rooms are quite small once you put 2 suitcases in it.

I have travelled east and west, But nothing matches this place. You have to experience this to know. Its places like this that raise the bar of the word service. I travelled with 2 children in strollers and 2 women older than 70. They were there with us all through our 3 days stay. At this hotel, you don't have to ask. They understand your needs and requirements and help you with a heartfelt smile. The breakfast counters are awesome and they are extremely helpful. But they did charge for my kids who are 5 and 6 years old as the room plus breakfast gives breakfast only for 2 adults. The Grannie Kyoto did not charge the kids the kids !!!!!!!Three big cheers to Ms Marie and Ms Yuki of the Concierge.These ladies are so helpful. They accompanied me to take a suica card, for a card refund , arranged to take me and my family to the platform and answered my million million doubts with a great smile on there face. These women are an asset to this institution and an great introduction to this fabulous place

The beautiful historic hotel is right above Tokyo Station, central to everything in Tokyo. The hotel itself if beautiful and and a destination. Our room was wonderful--especially the bathroom and shower. The staff provided the best service we have ever experienced in a hotel. Warm friendly greetings from everyone as soon as they see you. The concierge desk was so helpful in helping us to get around. They also called the airline to check for an item that I had left on the plane coming in. The bell staff walked both our heavy suitcases to the Shinkansen platform to ensure we got there at the right time without getting lost in the huge busy station. He did not leave until we were in line for our train. THAT is service. I would return in a heartbeat.

LocationUndisputably the most centrally-located hotel in all of Tokyo. Other hotels can claim to being near a metro station or a major interchange, and that is all good. But this majestic hotel sits directly at the most iconic train station in the country, and a stone's throw from the Imperial Palace. As a result of the convenience, you'll be fast-tracked to all major parts of Tokyo and even areas outside of Tokyo (e.g. Yokohama, Hakone) within 30 mins. The Tokyo Station is also a gold mine for food and shopping. Big malls, shops, and restaurants surround the station, including beneath it. Grab a map of the place and tap on the concierge for advice, otherwise getting lost is definitely a real probability. While the constant hive of activity within the train station can be a heady experience, an air of calm and tranquility greets you the moment you enter the hotel lobby. The crowds and noise give way to gentle instrumental music and polite guests/patrons. It is an amazing transition.Rooms In a word, beautiful. The rooms vary widely in size but are generally spacious across the room categories. Everything about the rooms (and corridors and common areas for that matter) exude class, elegance, refinement. They are tastefully furnished with lovely blend of natural lighting, light marble, wood, and teal carpets, and supplemented with quality luxury fittings.  A harmony of modernity and old world grandeur. These are rooms you will want to spend time in, so don't just use the hotel merely as a convenient base to travel.ServiceFriendly, attentive, and efficient, with good command of English to boot. Japanese hospitality and service excellence go hand in hand, and this is on full display by the staff - from the bell desk, front office, restaurants, and housekeeping. Everything is well-oiled and delivered with pride. The team of staff are clearly very happy to be part of the hotel, and have every reason to be.Food The breakfast at the Level 4 Atrium is not to be missed, not just for the wonderful array of Western and Japanese buffet spread but also for the wonderful restaurant ambience replete with high ceilings and natural light. It is a sight to behold. Be sure to have breakfast included in your room rate, or you'll be missing out on something memorable.Overall value-for-moneyThere are several compelling reasons why the Tokyo Station hotel merits your consideration. The most obvious would be the hotel's incomparable location and its classy service and quality. But it is so much more than that. This is also a hotel with a story - an iconic heritage that has evolved with the development of the country's capital. This is truly an experience beyond luxury. Factor in the competitive room rates, and you will very quickly appreciate all the rave reviews and accolades the hotel has received over the years and why it continues to rank so highly on TripAdvisor. Just to add, the hotel is part of the Small Luxury Hotels collection and is perhaps the crown jewel of the SLH collection. The hotel is proud of its association as displayed by the SLH badges on their uniforms and the collaterals around the hotel. This means that SLH members can look forward to enjoying additional perks like early check-ins/late checkouts, breakfast and possibly even room upgrades. Do therefore consider enrolling for the membership if planning a major stay here.

I want to say that Miyuki Saito, the concierge, was amazingly helpful. Way before I even arrived, I e-mailed many questions and needed lots of help figuring out the train from airport to hotel. Not only did they purchase tickets for us, The staff hand held us from our platform through the maze of the station, from arrival to departure, two times and we stayed there in the beginning and end of our trip. I commend the staff also, as they probably did not know what hit them as we seven Americans barged in.

We spent three wonderful nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel in April. All of the staff went out of their way to make our stay memorable. From check-in to check-out we were always greeted by smiling faces, with a warm hello and a request to be of service.Special thanks to the Concierge, Miyuki Saito, whose outstanding service began before we even arrived in arranging our pick-up at the airport. She provided service throughout our stay with recommendations for dining and finally arranging our transportation to the pier in Yokohama.Duty Manager, Mr. Yorhiki Kamata was warm and gracious on our arrival and was always there to help us make the most of our time in Tokyo.The hotel proper is in a great location, with access to the trains and subway. It is spotlessly clean throughout. We had a wonderful room with outstanding amenities that overlooked the Imperial Palace. The Lobby Bar was lovely and offered a tranquil spot for cocktails or a light meal.Before we booked the hotel we checked a number of “high end” properties, i.e. Mandarin, Four Seasons, Hyatt, Peninsula and found this hotel to offer luxury at much better rates . We would definitely stay at this hotel again and highly recommend it to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Very hard to find fault with this hotel. Professional and welcoming staff from the moment we arrived to the final check out.Spacious, clean, luxurious and comfortable room. We chose a dome view so looked into the station which was actually quite interesting yet also quiet. The bathroom was large and well equipped.We loved our stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel.

We had a wonderful stay at this hotel. Particular thanks to Tomonori Otsuka for his fabulous help at the concierge desk. He was extremely helpful with restaurant reservations and train travel to Kyoto.

Summary: I don't know that we can speak highly enough of the courteous, thoughtful staff at The Tokyo Station Hotel! We decided to try the station-view rooms, and we do kind of wish we had a room with an exterior view. If we had to do it over again, we would prefer that (especially to help us get used to the time change after traveling). Pros:*The staff goes above and beyond to make their guests have every comfort imaginable.*We took advantage of the train pick-up service at Tokyo Station, and we were *so* grateful we did. We got lost many times in that station, so it was helpful after 15+ hours of travel to have someone greet us right at the door of our arriving train (N'EX), take our bags, and lead us to check in.*Location. If you're doing a bit of walking, this is fairly central to things we were hoping to see, but also convenient (obviously) to the train station. We walked easily to Imperial Palace, Tsukiji Fish Market, and a few other places.*Bed was pretty comfortable (hard to say for sure because we were fairly jet-lagged!). The curtains were definitely black-out curtains :)*The bathroom had every amenity you could need (hair dryer, toothbrushes, razors, etc). and was nicely updated as well.Con:*Again, probably the room selection we made wasn't our favorite. It wasn't awful either, but I think we would prefer an exterior facing room in the future for some sunlight!

The hotel is very conveniently situated. The staff and the facilities are first class, attention to detail is second to none.The hallways are something to experience, either take a snack, or ask for a segway

Arrived very early after a long overnight flight to find the early checking requested by my travel agent was waiting for me, bliss! Typical Japanese attention to detail and service with hotel staff ready to help and unobtrusive at the same time.Location perfect with Tokyo station next door and Daimaru just round the corner.

The hotel was excellent in every respect. The staff without exception were outstanding. They could not enough for us. Our room was spacious and very comfortable. The location was perfect. Breakfast very good.

Catching the NEX train from Narita to Tokyo Station was so easy. Then being greeted by the bellhop on the platform in front of our rail carriage to guide us through the busy station right to the hotel’s check in desk. If you like ‘easy’... this is it !We booked a Palace Side Queen room. It’s advertised at 26 square meters , but around a third of it is bathroom. Leaving the actual room quite small. You need to be creative with fitting 2 suitcases in.But as everyone else says : this hotel is fabulous.Great central position.Great staff (particularly Marie Antoinette)Quite roomsWe’d certainly stay here again!

Where to begin? From the moment you arrive you are treated so well, from being escorted to your room by the bell hop (please remember no tipping in Japan) who helps you navigate the hotel and also points out the various features of your room.The room has an old world charm with a really big bathroom with separate shower and bath and separate toilet (which was so good I really would love to get a full featured one at home).The location is at what I reckon has to be one of the busiest train stations in the world and yet you hear nothing, it is so well insulated and there is a general sense of quiet and elegance about the place. You are within a short walking distance of the Imperial Palace and its many gardens. Being at the Station you can go to all points within Japan from this station by Shinkansen and most hub lines go through it so its ideal to get around Tokyo as well.We didn’t eat here as it was the pricey side (and there are lots of cheaper options just as good nearby).The one bonus we both enjoyed is that there is an in-house onsen style baths which were clean and marvellous with varying temperature pools (hot and cold) and dry sauna (which was the hottest I had ever been in) with a wide variety of complimentary toiletries so you can turn up with nothing and its a complete service.ProsLocation to the main train station of Tokyo (if not Japan), a true sense of elegance, the fantastic room and service. Great hot bath area.ConsLook this is a truly luxury hotel and certainly will not be for everyone at the price point as its not cheap, but truly worth at least a stay if you want to stay somewhere truly special.Highly recommend if you can do it

This hotel was stunning!!! The hotel staff was able to meet us at the Shinkansen train station to help with our bags and help navigate us out of the under ground maze of Tokyo Station. The room was very comfortable, spacious and luxurious! We got in room massages that were great and were also able to try out TEPPANYAKI SHICHI JYU NI KOU with perfectly paired sakes which made it a mind blowing experience! We had our own private chef and the wait staff were impeccable! It was so convenient to try a high end restaurant and not have to leave to hotel, but just take the elevator back up to our room! Upon checking out, we were helped with out bags back to the train station, which we were happy we did, because to get to the Narita Express Train in Tokyo Station was a bit confusing. The staff made this a flawless process! Highly recommend this hotel and its fabulous amenities to anyone wanting to make their trip top notch (even if its only for night)!!

My wife and I were absolutely delighted with our stay at The Station Hotel on 28th and 29th April 2019. The hospitality, helpfulness, friendliness of the staff and comfort of the hotel were exemplary. I must make special mention of the breakfast which was by far and beyond the best we have enjoyed anywhere on our travels. On a final note, the bellgirl who helped us with our luggage on departure and stayed outside the hotel to wave us farewell deserves recognition and our appreciation. A small gesture but most welcome and memorable.

This hotel is in a great location as it’s part of the Tokyo station complex. Any concerns that we had about noise were dispelled straight away as we travelled 27 floors to the hotel reception, where we were greeted by friendly staff.Our room was on 30th floor which gave us fabulous views over the city. The room was very large with a huge extremely comfortable bed. There was also tea and coffee making in the room.

I recently came back from my 9 day Japan trip. I used the Tokyo Station Hotel for my final night for several reasons. + The hotel is centrally located especially if you will be relying on trains. The hotel sits right above the train station and this makes it super convenient for getting around or for a final day to get to the airport with fewer transfers. + The staff is amazing- polite, friendly and willing to help out. The hospitality in Japan is top notch and this hotel definitely delivered. We arrived early before 3 PM check in- they held all our bags for us, and had our bags ready for us in the room. The bellboy walked us to our room, give us a brief history of this 100-year-old hotel (recent renovations- this place is gorgeous) and made us feel welcomed. + Gorgeous hotel, the room was huge with high ceilings and a huge bathroom this was great for our final night to get some rest. The only negative I would say will be to get to the hotel after you get off the train was difficult to find. We ended walking around for a while before we actually found the exit that left us nearest to our hotel. Wish they had more signs underground that lead to the hotel.
user_name:
Hector P
Rego Park, New York

review_body: Stayed here for 3 nights upon arrival in Tokyo and for 1 night when we departed two weeks later. Our first room was a Dome Room that was in excellent shape although it was a little on the small side. But the bathroom was large with a separate tub and large shower area. The Toto Washout toilets are an experience in themselves. The second time we stayed here we had a Palace Side Superior room booked but upgraded to a larger room for 8000 yen more. The room was huge with lots of storage space and beautiful bathroom area and separate powder room. The beds in both rooms were the best that we slept on in the 16 day trip. The breakfast buffet is not to be missed but is on the expensive side at $81.00 for two people. We enjoyed the hotel bars and the service from the hotel staff.Tokyo Station is a maze of thousands of people coming and going on the trains and is a sight to witness itself. We used a pocket WIFI we rented from Japan Wireless on this trip and it guided us around everywhere. The cost was $96 for 17 days and was worth it. We would stay here again if we ever return to Tokyo.

The hotel is very convenient, its location being self-explanatory. The staff is accommodating and friendly. The interior decor of the room is elegant and the bathroom is of a decent size but the room is slightly small

this was my first time in Tokyo. I decided to stay in a location that provided transportation. The Tokyo station is a hub for many trains . Tokyo, after reading a lot in guidebooks still seems daunting to me. I decided to stay in the Tokyo station hotel for convenience and luxury. arriving late in the evening I caught one of the last next trains into Tokyo station. Apparently JR Office closes at 9:30 so I was a bit worried on how I was going to get into town. Everything worked out. I was able to get out of immigration quickly. I was given a room that was very far away from checkin.The The room was very comfortable but small. We had to rearrange suitcases to make room for walking. We had a view of buildings that were facing the hotel. The bed was very comfortable. The bathroom and shower were wonderful. I love having a window in my bathroom. The concierge helped us get tickets for the Nazomi train. She also made reservations for the return trip to the airport. She also helped us with restaurants. Plenty of help from the concierge make sure you take advantage. We Had breakfast For the four days that we were there. It was wonderful! much better than the food we encountered in the city!
