The only negative was that Tokyo station is a huge train and subway hub. I was having siatica problems. The huge station combined with the extra long walk to the room was painful. Not their fault. maybe if I had spoken up I could’ve changed my room. Yes I would stay there again that extra bit of luxury in a hectic city proved to make my memory of Tokyo a good one. Service excellent!

We picked this hotel due to it's location to Tokyo Station.This hotel while quite expensive, really is beautiful and not effected by the train/foot traffic in the station below.There always seemed to be someone available who could speak English,which made our stay that much more comfortable. In essence this hotel is quiet, and very clean, with most amenities that you would need .A special thank you to "Mummy"'our lovely bellhop ,who was very friendly, informative and professional.Staying at this charming hotel was a wonderful introduction to Japanese Hospitality.

It might be Tokyo station that almost travelers from out of Japan firstly drop in. The station has many ticket gates, the gate that the guests staying this hotel should pass through is the Marunouchi South ticket gate. Thereby they will be able to directly access to the hotel. This hotel’s beautiful building is designated the Important cultural property by Japan Government. The whole building was reconstructed from 2006 to 2012 in order to get anti-earthquake reinforcement and restore its original appearance before World War II. For this reason, guests will be able to feel not only just contemporary but also historical atmosphere from the exterior and interior.This hotel has several restaurants, every restaurant is quite wonderful. Especially 'Atrium' provides traditional Japanese breakfast in buffet style, you can enjoy it to your heart's content.＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊＊

We had just a one night stay before leaving Tokyo the next day, but wish we could have just moved in and stayed for a month. We were upgraded (thank you!) to a very large, elegant, and altogether amazing room that was the size of apartment with large seating area, walk-in closet, bar area, and magnificent bathroom. The bed was supremely comfortable. It was very quiet. The view from the room to the front of the hotel overlooking the large courtyard in front of the station was grand. We did not opt for the breakfast buffet so cannot comment on that. The staff was uniformly welcoming and helpful. The location is superb. Overall our one-night stay was one of the best hotel experiences we have ever had.

I cant recommend this hotel enough!!! Absolutely amazing! And the staff, especially Miyuki at concierage, i have never met anyone as helpful as her. Even Tomonori and every single person i have dealt with at this hotel is exceptional. They make you welcome and look into all your needs. They bought us our train tickets, booked all the hard to get into restaurants including Sukiyabashi Jiro, sent porters to help with our luggage to the bullet trains and back, bought disney tickets, did everythibg they possibly could to make our stay perfect. Even the kids got their own bathrobes and toothbrushes and cups in the room. Their toys and clothes were folded and arranged neatly every single day. Been to many many hotels but never anything like this. Absolutely love Tokyo station hotel! You guys are amazing

Every stay at historic The Tokyo Station Hotel has been perfect, memorable. At the Hotel, I have stayed in different rooms of different sizes, with different views, but each has been exceedingly comfortable and unique. Furnishings are plush but very functional and logical: lighting is excellent, electrical outlets abound, the bathroom/showers luxurious. Service is always exemplary, the Concierge giving wonderful counsel on everything from viewing azaleas at Nezu Shrine to buying baseball tickets for our next visit. The Tokyo Station Hotel remains a unique gem. Location is excellent, actually in Tokyo Station, steps away from Narita Express arrival, as well as the train from Haneda. The surrounding financial and shopping area, already lively, gets more vibrant with each visit, yet the serenity of the Imperial Palace and its gardens is just a few blocks away.

We only stayed the one night, great location and beautiful building. The thing we really liked and thought was very classy is the help we got from the hotel concierge before our arrival. I asked them if they could book my bullet train tickets before my arrival in Japan and they could not have been more helpful. They also met us at the train when we arrived and took us to the bullet train when we left. Really took all the stress out of the start of our holiday. Touch of class especially as we were only staying the one night!

A hotel at the Tokyo station since 1915 with over 104 years old is our first choice of this trip to Japan as we arrived late and need to take a rest before next morning’s Shinkansen trip to Aomori from Tokyo Station. Due to its prime location and heritage and its excellent and professional staff, the hotel rooms are not cheap. It’s like comparing to the peninsula hotel in Hong Kong except that I would prefer them to make bigger and nicer rooms with better amenities as we hardly can put in our 4 suitcases in the room. Our room is the Dome Side Room and it’s facing the inside of the Tokyo station though the windows can’t be opened.Breakfast choice and quality were excellent and service was exceptional too. So if you are looking for a very short stay with the convenience of the location like we did, this is a good choice.

I had selected this hotel for our final night in Tokyo given its history and location to the Imperial Palace. I have no complaints whatsoever. Everything is historic and beautiful and its right on top of Tokyo Station. Please note that there is no way to go directly from the station to the hotel; you have to walk outside and take a separate entrance. The staff is supremely polite, accommodating, and helpful; I was able to make several Michelin star restaurant reservations through the Concierge. Highly recommended.

Our stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel was one of the highlights of our trip. Arrriving on the Narita Express, it's not the easiest place to find and it would be helpful if the hotel indicated which station exit to aim for. However, our second floor room was wonderful with a large window overlooking the square leading up to the Imperial Palace. Couldn't ask for a better location in terms of convenience for trains, subway and sightseeing. The room was elegant, quiet, well-appointed and very comfortable. It was a long walk from reception but once we realized that there was another entrance right below our room and another elevator that went straight to the breakfast atrium, that didn't matter. Breakfast was outstanding and well worth the money. Service was impeccable throughout. Yes, it's expensive but so is most of Tokyo and this is one expense that you wont regret.

From the minute we checked into this hotel until we checked out we were treated as special guests. Our room was very spacious, bigger than others we had stayed in in Hiroshima and Kyoto. The bathroom and it's facilities were luxurious. All the staff were exceptionally friendly and more than happy to help in any way. The location is very convenient to the station as you would expect. The breakfast was especially amazing with so many varieties of food. I loved the half avocado with smoked salmon, poached egg and hollandaise sauce. Delicious!I would definitely recommend this hotel if you want a bit of luxury.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is a classic hotel in a very convenient location, excellent facilities, excellent hotel. Our room was was large enough for two adults and one older child. While it was more expensive than other hotels, other hotels would have required us to book two rooms. Staying in this gorgeous hotel made our trip to Tokyo remarkable!

My group had an amazing stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel. The concierge was extremely helpful in booking restaurant reservations and our bullet train tickets. The rooms are well appointed, and we especially loved the large shower and tub. The breakfast buffet was nice, with both western and Japanese options. And the location of the hotel can’t be beat if you plan on using the subway system. Overall, it was an amazing experience and we would definitely recommend this to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Love, love, loved our stay at this hotel. 100% worth the price you pay. The staff and rooms are exceptional. Location is great.Every time you enter the lobby you receive a friendly greeting and a smile. I am so sad I didn't get the name of the staff member who showed us to our room on the 2/4 (hopefully if the hotel read this you can figure who I am talking about). She was such an exceptional lady. So friendly and started our stay off great! We mentioned it was our Honeymoon she made sure to let the front desk know and we got a picture taken by the hotel outside the beautiful Tokyo Station building which was then printed and placed in a lovely card for us. This was such a lovely touch that we appreciated.This was definitely one of the nicest hotels we have ever stayed in world wide. The shower was the best shower I've ever had lol!!! The room was so clean and we had a great view over the courtyard area at the front of the station. I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking to stay in the Tokyo Station area. It's obviously super convenient to the station!

The Tokyo Station Hotel is a classic hotel in a fantastic location. There is an endless network of restaurants and shopping underground, in the train station, and nearby above ground. Our room was a two twin which was large enough for two adults and two children. While it was more expensive than other hotels, other hotels would have required us to book two rooms. Staying in this gorgeous hotel made our trip to Tokyo.

This is the second stay in this hotel. It is expensive USD650 to 700 per night for a premium twin room during cherry blossom peak bloom weekend. We paid for the convenient location on Tokyo JR Station and 10min walk from Ginza; and the comfortable room with large bathroom. We came back to this hotel for the excellent service of the concierge team. The team of Ms. Mori, Ms. Saito and Mr. Otsuka helped me with booking of dinners; and I changed restaurants, changed number of guests. They patiently helped me to book and changed. I shall come back to this hotel again.

We very much appreciate the help from Tsuda and the night duty manager Oyama. They are very lovely and kind. This is one of the reasons why we love Japan so much, the people is very welcoming. Can’t wait for our next trip and our stay here next time. The hotel is gorgeous and has the best location!

My friend injured her knee on the trip to Nagano. We arrived at Tokyo Station with the request to have a staff coming to the platform to meet and help us getting to the hotel. They sent 2 staff members to help us out. What a relieve it was because going from the train platform to the hotel was not an easy trip, especially in a wheelchair. Throughout our entire stay, the staff was extremely helpful in every way--making reservations for meal and acupuncture, wheeled us to the hotel restaurant, guided us to see the sakura. Thank you Tomo-san, Miyuki-san, Chisachi-san. We couldn't have done it without your support!! We will definitely come back.

After our first stay a couple of years ago, we decided to return each time we’re in Tokyo. Location is great as it’s at Tokyo Station itself which made it easy for us to move around. We tried different types of room and it was always interesting. The staff especially the concierge team were lovely and assisted us even before we arrived as we had made some requests. We look forward to our next visit to Tokyo and stay at Tokyo Station Hotel.

I’m sure there are better/nicer hotels In Tokyo- not even going to look. This is classic-, anything you might like or need in a hotel. Beauty, service beyond one's expectation, history.Immerse yourself in luxury!

Service was outstanding. The concierge knew our names and greeted us in an unimposing manner. They recommended great wagu restaurants nearby and sushi at the fish market. They even took our luggage to the train. Will definitely will stay at the Tokyo Station again. It is a small luxury hotel but worth every yen we paid. Awesome hotel highlighted by great staff...highly recommend to anybody going to Tokyo.

Overall the hotel was great. Nice location in Tokyo and super convenient with the train station right there. However, the difference maker was the concierge team, specifically Tomonori who went above and beyond. My fiancé has quite a few allergies and Tomonori was great about helping us secure reservations and speaking with them to ensure they could accommodate. Once we arrived he also was great for any questions we had and even walked with me to the station to help me purchase a ticket for Kyoto. Thank you!!

Spent one night here on a layover between flights. Access to Haneda Airport is quick and easy via monorail and Yamanote Line. The breakfast is sumptuous and well worth booking as part of the room rate. This hotel is a beautiful landmark.

Stayed in this hotel for 2 times as we really love the Maisonette room. So beautiful and luxurious. The only thing I wish they could add to the amenities is bath salts, when there's such a nice big bath tub there. Location is excellent, right next to Tokyo station. Won't stay elsewhere when I'm in Tokyo.

Per virtually all the reviews, it's hard to beat the location. Coming from NRT on the N'EX you arrive at your hotel within moments. This is wonderful after flying 14 hours and waiting to buy a ticket on the N'EX for over 30 minutes. Service at the desk was cordial and the bell person showed us to our room. The living space was very small...the bathroom, however, was good sized. Lots of nice touches that made the room comfortable, along with a very comfortable queen bed. Breakfast buffet for hotel guests was nice. If your goal is easy access to travel around Japan, with Tokyo as your hub, it's hard to beat this hotel. Per other reviews, expensive!

Exceeded expectations. Beautiful hotel, you feel pampered as soon as you step through the door. Room was tasteful but as with all hotels in Japan a little cramped but this did not detract from the experience. Great location for exploring. Would stay again.

This was my third visit to the Tokyo Station Hotel. I just love it. I arrived grumpy and tired, after a three hour trek from Narita, which included a 45 minute queue for a ticket on the Narita Express. It is only one stop from Narita to Tokyo Station, so the train is definitely the best option. I managed to get lost in Tokyo Station, despite having made the trip a couple of times previously. It is definitely worth taking up the hotel's offer to send a bellboy to meet the train at your carriage.However, once I arrived, my grumpiness disappeared quickly. My room was smaller than previous visits, however I was travelling solo and only staying one night. It was immaculately clean and very well equipped. A couple of martinis and a Wagyu steak in Bar Oak sent me off to bed in very happy form. I slept beautifully in the amazingly comfortable bed, which has the finest bedding I have ever experienced.Staff are absolutely delightful, and I got lovely service from the concierge.Location is perfect. I strolled to the centre of Ginza, and the old Fish Market, plus some of the very upmarket shops.I recommend Tokyo Station Hotel very highly. It is very Japanese, and rightly proud of that, but has service as good as any five star hotel I have experienced around the world. My wife is travelling to Tokyo solo in a couple of weeks, and I have no doubt she will be wonderfully looked after by The Tokyo Station Hotel team.

This was my second trip to the Tokyo Station Hotel, and I was again very happy to stay here and would recommend it to a friend. The location is inside Tokyo Station (take the South Marunouchi exit), so it is ideal for getting around Tokyo, and the immediate vicinity includes the Imperial Gardens and Marunouchi neighborhood.Everything is clean and functional; the hotel is higher end than the name might initially suggest.Three things to note:1. The corridors run the entire length of Tokyo Station beneath; if you have a room in the 00-20 range, it is a very very, very long walk from the lobby. Try for a room in the 40-50 numbered range.2. Windows in the guest rooms do not open, so you cannot get fresh air.3. The hotel lacks a casual dining restaurant for a quick easy lunch or light dinner.
user_name:
TransConFlyer
New York City, New York

review_body: I primarily chose to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel due to it's close proximity to the Tokyo Marathon finish line (about a block away). But a major bonus is it is literally in the Tokyo Station City complex (6 levels?!). As such, the Narita Express and many of the other Tokyo Metro and JR trains stop there. Also, massive shopping and restaurant options are available. As a single traveler I booked the Palace Side Queen and it was much more than I could have expected: beautifully decorated, the ceilings must have been 12' or higher, a chandelier, foot lighting (new to me!), in room safe, a massive shower head that was a delight and even a heated toilet seat (very new to me but that was great...LOL). This was the first hotel that I have ever stayed where I could not hear any of the adjoining guests. Very quiet with little to no outside street noise either. But, aside from the stunning room, ornate lobby and well-appointed property, the staff are what makes this hotel a 5 Star. Every encounter I had with either the reception or concierge staff was very professional, friendly and genuinely interested in making sure that both my questions were answered and my needs were met. For example, as mentioned above, the Tokyo Station complex is massive spanning at least 6 levels and is a city in itself. As such, it can be a bit overwhelming trying to learn the layout and operation. The hotel staff offer to meet you when the NEX Narita Express train enters the station and guide you through the maze to the reception area (they will cheerfully provide the same service in reverse when you leave). One member of this amazing team I have to give a special nod of appreciation to is Ms. Miyuki Saito. She was a real joy to interact with and always had a very warming smile for me when I saw her. In addition, as I entered the hotel after the marathon, she insisted on taking a picture of us together (see attached). When I checked-out the next morning I was presented with a very professional greeting card with the picture included...which was very touching to say the least. So in summary, do yourself a favor and book your travel at this beautiful hotel with amazing staff...you will not regret it.

It is a beautifully restored hotel and the feel is totally different from the usual Japanese aesthetic or design. The facade is stunning and it is a gorgeous hotel. The location cannot be better, being directly linked to the train station. It's in front of the imperial palace and that provides a nice running route.Service staff were excellent. I was shown to the ticket vending machine to buy the ticket for Narita Express before being shown to my room. Very personalised service.The only downside is that my room faces the interior of the train station, which is not a bad view actually. But I could feel the rumbling of the trains. This may be an important consideration.

What a fabulous treat. We decided on a one night stay on our travels back from Hakuba before we flew back to Australia.It is pure luxury and a beautifully renovated hotel with keeping its tasteful art deco style blended with all the mod cons. We were super lucky to have our room upgraded which put us in the Ambassadors suite, which was just so gorgeous. The bed was super comfortable, the amenities a real treat and the whole experience brilliant. The aircon was really quiet which meant a solid nights sleep for me. We used the gym, it has an excellent selection of technogym equipment to have a great session.The staff were all fabulous and very attentive, a must stay if you are looking for a wonderful treat or easy access hotel.

Lux hotel rooms so convenient after a long hall flight very comfortable clean and quite loved my stay. The best choice if you are travelling around Japan is to be close to a Rail Station.I think if I had the opportunity to stay and explore Tokyo this is were I would prefer to stay.

We stayed 3 nights, choosing this hotel because of location above Tokyo Central Station as we were travelling on from there.It was also central to viewing Tokyo City. Well appointed, comfortable rooms. Great amenities, including very nice Spa facilities and a small/medium gym( though extra to use) . Bars and restaurants as you would expect at this level were excellent. It was expensive, but worth it. Staff were very efficient and helpful, all spoke English. Local area very modern & close to Imperial Palace.

Can’t recommend this hotel enough. This historic hotel is completely modernized inside and has an excellent location, obviously, being at the main train station in Tokyo. Everything is beautiful and clean. I recommend splurging for the breakfast, the spread is huge and the atrium is extremely pleasant.

I was there last week had never thought it was possible to get such a good service at a hotel. The employees do everything they can to make sure you have a great stay at the hotel and in Tokyo. They bought tickets for the shinkansen for me.They also followed me to and from the shinkansen.This they suggested without me asking for it.I would like to thank the employees very much, especially for those who work at the reception. They helped to make my stay in Japan perfect for me.I'll be back.

On a recent tour of Japan we used the Tokyo Station Hotel to a launch the start and finish of a three week journey. We had arranged airport pickup and local guides through Chief Concierge Marie Antoinette Mori Prior to us getting to Japan bad weather forced us to substantially change all our arrangements and Marie and her team went out their way to ensure everything was rebooked. It was extremely stressful time the the hotel could not have been more accommodating in making everything as we needed it to be. When we arrived we were delighted with an outstanding warm greeting and check into this iconic hotel. The next morning we met Marie and she greeted us as old friends and with recognition and warmth. We cannot say enough about the service we received our entire stay including being escorted to train platform on our first train trip a gesture we really appreciated. We had two rooms both comfortable and different. The one with view of Imperial Palace grounds was fabulous. The location is excellent and we were extremely pleased with our decision to use this hotel as both starting end point. Major thank you to Chief Concierge Marie and here entire team who treated us so well

Good small 5 star hotel in great location inside Tokyo Central station & near Royal Palace & shibuya..Rooms small but nicely presented. Staff very efficient and helpful.No swimming pool.Would stay again.

We stayed there twice, each time was a great experience: the rooms are so nice and classy (the ones with view to the palace, though far from the palace, are great, so are the ones with street views) hotel staff are super friendly and helpful (their English is excellent!); be sure to ask for help to book restaurants, the staff are so helpful and thorough! also be sure not to skip the breakfast buffet - it's very high quality and pleasant; location is the best: there is an entrance to the subway/JR station, as well as to the shops (if you have been in Tokyo you know how important it is for trains and subways! ); numerous shops and restaurant all in walking distance, and also you can walk (or run) to the palace (attention runners: there is a very established running route around the palace). great place! will stay there again!

fantastic old style Hotel, a real treat and perfection - if you can afford it then do it, its going back to an age when people cared about service and style. lovely location and wonderful staff - Japan at its best

This hotel was fantastic, excellent location, so easy for transport and lovely surrounding area. The hotel was very elegant and the staff were all exceptional. I have to say i thought the price was very good too for how upmarket it was. Room was massive too, beautiful decor and very plush. Excellent concierge who confirmed our reservations and suggested other excellent dining experiences too. Highly recommend.

It wasn't cheap, but what nice hotel in Tokyo is? It's location, connected to Tokyo Station, makes departing and arriving from Narita super convenient. You can also catch pretty much any train line from there to other parts of the city, too. The rooms are small (it's Tokyo), but they were nice. The bathroom was the best! But if you want to know the best part of the hotel, it's hands down the Toraya Café. We spent two mornings there having matcha green tea and wagashi treats.

I stayed here for just one night upon my arrival in Tokyo. I would be catching the shinkansen to Kyoto the following day, so was looking for a hotel near Tokyo Station. This hotel is connected to Tokyo Station and spans its entire length on the station's Marunouchi side, so its convenience was perfect, as was, it would turn out, its level of service. The hotel originally opened in1915, but was extensively damaged during World War II. It had its grand reopening in 2012. The hotel offers a Meet & Greet service where, with advanced notice, someone will meet you at your train platform and car to escort you to the hotel. I did not partake of this service, as I wanted to explore the enormous Tokyo Station (especially its dining options) a bit before checking in. The Marunouchi South Gate exit is most convenient to access the hotel; there is a side entrance in the dome, and the proper entrance is just outside. Upon entering the lobby, a bellwoman (there seemed to be more bellwomen than bellmen throughout my stay) immediately jumped to attention and escorted me to the front desk, where check-in was quick and efficient. She then escorted me to my room and spent a good amount of time explaining its features. She would later even escort me to the proper ticket office to purchase my shinkansen tickets (ticket booths within the station only sell same-day tickets). The hotel seems to span the entire length of Tokyo Station on the Marunouchi side. Thus, there clearly can be lengthy walks from the central elevators and entrance to many rooms. The hotel seems to have more convenient secondary entrances that have room key access and are closed late at night.I booked the hotel's smallest and least costly accomodation, a Palace Side Queen. There seem to be very few of these rooms, which are located in the Station's 2 domes, facing outwards. My room was indeed compact, but had a very high ceiling (as do all rooms) and even a chandelier. The queen bed was pushed up against the window, so one could access the bed only from one side. For 2 people or for several nights, the room's size would perhaps be a detriment, but it was fine for me. The bathroom was actually quite sizable with a large wet-room (bath tub and adjacent multi-head shower with chair). Of all the Toto toilets I would encounter in hotels during this trip, this ond had the most features, including automatic seat lifting when I approached. The room had pajamas and slippers, a humidifier/air purifier, minibar and fridge and coffeeand tea-making accoutrements, and a cell phone with local and hotel information. One niggle: the desk had neither electrical outlets or USB ports convenient to it. I had breakfast in the lovely and soaring 4th floor space called The Atrium, open only to hotel guests. It offers an expansive buffet with many Japanese and European/Western selections--very delish.The hotel has numerous other dining and drinking establishments--French, Japanese (several options), Chinese, Italian, plus the open-all-day elegant and popular Lobby Lounge.Tokyo Station itself also has many dining options, including innumerable stalls selling bento boxes to go. This is a hotel to consider if you need to be near Tokyo Station.

Located directly above the main Tokyo train station, the hotel could not be more ideally situated. But what makes it really special is the luxurious but homely feel and the wonderful staff. From the moment we arrived staff were helpful and accommodating and eager to assist with any requirement. Our room was spacious and extremely well-appointed with a deep bath and rain shower. The upstairs restaurant was cozy and welcoming and the food exceptional. While not unusual to have an egg station, the creations (particularly the eggs benedict) were superb. There was a wide range of breakfast foods including both Japanese and European offerings. Entry to the hotel can be made from multiple locations in the station which ensured we did not have to wander around trying to find the correct exit. The concierge staff were brilliant, offering activities that suited both the adults and teenagers, and when we queried how to find the correct platform for a train to Osaka, walked us through the station to the correct point. All of the meals that we ate in the hotel, including room service, were delicious. There are many shops in the surrounding buildings and a small supermarket in the basement of a neighbouring building. Within a short walk are local eateries and Ginza is only a short walk away.This hotel was so lovely, that I would not hesitate to stay there again!

As an Art Historian, I particularly looked forward to the final hotel on our already fabulous first trip to Japan. The Tokyo Station Hotel most certainly 'checked all the boxes' on our hotel wish-list for excellence.---So much so that our Kyoto-born, Japanese-American friends, (who return to Japan at least once a year), vowed to stay at the TSH, based solely on the experience my husband and I shared. It is not just the history of the renowned Tokyo Train Station and its unique Hotel, (archivally preserved in tastefully framed photographs which adorn the spotlessly maintained, long hallways on the Palace Side of the luxury Hotel) that delights visitors from around the world. It's the people, the staff, the hotel management who graciously extend themselves in every way possible to ensure that each traveler enjoys a memorable visit to The Tokyo Station Hotel.Starting from the moment we entered the lovely lobby, there were no fewer than five staff people (bell persons, concierges, managers), offering assistance, expertly and efficiently checking us in, seeing to our luggage, etc. And that number and level of staff availability and assistance remained consistent throughout out stay: From the very tall, distinguished-looking bell-captain who navigated us through those l-o-o-n-g Palace-Side hallways to our 'Elegant and Refined European-Themed Superior King Room withBreathtaking View of Tokyo Financial District', to the attentive, petite young female bell-persons who could 'wrangle' heavy departure suitcases and parcels with equal aplomb.Our room was exactly what we had asked for: Quiet; Serene European decor; Highceilings; Tall windows; Soft lighting, including chandelier; Large bathroom with make-up lighted vanity, Toto multi-featured, heated-seat toilet, and spacious glass-walled walk-in shower.Sumptuous Daily Breakfasts in the sun-lit Atrium. Quiet Cocktails in the Lounge. Lunchavailable in the elegant British--style Lobby-Level Tea-Room. And always available to help, with a friendly smile, concierges and management persons such as Duty Manager, Yoshiki Kamata and, at the Front Desk, Ms Yuko Hosoi were very much appreciated.Thank You, one and all for making our stay at the one of a kind Tokyo Station Hoteltruly memorable!-BJLaB

Hands down, the best hotel I’ve stayed at (I travel quite a bit). The service, the food and the location make this hotel amazing. If you’re coming to Tokyo you must stay here. A big THANK YOU to the Concierge team.

I can't really fault anything - service was good, room and public spaces beautiful, location amazing - just that it's very expensive!I would certainly stay here again, incredibly convenient to metro, JR and shinkansen, and not noisy at all.

Had a great stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel with my wife. We stayed in one of the dome rooms at the north end of the building. The room is very nice, clean and well appointed. The walk from the lobby to the room was a bit far as expected, but to actually exit the hotel there is a side door that is much closer to the north dome. The side door closes at 1:00 am IIRC, so if you're leaving or getting back later at night you'll have to go through the lobby. It's conveniently located at Tokyo Station (obviously) which is great for transiting around the city, but in terms of just going out at night to walk around or have a drink, this location isn't going to be lively like Shinjuku/Shibuya etc. Concierge is very responsive and helpful with restaurant bookings, and they also offer a porter service that can meet you or drop you off at the NEX platform of Tokyo station when you arrive and leave. Invaluable when you have too much luggage lol. I'll definitely be staying here again.

This was our second time to stay in this hotel, as I made a promised to myself, that I definitely coming back. And that’s still my best decision. Actually, I’d like to spend my Christmas there, but unfortunately I just made myself clear by January instead. So we stayed for 2 nights on Jan 15 – 17, 2019 and choose Palace Side Superior Twin room as this is our last room type and suited our need best, we got room no. 3092 this time, and the view now, we got to see KITTE Mall and Post Office building next to the left side of our window. Detail things are pretty much the same as we got previously. All the cleanliness, beautiful room, amenities, comfy-ness, I can go on and on. But this time we got Handy in our room, the android phone like mobile device that you could carry around when you strolling the city. This is very helpful as the map is slightly better than google map, you can browsing for what’s trending or found any recommendation to dine or shopping or anything, make a local or international call, and the most important thing that you can save your phone battery for something else. There’s slightly rain when we arrived at the hotel, and one of the staff running out of the hotel toward us to help carry our heavy luggage and that’s not the end, as she (yes, you read it right) them, the other staff hand her a towel to dry out our luggage. We never ever have this kind of service experience before at any other hotel at the same situation. And more of this was when we’re checked out and very early in the morning, we ask one of the staff at reception desk for a taxi, and she was checking the taxi arrival for every couple of minutes to make sure it, while we just sat comfortably in the lobby instead of standing in a freezing cold morning. For all the staffs we can't thank you enough for your hard works and excellent dedicated performance. All I can say now, I'm coming back definitely and soon hopefully.

My family and I stayed recently at The Tokyo Station hotel for our Christmas-New Year's trip and very pleased with our stay. The hotel was centrally located and walking distance to our favorite places to go to in Ginza and Marunouchi. Kitte, Daimaru are nearby and very easy to get to. The rooms were well appointed with all the amenties you would need while traveling. The laundry service was great, I could not ask for better service. It was also easy to take the Shinkansen for a short trip to Nagoya being right at the station. Our restaurant and transportation requests were handled prompty by the awesome Concierge team - thank you Saito-san, Otsuka-san and Mori-san. As we were checking out, we were already planning our return trip and hopefully we get to stay at the hotel again. Thank you for making our stay a great family experience and looking forward to coming back again.

All the other reviewers have said it before, this hotel is awesome. The staff is so gracious and extremely helpful. They assisted us to the train station and ensured we got on the right train. I will definitely stay there again when I go back to Tokyo.

If you like hotels that arent Western copies of each other, this is a spectacular choice. The rooms are beautiful, restful and quiet. The staff is excellent in every way. (A shout out to Marie Antoinette, head concierge. She and her staff will make everything you want come true.) The hotel is located right in the train station, (rooms with a view of the big beautiful train dome of amazing.) If you love classic hotels with history, that have kept up with modern Toyko, choose this.

This hotel was not only central and conveniently located at the rail station hub, but it also has luxurious amenities of the highest class that made this one of my most comfortable stays during my week vacation in Japan. However, what really set this place apart was the quality of service by its staff. They welcomed me back to the hotel with a smile every time, they had white out when I had typos on my postcards, they mailed my postcards for me, they sold me stamps, and they extended my checkout to 1:30 pm so I wouldn't be inconvenienced by a 2 pm Narita Express departure. Their best staff, in my opinion, was Saori Shinoda who was my bellhop. She not only carted my bags to my room and carried on a pleasant conversation the entire way in perfect English, but she also went the extra mile in carrying my backpack for me to the train station platform upon checkout. The photo of her with my very heavy backpack is not just ridiculous given her tiny frame, but it's also the best example of why I enjoyed my stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel. Their staff, and especially Ms. Shinoda, set a new bar for service and now my standard of what I expect from a five-star hotel. Domo arigatogozaimashita, I will definitely return!

The people who work here make this hotel simply one of the best to stay in Tokyo. And talk about centrally located with train lines all over the city -- and country -- just steps away. I emailed 48 hours ahead of arrival requesting their NEX arrival service and was met immediately outside of our NEX car by a hotel attendant who helped us with luggage and a quick walk to the hotel. The rooms are on the small side like most hotels (we stayed Palace side on our first several days before taking off for Gora, and then a Dome side room for our last day) plus they have a sumptuous bathroom set up and I certainly took advantage of an evening bath every day in addition to a morning shower. If you don't know about Taq-u-Bin luggage transfer hotel to hotel, google and use it if you are traveling from hotel to hotel, city to city. Also, be sure to book with the breakfast included because, for us, it was a morning ritual and delightful way to start the day with selections of global goodies with great coffee and tea. In leaving to return to the airport, we were also taken by an attendant back to the NEX platform. Absolutely perfect.

Just off a long haul flight.Arrived at hotel. Told no check in until 3pm. Not ideal, but I get it. Go for lunch. Get back for 3pm. Massive long line of guests all waiting to check in, whilst an army of staff (including the duty manager) watch and do literally nothing.We waited 15 minutes just to check in (they already had all the details of course, hotels always do!) and we're basically told there was nothing they could do about it.Duty manager kept blaming his lack of check in terminals and essentially all the guests for arriving at the same time. Failed completely to manage or even ameliorate the situation.Amateur hour.V v bad first impression of Japan.

Stayed for 3 nights with my family and it was one of the best hotels I have experienced. All the staff were so courteous and professional. The rooms were impeccable and breakfast in the Atrium was fantastic! The location was easy - joined to Tokyo Station, it makes it a very easy base to get around Tokyo.

I was treated to a night in this hotel by a Tokyo friend... I had no idea how wonderful a hotel it is. This is worth the money you'll spend, it isn't astronomically expensive but it isn't cheap. However, it's attention to detail in every way is just stunning. Yes, it's right in the station so you'll hear a bit of noise of the trains rumbling distantly below, but the staff are extraordinary, the rooms stunning, and the pyjamas a perfect fit (and that's important for us Western people who are not petite Japanese!) I'd come back here in a heart beat... granted I could afford it, but spoil yourself. It's worth it.

Had a wonderful stay in a dome side king room. Although the room was a bit small, the luxurious appointments, amenities, and great view of Tokyo Station more than made up for it. It is in an obviously excellent location to explore all of Tokyo, to connect to the Shinkansen, or Narita Express. Will not hesitate to stay here again, and highly recommend it. Service was absolutely phenomenal.

I visited this hotel with my husband annually for five years. Service has improved every year. This time we came with a friend during mid of Dec. 2018. I wanna thank you meet and greet team who welcome us since dropped off from NEX so much. We had many big luggage and you still carry for us till we arrive hotel. Such a warm welcome during winter. I never felt like stranger with this hotel. The concierge team, K.Mori, K.Otsuka and another new girl were helpful for us very much. They arranged eating trip for us with useful suggestion and very supportive. I admire their "can do" attitude and quick response a lot. The room and service are excellence. Clean and nice decoration with good housekeeping.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is a beautiful hotel in a great location! My husband and I spent five nights here last month. The hotel staff were very attentive. We loved the convenience of being right at Tokyo Station with its connections to the bullet trains, various subway lines and many shops and restaurants. Our room rate included the daily breakfast. The breakfast had many delicious Japanese and Western options. A great feature of the hotel for tourists is the complimentary, local smartphone in every room. The phone was very helpful for navigating around Tokyo and searching for shopping and dining options while on the go.

This renovated hotel has very nicely adorned rooms and central location. We stayed in a dome side king room for 1 night.(1) RoomWe thought our dome-side room was compact but nicely appointed, with high ceilings and a very interesting view of the station dome. The bed and pillows were very comfortable, and there is a large-screen TV and nice chairs. The bathroom is very modern with a Japanese style toilet and an enclosed shower area with adjoining tub. Our room also included a small refrigerator/mini-bar.(2) ServiceWe found the front desk staff very accommodating and kind. They were more than happy to help with whatever questions we had for our stay. Porters were very friendly and helpful with our bags and showing us the room.(3) FoodWe tried their buffet-style breakfast (not included in the cost of our room) which was held in the Atrium. Overall, we were pretty impressed by the selection and setting. They have extensive options of both Japanese and Western items, as well as made-to-order omelets and eggs. Probably one of the best breakfasts we’ve ever had, in a room that had great natural light.(4) AmenitiesWe ended up not using the fitness center or spa, which incurred an extra fee. Each room also includes a “Handy” cell phone which was free to use to make calls and access the internet, which was a nice touch.(5) Location/ConvenienceThe hotel is situated right at Tokyo Station (Marunouchi side), so is fairly easy to get to, particularly if you are in transit. It also has a fairly central location in Ginza, which is surrounded by lots to do and eat. The very nearby station was great in helping us get to the Narita airport (via the Narita Express). Overall, we found the hotel to be a great home-base for exploring the city.

Love the theme design and decoration. Good feeling for a wonderful solo relax trip in Tokyo. The view from the room is nice. All the staffs were the five stars standard. I’m so touching by the bell staffs. Wonderful service mind & try so hard to please me. Thank you for the treat. Will be back

In addition to its great location, the Tokyo Station Hotel has a lot more to offer. The guest experience was perfect from check-in to check-out. Courteous service, very good restaurants and breakfast, spacious and luxurious rooms. And most importantly, a cozy and quiet "club" atmosphere which completely matches the building's architecture and isolates you from the hustle bustle of Tokyo station nextdoor. I will be back.

It's not often that you come across a beautiful hotel with as rich a history as The Tokyo Station Hotel. The decor is stunning but in an understated way. The location is unbeatable as it's right above Tokyo Station, so easy access to the trains, Shinkansen, buses, taxis, etc. The service is impeccable. There's nothing I can write negatively about the hotel, other than I wish The Lobby Lounge wasn't so popular that we couldn't get a seat the first day we were there, or that maybe they can prioritize hotel guests for a seating.

This was our third trip to Japan in four years and food has been our primary focus. We booked Tokyo Station Hotel(TSH) dome room for seven nights after learning in the foodie circles that their Concierge Service is one of the best, if not the best, in Tokyo.TSH’s central location is hard to beat with the extensive rail system literally at your doorstep. Ginza is within walking distance. The room was immaculate and quiet with a luxurious bed and pillows. The rain shower was addicting and difficult to get out once you get started. My wife even wanted to take home the silky one-piece pajama, unfortunately it was not for sale. Both the Japanese and Western breakfasts were delicious with varied choices and lots of seasonal fruits. We never got tired of breakfast during our stay.However, what separates TSH apart from the rest are the people. Service excellence is in their DNA. The Concierge Service headed by (Ms) M.A. Mori and associates (Ms) M. Saito and (Mr) T. Otsuka made our culinary dreams come true. We dined at Michelin starred restaurants including Ryugin, Jiro Sushi, Harutaka, Tempura Uchitsu and Le Sputnik. They also facilitated the purchase of a special Japanese knife and guided us to the nearest Pokemon store and tea house. Another stellar example, the porter packed a large cardboard box and accompanied my friend to the post office; however, since he did not have enough yen, the porter returned to the hotel to get the money to complete the transaction. In my book their service is second to none! If you love food, Tokyo—the culinary capital of the world—is the place to go and TSH is the place to stay.

My wife and I stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel for 3 nights in November. It is a high-end luxurious hotel and the clientel leans toward older, more refined guests (we booked it because we had a discount through a travel club). The hotel is long and low, along the west side of the station looking out towards the Imperial Gardens, Marinouchi side. We had a dome-side room (overlooking one of the domes in the station--basically the windows opened to the inside of the station, above one of the entry domes, looking into the station. I thought it might be loud, but the windows must be thick, because we couldn't hear anything from the station. On the other hand, there's no real outside view, so it was hard to tell if it was cloudy or sunny until we went outside). The room was well-appointed, but because of it's age (built around 1915), the bed took up a lot of space and there isn't a lot of storage space in the room, but it is well-appointed, good linens, comfortable bed, great bathroom amenities and very good water pressure. The hotel, as some reviewers have noted, is long and low, so it can be quite a walk from the elevator banks to the room--it seemed like it was well over 40-50 yards, but the hotel reeks of old-school gentility and is a welcome respite from the crowded streets outside. The convenience of being in the train station cannot be overstated. The main train station is large (not as confusing as the Shinjuku station) but offers wonderful restaurants and shopping.The hotel's guests seemed to be many older Japanese couples, business people and some families. It's a quiet, respectful place. We had the breakfast package and the food is wonderful, both Japanese and western food. The staff are excellent, accommodating and unobtrusive. I would stay here again in a heartbeat, but if walking a long way to your room is a turnoff, ask for one closer to an elevator!

We have stayed at this absolutely beautiful hotel 3 times for a total of maybe 5 nights. It is a bit of a mixed bag of extremes.The good stuff:Very handy location if it is your first night or last night, especially for shinkansen access;the building is gorgeous and historical with lots of interesting information;plenty of exercise getting to rooms in the domes;the breakfast is amazing;the staff are attentive and increasingly friendly.The bad stuff:it takes time getting from one end to another;the bar is a smoker's paradise as is the casual restaurant;the area is pretty boring, really;the rooms are very small;the interior dome rooms lack privacy but at least have something to look at, some other rooms face the windows of a building and have no privacy;It is expensive.So for some aspects I'd give it a 5, for others I'd give it a 1 or 2, which is why I settled on a 3. Having been 3 times the negatives are outweighing the positives, but I'd still recommend it for a night just to see the amazing architecture.

Although there are hundreds of hotel in Tokyo, it is not easy to find a hotel that is spacious, modern and convenient. This is the reason why I returned to this hotel. This time we stayed in the Dome side room. The bed was 180x203cm. There was rain shower and separate bathtub. We had enough space for packing our luggage. The room was on the 3rd floor facing the concourse of the station, but it was very quiet. There was a direct walkway connecting to the Marunouchi South Gate. A tourist information centre was right at the Gate, where you can buy the JR pass. It takes only 10-15 minutes to Shinjuku by the Chuo line (JR). The Shinkansen brings you to the whole country. We don’t need to take breaks in the hotel as there was lot of restaurants in the station. An underground shopping mall sell lot of toys. The room rate is the cheapest among the 5-star hotels near the station. Highly recommended.

I recently spent three days in Tokyo by myself before meeting my family there; Tokyo is not an easy city to navigate, especially on a first visit. From the very first contact, the entire concierge staff was extraordinary! They had someone meet me at the Tokyo Station stop when I arrived from the airport and accompany me to the hotel - what a help!! They then helped me purchase train tickets to Kyoto and from Kyoto back to Tokyo - they were endlessly patient while I coordinated travel details with my daughter.Not knowing how difficult it was to get dinner reservations in Tokyo, they really came to our rescue by getting us into one of the best sushi restaurants on very short notice, making our last night in Tokyo an extraordinary culinary experience. I hope to return to TOKYO in the future and would only stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel. In addition to the extraordinary service, the rooms are comfortable and well-appointed, the location is excellent, and the overall ambiance is extremely welcoming.

This is a great hotel, particularly for your first night in Tokyo. It is literally located within Tokyo Station, which makes it very convenient after you take the train in from Narita Airport. Not having to navigate the subway or a long walk from there with jet lag is worth the price! The hotel is lovely, the staff are very friendly, and the rooms are large and very clean.

Elegant hotel, traditional with modern feeling, chandelier in room adds grandeur. Footprint of room not large though very high ceilings room has spacious feeling. Seperate toilet, large wet (full bath & separate shower) all extremely clean.Bed extremely comfortable with the right amount of softness (enjoying as most Japanese beds are like sleeping in the floor) you will get a great nights sleep on in this bed.Easy access to train station and lots of nearby restaurants, check out level B1 of Tokyo station for plenty of places to eat & shop. Also go over the road to the Shin-Marunouchi Building for a wide selection of restaurants that are open till 10pm.

I stayed on the 2nd floor, in what surely is one of the smallest rooms in the hotel. Comfortable bed, but no real room to do much more than sleep. Had a drink in the Oak Bar, also on the second floor, which is typically Tokyo...extremely small, but everything available and in its place.Good service, as is expected. No real noise from the station, which was literally through the bedroom window.

My wife and I have stayed almost a dozen different places throughout Tokyo on our trips through the years, and after staying here, we can't ever go back to the others! Starting with location, we fly into Narita, and the Narita Express takes you directly to Tokyo Station, they will even have a person with your name on a sign to guide you from train to reception if you request it. Being a JR hub and having a metro line with the next station over being the 5 metro line station Otemachi (more quickly walked to then even taking the one stop train ride) you have access to nearly all of Tokyo. You step outside from the hotel (from the quiet guest-only elevator nearest your room) and can visit any number of shops and restaurants around Marunouchi or head into Tokyo Station, that you are literally sleeping above every night, and fill your whole trip just exploring the Marunouchi and Yaesu sides of the station. With a nearby convenience store as well, you are able to stock up on drinks and snacks at the start of each day before heading out. Now, the staff was wonderful and spoke very good English. They handled everything we ever asked for, while also holding our friend's bags (that were staying at another hotel even!) when they had to check out early. The room was so comfortable and spacious, with a very conscientious cleaning staff that even organized the makeup on the vanity by size on its own towels to give just one example of the care and attention given when they clean. And even if you are prepared for running around Japan with your pocket wifi, or sim card, they have a fully functional smartphone in your room for you to take with you that can make domestic and international calls, 4G LTE, and we even downloaded Facebook and other apps we use back home, all of which get erased when you check out of the room at the end of your stay so you don't have to worry about your information. I can't even count how many times google maps, google translate, or being able to make a call to a business to make a reservation, when we were away from the hotel's concierge, helped us when our rented wifi hotspot finally gave out toward the end of each night. The bathroom was ridiculously spacious and if you wanted a hot bath, it fills in about two minutes. And if you are able, eat at the Atrium at least once. Bring down the English newspaper they have waiting outside your door, and have breakfast at the Atrium, which was the best breakfast we have ever had in Japan, with a huge selection of Western and Japanese foods. Definitely worth the price to hit at least once to experience it, but if you have the budget to eat there every morning, do it! Can't say enough about this place. This is where we will be staying every year now. More than 5 stars. Thank you to the Staff for giving us a wonderful start and end to each day.

I have stayed at this hotel twice and the experience is even better the second time.Perfect location if taking the trains from Narita or the region into Tokyo.The check in was seamless and bell service was prompt. It is a really good service to walk guests to the train platforms with the luggage on check out.The concierge was helpful and professional especially Ms Marie Antoinette Mori. I have emailed the hotel to make a dinner reservation and they not only made the reservation but followed up with a print out of directions to the restaurant when we check in. On the second occasion, when the restaurant that we had wanted to dine at was full, a follow up email of alternatives were suggested.The rooms facing the station are small but very comfortable with little noise despite over looking the station.The rooms facing the city are bigger and brighter. Do ask if available.I will definitely return for future visits to Tokyo.

This was the best the 5 star hotels I stayed in during my recent Japan trip. Impeccable and super friendly service, spacious and luxurious rooms, more English speaking TV channels than other hotels and an amazing shower! Overall just a tremendous hotel. I would have liked the gym to open earlier than 10am on Sunday so I could work out before going sightseeing, but you can't have everything. Highly recommend.

We recently stayed for two nights on a stopover from Australia to the UK. The hotel is very well located and makes transport a breeze. Our room was a little small but luxurious. We had a doom room so we could view the comings and goings of the busy train station which we enjoyed. The staff were excellent in every way. The breakfast was one of the best that we have every experienced

I have so many wonderful things to say about the Tokyo Station Hotel.Firstly it is a little more expensive then an average hotel, however it's absolutely worth every penny (If you have the budget then you definitely have to stay here). From the second we came in we felt like royalty, literally everyone is there to please. The room itself was a bit small however very luxurious for a business hotel and they offer a long list of amenities. The best part about this place is the staff, they really do go above and beyond to make you feel welcomed. If you are concerned about any language barrier, don't worry the staff do speak english. As a person who is still learning Japanese I was really worried but was pleasantly surprised how easy it was to get around and ask for any assistance. Also the hotel is perfect for transportation, literally the station is a few steps away and getting around Tokyo was a breeze. Not to mention they do have stores nearby as well as shopping areas. I honestly have nothing bad to say about the Tokyo Station hotel and I can be rather picky with places I stay. So if you are looking for a wonderful hotel in the heart of Tokyo then this is the place to stay!!!!!!!

one of the best hotels in Tokyo. the hotel is located right in the station building. from the airport direct Norita express (50 minutes). subways and trains are close by, and this is important. rooms are medium in size with a large bathroom. 100% silence and cleanliness. Breakfast of European and Japanese cuisine in a large bright atrium. recommend.

My wife and I booked a Junior Suite and were pleasantly surprised by our reception and room. The room was spacious and looked out onto the Imperial Palace. Could not be more pleased by our reception and room. Also, a special thanks to the concierge service. I e-mailed them about doing an airport pickup and all was handled with such professionalism and expediency. Also, I requested at a late date reservations at Nariswaw's, not an easy place to get into! They were able to get us reservations!!! A special thanks to Ms. Mori and her team are great. A special thanks to Miyuki Saito for her help with our requests. The breakfast in the Atrium was fantastic, A great selection and even an egg-to-cook station. Really enjoyed the warm greeting and filling breakfast which help last most of the day.When we return to Tokyo this will be our first choice to stay!! You won't regret staying at Tokyo's Grande Dame!!!

This is a must pass thru direction I will go from my office to my hotel during my stays.The building looking fantastic and full with exits with routes all the commuters to the place the need to.Recommended visit.

From this hotel, you can walk around Maranouchi and Gonzales’s areas, visit untold numbers of restaurants, cafes, shops etc and of course, access the train network with unparalleled convenience. But wait - there is more. The public areas of the hotel are lovely, particularly the lobby lounge. It’s very tasteful, with beautiful fresh flowers and charming pictures. All peaceful and calm, and in stark contrast to the frenetic activity in Tokyo Station next door.Like most reviewers, we found our room to be very small for the very large price, and we loved the bathroom. My husband thinks it’s the best shower he has ever been in.And speaking of the best, the concierge service is brilliant. Ms Mori runs a great operation with a depth of detailed information that makes Tokyo manageable and fun. While Miyuki Saito is able to tell you (in a sublimely charming way) what you want to do before you know it yourself. In short, the hotel is a marvellous, if very expensive, place to stay. Good

The hotel is easily recognisable given its beautiful facade and is directly connected to the JR Tokyo Station, which makes it extremely convenient, especially if you're taking the Shinkansen. The service is also top-notch. I had written to the concierge regarding restaurant reservations & other queries prior to my trip, and the team has been very responsive and helpful, always responding within 1-2 business days. The staff we encountered during our stay were all extremely helpful, courteous and spoke very good English. The room is tastefully decorated and ample amenities were provided in the bathroom. The bed was comfortable and the room felt quiet even though neighbouring rooms were occupied. Venue for breakfast was stunning and the breakfast itself was decent, but the variety of buffet selection was not as extensive as one might expect given the price, and the hot food weren't really hot as it was not kept heated over steamers and most of the food just tasted mediocre. I would thus not recommend paying extra to have breakfast included in your room rate unless there's a discount, as there are plenty other more reasonably priced options around the hotel. Overall we enjoyed our stay very much and would like to thank the considerate service provided by the hotel staff which made our trip more memorable. No hesitation in choosing this hotel again on our next visit to Tokyo!

Stayed there for three nights during a roadshow. What an impeccable service. From the check in till the check out. Everything was up to perfection. Can highly recommend to experience this historical hotel. Great and convenient location to all major sights. Would stay again without any doubt.

Commenced our Europe trip with our 1st stop in Tokyo as we had never been to Japan before. Chose the historic hotel as it looked interesting and we were not disappointed. We arrived early in morning and although I had communicated this before we arrived they could not provide an early check on which was disapointing but they provided a free session in the Onsen to allow us to freshen up. The Hotel which is built over the railway station would be up to 600 mtrs long and has been restored perfectly. The room they took us to was about 400 more walk and was directly over the station entrance. We were disappointed as we had booked the hotel for 3 days to really immerse ourselves in the experience and felt very isolated. After voicing my disappointment the manager kindly provided a room much closer to reception. Wow it was an upgrade like no ever. A 4 room suite thst was fit for a King and a Queen. We could not believe it. Our view went straight up to the palace walls. It was outstanding. Tokyo was outstanding. We are returning tonight but unfortunately could not get a room at the hotel so are trying the Hilton Obaida which Im sure will provide from the reviews I have read another perspective of this beautiful city.

I literally spent more time in the air than I did in Japan. I’d normally stay at a Manadrin property when in Asia but this was arranged locally fo me and I wasn’t disappointed. While I had expected a few days here, changes to business plans made this a 1 night stay which was disappointing. The hotel is extremely well located - near the ginza and all the surrounding restaurants and bars in the area. Hotel was top notch, courteous to a fault but it is Japan so not a surprise. Amenities (in room) were extensive. I didn’t have an opportunity to try any of the hotels dining options but I can say the Bar Oak, one of their on property bars was a pleasant surprise and I thoroughly enjoyed sampling their whiskey tasting/flights (and I’m not a whiskey drinker!). Stayed only 1 night - Maisonette King Suite. Great breakfast before getting back on the plane for the *long* flight home. Note: This has practically direct access to the trains which can be extremely convenient - they don’t call it Tokyo Station for nothing. Would recommend, especially if you’re here in business.

From the moment we were greeted, we were made to feel special and welcome. The service was attentive and helpful. Everyone called us by name and no request was met with anything less than a broad smile and ‘my pleasure’. The room was large and luxurious. The bath had every amenity, even the newest Japanese toilet. Breakfast was a feast with Asian and western items, probably around 75-100 items to choose from....you will feel pampered and lived here.

The hotel was beautiful and in a perfect location in the center of Tokyo. The entire stay was exceptional, even during the Sunday night typhoon. Most of all, we need to thank the incredible assistance shown us by Concierge Ms. Miyuki Saito both before and during our stay. She helped find the restaurants and book the tours and trains that made our visit so memorable.

We had an extremely pleasant stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel. We were treated so kindly and with utmost respect. The hotel itself was beautiful, the rooms were comfortable and the employees were top notch. In particular the Concierge Mikuki Saito - she went out of her way to help us navigate our way as this was our first trip to Japan. She made reservations for us even before we arrived, she secured transportation for us and our luggage, and was particularly helpful with details as the typhoon was approaching! We would definitely stay at this fine hotel again:)

Spent a few nights here for a business stay.Super location for office and a short hop to the imperial palace.Easy access from Haneda Airport and obviously easy for trains too.Staff super polite as you’d expect, all areas are very clean: corridors are long as has been mentioned but, that’s a function of the type of building it is, so not much you can do about that.Breakfast is in a lovely room called The Atrium but although nice I didn’t think it was as nice as others I’ve been lucky to experience. A little expensive for what it is.My room was very small with a view of a wall, so I hope not all of them are like that.Bathroom was fine with good toiletries.There is a gym and spa on site which you have to pay for. I get paying for the spa but, the gym? I have never understood why hotels (expensive hotels too) charge for gym access.Gym itself is small with staff that follow your every move which I found a little off putting.A colleague recommended the on site sushi restaurant which I was unable to try sadly.Overall very convenient for my needs.
user_name:
R1der
Kingston upon Thames, United Kingdom

review_body: This is a splendid five-star hotel. Excellent public areas many restaurants. We liked the Camellia … a sort of bar/eatery combo at which we ate and drank excellent Japanese single malt whisky. Our room was a bit small. Using a smaller wing chair could have made it more comfortable. Our only other issues were that the room was about 250 lineal metres from Reception and that an early check-in wasn't available for travellers on an overnight flight. Despite all this is it still in the five-star class.

We could not have asked for a better hotel to start our holiday.The staff were excellent. Before we arrived the Concierge helped us secure tickets and make reservations and once they knew what we were looking for they made some great recommendations for places to visit (Team Lab Planets) and places to drink (Majestic Bar). Miyuki Saito did a really top job.The room was first class. I think I read a post about a room being tired......definitely not the case at all. We had an inside room which looked into the Dome - fun to see everyone scurrying off to work.Location. Easy to reach from Haneda and centrally located with easy access to all the corners of Tokyo. Nice to walk over to the Imperial Palace.Breakfast. I think this has been covered by other posts.Conclusion - the staff gave you the service you would expect from a boutique hotel but with the facilities and services you would expect from a luxury hotel.

This is a wonderful heritage hotel with excellent staff and customer service above and beyondVery long corridors mentioned in other reviews didnt matter as it is a long lowrise building so that cant be helped..corridors were immaculate and charmingEasy to arrive by shinkansen and take the maranouchi central exit.. hotel entrance is on your leftHad a few drinks and meal at camelia bar on 2 nd floorLovely and very reasonableOak bar is very clubby dark and great olde worlde feeling but expect to pay a lot more for drinks and foodPlenty of good eating places around mainly on the left hand side of front entrance then left again..kitte building is a nice place for shops and eat/drink as is TokiaGreat jazz club (cotton club) in Tokia bldg too

Beautiful, stately rooms with high celing. Huge bathroom and tub. Toilettries from Gilchrist & Soames London. Beds are super comfy. Breakfast buffet is pricey but so worth it. It's for gourmands ! Eat all-you-can super sweet melon and cherry. So many Japanese dishes that we tasted for the first time. They have Chirashi sushi in the morning. Shrimp with Avocado and Lasagna too. We will definitely come back!

Wonderful stay for the last two nights of our trip around Japan, we needed a little luxury and weren’t disappointed The entrance to the hotel is on the Marunouchi side of the station, not easily accessible if you arrive on the bullet train from the west, just ask for directions, everyone is really helpful

I just returned home after enjoying another wonderful stay in the Tokyo Station Hotel (my second time there) and it is still every bit as good as I remember it from the last time. The staff are very professional and you are always greeted with a smile. Mine was a Palace Side room and it was very spacious, immaculately clean and had a very large bathroom with separate shower. There was every amenity that you could wish for and the views from the large windows of the Maronouchi skyline and the square in front of the hotel were sumptuous, especially now that the building work in the square has been completed. There are many restaurants in the hotel to choose from and the room service selection is also quite wide.A very big advantage of the hotel, especially if you intend to do much travelling by rail, is its location inside the Tokyo Station building. Trains, including the shinkansen, radiate out of Tokyo in every direction from this station and the platforms are only a minute or so away. There is also a metro station just in front of the hotel, giving access to the rest of Tokyo. In addition, the fashionable Ginza shopping district is just a 10 minute walk from the hotel and the beautiful Imperial Palace Gardens even closer than that. When I am next in Tokyo I will definitely stay in this hotel.

Our first night stay in Japan after flight from London. Allowed access to room an hour before check in time. Courteous staff in this very comfortable hotel. Slightly disappointing room given the price. No bedside table on one side and little seating one the cases were open. Air conditioning fierce on your face once in bed but it needed to be as the rooms were airless otherwise. Breakfast very busy at 7.45 interesting selection of food. Very good area for food and shopping and museums too

The Tokyo Station Hotel is one of the best hotels my husband and I have ever stayed at. The rooms were beautiful, immaculate, and elegant. They were also very quiet (we slept so well!), and the showers offered great water pressure. Our room faced the dome of Tokyo Station, which offered an excellent view of the historic interior architecture of the train station. You cannot beat the location. It’s central to all of the major sites of Tokyo, which are all a short train ride away. Plus, you are within walking distance to some of the best restaurants and bars in not only Japan but the world. What truly made this hotel stand out though is the top notch concierge service. Chief Concierge Ms. Marie Antoinette Mori and her team members, Tomonori Otsuka and Miyuki Saito, were amazing to work with. All of my emails were answered promptly. In addition to arranging a Meet & Greet Service after a long international flight, they were also able to secure a dinner reservation to one of the most difficult sushi restaurants to get into, Sawada. I am forever grateful and appreciative of their kind service. They made our stay in Tokyo truly unforgettable. Arigato.

I stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel last March and April and I must say that the hotel and staff really exceeded my expectations. First of all, after I had booked my stay, the concierges of the hotel (Marie-Antoinette and Tomonori) helped me out with my restaurant reservations and my tickets for the Shinkansen. After arrival, I got welcomed by super friendly staff of the hotel and the front desk receptionist gave me an upgrade with my room. The room was suuuuuuper beautiful and clean, I had a great view (overlooking the Marunouchi cityscape) and the location of The Tokyo Station Hotel is perfect. After I came back to Tokyo from Kyoto, I decided to cancel my hotel reservation at a different hotel as I really wanted to stay at The Tokyo Station Hotel again. When I came back, they welcomed me again and recognized me as well. All by all, super service at a super beautiful hotel. Next time I will definitely stay here again.Thank you for the great time and service!!

This hotel offers high-end European inspired accommodations at a price. Owned by Japan Rail with mostly Asian customers. Quality guest rooms with high ceilings, however access to room is via very long corridors. We were surprised there was no nightly turn-down service. The Fitness center is an extra charge and is bizarre. Excellent front desk staff who provided us with direct access escort to the Narita Express at checkout.

I've been wanting to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel for quite some time and finally booked a Dome side room last trip. It is not cheap, but you do pay for the privilege of watching the world goes by right under the window - do note that there's no direct sunlight in the Dome side rooms.Concierge booked two restaurants for me as well as a visit to the Shikishima show room, very happy with their service.However I do feel the room is on the small side for that price...

This is a fantastic hotel in almost every way. This is now one of my favorite hotels world wide. The rooms are clean and comfortable, although a bit small. The bed is super comfy. There is a "handy" smartphone free to use around town with free data and calls. The shower is amazing. The breakfast is excellent - best french toast I have ever had.What really sets this place apart is the service, specifically the concierge. There is a free meet and greet service in the station if you are arriving by train, which was great the first day. They also helped me with luggage and buying tickets when I took the shinkansen.They did a great job with my restaurant reservations - Florilege, RyuGin, and Jiro.They also did a great job with directions and train times.I worked primarily with Miyuki Saito and Tomonori Otsuka. These two are absolute rockstars.I have no desire to stay anywhere else when I return to Tokyo, The likelihood that a hotel would be better or have better service is extremely slim - why take a risk?

It’s been on my radar for some time and lived up to expectations. So beautifully maintained and you won’t find a speck of dust. Oak bar for a drink for late arrivers then big breakfast in the Atrium next morning. Concierge has staff to help you find your way to the Narita and in the Japanese tradition tips are not expected.

We arrived at the hotel almost passing mid-night. However, many staff were still on duty around the lobby and we got very warm-welcome. We were a little hungry and asked them if we could have some bites around the hotel. One of them quickly informed IRD to wait for 10mins for their daily closing. All staff try to find any places that we could have something to eat that very late night. We felt very thoughtful cares from them. Especially, since I just had undergone an operation before my long flight to Japan and I didn't feel well, their kindness touched us very much.A night manager gently escorted us and explained the hotel and our room. Welcome fruits heeled my body also.We had breakfast at the restaurant and all staff were very polite and gave us refreshing atmosphere. Thanks to a chef in charge of the live cooking station. He found me lookiing for a server at the table and kindly sent me one right away. We did feel your hotel team work a lot even during our short stay,Wish to come back soon!!

Located directly inside the Tokyo central railway station. You immediately understand that you are in the upper range of 4 stars hotels with pro and helpful staff, rooms with a lot of amenities and good breakfast.

During a short stopover in Tokyo enroute to Vancouver from Australia we stayed three nights in the Tokyo Station Hotel. Beautiful old world hotel and very well situated immediately adjacent to the Tokyo Station and very convenient if you catch the Narita Express from the airport. Spacious and comfortable rooms, excellent staff and a great breakfast selection. Easy access to the station from within the hotel. Walking distance to the Ginza shopping and restaurant district. Would not hesitate to recommend to friends or stay there again when visiting Japan.

I stayed here with my wife and twin 6-year old daughters and we are all sad that we can't live here. The staff and the concierge were incredibly helpful with anything we asked of them. I could tell that they loved their jobs and were eager to help. The rooms are beautiful and have everything you would need. We got a view of the train station, which was really cool. The breakfast was one of the highlights of our day. I would highly recommend this place.
