We just arrived today, after a disappointing experience with a five star hotel in London. Tokyo Station Hotel warrants about ten stars in a head-to-head contest. It is a very attractive hotel, in the perfect Tokyo location, with beautiful, calm, spacious rooms, and the most delightful staff.We arrived at 7.30 a.m. and were told that our room was ready, which was a huge bonus. We were able to unpack, shower and breakfast, before heading out to explore Tokyo. Some hotels would try to charge half a day's room rate for the privilege.Very highly recommended.

We chose this hotel for the location. We landed in Tokyo and wanted an easy night in town. We got there, tossed the bags in the room and went down into the station to first buy our train tickets for a trip the following day, and then grab a meal in the train station, which is teaming with options. Hotel staff even walked us into the station and helped us buy our Shinkansen tickets. The location worked out great. Rooms as expected were small but lovely in decor, clean and quiet. Spent a cozy night followed by the most unbelievable hotel breakfast ever - the setting, the food choices, it was magical. Do not miss breakfast.
user_name:
Jennifer H
Upper Montclair, New Jersey

review_body: Small Luxury Hotel collection. The hotel is absolutely magnificent and if you love the historical, ancient style of buildings, this is the place you should go. Totally unique and once you entered the hotel, it feels like you actually walk through a time tunnel to the pass. The hotel corridor is very long, no housekeeping trolleys are used at the hotel (all housemaids curried a bag to service the rooms), which I've never seen any other hotels doing that. They told me that it is because they do not wish to damage the hallway wall with the trolley. Staffs are friendly and helpful. Definitely a good choice to stay in Japan.

My first experience of the hotel was when I was told by a customs person at Narita Airport not to bother to fill in the address for the hotel on the entry form as everyone knows it.The hotel has a fabulous location at Tokyo Station and is a wonderful place to stay and get your bearings when you first arrive in Japan. The hotel has been extensively refurbished with the rooms being spacious and luxurious. The bathrooms are wonderful and remembered very fondly as I travelled with my family to other parts of Japan. Breakfast is well worth including for the experience.Staff were polite and attentive.As is expected of hotel of this quality, room rates can be at the expensive end, however for our visit in January 2018 the rates were remarkably reasonable.This hotel is well worth staying at for the experience and I look forward to returning.

First thing you'll see when you arrive is a dozen staff just waiting to help you take your next step. It's pretty fancy! Very nice! Luxurious room, high ceilings and just all the glitz and glamour. Down side is that the halls are SUPER long...but I didn't mind... still 5 stars and would stay here again in a heartbeat! OH... and the breakfast is just amazing

Everything was perfect. an amazing experience.Perfect staff ,very nice restaurant and it is very very close to an important station of Tokyo. They are also great in helping you in reserving hotels, private drivers or restaurants and much more.

It is a very unique property. We stayed in standard room. Was large and well appointed.Very easy access to the airport train. Did not try the breakfast due to the very high price. Lots of food options in the neighbourhood. Easy walk to the Imperial Palace.

Thank you TSH for impeccable service. Your restaurant suggestions were wonderful and no question was too hard. The pyjamas were a very luxurious touch. You have thought of everything. The addition of the local mobile phone made us feel less foreign and able to engage with Tokyo in ways that were never possible before. This is my home away from home.

We spent 1 night here in transit.This hotel is both beautiful and extremely practical. We had a day in Tokyo before heading up to Nozawa Onsen. The hotel was great in arranging Shinkansen tickets, had the rooms ready relatively early - 10am, when we fly in at 5am and made us welcome by providing breakfast in the top floor restaurant. The just do the small things well.The rooms are modern western style, but with old style touches. The rooms are very large for Tokyo, and hence you pay for that. Bathroom was huge and had all the mod cons you expect from a 5 start property.The breakfast buffet is huge and has lost of options, both western and Japanese. The whiskey bar is cool - but note it is a smoking bar, so unfortunately we only had one drink there.On top of all of this, the location is perfect - 30-40 minutes from Haneda airport by public transport. Then right at the station for Shinkansen to other parts of Japan - the bell boys will even walk you to your train, wait for it to be ready and carry your luggage on to the train!And Tokyo station has plenty of eating options, as we as access to get to any part of Toyko.We highly recommend this property.Pros- Location- Good modern rooms, with old school charm- ServiceCons- Expensive, even for Tokyo- Bar is a smoking bar

Beautiful Hotel, reasonable sized rooms for Tokyo, staff were extremely helpful. The location of this hotel is fantastic right above Tokyo Station and a short 10 minute walk into the shopping district of Ginza.

If you can manage to stay at this hotel, please do so. It has history back from ~1910 ish (I cannot remember the exact date) My review is only for the basic king size bedroom, buffet at 4th floor, front desk/concierge and the work out room. As far as those things are concerned, I can honestly say that they do better than typical las vegas hotels. the room is very "atypical Japanese hotel room" - spacious, elegant and really expensive and quality materials. I'm 175lbs 5'9'' so if you are bigger than me, you may think otherwise. My room overlooked the tokyo station Marunouchi south gate exit. The entrance to the hotel is on the right side as you exit the ticket purchasing area. (don't go outside, it is in the same hall, on the right side. You will see the "tokyo station hotel" sign in english. You can sometimes hear the sounds from the train station but overall not bothersome. Atrium buffet (4th floor) was nice too. They have 2 different sections for the breakfast, western style and japanese style. the servers are very polite and ask for my needs time to time. They took away my used silverware and plates quickly (perhaps it was not crowded). Food was above average and probably not justified by ~$40 price tag. But everything spoke elegance and opulent. What impressed me the most is the exercise room. I have never been to a hotel with so many people working out (no wonder japanese people are healthy overall). They have top of the line equipment: O2 chamber, legit vibration plate, and 2-3 staff always attentive to your needs. Yes it does cost ~$10 but it's worth a visit if you are into exercising regularly. Overall my stay at the tokyo station was unforgettable. Staff are attentive, polite, (front desk staff need to speak loudly. Be confident in your English, you guys are good as is.) Rooms are clean and elegant. If you can afford to stay here you won't be disappointed.

Tokyo Station Hotel is a wonderful addition to hotel options in Tokyo. Beautiful old heritage building, perfect location, large rooms and very large and plush bathrooms for a Tokyo hotel. Feels a bit like old-world Japan in its discreetly luxurious feel and service, and refined clientele a little like out of the Makioka Sisters. However, our stay was slightly let down by having to wait for many services - had to wait for a table for breakfast (which once we got to it was an amazing spread in a beautiful setting), had to wait to get into the Oak Bar in the evening (which we decided not to do). A solution to the bar problem might be to keep the downstairs lounge open later at night (closes down at 10pm, and the Oak Bar is very small; if you're in there this is probably wonderful, but for such a large hotel it is a very small space). Overall, this is the almost-perfect hotel and will be my hotel of choice in Tokyo from now on.

Certainly one of the finest hotels we have ever stayed in, and we have plenty of experience globally.Our room overlooked the plaza and it was fun to see the people walking about. Obviously it’s a very convenient place to get around the city and there are many nice restaurants in the handsome office/retail buildings nearby.The ceilings are very high, furnishings perfect, maid service perfect, very large bathroom was perfect, concierge and bell service perfect, etc...

I have stayed in many, many hotels in Tokyo and so I wanted something a little different. The Tokyo Station Hotel was really excellent from the helpful duty manager Mr Kamata (an urbane, friendly and knowledgeable manager) to the large and luxurious rooms and the very convenient location.All matters were taken care of quietly and efficiently. In general discussion, we mentioned something that we had to arrange and we were pleasantly surprised to find that it was completely taken care of by the staff.The bedroom was very quiet (even though it was on the front of the building), well decorated and large with all amenities. The bed was very comfortable with a range of pillows. The bathroom was also very spacious with separate shower/ bath area, WC room and vanity area. The location is superb with easy access to trains and so we used the hotel as our Tokyo base.In all, we didn't need or want anything more. I will certainly be staying at the Tokyo Station Hotel again whenever I'm in Tokyo.

This place isn't cheap, but we decided to treat ourselves for the final two days of our honeymoon, and I'm so glad we did.We were upgraded to a suite, and everything about it was brilliant. It was also incredibly quiet - as in practically silent - despite the brilliant location in Tokyo Station. Speaking of which, it has its own entrace that saves you getting wet if it's raining - head for the Marunouchi South exit, and go through the passage near the ticket office (see pic).The Handy device (basically a free Android phone to use around Tokyo) was a nice touch too. As were all the complimentary bottles of water. I do like a freebie.Anyway, if you can afford a night or two here, then splash out; treating yourself to a bit of luxury in a convenient location is well worth it.

My husband and my 11 year old daughter stayed here for 4 nights to explore Tokyo and we couldn’t be happier with our decision. Like many of the previous reviews, I cannot emphasise how wonderful the service staff were, from Mr Otsuka the concierge , to the bell captains, all who made us feel as if we were the only guests in this grand dame of a hotel.The beds were very comfortable and the bathing area had a side by side shower and bathtub (true to Japanese style) . The room itself was very clean and felt new.Breakfast was excellent. All the food was prepared to a high standard and presented beautifully. The espresso topped it all off.This is an excellent base to explore Tokyo as it is right on top of the JR and subway stations, and is walking distance to Ginza. Loads of food options too, so even though the surrounding office buildings look quiet after office hours, their restaurants are busy at night with the after office crowd.I would definitely return.

Much has been written about this boutique hotel which grew out of the railway station, much like in many big cities. It rejuvenates a mundane travel area into a beautiful scenic playground to explore.This was my 4th visit to the hotel. Without doubt, the facilities and amenities are what you expect from luxury small hotel (LSH) group.Most importantly, it’s the convenience this place connects to all parts of Tokyo by the many lines of the subway as well as the JR lines. The Narita is also conveniently linked.The Imperial Palace gardens are a short walk away along tree line boulevards. A morning stroll is a great way to start the day. Nestled among the many high rise buildings around the Marunouchi district are many elegant cafes and restaurants. My favourite Tokyo Hotel

I have previously stayed at this hotel and was interested to see if the standard had dropped following it renovation. I'm pleased to say that it is a great as ever. I stayed for two day a couple of days ago on the third level and the room was really nice with a great view across the old foreground of the hotel. The bed was really comfortable and the shower was amazing. breakfast was on the 4th level with a great range of both east and western food. Other hotels should take a leaf out of the service that is provided here... nothing is too much and I can do nothing but recommend this hotel if you are here for work and want easy access to both the business district and Tokyo station. It is a small luxury hotel which should give you a idea of what to expect will be back.

After returning from Kyoto and having one last night in Tokyo, we were looking for a hotel that was convenient to Tokyo Station - to allow us to easily jump on the airport Narita express train early in the morning to catch an early flight. We shouldn’t have chosen such an expensive hotel but we wanted the ease of departure for a long travel home. And yes perhaps one last night of luxury seemed appealing. Well this hotel was that. Very luxurious room and hotel lobby. Upon arriving, staff immediately assisted us with our luggage, which was appreciated as our room was an epic walk across the hotel. It’s a very long hotel that is above the train station. There are other access doors in and out of the hotel so leaving and entering was not a problem.The beds (2 twins) were super comfortable and the shower (and large bathroom) were awesome. Super quiet stay even though it was above the station. Not sure that we’ll stay here again as it was a tad too expensive considering other hotel options - but it was a “treat yourself” fancy way to spend our last night.

We stayed at the Tokyo station hotel for three nights but left wishing it could have been longer. The service was phenomenal from the Narita express pickup (where the uniformed staff waited outside our coach) to the careful drop off back at the bullet train- this ranks as one of the best service experiences we have had. We stayed in the palace side luxury room and it met our needs in terms of space and impeccable cleanliness. The location is perfect right next to Tokyo station with lots of restaurant options and easily accessible transport. Would absolutely recommend this hotel!

Recommended hotel because of their staff cares about their guests. I stayed there for 5 nights last week. I provided my comments to their service at one of the restaurants two days before my check-out date. Impressively the director of rooms showed up to my room shortly and acknowledged my feedback. Then they did make things right. The speed and quality of service recovery are beyond expectation. Their staff is the secret ingredient makes me stay with this hotel whenever I am in Tokyo in the past 3 years.

It is an excellent and fun hotel with many reasons. The building and the room are classy. Service is great. Location is good; it's convenient especially to go outside of Tokyo. Even though it's an European style hotel, I was able to feel "Japan" here and there, which was fantastic.Food was AMAZING. Breakfast buffet is at the beautiful atrium where only hotel guests have access. There were so many kinds of delicious food, including a variety of Japanese food. (I felt SO at home!) We’ve also tried a couple of restaurants inside the hotel: Blanc Rouge (French) and “en” (Cantonese). They were absolutely incredible. I’m already dreaming of going back there. I would avoid Cafe Camellia for snack though because sandwich was tasteless and tea was unbelievably small.What didn’t work for us was that the room we stayed, which was Dorm Side Comfort King, had too limited storage. We were with 2 big suitcases, 1 carry-on and 1 computer bag. Other 4 and 5 star hotels in great locations in Tokyo we stayed had much bigger storage at similar price range. If you travel light, that might not be an issue though.

Prices are lower than 4 Seaons or other upper 5 Star properties, and for what you pay it is excellent. Don’t expect perhaps the ‘super best’, it isn’t priced in that stratosphere, but it is a very good option. Rooms are spotlessly clean, the shower and bath is awesome. We stayed in two ‘Dome rooms’ with very high ceilings and excellent finishes. I stayed here with my wife and 2 kids on a holiday and it is a great, centrally located option in Tokyo. Very easy for moving around if you are touring, because of its immediate proximity with the station. Would consider staying here again. H.

Yours are perfect and bigger versus all other hotels in Tokyo. Beds are very comfortable and wide. Breakfast buffet style as in most top hotels large choice of international food. The hotel has a beautiful designed Spa; disappointing massage rooms as overheated . Also very disappointed on the massage it self. Not very professional as in Hyatt, Peninsula or Okura Hotel. I would go back to TSH for its location and big rooms but not for the spa.

One of the highlights of my trip to Toyko was staying at The Tokyo Station Hotel. The staff, the rooms, and service is just flawless. Marie Antonette and Tomonori san at the concierge desk could not be more helpful and patient. As a first time visitor to Tokyo, they made our visit so much easier to get around. They were delightful. It's a great location and the staff really makes you feel welcome and at home. They even escorted us to the train platform when leaving for Narita airport. There are plenty of restaurants in the immediate area within walking distance and lots of great shopping. The staff at the restaurant on the 4th floor makes breakfast such a special experience. Such nice sweet people. We cannot wait to return once again.

This is a fabulous hotel from not only a location perspective but the comfort of the rooms, exceedingly friendly staff and services available. It is worth the dollars if your budget allows. We had a wonderful stay and were even escorted to the bullet train (luckily as we were sure to get lost - again, at Tokyo Station). A fantastic introduction to Japan.

I had the pleasure of staying at The Tokyo Station Hotel for a few days and while I'm usually not a big "reviewer", I couldn't miss the opportunity to share how great it was. From Mr. Tomonori Otsuka, the concierge to Namiko, the beautiful lady at the front desk, everyone was so over the top helpful. They just seemed so eager to make us happy. The respect and kindness of Japan as a whole made me fall in love but to start our adventure at TSH was ideal! Location was great too! It kept us central to everything and it was a breeze to get to and from the airport ... no taxis needed. The staff at TSH even walked us to our train platform!The room was a vacation in and of itself. The bed was heavenly, pillows were perfect, and the pajamas in the drawer ... OMG. If I was able to somehow get 100 pair, i would! I cannot wait for a trip back (which is no easy task from NYC) but they truly made it home away from home!

My wife and I stayed here on our final night in Japan after a week or thereabouts in Tokyo and then Kyoto - we wish we'd stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel earlier and for longer!The staff were amazing, the location perfect for getting around town and the renovations to the place were beautiful. Breakfast was great, a beautiful room in the Atrium of the station with a great selection of western and Japanese options.We had an evening snack and a cocktail or few in the bar/lounge Camellia which was really reasonably priced considering what you'd pay in similar places in Sydney and there were some delicious options (both food and cocktails). To wrap things up we had some lovely tea and cakes in The Lobby Lounge before finally heading to the airport and home. Perhaps the upgrade to the Ambassador's suite helped but honestly, this was a great way to end our holiday and next time we're in Japan we'll absolutely be staying here!

It was our 1st time in Japan and staying at this beautifully renovated and perfectly situated hotel was a key to a wonderful 4 day stay in Tokyo. From the moment of our arrival being met at the Nartita express train stop just under the hotel and having help with our bags to collapsing on the most comfortable beds following the direct 14 hour flight and then freshening up in the luxurious bathroom we quickly were revitalized. The hotel staff helped secure reservations prior to our arrival and were just waiting up be of assistance. Breakfast in the atrium was a 4⭐️ experience with both Japanese and western options. Most important excellent coffee. Thank you for a great stay.

What a fantastic place! The staff is the best ever! Very friendly, polite and proactive! I had a chance to meet the Director of sales Atsushi who gave me a tour of the property. The hotel is very well managed and the building well taking care of ... expensive but worth it!!

Stayed at the Tokyo Station hotel for 3 days. Perfecty renovated a few years ago. Nice comfortable rooms and although at the station, no outside noise in the rooms. Breakfast is very nice in the atrium at the 4th floor. One of the other highlights is the Oak bar, a small bar with only 12 places. Loods like you are in the 50's. Bartender is a nice old man (85?), who is mixing good cocktails of serves good whiskies. Smoking allowed. Didn't try the restaurants.

We loved staying at The Tokyo Station Hotel. It is in the midst of all the hustle and bustle, but somehow manages to create quiet corners filled with bits of nostalgia, including harp music in the Lobby Lounge and wonderful floral displays. Breakfast in the Atrium was a treat with both Japanese and Western selections. I filled my plate with Japanese pickles and sashimi, but I snagged a croissant, fabulous fruit jams, and a cappuccino as well. Guests can have their eggs any which way, and select from a variety of cured European meats. Fruits, yogurt-- it is all in the Atrium. For dinner, we went into the main station and ate at Ramen Corner. Our room couldn't have been more pleasant, and when it was time to check out, we just rolled our luggage to the train bound for Narita airport. Just a quick note: Smoking is allowed in the classic, wood paneled Oak Bar, but not in the other restaurants.

I stayed at this hotel as a special treat after a week in Japan. The staff was friendly and gracious. The room was wonderfully comfortable. And the food in the bar and at breakfast was wonderful. I cannot find anything to complain about except not staying longer. My room overlooked the plaza facing the Imperial Palace. The location is convenient for a lot of things to do in central Tokyo and it is very convenient for the train to Narita. The hotel is also in a restored historic building with an interesting history.

Arrived at Tokyo Station Hotel after a 10 hour flight and one hour train trip to a sanctuary. As it is our first time in Tokyo we are bowled over by the cleanliness and efficiency. We have upgraded to a larger room and the amenities are first class. I could not fault the Tokyo Station Hotel and its location between the Imperial Palace and Ginza District is perfect for walking this great city. It’s walking distance to the Tsukiji Fish Market which even if you miss the auction (too early for us) is a ‘not to be missed’ spot. Ms Mori at the Concierge Desk is a star. Great recommendations on shopping and restaurants. If you want a high quality fantastically well located hotel that is beautiful inside and out the stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel.

I stay there with my wife for our wedding anniversary. We are so appreciated the staff who help take our luggage to the room actively suggest take a photo for us when he knows that we stay there for our celebration.Although our room is located near the road, but it is so surprise that the room is so quiet as double windows are being used. Moreover, the bed are so good that we have a sweet dream.The guest must try their breakfast buffet at the Atrium which is located at the 4/f floor as you will see the old structure of the building.The only point I think the hotel can be the best of the best is the hair dryer is not powerful enough and the glass for tooth brushing may consider changing to a better quality one.

Conveniently located next to Tokyo Station, the hotel provides excellent connections to a variety of subway lines, Narita Express and Shinkansen.The service and reception are of the highest class and you are immediately welcome as a guest.The rooms are large and maintain high standards. An additional plus for the mobile handy solution that the hotel offers its guests."Handy" will be your best friend during your stay. It offers free GPS with, for example, Google Maps as well as calls.The breakfast offers something for everyone, ranging from eggs and bacon, sashimi, waffles with serranoskink and egg benedict.

We travelled as a family with 2 young kids (3 years old and 5 years old). We choose this hotel because of the location and the good reviews we read online. When we landed at Narita, we bought the NEX tickets and dropped the conceirge an email with our expected time we will reach Tokyo Station. They send someone over to pick us up the moment we stepped out of the train car. *Claps*Tokyo train station is huge, and with someone to help us and guide us, we already feel good staying in this hotel. The week we were at Tokyo was a rainy week. Luckily it was a sheltered underground walk so we are good. The rooms are clean, and it has a very high ceiling, making us feel there is space, even though in theory the room isn’t considered big. Our room face the main entrance of the tokyo station and we can see many people walking outside or taking pictures in front of the station. Lots of dining options within the station premises. There are also shopping. We spend 2 days within tokyo station (our Daughter was sick so we cancelled our original itinerary) and we haven’t fully explored this area!The hotel staff also helped us to make reservations at Bills Ginza. Awesome service!

The Tokyo Station Hotel has to one of the most beautiful hotels we have stayed in. Our room overlooking the square was enormous and the huge rain shower and deep spa bath were a treat after a day's sightseeing. The king size bed made for a lovely night's sleep. The staff were attentive and very helpful and the location above the station was perfect.

The hotel offers a meet & greet from the Narita Express station. So the moment we stepped of the train we experienced the amazing service of the Tokyo station hotel. The hotel is located in the historic Tokyo Station building which was renovated very nicely. The location is beyond convenient, as you are literally connected to the main train station in Tokyo. I highly recommend trying the Japanese Breakfast, which is only available to hotel guests. It is expensive though, and unfortunately served buffet style, but the quality was excellent. Our queen bedroom was small, but I believe this is normal for hotels in Tokyo. The bathrooms and shower/bath are very nice. Overall, we had a very nice stay and would love to go back next time we are in Tokyo.

I travel to Tokyo frequently, specifically to eat. Since I don't speak much Japanese and I live overseas, I rely on hotel concierge services to make bookings on my behalf. Having stayed at quite a few luxury hotels in Tokyo (including two stays so far at the Tokyo Station Hotel) I can say with certitude that the concierge service at the Tokyo Station Hotel is by far the best I've had the pleasure to deal with. Head concierge Ms. Mori and concierge Mr. Otsuka are simply amazing. They are extremely friendly, professional, and efficient. They've managed to book many difficult restaurant reservations on my behalf. The hotel itself is very nice, with comfortable rooms and lovely bathrooms. The location is pretty convenient for me, with fairly easy access to Ginza, Shinbashi, and Nihonbashi (where many of my favorite restaurants are located). The service, however, is what takes makes this property truly special. The service (again, especially from the concierge team) is simply the best I've experienced anywhere. They take omotenashi to the next level!A huge "Thank you!" to Ms. Mori, Mr. Otsuka, and to the entire staff for the wonderful hospitality you offer.

The Tokyo Station Hotel re-opened in 2012 after six years of renovations. That alone ought to entice you there. Our room was gorgeous, beautifully renovated to the glory days of the hotel, overlooking a cupola inside Tokyo Station. It was dead-quiet. The room was luxurious with a very comfortable bed. The bathroom was first-class with a rain shower head and a great bath that my wife availed herself of a few times. The standard high-tech toilet in Japan was one-upped by this toilet with a heated seat that raised the lid automatically and flushed and closed the lid automatically. The amenities were first-class with hairbrushes, toothbrushes and toothpaste, shavers and shaving lotion, to mention a few. Breakfast at this hotel was world-class. The European style buffet included lovely croissants and other baked goods. For North Americans, waffles and eggs and bacon were available along with fresh yogurts, cereals, fruits and the like. Of course, there was an extensive Japanese selection and even a Chinese breakfast. Coffee was top quality. It was as nice a breakfast buffet as we have seen anywhere in our travels to top quality hotels.The service was incredible. The concierge, Tomonori Otsuka, made restaurant reservations for us while we were still in Canada and his suggestions were outstanding. He provided walking maps, running suggestions and subway and train guidance. His oral and written English skill are excellent. When it came time to check out, he sent a porter to take us and our luggage directly to the train platform. Now that's service!Now on the location - surely it must be the best in Tokyo. One is right in the heart of the financial district. It's an easy walk to Ginza or to the Imperial Palace. We took the train from the airport at Narita and it essentially stops at the hotel. It doesn't get any better than that. Without even having to go outside, the entire JR Rail network is available as well as Tokyo's incredible subway system (which is easy to use, ultra-clean and safe). We highly recommend this excellent hotel if you are staying in Tokyo. Top quality on all fronts and amazing service. Thank you, Otsuka-San!

Stayed one night here on the way back to the airport after a fortnight in Japan. Really convenient location in a very nice part of Tokyo. The hotel was luxurious with very spacious rooms and a high quality feel. The staff were incredibly polite and spoke perfect English, were able to help us book a meal in the evening at short notice. The room rates are not cheap, but it made for a really special end to an amazing holiday.

Don't miss this gorgeous hotel, with the perfect location and best ever customer service. The hotel is located in a beautifully restored landmark building above one of Tokyo's busiest train/subway stations. However, it's so quiet you'd never know trains were anywhere near. You can take the Narita express bullet train from the airport (much faster than taxis in traffic clogged Tokyo) directly to Tokyo station and the hotel's amazing Meet & Greet Team will meet you at door of your train to take you and your bags to the hotel's check-in counter. They will do the same when you leave. You can get anywhere in Tokyo from the train/subway station below. Glamorous Ginza with Tokyo's most elegant shopping district, glorious restaurants and the Kabuki theater is just a 10-15 minute walk from the hotel. The lovely hotel rooms were tastefully decorated with heavenly bathrooms and fresh pressed pajamas supplied daily. I rarely eat breakfast in my hotels, but Tokyo Station's is not to be missed with oodles of delectable Japanese and Western treats. I am always skeptical about using concierges, but Head Concierge Marie Mori and Concierge Tomonori Otsuka treated us as though we were privileged guests in their homes. I can't say enough about their professionalism, attentive service and concern for our well being. I started emailing the concierge desk a couple months before my arrival and their prompt helpful responses made the difference in our trip. One night when our taxi couldn't find our restaurant and dropped us off on the sidewalk, Marie called the restaurant to make sure we would find the door and confirmed that we had safely arrived. No request was too big or small.....they made it happen. The entire hotel staff were also gracious and helpful.Be sure to make it to one of the depachikas, the sophisticated, yummy food halls in the basements of Tokyo's famous, high-end department stores. Scores of offerings of chocolates, pastries, ice cream, salads, japanese delicacies, wine & sake and just about anything else you'd want to eat are on display. My Favorite is at Ginza 6, Tokyo's newest, fancy department store that just opened this year. Another great shop within Ginza 6 is the Cibone store showcasing mostly Japanese made housewares that you can't live without. I had so many great meals in Tokyo, but the can't miss is Michelin one star Motoyoshi. Reserve early to get one of the eight seats in this tiny restaurant and savor one of the omakase Tempura menus cooked in front of you!Book your trip to Tokyo now and don't even consider staying anywhere else!

This hotel was chosen because of location at first. We were hoping on the train many times and it was great being right there. The lovely surprise was the hotel was exquisite with everything one could dream of !!! You are cared for in every way possible !! Arigato Gozimas

I wanted to take the time to write a note commending the staff as much as I possibly could. First and foremost everyone at the hotel was wonderful with helping us prior to our arrival. That said one person in particular had gone truly above and beyond what I have seen or consider 5 star service.The person I speak of is Ms. Marie Antoinette Mori, the Chief Concierge.I would consider myself very well traveled, as with over 30 years and 150+ countries visited while staying in 4 or 5 star hotels (where applicable), I know a thing or two about good service versus exceptional service. In my travels to Tokyo I have stayed at The Park Hyatt, The Mandarin and the Aman. I can say with complete certainty that although I felt very taken care of in these establishments, never once did I receive the type of personal attention I did from Ms. Mori and her team in the Hotel. She without question went above and beyond for us in so many ways with regard to reservations, advice and guidance on how to proceed with our booking. I really can not fathom how much effort she dedicated to our requests for when I was at the other hotels I mentioned, it could not be helped that we always felt like we would be taken care of when they could get to us. At the Tokyo Station Hotel we always knew we would be taken care of and Ms. Mori, Tomo and team were the reason for this. Not once did we ever feel like we were part of a que or that we would be gotten to "in due time". Her updates and follow through were consistently amazing. So again I state the obvious in that she is by far the best concierge I have ever had the privilege of working with during my travels. I truly hope the hotel recognizes the superior value that she brings. I would also add that if anything Ms. Mori is the standard by all staff/team members of hotels should be compared to. In summary we were lucky we chose the Tokyo Station Hotel, them having such a wonderful team member under their watch and we truly are looking forward to staying again soon.

We had a great stay for our honeymoon here. The room was perfect and comfortable. The hotel was very clean and accommodating. The hotel was inside the Tokyo Station so it was super easy to get around Tokyo and around Japan by train. The staff was helpful with regards to sending a post card for us and exchanging money. The breakfast buffet was huge and had both western and Japanese breakfast items. It was also super quiet. We kept commenting that we couldn't even hear people coming/going from their room. We felt like we were the only ones sleeping there. Definitely did not hear any trains so no worries there. I would definitely stay here again.

I highly recommend stay in this hotel. Staff is brilliant and they help with anything you need. The room we had stayed in was also very clean and modern which certainly was a plus, an all round excellent from myself but it was the level of customer service that won the high five from us

Beautiful property and exceptional staff. Mr. Takeshi Hirano,Chief Receptionist-Rooms Division, THE TOKYO STATION HOTEL took excellent care of us when we were concerned about construction outside/nearby our hotel room. Could not have asked for a nicer place to stay or to be treated any better. The height of professionalism, charm, class and grandeur. And great location. We loved our time there and will never forget it.

My husband and I took our first trip to Tokyo in August 2017 and we loved the Tokyo Station Hotel... both for the comfortable rooms that provided a very welcome respite from our incredible days of walking, but also for the remarkable customer service. We had a 24-hour travel day coming from Cleveland, Ohio. When had looked into taking a private car from Narita to the hotel because of the length of our travels, but it was cost prohibitive and we opted instead for the train. We knew that the hotel was located at/near the train station, but after a really long travel day, we were absolutely thrilled to see an actual internal door from the train station into the lobby of the hotel. We had arrived! High fives everywhere! As in many hotels, hostesses guide you to your room when you arrive. The hallways are the longest hallways I have seen in my entire life! It makes sense when you see the hotel as it is a very long building. Our room had a view out to the front plaza. Once we figured out the elevators and small lobbies that are midway through the building allow you access both as an entrance and exit to the hotel, it made the walk easier. We ordered room service one night and it was prompt and delicious. The rooms (at least ours) is small, but it is very well appointed. It was a little tricky trying to figure out where to put two large suitcases, and we did have to move one of them around both in the morning and again in the evening. I would prefer to eliminate the desk to make room for another suitcase. The bathroom is really big, and I was very excited about the shower. It was large, and had a multiple different types of shower heads (I liked the rainfall version from the ceiling), and it was one of the best bathrooms I have ever had at a hotel. So, that made up for the size of the room in my book. With all that being said, the highlight of the hotel was the customer service, and we are still talking about it. Most specifically, I had visited Mr. Tomonori Otsuka at the concierge desk with two questions. One... I wanted to go to a hibachi restaurant. He set us up with reservations of our choosing at a restaurant in the Ginza district for that evening. Secondly, and most impressive, Mr. Otsuka had emailed me with a confirmation about our dinner reservation, which meant that I had his email address. The next day, my husband and I were touring Tokyo and we had questions about something unrelated to that dinner reservation. We had purchased baseball tickets to see the Tokyo Yukalt Swallows baseball team, and were concerned about the rain, the refund policy and whether or not the game would be played. I wrote him a note to ask one simple question. That turned into him sending me updates throughout the day about the status of the game. Luckily, the game was played (yay!), but the experience was made so much better by knowing that someone was thinking about us, and making sure we had the most updated information. Top notch hotel... recommend it highly!

Lovely restored building,in an excellent location . Rooms are very well presented and very quiet- no noise to be heard which was great relief after a long flight. There is a good choice of places to eat both within the hotel and within the immediate local area ( all walkable - 5 minutes) . The hotel staff were amazing: polite, friendly, thoughtful, helpful: nothing was too much trouble. We felt they wanted you to have a great stay and made sure you received it. This is a wonderful hotel.

This is probably one of the best hotel I have visit around the world. I stayed here only for one night, but I wish I had stayed for more. The rooms are impeccable. I stayed in a normal double room and it was more than sufficient. Maybe, a bit on the smalll side though, but hotel rooms in Tokyo are rather small if you compare to other cities. Everything is neat and tidy and the bathroom is one of the best I have ever come along, perfect !. The breakfast area is really good and the variety is humongous. You will get everything you can imagine and if you can't find something that you like, they can probably get it for you. Just ask them. This is also one off the things that this hotel do so much better than other hotels- SERVICE. If you have a request or a problem with something- they fix it. I had a problem with a delivery of a portable router that I had ordered a few weeks ahead. So I talked to the concierge and she immediately rang the delivery company. 45 minutes later I had my package delivered to my room. This is what I call efficiency. The only thing I maybe have something to complain about is. If you get a room in the far end off the hotel, you will spend some time walking to and back from the lobby. Endless corridores!. I would highly recommend this hotel for anyone who appreciate tranquil sleep, perfekt service and super breakfast. It unfortunately comes with a rather hefty price though - it's not cheap to stay here.

This was a real surprise. Booked primarily for location and convenience (we were catching a Shinkansen the following morning) we were not expecting the Tokyo Station Hotel to be as nice as it was. SLH hotels rarely disappoint to be fair but in a city of countless iconic, uber sleek and luxurious high rises, can a 3 story property attached a train station really cut it? In a word, yes.It is certainly luxurious and our duplex room (we were upgraded as SLH members) was probably bigger than most Tokyo apartments. Everything that could be (including curtains and blinds) was electric as you would expect and we had a month's supply of Bulgari toiletries in the gorgeous bathroom but the room (and whole hotel) manages to exude genuine old world charm thanks to the meticulous restoration of the original building. It is this effortless combination of old and modern that gives the Tokyo Station Hotel a fairly unique charm. The location is fantastic too. Not just for the station itself but Ginza with its wealth of eating and shopping options and the Imperial Palace all within a comfortable stroll. We've stayed at the Mandarin Oriental, Peninsula and Park Hyatt in Tokyo on previous trips to Tokyo and surprisingly, this gives them all a run for their money in many ways. If anything lets it down it's probably the bars, neither of which are places you'd probably want to spend too much time in (compared to the eye-popping, cloud-touching effort at the Mandarin Oriental for example) but with Ginza on your doorstep you are not short of alternatives that are kinder on your wallet too. Highly recommended.

Simply the best hotel in Tokyo. Stayed 4 nights in a palace side room in June. Impeccable service. Outstanding bar venues (Bar Oak & Camellia). So convenient. You are steps away from a train to anywhere in Japan. Be sure to have breakfast in the Atrium Room. They serve an excellent blend of east & west cuisines. The entire property really nails a perfect blend of both cultures. It's awesome!

Our family of 4 including a toddler and a baby stayed in this hotel for 5 nights in June 2017. Given our many luggages and the children stroller, the location of this hotel could not have been more convenient and suited to our needs. The hotel was even kind enough to send their concierge staff to help carry the luggages from the train platform. We used this hotel as a base to visit Disneyland for 4 days & the train journey only takes 10 minutes. Efficient and convenient.

Spent 2 nights took a train to Kyoto for a couple of days and returned for a 3 night stay. We consider this one of the best hotel stays ever. We were treated by every one from bell hops to reception and concierge as if we booked the most expensive room in the hotel which was far from reality. We have never experienced such professionalism and politeness . Held luggage while we went to Kyoto, escorted us to bullet train platform and made all arrangements for a taxi to Yokohama for our cruise. Rooms were of good size beds were very comfortable and a bathroom to die for. WiFI was strong with no interruptions. You could not ask for a better location for transportation and restaurants. If we ever return to Tokyo this is the only hotel we would stay at.

We stayed at the hotel in a Dome Room and felt terribly suffocated with the smallness of the room and cramped experience.In our next visit, we stayed in a Palace facing Superior Twin room and oh! what a pleasant change this room was.Large room, well appointed, and with all the comforts and luxury that a first class hotel has.And being inside Tokyo Station itself means so much less hassle while catching trains and shinkansens.

It is a luxury hotel by all means: high quality service, staff, rooms and all utilities. It is a bit expensive of course, it is Tokyo; but you get what you paid for. It is very central ( i can't think any hotel more central than this); and this is a big plus in a city like Tokyo.In short, staying in the Tokyo Station hotel was very satisfactory by all means; definetely recommend.

This is a beautiful, convenient hotel. It was very nice flying into Narita, taking the airport express, and arriving directly at the station, where it was an easy walk to get to the hotel.It is easy to take trains to other parts of Tokyo from here, and to get to the Shinkansen track for when it is time to depart.The service and amenities here were top notch, and it was a very comfortably sized room compared to others I've stayed at in Tokyo.
user_name:
Jake L
New York City, New York

review_body: The building is a refurbished part of the Main Tokyo Station building. The rooms are reasonable sizes with high ceilings. We had a room at the front overlooking the entrance courtyard area,however still found it peaceful & quite. The beds are comfortable and staff very attentive. Good service and of course no tipping! The food areas within the hotel are always in demand and bookings are required, unless you are happy to queue and wait. If you can get a spot in the lobby lounge, its worth a visit relaxing with a coffee or bubbly. It does get busy with a lot of local business people.However, we quickly found out that lots of eating places exist in the station basement area and within 5 min walk of the hotel, which are very reasonable priced compared to the hotel prices. We did our sight seeing via the train system, which is very easy to use. The location of the hotel was perfect for this because all the rail lines go through Tokyo central, so its easy to get back to the hotel. Best option is to buy a rail pass, which you can top up as required. You can buy these right next to the Hotel.A lovely buffet breakfast is available in the hotel, but has strict closing times, don't sleep in. It was about AUS$50 a head, worth doing at least once. However, if you walk across the road to the shopping tower, it has cafe's that will cost you $15 for coffee and brekkie. In summary, if this is you first visit to Tokyo, and you plan to do some sight seeing within the city and country area, this is a great central location providing you are ok using the train system (which is excellent). Make sure you catch a bullet train to further locations, which are possible as a day trip.

On my friend;s recommendation, we stayed for 5 nights in August in a king, palace side room. Absolutely no construction noise for us - though I could see if you had a room closer to the work, it may be noisy. Our room was 3078.From check-in to check out - everything was fabulous. Check in was quick, friendly, professional. The room is gorgeous, large by tokyo standards and the bathroom luxurious. I loved how they combined western style with japanese style in the shower/tub.The concierge staff is amazing! Planning meals, tours and even giving down to the minute train recommendations for us. The hotel staff even supplied our tour company with umbrellas and water for our day out to Mt. Fuji! Amazing.Be sure to check out the dome views, the history behind the hotel is amazing and part of it's charm.The location, location, location in Tokyo station is phenomenal. If you're traveling by train/subway in Tokyo (& I recommend you do) then this is certainly the hotel for you. It's combination of luxury, amazing service and convenience can't be beat.

Staff and location are standouts. Concierge (Marie Antoinette, Tomonori Otsuka) was faultless as well as front staff and room service staff, especially bell hopper. Communication pre-arrival was prompt and I was able to arrange access to Spa Tokione after an early morning flight arrival as well as store luggage before check-in. Posting a parcel was taken care of smoothly.Room is perfect for solo traveller. Plenty of amenities, superb hardware and excellent sound proofing. Breakfast had some standout dishes (soy pudding, konjac in yuzu dressing) as well as different organic juices. Attentive service from wait staff.Above all, the fact that it is a hotel located in a station gives it a leading edge over other hotels. The station is connected to surrounding buildings underground meaning adverse weather (July heat) can be avoided. Friendly staff will walk you to the platform. Due to the hotel being located within a long station it means quite a bit of walking but this just means some exercise. For the traveller seeking ease of access to their next destination the historic Tokyo Station Hotel stands above the rest.

We stayed in two rooms, both with double beds, for one night. What an amazing stay! Yes, the rooms are on the smaller side (though high ceilings!), but it is expected because, well, it's Tokyo (if you need a larger hotel room, perhaps you should go to a city that has a population of less than 36 million. And lots of land). The decor and ambiance of the rooms were exactly as seen in the photos: luxurious! And our rooms were at the front of the hotel, so we were able to watch other tourists enjoy the history and grandeur of the hotel! If you need a spa day, but don't have the time to have one (hey, you're in Tokyo after all!), you can have a makeshift one in the comfort of your room's bathroom! Wash away the day with the overhead rain shower and enjoy the ambient lighting in the tub to relax (the light switch was right by the tub - no need to get out. Perfect!)Breakfast in the beautiful Atrium was a great way to start our day with lots of delicious choices! Staff at both check-in and check-out, as well as at breakfast, were all very courteous, helpful, and exceptionally professional. Thank you all for an unforgettable stay!

A beautiful hotel with a lovely spa. I booked two treatments which were among the best I've had! The buffet breakfast although pricey is amazing and delicious. My first experience at Japanese buffet breakfasts and I was not disappointed. It's worth it just for the experience alone and the food and coffee was really good! The staff were friendly and helpful. Good options re room service if tired from traveling and want to eat in. Would stay again!

This 4 story hotel is newly renovated. Rooms are big and clean. Staffs are friendly although not every staff can speak English. It is situated on top of Tokyo station. However, there is a small inconvenience when it is raining. There is no access directly from the station if you are not taking the train.There is only one exit from the station that you have sheltered access. If you are coming through Yaesu side, you have to walk through the walkway in the station, and cross the open air courtyard before getting to the main lobby. Price wise, this is a little expensive, but for the size of the rooms in Tokyo, you are paying for what you get. Fair enough.

We stayed at Tokyo station Hotel this past week. The service was excellent . Their house keeping has a standard that they meet everyday of your visit . They replenish the amenities on daily basis . The staff is very humble and quick in responding . It was surprising that though it was a small hotel but they provide most of the luxuries you expect . Their location is a bonus anyways . They even gave us escort to Narita express :)

This is a boutique hotel & it occupies upper levels of the historical Tokyo Main Railway station. As a result, the rooms are rather small in Western Standard but its proximity is superb with Subway & Shinkansen right at the door step, not to mention there are endless choice of nearby eateries & restaurants within the Train Stations. Moreover, Tokyo Bus/Coach Terminal is just opposite building housed with Daimaru. The hotel has a very popular High Tea lounge on the ground floor with live Harp music, & it has a stunning Glass roofed breakfast restaurant on its topfloor. The interior is meticulously refurnished to the original state, & there are small galleries in the corridor way to show you all the old pix of the Station. Rooms are well equipped with the modern day apparatus. Service is first class & all the porters are female.

This hotel got our attention right from the very first time me and wife looked for a hotel at Tokyo. And our decisions were absolutely right. The pleasant impressions just right from the start we arrived at the hotel. The exterior is beautiful (especially at night, very romantic), the front desk was very helpful and so polite. The whole lobby teams are amazingly friendly. The lounge, the hall and the room are amazingly beautiful and super comfy and the privacy is excellent. You don't even have to ask me about the foods, they are extremely delectable. You can even arrange your own Japanese breakfast (well at least it's my first experience to have my own selections). The manager at breakfast was very helpful, he passionately tried to explain how i can explore this historic hotel's building as mentioned by the front desk guy when we're check-in as well. I can tell, their services are second to none, one of the best for me. At last but not least is the location and access. You don't have to come out of the hotel building to get into the Tokyo station, you get your own access as they're technically in the same building. Final word, yes, absolutely one of my best hotel experience and can't wait to get back again, hopefully the soonest.

Just email the train ticket to the concierge and you can be escorted to the hotel right when you get off the train. The service is extremely useful for a tourist like me who is not familiar with the place. The service staff is so courteous, professional and polite. It is really a superb service.

We stayed 3 nights as an add-on to a business trip and enjoyed the hotel very much. It is in the financial district, which in and of itself is not very exciting, but by being above a main transit hub it is close to and easy to get around to a lot of places around the city. The hotel has a bunch of upscale restaurants and a helpful concierge. It is a bit labyrinthine but there are directional signage and maps. Our room was a "palace side superior twin" - it was lovely, clean, well-appointed & quiet. They have room service and I can't remember if there was a mini bar. The breakfast was great, huge selection of Japanese and Western foods. I would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
Schuyler F
New York City, New York

review_body: Right in the station at the south entrance. The room was small but the location can't be beaten. Right on the imperial palace. Perfect for the train from Narita and for the train to Kyoto. Walking distance to Ginza

We were lucky enough to spend a whole week in this elegant hotel. I booked the Tokyo Station Hotel primarily for it's location above the Tokyo Station which proved ideal for getting around. However the beauty and service of this hotel was an absolute bonus. Highly recommended!

I was travelling on my own so the fact that the room was smallish didn't bother me but a Dome room would probably be a bit cramped for a couple. Although the room was small it was very comfortable and well appointed. The hotel is in a great position as part of the Tokyo station. It is only 3 floors high so there can be a long walk down very long corridors to reach your room. I ate breakfast at the hotel once and it was very good. I wouldn't suggest that you have breakfast included as another morning when I tried to go to breakfast I was told that there was await of over 30 minutes. I simply went somewhere else but it would have been very annoying is I had already paid for it as part of my rate.

Upstairs hidden away is a wonderful bar that serves drinks and food. It is quite popular with reservations for bar seating so we felt quite lucky to obtain a seat for drinks and appetizers while waiting for friends to arrive via train. I would highly recommend this wonderful find and look forward to returning next time I am in Japan.

Our first time in Tokyo and our first time at this property and we really enjoyed it. I am a big fan of SLH properties and this was no exception. Small but VERY beautifully done hotel. Comfortable beds, very quiet rooms, gorgeous bathrooms with rain shower heads and fully automated toilets (as seems customary in Japan).Breakfast is amazing with a large number of ulta high quality Japanese and Western food choices/options. Coffee and tea were excellent and service was good. Minor issue being that the coffee is not proactively refilled quickly enough, so we had to ask for coffee and/or tea over and over which made us feel bothersome. Some of the staff also do not have great command of English, so communication could be choppy at times, although I thought this added to the overall feel of the place.Lastly, as far as location goes, this hotel is in PERFECT location especially if you take the Narita Express to get to downtown Tokyo. The NEX will stop right underneath the hotel, so even with luggage, it was easy enough to get to the hotel with minimal hassle. The hotel also offers a free "greet" service at the platform where an employee will meet you at the patform and help you with your bags. That is a service I did not utilize but wish I had.To take the subway, other statons are frequently more convenient to avoid having to change trains, but all of them are within 5 minutes walk, so still incredibly convenient.Overall, I could not have been happier with our stay and will return to stay here next time I am in Tokyo.

We stayed here one night on our last day in Tokyo. The rooms are very elegant with large bathrooms. We stayed in a room on the Palace Side. The hotel has some nice restaurants and bars associated with it including the fabulous Bar Oak. The hotel is part of the Tokyo Station so it is centrally located and very convenient to catch trains, including the Narita Express. The corridors are long so if you are travelling with family and have more than one room, make sure you request that they be close by.

We have stayed at Tokyo Station Hotel three times in the last year. This is a wonderful hotel -- location, history, design, luxurious bathrooms and more. We love the proximity to great food, Ginza shopping and Palace hikes. And best of all is the knowledgable and gracious staff. When you arrive at the hotel from the airport on the Narita Express, a staff member will meet you at your rail car and escort you through the maze of Tokyo Station. On our most recent trip (ending today) there were severe storms that disrupted the Shinkansen schedule. The staff stayed with us, researched the schedule changes, helped us purchase a replacement ticket, and got us on the right train to Nagoya -- not an easy or quick trick. We will be back!

Great location, very close to the main train station, with lots of good restaurants around. Excellent organization, clean an tidy rooms, beautiful installations. The staff was very kind and considerate, and the concierge service was very efficient. They managed to get us last minute reservations for a very good sushi restaurant. Also, I forgot my mobile phone on the train, and flew home the day after. They went to the train station, found my phone and sent it to me by mail. It was the best hotel experience of our whole trip!

One of the great heritage hotels, belonging in the same class as the Fullerton in Singapore and the Peninsular in Hong Kong. The Tokyo Station Hotel offered us an opportunity to stay in of the most iconic train stations in Asia. One word to describe our experience? Exceptional. The decor, with its long corridors and beautiful wall lamps, was truly splendid. The service was second to none, with the hotel concierge helping to organise unforgettable experiences and meals at the best Michelin starred restaurants in Tokyo. We highly recommend the hotel to anyone looking for a luxurious yet convenient stay in Tokyo.

We kicked off our 10 year anniversary Japan food tour with 3 nights at the Tokyo station hotel. The hotel was quiet, the room spacious and comfortable, but the service here was impeccable.This hotel was the best representation of Japanese hospitality. The staff throughout the stay just did everything to make us feel so special and was so accommodating.However, the concierge service was out of this world. Because we were trying to get some close to impossible reservations in Tokyo, I started contacting and borderline harassing them to make sure I would get the reservations I wanted. Miss Mori and Mr. Otsuka worked wonders for us. Not only did they manage to secure us some Of the most difficult reservations in Tokyo, they were beyond patient and courteous throughout the process. We literally exchanged over 50 emails! I really just would like to thank them for making our stay flawless.We will definitely be back!

This is my return visit to Tokyo Station Hotel. I suppose in terms of location, there is no further necessity to stress that Tokyo Station Hotel has the best spot in Tokyo to explore the city and beyond, and they very much match it up with their hospitality!We had a palace-side twin room, which is spacious with tasteful decor, spotlessly maintained, and it comes with a high ceiling along with a gorgeous chandelier (I do mean inside the room, not just the lobby)!The hotel is a masterpiece by famous architect Tatsuno Kingo, the building itself is an important cultural heritage from the Taisho era, but painstakingly re-furbished in 2014. As such, it retains a brilliant harmony of classic and modernity. Don't just stay at the hotel for the night, do take time to appreciate the pictures along the alley, it's a historical lesson on the hotel's amazing progress through the eras.The rooms have fridge provided, but if required, ice are available on every level, as are dedicated smoking rooms. In general, although the hotel lacks facilities such as garden and pool, they do have a paid gym. In addition, the varieties of bar and restaurants will certainly not disappoint. Breakfast at The Atrium was another exclusive experience, with high ceiling, impressive chandeliers, and a good assortment of food to please every diners.We thoroughly enjoyed our stay and hope to come back again!

We spent 4 nights in this hotel at the end of our Japan trip. The location is great and very convenient. It is located at the entrance of the station. You can easily explore the city from this point. The hotel looks great from the inside and outside. The room was nice and has everything you needed. The staff is very friendly and very helpful. The only problem I had was we only got one big towel a day. I would expect at least two towels per person. But the rest was very good.Highly recommended!!

We stayed here for the first time this trip. The location in amazingly convenient for traveling throughout the Tokyo region. I highly recommend getting rail passes since we used them multiple times a day, including to access the excellent restaurants and stores within the massive train station complex. The hotel is top-end luxury but interestingly owned by The Japanese Rail company. Many rooms look down into the train terminals. An amazing 3,000 trains come through the Tokyo Station daily, but the hotel is very quiet.The front desk staff, bell staff, concierge, and dining staff are all incredibly helpful and courteous. Their English ranges from fair to excellent. One of the great benefits is their help in navigating the train station and the numerous tran lines. Easy access to everywhere including Tokyo Disneyland ( highly recommended). We only used cabs a few times and mainly traveled by train throughout Japan. Note: it is generally best to buy your rail pass in the US.In particular we want to thank Concierge Marie Antoinette (really) who was so helpful throughout our 5 night stay. She was helpful in a variety of ways: sourcing train tickets to the airport, suggesting restaurants, sourcing a bottle of rare Japanese Whisky and providing detailed directions to shopping areas. She even had two excellent bell staff help us take our luggage through the train station as we left for the airport. Above and beyond!! The Oak Bar on the second floor is small but very nice and has a variety of excellent and rare Japanese and other whiskeys and other drinks. Get there early in the evening as the 20 seats fill up fast. This will always be our first choice when in Tokyo.

We stayed in 3 rooms during a probably very busy time (cherry blossom) in this hotel, two of which faced the front of the hotel, and were amazed by the quiet atmosphere despite the huge train station and a large construction site directly in front of the hotel. The rooms were tasteful, functional, and the service of the reception was excellent in helping us with various arrangements and organizational issues. Ms. Mori at the concierge, who speaks fluent English, is a very helpful and friendly person who provided a ton of help for us who speak no Japanese. We enjoyed walking to the Imperial Palace Gardens and to Ginza from the hotel with its central location and loved the super large breakfast selection in the light-filled hall every morning. We would definitely stay here again. This hotel may not have the views that some high-rise hotels have but the service and location are major plus points.

My family stayed here on a long planned trip to see as much as possible in two weeks. While pricey we couldn't have chosen a more central and appointed hotel. The staff, particularly the concierage and baggage handlers were exceptionally kind to us, letting us know about great places that they themselves enjoyed spending time with their families in Tokyo. They were very geniune in providing advice and helped us avoid some of the more "touristy" trap type places, which we went to anyway because why not :).The hotel is very large but feels cozy, the hallways are the longest and the baggage staff constantly, and uncessarily apoligize for it. The hotel is right on top of one of the busy stations in the country and its the perfect location to stay at to quickly launch from for travels to everywhere, we ended up going to Hijemi, Osaka, Hiroshama and Kyoto and several towns/villages and cities up in the Japanese Alps all in the span of two weeks. It didn't feel rushed because we felt we saved at least an hour of inter-city travel time by being right on top the station we planned on departing from.The rooms are well appointed and the beds extremely comfortable, which we were grateful for after a 15 hour flight and nearly 27 hours of traveling time to get to Tokyo. Read up on the history of the hotel, its an interesting architectural anomaly in country and society that loves tearing old things down and building up the new.Being in Chiyoda, while some consider it out of the way we found nice. It was quiet and peaceful compared to the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku or Shibuya, so if that is your thing consider the tradeoff in terms of convenience. The Imperial Park is right there and main shopping and dining isn't that far of a walk, 20 minutes max. I highly recommend trying out at least a night here if you find yourself in Tokyo and traveling
user_name:
sanmartinero
New York City, New York

review_body: We booked one night in this hotel because we were leaving for Kyoto in the early am from Tokyo Station. The rooms are tastefully decorated, very comfortable and the service we received was top rate. We easily took the N'ex from Narita to Tokyo Station- and our train to Kyoto the following am. The service and location can't be improved upon.

the most delicious breakfast I've ever had in Tokyo. organic leaves,amazing Japanese dishes,fresh and sweet fruits, and comfortable dining environment.highly recommend.Incidentally, my husband and I met a great concierge 玉井さん who gave us a warm welcome and very helpful to us.

We stayed in the Tokyo Station Hotel on the night of the 25th April and again from the 5th-7th May. We were greeted at the station by an extremely helpful and polite lady from the concierge who escorted us to the hotel with our bags. The staff are all incredibly helpful and attentive and very polite. The hotel is beautifully decorated and the rooms are clean, modern, comfortable and nicely decorated. Breakfast was plentiful and served in the very spacious atrium. We had dinner in the Cantonese En Ken Takase restaurant and it was absolutely fantastic, the food was excellent and the service again the same. All in all this has got to be the best hotel in Tokyo; we will most definitely be coming back. Special mentions to Tomonori Otsuka & Natsuki Nobe for their help with reservations. Tom Harris

Recently stayed here for our last 3 nights in Japan and what a way to close out this wonderful trip. We were upgraded to the 2-story room and it is something else, beautiful, elegant and immaculate. The service was also fantastic. Location can't be beat, literally at Tokyo station.

Stayed for our last night in Japan. Built into the station, it's easy to find. Great location. Staff were great. In the morning, one of the concierge members escorted us down to the Narita Express platform. We recommend this service because it's not easy to get around the station. Room and bathroom were lovely.Highly recommended.

The Hotel is wonderful and all that you would expect, but the Chief Concierge Marie Antoinette Mori and her team are exceptional. Travelling alone and not speaking Japanese... I was unfortunate to fall ill early in my stay. Ms Mori was so helpful, caring and kind in supporting me and getting me to a doctor. She literally came with me to the appointment and assisted through the pharmacy process. The Deputy Manager came to collect me and there was a rose with a hand written get-well note in my room on my return.I am so appreciative and could not have asked for more. It's that kind of service which sets The Tokyo Station Hotel apart. Thank you so much!

We stayed at Kieo plaza, shearton in Horisima and The Tokyo station Hotel.By far the best. The service was outstanding even helped with our bags to the train.Tomonori Otsuka (Mr) was an absolute standout. If you ever need help with anything while staying in the hotel he was truly excellent.When i tried to give him a tip he said no thank you. He showed great pride in his job and the Hotel.Regards Troy

A very beautiful hotel situated in the Tokyo Station's historical building. My room was looking over the Marunouchi station but was still very quiet. The room could not be said to be small, as there was a separate toilet, shower and bathtub.Staying guests are recommended to try their restaurants which serve superb cuisine. Their breakfast is impeccable.The staff are friendly and most helpful. I must thank their porter service who escorted me from the train station to the hotel on the day of my stay as I am prone to losing my way.Highly recommended for those visiting Tokyo and travelling to other parts of Japan by Shinkansen because of its location.

What a fantastic hotel the Tokyo Station Hotel is. As soon as you arrive you are made to feel special , the staff are fantastic and the real bonus when staying here. We arrived early morning as per usual when arriving in Asia from the UK and after quite a rough flight were both a bit worse for wear on arrival aroun 10am. Though after speaking to reception they managed to change a Inge and get us booked in early at 12 which was a blessing. We decided to stay for 4 days in Tokyo before moving on to Kyoto before coming back to stay here for one more night due to its excellent location for Narita airport.On our first stay the room was quite small though comfortable though charging for coffee if you wanted it in your room was unexpected for a hotel of this quality .We had breakfast in the Antrim on out first morning which is good though as expected expensive . On our return for the last night of our holiday we were upgrade to what I can only describe as a suite due to its amazing size.The hotel being located at the main train station is excellent location for the bullet and local trains as well as a great connection for subways and a buses .Close to the imperial palace which is nice for an early morning stroll.Overall excellent experience and by far the best staff I have ever come across they make you feel like royalty every time you enter or leave the hotel .

This was the first time I stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel. I was first attracted by its historical and beautiful architecture. And indeed, when my family and I entered the hotel, we were all impressed by the very well designed and comfortable environment. We stayed at the Dome Side rooms and the experience was unique and interesting, with tall roof and the special view from the rooms. The washroom should not be overlooked, with very considerate design and excellent ventilation. The hardware is definitely one of the best in the area, which I believe many people have commented on that. Meanwhile, the staff and the service of the hotel are something that should be highly complimented as well.It was a rainy day when we visited the hotel. Frontdesk staff had been so nice to wait for us at the bus station with umbrellas and guided us the way to the hotel, which we truly appreciated. Furthermore, they also arranged escort to the bullet train platform in the early morning. It was a huge assistance for those who might feel a little bit panic when they first entered the huge and busy Tokyo Station.The Concierge Team is so helpful and consistently patient and reliable to my requests. I have sought their support for reservation of a place for dinner and the contact with a local train company for a sightseeing train trip. Without their help, the trip could not be so successful.

We stayed as a couple in early May. The hotel was in the Tokyo station at the Marounoshi south exit. The location was perfect for traveling. The room was quite small but well decorated and very clean. The services were excellent, we can't expected more.The breakfast was excellent. Only drawback during our stay was there was a construction in front of the hotel, so the scenery was very bad. Anyway, we love this hotel and we will be back again.

This is a beautiful luxury hotel refurbished in 2012. It is brilliantly located above Tokyo station with all of the facilities that you would expect and more. The hotel employees are charming, polite and helpful. The rooms are super clean, soundproofed, have very comfortable beds, blockout curtains, fast wifi and are fitted with unbelievable Japanese toilets, including heated Toto seats. I want one. The toiletries are generous and frequently replenished. If you are travelling in on the Narita Express take the Marunouchi South exit and turn right. There is an overhead sign for the hotel. Choose a larger room with an outside view if your budget allows. Hint: the switch for turning off the room lights is located on what appears to be an alarm clock. It took us a while to figure it out!We would stay here again even though it was a bit of a splurge for us it was worth it.

The location is beyond ideal. Tokyo is huge, so you'll end up traveling quite a bit, and this is above a major train station. It's in the thick of it, but it felt quiet and secluded in a way. The rooms are beautiful and the staff was warm, welcoming, and knowledgeable. We stayed at another hotel due to availability (The Capitol) - we stayed here our last night to enjoy one more day in Tokyo. If we came back, we would prefer this location. We learned quickly, you need to pay up in Tokyo, and it's worth it.

Simply the best hotel I've ever stayed. Been to London, Europe, all around Australia. Nothing comes close. The Dome room Shouldn't be missed and breakfast, expensive, but worth every cent. Staff assist with every need. Thank you for a wonderful short stay. Myself and small family loved it.

To describe this hotel the first word that comes to my mind is immaculate. It delivers everything it promises in the descriptions. I stayed for two nights in a single room, the room was comfortable and clean, the bathroom was fabulous. The full breakfast was too much for me, but they serve a smaller one in the lobby bar, which suited me perfectly. But the absolute hight point for me was the staff. All of them are extremely friendly and helpful and make you feel right at home. I was very happy with my stay here!

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel for an overnight. Checking in was quick and efficient. Our dome view room was small but adequate for our short stay. The breakfast buffet was the best we've seen in any hotel anywhere. Staff were attentive, and we appreciated being able to do a walking circumnavigation of the Imperial Palace before breakfast. Great position for transiting passengers like us. If you're staying for longer ask about room size.

We came in from Osaka on a cold drizzly evening and after trudging all over the vast and crowded Tokyo station reached the hotel whose frontage is currently under renovation and hence the signage to the entrance is poor.We had chosen a Dome room as we were staying just for a night and was taken up by the description of the room in their website.The room is frightfully small and with our 2 suitcases we barely has space to walk around. The bathroom was bigger than the bedroom. Thankfully we had a n early departure and did not have to endure the cramped quarters for long.

My wife and I recently stayed here and we were very impressed.
