The hotel is luxurious and the staff could not have been more pleasant and helpful.The location is great and the staff will arrange to meet you at the Narita Express platform at Tokyo Station when you arrive(and also help with departure from the station) to the airport making getting to/from the hotel from the station very convenient for 1st time visitors - as the Tokyo Station is quite large and confusing for the 1st time visitor.They have many great restaurants to choose from and the breakfast buffet is extensive and very well done.Although like all luxurious hotels in Tokyo, this is not inexpensive, but it is well worth the price. I would stay here again if visiting Tokyo in the future.

I first thought about this hotel when I was considering Tokyo and earthquakes. Maybe a really old hotel that had survived one hundred years and that was a few stories high might be a good idea? Once these somewhat flippant thoughts had passed, the hotel seemed like a great idea for a first night in Japan. So it proved to be. The hotel is distinctive. One of a tiny handful of properties in Japan that date back to the late 19th or early 20th century and have that Victorian feel. The rooms have high ceilings and tall windows. The location is perfect for both a jet lagged stroll around the grounds of the nearby Imperial Palace Gardens and it's a short hop downstairs to the Shinkansen to Kyoto. The breakfast buffet is good value for Japan too.The hotel suffers from being at the crossroads. It is incredibly busy with large crowds for checkin and check out. However the staff seem well trained and able to deal with the crush and your welcome seems genuine and warm, up to the normal Japanese standards of hospitality.

the most elegant location in tokyo. the best connections nextdoors to reach all over tokyo. great jogging route around the imperial gardens. so nearby ginza, amidst marunouchi, pleasant walk to tokyo fish market.

My friend and I spent our first night in Japan here. We arrived at separate airports and met at the hotel. Wow, what a great idea! It is beautifully furnished, impeccable staff. Our room was one of the nicest I've stayed in, and I have stayed in many fine hotels.When I checked in, the desk clerk knew who I was and let me know that my friend was in the dining room! When we left on a bullet train to Kyoto, a staff person walked us all the way to our train. Although it was a splurge for us, it was worth every penny.

This is one of those hotels where management has anticipated and implemented almost everything (facility and services) guests could want. Because of that, it makes a great final stop on a trip to Japan - better to end with a topflight hotel than begin there and then have all your other lodgings pale in comparison. The location at Tokyo Station with access to Narita Express trains also makes it a logical final night stay in Japan before heading to the airport. A bellman carried our luggage and escorted us to our train's platform. If staying for more than one night, the Imperial Palace grounds and Ginza shopping are both just down the street. Though top hotels are expensive, this one offers a small discount to rail pass holders.

We stayed at this hotel during our recent trip to Japan. The hotel is In a great location especially for those using a JR Pass as it gives you direct access to the JR loop line around Tokyo which is a great alternative to the subway for some of the top spots. The hotel is in a beautiful building, very well maintained with an elegant interior. The room however was very small, although the bathroom was relatively spacious. It is an expensive hotel (both room and drinks, with a coke costing > €10 in the lobby dining area) however it is In a great location and very stylish place to sit back and relax. Out of all the hotels we stayed in during our visit, this one ticked the most boxes and we would book it again.

From service, location, comfort and facilities, the Tokyo Station Hotel has it all. From the moment we stepped in to the minute we left during our two nights stay, we were treated as if we were frequent guests although it was our first time. We wanted to stay two more nights but the hotel was fully booked.The room was very clean, relatively big by Tokyo standards and had everything to make our stay enjoyable. The bed was comfortable and the free in-room wifi speed was fast. The bathroom was also big with quality toiletries and well maintained. Being located above the underground Tokyo Station was really wonderful. Really, there is nothing negative one can say about this hotel. We will stay at this hotel again the next time we come back to Tokyo. It is certainly one of the best hotels we have stayed in during our travels.

Staying at this hotel is like stepping back in time and being part of history. Very easy access from Tokyo Station, just take the Marunouchi south exit and turn right after exiting the ticket gates. We requested a dome view room which was really interesting looking out at people coming and going through the station hall. Very attentive welcome and check in service. Staff even printed out a boarding pass for me on check out. Staff very friendly and helpful. Very spacious comfortable rooms and amazing buffet breakfast. Great selection and variety of food. Great wagyu steak from the lobby lounge. My only quibble would be that given the price of the rooms, access to the spa and sauna should be included. Otherwise, one of the most memorable hotel stays.

Favorite hotel in Tokyo due to location, staff and breakfast. Only negative is that there is absolutely no place to store clothes. There is a small hanging closet. Rooms are small but doable except for that issue. Not much time spent in room but it would be nice to unpack suitcase.

I've stayed here many times now. Of course it is very convenient, being inside the train station. The hotel has a great history as well. Nice big rooms, very well furnished, all state of the art amenities And yes - the breakfast is great !!

For some reason, I wasn't expecting a lot from this hotel. I had it in my head that the pictures online would of course be way better than what it actually was. That idea started to change when we entered the hotel from Tokyo station south exit, and we came across the beautiful bar/lounge area next to the reception area. There was quite a line to get in there, so obviously very popular. We kept going along the corridor until we came to the gorgeous reception area. We were greeted with beautiful beaming smiles from all the staff, and a genuine friendliness. We were escorted to our room, and shown all the amenities within. We had a palace side superior room - beautiful! Ample space, including a little sitting area, with seating for 3 and coffee table. Also, a lovely desk next to the TV for any work you need to do. Free wifi of course. Lovely comfortable bed. Safe. 4 free waters in the minibar fridge good to take with us on our sight seeing walks around Tokyo. There was a note saying there may be noise from construction out on the street in the mornings, but we heard nothing. The room is so well sound proofed. The bathroom is huge and gorgeous, complete with your option of using the rain shower from above, or the shower on the rail, with choice of varying functions, which meant varying water pressure to please everyone (let's hope!). The bath tub is large and great for soaking in after a hard day of walking, or doing nothing:) Heaps of toiletries included, above and beyond the usual. Watch out for the Japanese toilet if you have a little one. My 10 year old was scared of it for the first 2 days, and I had to stand outside so she felt safe! But it's great. You don't have to touch it at all. The lid lifts as you enter, the seat is warmed (!), it flushes itself once you stand up, and closes the lid about a minute later. I want one! If you are into bidet stuff, it had that too.Regarding other reviews about the long hallways, yes, if that is a problem for you, request one closer to the lifts. It wasn't a problem for us. There are directions to reception or rooms on the walls, so it's not like you would get lost, unless you're not paying attention, or forgot your room number. Even those long hallways and corridors are beautiful, and perfectly maintained/cleaned. Check out the photos on the walls every so often as well, of varying eras of the hotel, and stages of reconstruction after the big earthquake many, many years ago, and then after WW2. Its latest refurb was done in 2012, and has been done in a classic, contemporary feel that is perfect for the exterior architecture. In regards to location, it is absolutely perfect. Walking distance to Ginza or the Imperial Palace and gardens. Right above Tokyo's biggest train station means easy access to everywhere. The area feels very safe. The workers of the area are so impeccably dressed it is jaw dropping. Needless to say, we would definately stay here again.

I stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel early April. The hotel is in the station and very convenience. It's right in the middle of the town. During my visit, the people gathered in front of hotel to see the Emperor passed by. The service of the hotel was excellent. The hotel had a lady staff to escort and brought luggages to the room. We can request for additional complimentary bottle of water. The city view was very nice. The breakfast was exceptional with uni and varieties of food. Though the rent was expensive but you get what you pay.

We came from Narita airport by the JR train. We called the hotel from the airport with our train info , a member from the hotel was waiting for us on the ramp and accompanied us to the reception- great service and easy welcome to Tokyo.High class rooms, an amazing and outstanding western and japanies breakfast , with a very good service from all the dinning room employees .My husband has gluten free intolerance and a special hot baked rice bread was waiting for him every morning.High class techno gym equipment .The Spa has 3 soaking pools in a different temperature divided to separate females and males.Overall an excellent hotel , the only remark I would suggest is: to add more English speaking people in the reception ... it could avoid misunderstandings and time spend.
user_name:
navity
New York City, New York

review_body: 1) Location : The best in Tokyo2) Staff : The best in Tokyo3) Lobby Lounge : The best coffee , cakes and Harp Music4) Internet : very fast and complementary5) Breakfast : japan and western - Very Good6) Rooms : little bit small but with great bathroom

Thoroughly loved staying. We came from Narita airport and emailed the concierge our tickets and they were waiting in front of our train when we arrived. Getting to the hotel would have been quite a challenge otherwise!Super polite easy check in could not do enough to help staff!Great room over looking one of the famed domes. Comfy king bed and ripper walk in shower too. Yes it's expensive but worth it in my book. Had breakfast in the atrium and that also worthwhile.

We had a surprisingly wonderful stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel on April 7 and 8, 2017. The hotel is beautifully renovated with rooms with high ceilings and modern, classy décor. The two exceptional differences between this hotel and other 5 star hotels is their Meet and Greet service at Tokyo Station from Narita Airport and escorting us to our track at Tokyo Station upon departure. No other hotel can offer that service. Maneuvering Tokyo Station can be a daunting task - so to have this escort service/guide was just wonderful. Mr. Naoki Hiraiwa provided exceptional service and hospitality and Ms. Kotori Kobayashi greeted us warmly and helped us get settled in our room. This hotel is most convenient when activating Rail Passes and getting train tickets.

No argument that convenience should have a price. And the Tokyo Station Hotel does exact an exorbitant premium for being integrated into the Tokyo Train Station - and what do you get for it? Yes you get an exquisitely appointed hotel. But is that enough? Why should your $500 night just pay for the luxurious appointments like Bulgari soaps in the bathroom vs. including a breakfast? Why should you have to pay to use the gym - which only opens at 7:00AM - and requires you to find another elevator? Why should you have to discover that breakfast is served on the 4th floor which yet again requires another elevator? Why is there not an outlet anywhere close to the desk where you can plug in the computer? Why is there a fancy coffee machine that does not work? There are numerous hotels in the area of the Tokyo train station that offer a much better balanced approach to convenience in a much more useful manner-and do so at half the price. Sadly this hotel - and beautiful and luxurious as it may be - has missed the ball in offering the traveler searching for convenience in staying at a train station hotel a well balanced solution.
user_name:
CLO100
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Very classic hotel from 1914, newly renovated and very beautiful, our room was in the Palace side, superior King, breakfast and presentation is Michelin star class worthy, with both foreign and Japanese kitchen and the service is impeccable

We stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel for a couple of nights at the start of April. The hotel is very nicely renovated that has a really handy location (e.g. short walk to the Imperial Palace and to Ginza). We arrived in Tokyo in the evening so it was super convenient arriving on the Narita Express train. We had a Dome room overlooking the Station which was quite unique and I would recommend.I would like to acknowledge the service provided by Marie Antoinette Mori and the concierge team. They booked a couple of restaurants on our behalf prior to our arrival and also arranged our train tickets to Kyoto. They even walked us and our bags through the station to the the train platform!I can't fault anything about this hotel in terms of the services we utilised and thought it was good value given the service and quality. A great way to start our holiday.We would definitely stay here again.

We flew into Narita airport from Guam and had to leave the next day for the States from Haneda. The Tokyo Station Hotel was the perfect place to spend the night. We took the airport bus from Narita (in retrospect we probably should have taken the express train). We wanted to take the monorail to Haneda but were concerned because we had three roller bags and two backpacks and were unclear about which train to take to get to the monorail. We didn't need to worry. The hotel staff brought us - rolling our suitcases! - to the train and explained where to connect. Taking us through the bustling station and waiting with us for the right train was above and beyond what we could ever have asked for or expected. In addition, the hotel itself is beautiful and the room we had overlooked the station. The bed was comfortable and the bathroom was amazing with a rain shower and lovely amenities. The hotel is fairly expensive but worth every penny. It is also a short walk from the Emperor's Palace with its lovely gardens. We were lucky enough to be in Tokyo with the cherry blossoms in full bloom. I highly recommend the hotel.

Very cool place indeed new hotel above the central station! Came in for a little rest and Japanese tea good atmosphere good service. Very well decorated in excellent taste and very calm. Staying at the Ritz Carlton but may try here as a hotel next time here?

Gorgeous room with a lovely bathroom. The hotel breakfast is excellent- well worth the price. They had a huge selection and lovely freshly made eggs Benedict which was delicious. The bed was really comfortable and the room had great amenities - iPod dock, glasses and cups etc. Great location and helpful staff. I would recommend this hotel.

I had the pleasure of staying at this hotel for five nights at the beginning of my trip to Japan, and it certainly set a benchmark. In a great location above Tokyo Station, and given that most of your travel around Tokyo is by train it was ideal. No train noise could be heard in my room, I might add. We were met by staff at the station on arrival and taken to the correct platform on departure. The staff were exceptionally polite and no request was an issue for them. My room was beautifully appointed with a fantastic bathroom full of natural light, seperate shower, bath and toilet, and had every woman's necessity, a magnifying mirror. There were only two things I might mention, the front of the hotel is undergoing landscaping, but this wasn't an issue for access, more aesthetics. And there was a problem getting a drink at the hotel bars, there seemed to be a weird booking system, despite what the front desk said. A special thanks has to go to the wonderful Marie Antoinette, the Concierge, for whom nothing was too hard, she took initiative when making bookings for us, and was just a particularly pleasant person. One final thing, my friend stayed there for one night a week later and the type of pillow she had used previously was waiting for her on her bed! Thankyou Marie Antoinette for a wonderful stay.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel for 3 nights and were really pleased with the staff, location and facility. Granted it is a high end hotel, but the staff exceeded expectations whether it was to arrange a cab or dinner or to rearrange a tour for the third, fourth and fifth time; just outstanding. The room was spacious and remodeled to a high level. Food quality and price were high but it is an upscale hotel in a very expensive city. The building has an expansive foot print and if your room is in the North Dome, like ours, you can feel like you're going to the end of the world but you'll get your morning exercise walking to the lobby. If you don't need to go to the lobby, you can use the guest only elevators and entrance to reduce the walk.We would stay again and recommend it to friends.

We stayed a night there planning to take the express train to the airport and found this hotel right at the station, and the location is perfect.It is close to the imperial palace, all the highend shopping and the underground stores too. We are obsessed with this location just being so closed to all these things for a day trip and got to check out a lot of stuff without driving around. Room is very clean, definitely western style and the food is great. We treated ourselves breakfast (buffet, they have both Japanese and western selections, even some Chinese) there and it is definitely not to be missed.We were staying at the ambassador suite and it was probably one of the largest room/ suite in the hotel, so spacious and just loved everything there. Quiet, roomy, and it was just perfect for a family of 4. It has a big bath tub, a living room with a coffee table, a dining table, and a proper study desk. 2 bathrooms, very generous space.

Great location if you need to be close to Tokyo station, but this hotel is painfully overpriced. Hotel guests have to pay to use the gym and spa facilities, and that's in addition to what you pay for a spa treatment. Aside from that, the room and bathroom are nicely renovated, and small like most Tokyo hotels. If you're already willing to pay $500+/night, then there are other equally convenient options that'll offer a much more pleasant stay.

I thought this hotel was a bit expensive for what you get, but the convenience of the location can't be beat. It's right at the Tokyo Station and if you have limited time, it's a great starting point to the city. They also have pick up and drop off service which was just amazing. Someone will meet you at the platform (you have to contact them 2 days prior and you have to be taking one of the fast trains to use this service) and walk you to the hotel. At the end of your stay, you can also ask to be walked to your train's platform. It may not seem like much, but Tokyo Station is a humongous maze and if your time is limited it's just a fabulous service. The concierge was also excellent in booking us a dinner reservations and upgraded our room to celebrate a special occasion. They even left us a complimentary dessert in our room! The room itself was very spacious and the bed was very comfortable. The washroom was quite luxurious and we were very happy with everything.My only complaint about this hotel is regarding their fitness centre. First of all, they charge 1000 yen per day to use it. For a hotel that already charges so much per night, it's kind of tacky. Secondly, there are some really odd and rigid rules here. They tried to get us to pay 500 yen to use their "workout clothes" including shoes. We declined because we had our own, but when I entered the change room she tried to take away my shoes. I explained to her they were my workout shoes, she tried to tell me I wasn't allowed to wear "outside shoes" into the gym and wanted me to pay the 500 yen to wear their "indoor shoes". It was so bizarre. I told her they were what I wear to the gym and that they were clean, but she insisted on scrubbing my shoes with a towel before reluctantly agreeing to let me wear them. Once I got into the gym, there was someone standing next to me the whole time and pressing the screen for me while I was working out. I wasn't sure if she was there to help me or supervise me. My husband also had a guy stand next to him while lifting weights and he would sporadically inform him of random rules. We both felt so restrained that we left in 20min. We've been to hundreds of gyms around the world and this was just the oddest experience. In the change room too, there were random staff just standing there while people were changing. Again, I'm not sure if they were there to help us or make sure we didn't break any rules. I had a feeling it was the latter. The spa was really nice though. Overall, it was a nice hotel, but too rigid and rules need to be updated for this century.

I stayed here in October 2016 for one or two night, my reservation was originally for the entirety of my stay but I did not care for the hotel and went to stay at The Conrad for the remainder of my trip. This hotel is a 3.5 but due to my experience I decided to give it a 3 as it was more deserving than a 4 star.. The hotel is beautifully appointed and very conveniently located (its in a train station for crying out loud) but my hotel room was probably a good 10 minute walk down a never ending array of hallways from the entrance/elevator and overlooked a construction area. The decor is modern and plush but the food was just abysmal. We ordered a japanese breakfast in room service for over $120 and we literally rolled the cart back out to the hallway the way it came because the food was just unpalatable. The same could be said about the dinner we had our first night at the Italian restaurant on the property, we would have been better off eating canned spaghetti. The staff was polite but nothing more, and considering how polite and hospitable the locals have been during all my trips to japan they really fell short. I would not stay here again. The 3 stars( a true 3.5 star experience) are for the actual decor/design of the hotel and the amazingly convenient location that is worth gold in Tokyo, but service, room view of a contraction zone, location of room so far from elevator (5-7 minute walk from elevator to room door), and both room service and the restaurant providing horrible meals made this a hotel I could not recommend moving forward.

Located in the center of Tokyo city sits a beautiful historic hotel called The Tokyo Station Hotel. The train station and bus stops are conveniently located a few steps away. The underground maze has many shops to browse through as you walk towards your train platform, there are eating places or bento shops if you need to grab something for your train ride. (It is considered impolite to eat, drink coffee or text as you walk.)The hotel's staff are friendly, polite, professional and sincere. They made us feel very comfortable. Ms. Satomi Ida greeted us as we entered, helped us with our suitcases, explained the area around the hotel (Imperial Palace was walking distance), underground pathway, areas in the hotel and nearby to have a snack or meal). Both Mr. Kamata (shift manager) and Mr. Otsuka (concierge) were both outstanding - they took the time to answer all our questions, gave great detailed directions and suggestions knowing what our interests were and what we would enjoy. Mr. Kamata was fluent in English and Mr. Otsuka was able to communicate in English with some Japanese words - between the both of us he did great. This hotel is five stories, some rooms look into the station's people crossing area, others towards the street. Rooms are spacious, western style beds, soaking tub, rain shower and hand held shower, heated Toto toilet seats which open and closed the lid automatically, and complimentary coffee and water. Rooms were immaculate - every detail - including how they folded and stamped the toilet paper were done with care. Loved we received the daily paper (English version) every morning. Breakfast for hotel guests only on the fourth floor was outstanding! Best Eggs Benedict, and omelette, western meal selection located on one side, Japanese cuisine on the other side of room and a fresh fruit, yogurt, muesli, fresh juice and milk station in between. Staff were very attentive - coffee refilled, plates and new utensils replaced as you cleaned your plate. We were impressed with everyone we met. People here took great pride in their job - nothing to them was ever considered small or unnecessary. Not once did we encounter "not my job" response.We would definitely return to this hotel!

When I arrived the hotel, nobody helps me about my luggage. The concierge open the taxi door and the disappeared when he saw th luggage. It is a carry on loggage on plane with four wheels. So I went to check in. I cannot hear a word from the reception. Therefore I just gave my bamecard, passport and credit card to her. Still the check in tool more than 15 minutes. Then a bell lady brought me to the room. They put me at the very vert end of the room. We need to walk about 10 minutes from the floor lift to the room. I went ot the bar - Oak Room. It is nice but not much choice outsiode of whisly. They expect everybody to drink whisky but rememebr this is the only bar in the hotel. I beleive that there should be a choice. I asked the conceriage to book a restaurant and have not come back to me yet. I am going call back down now. Hope everyting works out. Otherwise, Tokyo Station Hotel only lives on the history of Tokyo Station which is sad.

This hotel was a pleasant surprise. It is located within the beautiful building of Tokyo Train Station, yet it is absolutely sound proof, none of the rustling of the area affects in the least the quality of sleep. The staff is polite (the Concierge was particularly helpful). The ambiance is of classical elegance. The bar is very agreeable. The location is unbeatable. If my room were not undersized (it had only space for night table on one of the sides of the bed), the experience would have been excellent.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel and am pleased with the location and the service rendered. Whenever we needed something, a phonecall away and service is provided almost immediately.The only thing we didn't like was the fact that our room was soooooo far away. Room 3020. After a long tiring day of shopping, we had to lug our feet across tons of room to reach our room.

This was my second and third time staying at The Tokyo Station Hotel, having chosen to stay there at the start and end of my recent trip to Japan. The excellent service started even before I reached Japan. The concierge team, especially Ms. Marie Antoinette Mori, was most helpful in helping me arranging some dining plans and were able to confirm them rather quickly. They even offered suggestions/alternatives when I had some concerns about seating availability. I really appreciated all their assistance and everything went perfectly. I did wish that they had provided me with the directions to the restaurants before I had to ask. It's a very minor quibble but perhaps it was due to having had such service from the nearby Four Seasons Tokyo. When I stayed with them and had restaurant reservations made, the hotel provided me with a location map and restaurant details etc upon my check-in.Our train from Narita experienced very severe delay and so by the time we arrived, 2 of our rooms were available to check-in. The room was very much as I had remembered it, cosy and comfortable with all the usual amenities. The bed was very much to my liking and the complimentary wifi very fast. The excellent location makes it very easy to access the train lines and I was able to travel from the hotel to the station exits without having to expose myself to the elements. Upon our departure, the hotel was also able to assist us in transporting our luggage all the way down to the Narita Express platform. Really helped my family a lot as we had quite a few heavy suitcases. Overall, I'd highly recommend The Tokyo Station Hotel for its excellent service, lovely property and unbeatable location. Having stayed at Oakwood Premier Tokyo, Shangri-la Tokyo and Four Seasons Tokyo previously, I must say that The Tokyo Station Hotel more than holds its own and is worthy of serious consideration, considering the options around.

Super location for Japan Rail pass travelers. Rooms are larger than many Japanese hotels but still more snug than US travelers are used to. Clean and quiet. Very luxurious. Very nice staff. We used this hotel as our base as we took day trips to Hakone and Nagano. So pleasant to fall into bed at the end of the day! (And the toilets are not to be believed!)

One bonus for international travellers at this hotel is that a staff member will meet you at the platform if you arrive by Narita Express from Narita airport. (tickets for this can be purchased on arrival at the airport, it is a quick and easy transfer in to central Tokyo) We phoned the hotel on arrival at the airport to let them know our train arrival time, and it all worked smoothly.We were so glad that we didn't have to try to navigate our way alone to the hotel through the massive Tokyo Train Station.Staff were efficient for check in, and very helpful generally, and happy to make dinner recommendations and reservations.Room was clean and well furnished, but very small. It felt a bit too cramped, with an arm chair and coffee table that weren't really necessary.Bathroom by contrast was huge, with a wonderful shower and a very entertaining toilet seat.Breakfast is hosted in a beautiful room, and the food choice was fabulous.A special thank you to the omelette chef, he cooked delicious omelettes, and he tolerated my poor Japanese with a huge smile.Don't be put off by the name of the hotel and idea of the hotel being over a train station , it was quiet and convenient, and we felt very safe in the surrounding area.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is absolutely fabulous... From the very moment one gets in till one leaves it- a spectaluar service, a marvellous culinary indulgence, wonderfully set rooms with a good taste and on top of it- a very practical location

Excellent Location Excellent Service Excellent Rooms Excellent People Excellent BreakfastExcellent ExcellentThis is one of the best hotels I have stayed in for the last several years. I would gladly stay here again the next time I'm in Tokyo.

Having made reservations with some reluctance in light of experiences in the rush of large city train stations, I was blown away by the high quality of both the facility and the staff I found at Tokyo Station Hotel. So much so that I slapped the very first sticker on my travel-weary suitcase: a retro TSH circle! Our room looked out at the attractive inside of the station dome, but provided a quiet roomy and comfortable accommodation. The bell-staff was exceptionally helpful - our departure bellman actually took our bags (and us) through the maze of the station to our platform and lodged the luggage onto our car. Even though the location isn't prime, I'll stay there again.

The hotel is at heart of Tokyo, a part of the historical Tokyo Station building. It is completely different from what one could expect from a hotel near/within a train station - clean, extremely quiet and classy. Service is brilliant in every aspect. Breakfast quality and room service is above most in 5-star hotel range. Ideal for travelers with plans to travel on the extensive train network and for those want to experience the history. Note: bed can be little small with young children if you don't mind it.

Extremely clean room and bathroom, large by Japanese standards, king size bed. Very convenient location, with entrance inside Tokyo Station. Did not try restaurant (which is extremely expensive). Staff was probably the best I have ever encountered anywhere in the world.

This establishment exceeded all expectations. The rooms are beautifully appointed - the whole hotel is. But for me it was the staff that makes this hotel my first choice for Tokyo. They are so helpful and full of concern when my luggage had not been delivered by the airline along with the baggage keys. They communicated on my behalf and ensured I did not leave without my travel bags.The restaurant caters for all tastes and is exquisite. This hotel is an oasis within the bussel of a large international city. If you are travelling by train stay here.

Tokyo Station Hotel is a beautifully designed, luxury hotel right above the station. While the rooms, service and amenities were top shelf, the convenience to the Narita Express and the proximity to run around the Imperial Gardens were a HUGE bonus. The service was amazing-- a concierge walked me to the platform for the Narita Express given it is 4 levels below, wow. He told me history & shared insights along the way. Bravo. Perfect location & hotel.My one suggestion would be to open the breakfast area before 8 am. As a business traveller, I would have liked to have coffee & a bite before heading out but was directed to a nearby Tully's coffee.

Would definitely recommend the Tokyo Station Hotel! We were looking for a place that was conveniently located to other neighborhoods in Tokyo - which this hotel definitely is. Being adjacent to the Tokyo Station makes this place ideal - it was only one or two subway stops to so many places we wanted to visit! The service was excellent. We pre-arranged for them to meet us at our train platform when arriving from Narita and they helped us navigate the train station to the hotel to get checked in - and did the same when we checked out. They went above and beyond - the concierge helped us get a coveted spot at Jiro in Ginza - and they helped us buy our train tickets to Kyoto. Would definitely stay here again.

This is our 5th stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel since 2014. This time we came here for our anniversary trip and a top dining destination in Tokyo.We got the excellent assistance from the concierge team, Mrs Mori and Mr. Otsuka to reserve one of the most difficult and number 1 sushi restaurant in Japan and probably, in the world, Sushi Saito this time and they managed to reserved all the below restaurant for us in one trip;- Sushi Saito (3 Michelin Stars)- Nihonryuri Ryugin (3 Michelin Stars)- Joel Robuchon (3 Michelin Stars)- Hatsunezushi (2 Michelin Stars)- Tempura Kondo (2 Michelin Stars)- Kaishoku Michba (Oiriginal Japanese Iron Chef)Each restaurant in the list is very hard on its own to get hold of the reservation, let alone putting them all together in 4 days but Mrs. Mori and her concierge team answer my request and deliver it every time. Kudos to The Tokyo Station Hotel!Also, I remembered that I did not mention to the hotel that this is our anniversary trip, apart from the only one time in our email conversation with Mrs. Mori regarding the reservation of Joel Robuchon that our friend in Japan will also celebrate our anniversary in this restaurant, however, when I arrived at the hotel, all the staff knew that this is our anniversary trip and upgrade our room to Palace King Side for the whole stay with the memorabilia photo of us taken in our room for this occasion. Really appreciate the level of attention and hospitality of this hotel.As usual, upon arriving home, we are planning to visit Tokyo again this Dec 2017 and certainly we won't change our hotel for sure.

This ideally located and historically charming luxury hotel offers the ideal location in Tokyo to see the city, explore the surrounding areas on day trips, or just dash to the airport.Located in the original Tokyo Train Station red brick building, the hotel is a very long and narrow collection of rooms that range from small to medium sized with luxurious décor, beautiful windows and amazing bathrooms that will be hard to leave. The hotel is not trendy or hip, and the views are low to the ground, but no matter where you go in the city, all trains almost lead you back to your home base. Tokyo has many spectacular hotels - I have stayed in them and love them all, but none are as practical and as traveler-friendly as this gem.

Area around hotel is under construction so the taxi driver had a tough time finding the drop off point, which is underground.From drop off take elevator up to the lobby to check in.Quick and easy process and escorted to room by hotel staff to explain details regarding the room.Two single beds, very high ceilings and very nice shower/bath.Also nice amenities.Restaurant is located on the forth floor with the service and quality of food being outstanding. Nice Japanese breakfast as well as western options.Only issue experienced: difficulty connecting laptop to internet.Great hotel, very convenient and highly recommend!!!

From our gracious airport pick up to our escort to our departure platform at the train station, this hotel never misses a beat. We had a wonderful dinner in the hotels Japanese restaurant, which they held open late for us. On our return to Tokyo we were met again at our train platform and escorted to the Narita Express! Such service is amazing, and that it was complimentary is far beyond expectations! We had the same escort both times, who was gracious and kind! Our 2 story suite was gorgeous, filled with the latest technology,and every amenity one could desire or need! We can't wait to return for a longer stay! One of the best!

We recently spent 4 nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel in a palace side king room and couldn't have been happier! The hotel is well situated, being literally above Tokyo Station itself. This made for easy access via the Narita Express train from the airport. The rooms are generously sized and the bathrooms huge by Japanese standards - the waterfall shower was splendid! Every employee we encountered was exceeding helpful and kind. Breakfast in the Atrium, while pricey, was a fantastic introduction to typical Asian breakfast fare alongside all you might expect at a luxury western hotel. There continues to be some construction going on outside the hotel that interferes somewhat with photography, however we were not bothered in any way by noise from it (or from anything else for that matter). In fact, we found it to be one of the quietest city hotels we'd ever stayed in!In modern Tokyo, with it's many tall, featureless buildings, the Tokyo Station Hotel stands out as unique and charming, with wonderful rooms and gracious staff. Highly recommended!

Whenever I stay at a hotel, it is always the staff that makes a difference. The counter staff, concierge and bellboy remembered me when I returned from my outing. I like their personalized greeting. The general manager's personal note and little gifts like Bvlgari chocolates and traditional Japanese red bean cakes inside the room also made a huge difference. Among these, I wish to personally commend the male middle age concierge (who I unfortunately forgot to take his name). He was very professional while providing me advice for my trip, and always took care of little details to ensure my trip is perfect. The hotel is perfectly located in the beautiful Tokyo Station which is a tourist attraction by itself. As it is located in the Tokyo Station, you can easily travel to places like Shinjuku or Shibuya, or out of Tokyo (this is a huge plus point since I needed to travel to Yokohama, Kyoto and so on). It is also located near the Imperial Palace which is also a major attraction. The hotel has a lot of famous restaurants located within, and the toiletries are the branded Gilbert and Soames. I will definitely come back for my next stay and I will strongly recommend this best Tokyo hotel to everyone. Last but not least, the general manager sent us off personally during my last day. I was so touched.

This was one of those that was rated fairly well, but you never know. We lucked out. Got it at a very good price and turned out to be wonderful. The rooms are small, as in most big cities, but nicely appointed and a very nice view. The bathrooms are wonderful with a delightful shower and tub, plus a heated seat toilet/bidet! We had never been to Tokyo and were a little apprehensive about getting around, but the Concierge, Tomonori Otsuka, relieved us of that. We was wonderful with perfect English. Arranged a great tour guide for a day, made restaurant recommendations, and drew multiple maps and instructions plus answered all our questions on local customs such as tipping. He even followed up with email confirmations. The hotel sits on tops of a gigantic train connection probably 4-6 stories deep. There are multiple shops and restaurants. Just across from the hotel are high rise buildings that are also full of restaurants and shops. You could never leave the area for days. It is also a very short walk to the Imperial Palace and gardens. Cabs are always available and reasonably priced. At one point, Tomonori came out with us to explain to our taxi where we wanted to go. On departure, Tomonori arranged for two assistants to take us and our bags to the platform for the airport express train. Thank goodness. It was numerous escalators and 2 elevators away. We would have been lost for hours. The hotel has two very nice bars (Oak Bar the nicest, smoking but didn't bother us), but they are hidden away and you will need instructions. You won't believe the coffee maker in your room. It took me a couple days to figure out how to use it.

Nice hotel - large rooms but you pay for them. Great location at Tokyo station allowing access to the JR line and a direct route to Narita airport making life easy. A couple of downsides for me where the fact that the hotel is located in a business district which means you need to travel to find nightlife and good eats (though you are right next to the train station so not that difficult) and in house eats are expensive. Also it is a large hotel with very long corridors so make sure if you have multiple rooms that they are close together. Will say that the service throughout our whole stay was excellent.

5 nights over 2 separate visits in Nov 2016Served its purpose very well. Hotel:Very good functional modern hotel, clearly had a recent refurb which is always better.Very central and very convenient location for getting around Tokyo, airport access and onward train travel. Modern with some character.Friendly and professional staff. As usual in Japan, very good serviceDecent friendly bar.Our King / Queen rooms: Queen was very compact, possibly too small. King had usefully more space. Very clean. Very comfortable. Very comfy beds. Very quiet, with vg sound insulation. Slept v well.Very good modern compact bathroom.Frequent towel changes when wanted.As usual for many modern and especially Japanese hotels, very little hanging / drawer clothes or bag storage. We had stuff for a 3-4wk trip.

We stayed here for 1 night as we were arriving by train after skiing near Nagano and were leaving from Narita airport the next afternoon. It was very difficult to find the hotel from the train station and we spent a frustrating half hour going around Tokyo Central station trying to find the right exit to access the hotel.The rooms were nice but small and it was a shame about the construction work outside, though the rooms were so quiet we were not disturbed by noise from it. The service was good overall but it was disappointing to have to pay 1000Y extra to use the gym.

If I return to Tokyo I would definitely choose to stay here. Yes, there is construction in the front, which is a bit of a shame, but it really does not detract from the hotel itself. Everything about the service and the ambiance is charming. The staff are very attentive, the breakfast is expansive, and the location is perfect. You can walk to the Ginza district, to the Imperial Palace, to tons of upscale shopping and restaurants just across the street. The train and metro stations are right there. This is the centre of Tokyo. The rooms are a tad small, but still very comfortable. (The bathroom was huge, however.) I agree with the other reviewer who wished for a spot to unpack clothes. I did ask for more hangers and promptly received them.

This hotel is in a quieter part of the CBD but all the action is actually below ground in the (impeccably clean) train station tunnels! We dined at Kitchen Street, and Ramen Street and the children loved Character Street. Across the road are the boutiques of KITTE building and on the other side of the station is a Daimaru. Great access to the subway and easy walking distance to the Imperial Gardens, Marunouchi boulevards and Ginza.The hotel design and decor is traditional and fresh and the rooms are generous for Tokyo. The beds and linen are divine and while the rooms we stayed in were narrow they were long and had high ceilings. We stayed in interconnecting rooms. Housekeeping and concierge service were always excellent. It's a boutique hotel by Tokyo standards and we enjoyed the cosy ambience.I must mention the atrium breakfast room. It is located in the original dome of the station building and is light, airy and elegant. The breakfast buffet was excellent - especially the Japanese selection and the engaging chefs on the omelette station. As you leave each morning, the staff give you a delicious powder puff of a cake for a snack. We didn't dine at the restaurant or bar.The external plaza construction works did affect the sense of arrival to the hotel but we noticed no noise at night. The taxi drop off has been disrupted during construction, so taxis will drop off in front of the station entrance and not the hotel entrance. If arriving with a lot of luggage (as we did), I suggest that you fetch a porter from the hotel lobby or call in advance so that they are waiting to assist with your luggage. This location is quiet at night time, although very safe. If you are looking for dinner or supper, the closest options are the excellent station tunnel venues rather than street options.I am looking forward to returning to this hotel when the plaza work is complete. It's a fantastic base from which to explore Tokyo and the quieter neighbourhood is a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle.

We stayed 5 nights at the end of our trip to Japan. The hotel is beautiful, the staff were wonderful (I emailed prior to arrival about my feather allergy- they responded quickly and provided hypoallergenic bedding for our stay), but there were some small niggles. The first one (this is not the hotels fault as such) is there is building work currently going on outside the station to make a new park, pavemented area. This will look amazing when completed but is a bit of an eye sore at the moment (plus they were still working at 9:15pm on one evening which was disturbing). Maybe check with the hotel to see if this work is still on going?The rooms are lovely with high ceilings, and very good black out curtains. The bathroom/ wet room is great! There is little draw storage space- two small bed side units with 2 draws (one draw had the safe in it, another had the touch and hotel night wear). Staying for 5 nights more space to unpack would have been great, the room had space for a chest of draws.There is hanging space for clothes but not many hangers (but I suspect the hotel would provide more if asked). You can occasionally feel some of the shinkansen arriving/ leaving the station but its not disruptive. One of the train stations entrances goes under some guest rooms- but this entrance is closed at night. The location (apart from the current building work) is excellent for the metro, JR lines, N'EX and shopping/restaurants. Would definitely stay there again but I think I will be checking to make sure there is no ongoing construction work!All in all a very well appointed hotel with great staff.

This is a beautiful hotel with wonderful service. However, travels should be aware that there is ongoing construction outside. The double-paned windows thankfully keep the sound out. I don't believe this construction affects the dome-side rooms. Also, being over a train station, one "feels" the trains coming in and out. Of course, this should be expected in a hotel over a train station. The room was beautiful and the room service presentation was one of the best I've seen.

This was our first trip to Japan and Tokyo. The hotel is very conveniently located at train station express stop from Narita airport. We emailed our arrival time and a hotel employee met our train and helped us with our bags and easily brought us to the hotel through a very crowded and hectic station during evening rush hour.The staff is competent, friendly could not do enough for us.Dinner suggestions and sightseeing were handled efficiently by the concierge. Every request was met by a genuine smile and bow.

Great from time of check in to check out. The reception staff are able to speak English well and are knowledgeable about directions and things to do. The lobby is small but very cosy with a fire place. We stayed in the Dome side room and it is a little small. However, the amenities made up for it. Huge shower area with a nice bath tub. Fully automated toilet seat too. Accessibility to subway, Narita express and JR lines is excellent. They are just within 1-2 minute walking distance from the hotel. In the subway, shops are all interconnected. There are several shopping malls with lots of cafes and restaurants like Kitchen Street and Tokyo ramen Street. All located underground without the need to go out in the cold (in winter that is). Direction to the hotel from the Narita express station is slightly confusing. However once you get your bearing, it is very near. Overall, we had a really amazing stay in Tokyo because of the great connectivity.

This hotel is absolutely stunning! Every person working in the hotel is polite, friendly and helpful. We especially had excellent service from two very competent, friendly and knowledgeable employees, Namiko Hisakura (Guest relations, rooms division) and Tomonori Otsuka (concierge). Ms. Hisakura went out of her way to assist us with Shinkansen tickets the night we arrived and remembered us later in our stay by going out of her way to say hello. Mr. Otsuka helped us with our day trip to Kyoto. He recommended - and set up - a driver/tour guide to meet us on the platform in Kyoto and take us around for the day. This made our trip to Kyoto so amazing, and we wouldn't have thought of it ourselves. We are so grateful for his expertise. We had two rooms in our party, and were put next to each other without having to ask. The rooms are so quiet and the beds are so comfortable. We also really enjoyed having afternoon tea next to the lobby. We have fabulous memories from The Tokyo Station Hotel!

everything is perfect in this hotel. the service was good, the room was beautiful and most important, the bed was very comfortable! I also found some of the best restaurants in this hotel. i will definitely stay here again when i go back to tokyo.

We chose this hotel for its location to Tokyo Station and its luxury charm. It did not disappoint on any front. We arrived late in the evening to Tokyo, via Narita Express, and were very pleased that we only had to navigate to the Sth maranouchi exit to find the hotel. The welcome was polite and efficient. Our room although sufficient was a little small as one could approach the bed from one side only, double bed. The bathroom was well equipped with a large shower. We did not use any restaurants as we arrived late and departed early to a Shinkansen train. We did visit a bar and the service was friendly. The decor and luxury feel of the hotel was appealing. We loved the historical pictures of the hotel positioned along the hallway. We did use the the valet service on our departure as the bell girl took us directly to our platform for our Shinkansen train. We appreciated this on our first visit to Tokyo. This is a luxury hotel in a great location and we would love to stay here again. This location is quiet but convenient to the trains!

As the name suggests, this hotel is part of Tokyo station which means that it is extremely well positioned for travelers who need to get to the station at odd hours. The hotel itself has been recently renovated and it is gorgeous! The beds are amazing and the staff are very friendly. Although the hotel is on the pricy side, it is worth a visit even if only for one night to experience it.

My recent stay at The Tokyo Station Hotel has raised the bar for all future hotel experiences. We stayed here for two nights, one on each side of excursions to Kyoto and Osaka. I was concerned about booking Shinkansen tickets during the New Year holiday, which is what initially prompted me to investigate this hotel. I hoped its JR affiliation would afford assistance on this front. They went far and away above what was expected. Not only did their concierge staff handle purchasing our train tickets well in advance, a uniformed porter met us outside our train car each time we arrived at Tokyo Station to assist with our luggage and guide us through the congestion of the station to the hotel. Similarly, each time we departed, we were guided smoothly to the correct train car prior to departure. The logistical assistance alone would be enough for me to recommend this hotel, however, the hotel amenities and staff are similarly and consistently impressive. I cannot say enough wonderful things about this hotel. I look forward to staying here the next time I am in Japan. I may even plan my future travel to include a layover simply for the pleasure of staying here again.

When I think of hotels near central stations I don't associate them with the highest levels of service and amenities. This was a pleasant surprise in every sense. The location is brilliant, the service of the staff is impeccable - like most of Japan, but with a beautiful and traditional formality. The staff went out of their way to help us in every way. The rooms are beautifully appointed and we didn't hear any train noise at all. We will definitely return.

Attached with the train station with less than 1 minute walk. Easily access to underground shopping street with all kinds of restaurants and shops. Hotel breakfast on the 4/F restaurant is great especially the Japanese style food.

A convenient option for your last night in Tokyo so you do not worry about missing your early Narita Express or your return flight. Upscale hotel located inside Tokyo Station. Standard rooms enjoy the type of fittings you'd expect in a five star hotel (including chandeliers), although they are not really spacious. However, even these tiny rooms have rather stunning marble bathrooms. Good front desk and efficient check-in: check-out is not much of an issue, since you're already inside the station; the only thing that may slow you down are actually the endless corridors as the hotel is located in one of the station's wings. At 35,000 JPY this was still good value, although pricing can get unreasonable during the high season.

At the name suggests this iconic hotel is connected to a very busy JR station which is the hub for many different lines. The hotel has two entrances: north and south. Upon exiting the JR station we arrived in the atrium of the station and while signage showed "north" and "south" entrances to the hotel, it was not clear where to enter. Construction in the immediate vicinity did somewhat obscure the main hotel entrance but we managed to find it after exiting the JR station.The lobby is smaller than expected but elegantly decorated. Check-in process was efficient and we were brought to our rooms by a courteous and friendly hotel staff. Rooms are tastefully appointed with classic European flair, and bedding and other amenities are comfortable and in good/new condition. Our rooms faced the street with the construction but noise was undetectable and the quiet ambience of the hotel offered restful sleeps. Breakfast in The Atrium is exceptional. Both Japanese and international food items are available as buffet, with excellent service on hand by attentive staff. It is on the pricey side but well worth the culinary and cultural experience. The convenient location of this hotel is certainly another one of this hotel's many fine features. But we were surprised that guests have to pay to use the in-hotel gym which is a complimentary inclusion in many hotels of a similar class both in Japan and internationally.Overall, this hotel offered us a wonderful stay to add to our fabulous time in Japan.

It is amazing to find this small boutique with excellent location and impeccable service. The room is spacious and very nicely decorated with great bathroom amenities. We had a party of 6 adults and 5 kids staying there for 3 nights and then to Karuizawa and back for one more night before departure. The concierge staff helped us to buy train tickets and escorted us to the train platform to and from Tokyo station. I particularly wanted to thank Ms M Sampei and Mr Otsuka and the Guest service manager (I don't remember the name). They are all polite and responsive to our requests. We also enjoyed the breakfast a lot at Atrium restaurant. Good selection and high quality. Worth to go there at least once although it is very convenient to find places to eat around the hotel. I couldn't say more of this hotel but will definitely go back on my next visit to Tokyo.

We had a very good stay at this hotel recently.The hotel is great and we loved it.I will start with some minor negatives. The reservation was a bit difficult. E-mails need to be resent numerous times for answer. We were a little bit unhappy to be asked to pay for our kids breakfast. It was fair to pay for my six years old but to also pay for my four years old who does not eat much was a bit unfair. Now this is not a long list of negatives.Other than this everything else is great and the positives are long. First off the hotel is in a great location. Right at Tokyo station where you can catch trains to almost anywhere there is a train. The JR ticketing office is also right beside the hotel. The surrounding area is also great. Walking distance to Imperial Palace and Imperial East Garden. The location at the station makes it a great place to return from the day excursions. Also plenty of good food near and around the hotel.From the reservations we were not expecting much but once we walked into the hotel the warmth and friendliness of the staffs were apparent. Service was very good and staffs were genuinely helpful. We had a good chat with the concierge. The rooms was good with everything in good condition. The classic architecture of the hotel is also very very nice. No huge lobby but a warm cosy feel.Despite being unhappy about having to pay for my kids breakfast we were very happy with the quality of the breakfast. The food was of very high quality and taste is great. Free flow strawberries, melons and other seasonal fruits.I repeat, the breakfast is great.We do however wish that they have a king size bed room where we can add an extra bed. A good thing for families travelling with young kids is that they allow the kids to stay in the same room as long as you can share the beds. In our case we have two of them age four and six in tow.All in all it is a great place to stay if one is willing to pay for it.

This probably one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in & I have stayed in a lot of hotels because I travel for work as well. The location is excellent, it is in a very centralised location with access to both the JR & Metro trains that will connect you anywhere in the city & Japan as well. It is situated in quite a nice neighbourhood & since it's not located in a party or shopping district, a very nice place to come back to after a long day of exploring the city/country. It's also within walking distance to the Imperial Palace. There are still lots of restaurants & cafes around the hotel. You can find convenient stores in all of them. Anywhere from 5-15mins walk.The Japan Post Office is next to the hotel in the Kitte building where you can change foreign currency to Japanese yen at banking rates.The service staff at the hotel is beyond compare, they are efficient, extremely friendly & courteous. Always at hand to help with any travel question or making reservations at your selected restaurants. You usually will need a Japanese speaking person to make reservations. Some of the best restaurants in Tokyo is location in & around this hotel The hotel itself is modern & classy architecture design. Rooms are beautifully done & big for a Tokyo hotel. I stayed in their most basic room size & it's approx. 26 square meter. High ceiling gives you a more roomier feel to the room. My girlfriend swears they have the best beds she have ever slept in. I say enough of good things of this hotel, if this is within your budget, I will recommend anyone who wants a nice, friendly & carefree place to put down roots for a short period to choose this hotel

Absolutely great hotel, very clean rooms and great restaurants. The location is just perfect. Staff is not very friendly, especially in the bar, but the rest of the hotel makes totally up for it. We will come back any time.

We stayed 3 nights at The Tokyo Station Hotel (Palace Side Queen Room) and we loved it. The hotel and guest room are very beautiful. The location is great, very convenient for persons who are arrinving from Narita Airport.The bathroom was huge, with separate shower and bathtub, wich I really appreciate.We only had breakfast once at the hotel and it was very tasteful, although a little expensive.The front desk and bell desk personnel were really friendly and helpful.The guest room is very clean and I felt safe in the hotel as only staying guests can enter the guest room floors.The only complaint I have is that the guest room felt a little cramped. I'd suggest that the big chair and glass table in front of the bed would be replaced by a small bench. However, I did enjoyed my stay at The Tokyo Station Hotel and I'm looking foward to stay there again.

This luxury boutique hotel is located at one of the most complicated railway station in the world, surrounded by high rise buildings and the imperial palace entrance is only within 10 minutes of walking distance.The Junior Suite that we are staying is large by Tokyo Standard at 58sqm. The selection of color combinations and high quality furnishing generates a harmony and classy room ambience, couples with double-glazing glass windows that insulates the noise from bustling street outside. It feels like staying in Oasis of deserts. Beside this, the shower room is huge with strong water pressure. The BVLGARI shower gel smells nice but its aroma can be a little too strong.The hotel offer butler-like personalized services. Always with smiles and polite.For breakfast, It is located on 4th floor of the hotel, the breakfast venue is tastefully decorated, the spread while it is not much but it is up to the standard especially the signature egg benedict, it is highly recommended. However, one quickly get bored when the exactly same breakfast spread is being offered for three consecutive days. Does not worth the value if it is not included in the room plan.Nevertheless, there are a few downsides worth to mention. First, it is the major construction in front of the hotel that blocks direct entrance to the hotel lobby, it is unpleasant to look at from the front window. Secondly, the hotel lobby is too insignificant to the extend that taxi is unable to find the drop-off entrance. There is no hotel staff standby at the taxi drop off entrance, so i have push all my luggages and stroller all the way to the lobby through ramp. This is truly unexpected for hotel at this level. In overall, the experience is good. This hotel is highly recommended to traveler for its central location with easy access to everywhere including the airport access.

we spend a short trip and chose Tokyo because I haven't return for sometime. Tokyo is always on top of the list to visit and never get bore. The hotel was an excellent choice. the staffs were so wonderful. we had very short stay but manage to do all the things we had to. thanks to the concierge team especially Mr. Tomonori Otsuka. The best experience we ever had from points of pick up at the station to check in and out. everything you can think of it's manageable. We enjoyed our trip very much and would recommend to stay. it's a wonderful location and good access to all the places but train, taxi or even walking. the newly renovated rooms and love the high ceiling made the hotel very rich unlike the modern hotels. love the low floor building made it event more intimate. very enjoyable and delighted to introduce this hotel to first timer to tokyo!

An extraordinary hotel in every way, from the greeting to the departure. The property is exceptional - beautiful appointments in the common areas, stylish rooms, and impeccable service. The review asks if the hotel is in a modern style. The answer is architecturally no but the hotel is modern in its understanding of what a great hotel should accomplish for its guests. I would return in a heartbeat. Don't think twice.

Well-appointed luxurious rooms with old world charm and modern day comfort. The high ceiling effectively provides a sense of spaciousness to the rooms. Breakfast was good with a fair selection of Western and Japanese pastries. Staff were friendly and helpful. A good hotel to stay in if you need to commute mostly by trains for your travel, otherwise you might want to choose another hotel nearer to downtown shopping district.

This hotel was beautiful, clean, quiet, and in a very nice convenient location. I took a trip with my 5 year old and when we arrived she exclaimed "this hotel is magical!" Anyhow, the amenities were great (bath robes, slippers for myself and my kid, toiletries, heated toilet seat, luxurious rain shower). Complimentary water. The breakfast buffet was excellent - a nice mix of eastern and western dishes to enjoy. This location is very convenient. The trains & subway stations are all onsite. We never had to step outside the hotel to get into public transport - it rained and snowed during our trip so this was really nice to have. The staff was wonderful and helped us navigate directions on public transport and booked taxis when we needed them. Because it is at the station you might think the hotel would be noisy - no it wasn't. The hotel is very quiet! My daughter and I slept so good each night. No noise and comfy beds! I am coming back in the spring and will stay at Tokyo Station Hotel. Thank you for making our stay enjoyable!

Beautiful luxury hotel right on top of Tokyo station. So easy to get to the Narita Express! Truly lovely and luxurious accommodations with wonderful cafes and restaurants. Service is terrific too. Rooms are elegant and the bath exceptional.

I was traveling around Japan via train so you can't beat the hotel location if you are doing this and visiting Tokyo. Access from the airport via the Narita Express is also obviously another great thing about the location.The hotel building itself is lovely and very well maintained as was my room. The staff are very friendly and helpful and the breakfast buffet offers lots of choices. I would definitely stay here again!Tip: The building is quite long, so it can be a relatively long walk to get from one end to the other. For example, I was staying in the northern end but all the restaurants are located in the southern part of the building so if you have mobility limitations and you want to use the hotel restaurants, you might want to request a room in the southern part of the building.

I had a long layover in Tokyo, and I picked the Tokyo Station Hotel because it was an easy train trip from Haneda Airport. I was delighted by the service and the beautiful view of the dome and the inside of the train station. When I told the bellhop it was my birthday, he came back with a camera and took a great photo that was used for a birthday card I received when I checked out. I wasn't there long enough to use room service, but the room itself was perfect and had everything I needed for my short stay. The service at reception was warm and welcoming.

We had an excellent stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel. This was a foodie/honeymoon trip for us. Prior to arriving in Japan, we communicated with the concierge extensively regarding restaurant reservations. Mr. Otsuka and Ms. Mori were very helpful. They often responded to emails within the hour. When reservations were not available at certain restaurants, they suggested wonderful alternatives and secured reservations for us. Once at the hotel, service continued to be impeccable. From the moment we checked in, staff members greeted us by name. When the lady who helped us with our luggage learned we were on our honeymoon, we returned to our room to find a beautiful swan display and fruit. Every staff member we interacted with was professional, helpful, and friendly. The staff helped us with our forwarded luggage, mail, holding our luggage, and with our cab to the airport. Room service was prompt and always came with a smile. We did not have to ask for help—the staff anticipated our needs and followed through with excellent service. As we do not speak Japanese, we greatly appreciated that the staff members all speak excellent English. Most impressively, the entire hotel staff was always in sync. When we called the front desk for help with our luggage the day that we were checking out, the lady who helped us knew that our flight was going to be late that evening, had reserved a taxi, and needed our luggage to be held by the hotel until it was time for us to head to the airport. When we returned to the hotel that evening to pick up our luggage, the staff member at the entrance of the hotel knew exactly who we were and went to get our luggage right away, without us asking. Among our travels around the world, this is the most well-run hotel we have seen. Truly impressive!

My wife and I were first-time visitors to Japan. Since we were traveling by train, both intercity and in the Tokyo area, we chose the Tokyo Station Hotel for its location. The convenience of being right at the main rail station cannot be beat and the hotel is also a short walk from the Imperial Palace and very accessible to the Ginza and shopping. In addition to its premium location, the level of service from hotel staff is outstanding. As just one example, I inquired about finding the hotel entrance from our Shinkansen train platform; the concierge immediately offered to have a bellman standing on the platform at the precise location of the car in which we were riding to guide us into the hotel. It was another comfort in a big, bustling city to have the lobby staff address us by name after our first day there. An outstanding property.

This hotel is absolutely brilliant and our experience was a lovely one. Started a bit rocky as we did arrive very early off a flight from Australia. The concierge was wonderful - took our bags, greeted us with genuine warmth. We were ushered to reception to check in and while the receptionist was nice but she did tell me check-in was 3pm four times. As an hotelier I understand the situation but did find it annoying to be told over and over as I explained we would be going out for the day. We came back from being out and our room was ready around 1:30 pm and the greeting was again wonderful. From there on it was a brilliant stay. The staff are courteous, warming and so helpful. Clearly they deal with the as individuals and not numbers. The rooms are lovely – spacious and beautifully decorated and with everything you need for a great stay. The next day we had breakfast and again wonderful. We checked out for a day and returned to the hotel and we were greeted as old friends by a number of staff but particularly by a lady at concierge. I wish we got her name as her greeting back was such a nice experience after a long day of travel. They had also kindly upgraded our room. The only negative I can say is the one restaurant we tried Ristorante Enoteca Norio. We wanted to go to Blanc Rouge, the French Restaurant, but you needed a jacket something I do not travel with as I wear them for work. We settled on Ristorante Enoteca Norio and what a huge disappointment. There was a group of business people celebrating something and we were in a smaller area which was fine. Unfortunately it meant poor service which did not start the meal well. Would have been willing to overlook this as the staff and manager were obviously stressed but the food was exceptionally average and very limited. My partner and I will definitely stay at this hotel if we are in Tokyo again and recommend it to anyone travelling to Tokyo but would warn against dining in Ristorante Enoteca Norio.

Treat yourself and stay here. The history abounds, the service levels are impeccable and the attention to detail is second to none. Every staff member was eager to assist. The rooms are large, comfy and yes they have heated toilet seats. Great choice of in house restaurants and so near others in the area. The convenience of the train station and metro is ideal.

Other reviews discuss the location and heritage, all of with which I agree. My comments relate to my experience with the staff when I discovered on arrival from the airport at 9 P.M. that a bag with papers including passport had been left on the Narita Express. The Duty Manager took ownership of the "problem" and within less than 2 hours I was advised that the bag had been found and was waiting my pick up the next morning. There is the evidence of at least two things you hear/read about Japan: their honesty and efficiency. So take my word for it - don't test it yourself. In addition I must add that the area around the station is very interesting, be it small restaurant/bars in parts of station itself or the many stores etc. found in the surrounding buildings. There is info. on the internet worth looking at which suggests" how to spend a whole day in Tokyo station". The construction that is going on caused no issues at all as the sound proofing is perfect and I enjoyed watching the construction. Service by the reception/concierge is also the best I have ever seen. Example, walking us into station to show how to buy/load cash cards for travel and taking our bags and us to platform when we were departing.

First time staying at this hotel as work usually book us in the Conrad Very helpful welcoming staff , bed so comfy getting up was a nightmare lol , perfectly accessible for travelling to other places and shopping as well

We arrived after a long flight from NZ and the the train into Tokyo station. Some one from the hotel met us at the station and helped us with our many bags to the hotel. The hotel itself was beautiful. The service was impeccable and staff very kind to our boys aged 6 and 10. Great location too. The concierge even managed to get us tickets to the Ghibli museum. We didn't eat at the hotel. Easily the best urban hotel I've stayed at.

This was our first trip to Japan and after a long flight from Europe to Narita airport, it was great to simply take the Narita Express (included in our JRpass), arrive at Tokyo Station and to find very friendly hotelstaff waiting for you at your traincar (one has to arrange this free meet&greetservice in advance).Tokyo Station is very big and very crowded, so we were extremely happy to be accompanied to the hotel.The hotel is located at the Marunouchi exit of the station and is in fact part of the station, but once inside, one does not notice the sound of the trains.The hotelstaff is very helpful and kind, the hotel itself has a very luxurious atmosphere and our room, with views to the square in front of the hotel, was spacious and impeccable. During our visit there were roadworks in front of the hotel, but these did not bother us.We had lunch in the sushi restaurant on the first floor. It was good, but a bit expensive. Later we discovered many restaurants either at the station or in the vicinity of the hotel, so one has huge choice.The location of the hotel, right at the Tokyo Station, is both perfect to discover Tokyo and practical to continue a trip through Japan by railway. So, this combined with the fabulous service and quality of the hotel makes the Tokyo Station Hotel an excellent choice.

A classic hotel located at a perfect location.The room decorate well and the bathroom is perfect.All hotel wokers are friendly and helpful.They even guide me to take my train avoid me lost in the busy station.

Beautiful landmark building. We could not have picked a better location for day trips to nearby attractions and sight-seeing in Tokyo; Royal Place is one block away. Small but luxurious rooms. Helpful and courteous staff. Nice discount if you purchase the Japan Rail Pass.

Stayed here for the convenience of the station. There are works going on at the front so fortunate that our room was at the rear. Our room was ok, not huge and a view of a multi-storey car park but was very comfortable nonetheless. Reception did try and upsell a bigger room but at almost £90/night extra we felt this was way too much so we declined. We didn't eat dinner in the hotel, there's plenty around for dinner, although there is a wide selection of in-hotel restaurants.Staff were extremely helpful and sorted out our bag-forwarding, directions and maps etc.The breakfast is remarkable- everything you could wish for really, was probably the best breakfast we've eaten in Japan. We are back for three nights in a couple of days and looking forward to it.

This hotel is brilliant. The staff were absolutely great from the bell hops to the excellent concierge, Marie who could not do enough for us and the reception managers, Mr Tahara and Mr Hiroma.This was complimented by the extremely convenient location and the high quality of the accommodation. There rooms we booked were very well sound proofed. That bathroom is magnificent.There are an abundance of shops and restaurants in the station's basement level. Food was very reasonably priced and there is also a ramen street below.The hotel is also suroounded by many cafes and restaurants. To top it off, Marie very kindly arranged for us to be accompanied to the platform for our next destination. This is one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in.Will be back the next time I am in Tokyo. Keep up the good work management and team!

Elegant hotel, Excellent concierge A great classic hotel! It was very clean and nicely renovated.
