With its convenient location, we saved a lot of time in travelling from and to the airport as well as the outskirts. What impressed us most was the super helpful service from Concierge especially Tomonori Otsuka and Marie. We were provided with many nice dining options which made our stay even more fulfilling! On our way departing to the airport, Tomonori even guided us through in the JR station. We had never had such friendly service ever. In a nutshell, we were very happy during our stay and would definitely recommend this hotel to our friends!

This is a great location right in Tokyo station. Staying here was a super experience as it has everything you would expect in a top quality hotel and is not at all like a modern, impersonal luxury hotel. I would strongly recommend it. I shall never stay anywhere else in Tokyo.

Location is very central and fascinating building within the railway Station. Service very attentive, amazing breakfast and nice SPA. Performing internet connection, ideal choice both for Leisure break or business trip.

During our trip in Japan on october, we choose the Tokyo station hotel as our home in Tokyo. The choiche was perfect, as we have been received a warmfull attention, not normal even in a 5 star luxury hotel. For example I have lost my cell phone on a taxi in Kyoto and mr Tomonori Otsuka, concierge, and his staff, were able to organize all the necessary stuff to find it in the lost e found in Kyoto and to have it delivered to the hotel just in time for my departure. All of this with kindness. There is nothing to say about rooms, public spaces and breakfast: 5 star rating. The position is also perfect for it's position in the heart of the city.

Have been eyeing on this Tokyo Station Hotel for a while, but it's always fully booked. Decided to make an early booking to experience the hotel for 3 nights and was stunned.The room was absolutely amazing with beautiful settings, comfy bed and spacious bathroom.Located next to Tokyo Station which make travelling really easy, even though it could be really crowded during peak hours as it serves as one of the major stations..

This hotel is beautiful. From the colonial architecture to the elegant interiors, it really is a great hotel to stay in. The hotel is located right at Tokyo Station, which makes it very convenient to go around, whether going to other places via other train lines or walking around Ginza area, it is wonderfully set. The room we had luckily overlooked the front of the hotel, so we were able to see the bustle of people going through. The room itself is luxurious and elegant. The staff were very gracious and helpful giving us directions to places we wanted to go to, and recommended a few other things to try out. The lobby, cafe and dining areas were all beautifully set and elegant. It felt being in a completely different place. This hotel is definitely on my list when I come back to Tokyo. Loved it a lot.

Entry not easy to find when arriving by airport express. Need to go to South exit. Once there check in was very efficient. Long walk along corridors to our room. However, once there pleased to find a very large room with large bathroom with bath and separate shower room. State of the art toilet with all the bells and whistles. Hotel is very clean and comfortable with very friendly and helpful staff. When we returned to our room one early afternoon and it was not made up we were given complimentary coffee and it was attended to immediately. Overall a very pleasant stay at a central location for exploring the great city of Tokyo.

Tokyo station was built in 1913 and completely renovated 100 years later. The building is cherished by the habitants of Tokyo. The hotel is the best I have ever stayed in and i have stayed in many hotels all around the world. Service was outstanding, they even sent a bell boy to walk us to our train at departure. The rooms are spacious, bathrooms are huge, breakfast in the atrium is grand and the service, never experienced such high level before. The only min point is you have to be ready to wait 20' before you get seated for breakfast as their sitting capacity is limited.

We stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel for 9 nights before leaving Tokyo for southern Japan, and will be staying for another 10 nights on our return to Tokyo. We stayed at this hotel 2 years ago for a similar period of about 3 weeks and found it comfortable, quiet, very well located for rail travel within and outside Tokyo, and the service was impeccable but very friendly. The breakfast in the atrium was probably the best we''ve had in all our many years of travelling around the world. This year was no different and when we arrived, it was ssinf we had never left. We felt we were back home.A number of reviewers have commented about the limited restaurant facilities and, while this is true, it is not a real problem as the immediate area has many good restaurants.The hotel concierge, Marie Antoinette Mori is extremely caring, helpful and knowledgeable and on both our visits was able to obtain tickets for us to the opera, Noh and Kabuki theatre. The hotel staff are obviously well trained and conscientious. We have had the pleasure of meeting the hotel General Manager, Mr. Fusijaki, and the Assistant Manager, Mr. Kamata, who are very focused on providing the best of service and especially proud of this wonderful historic hotel.Thank you to all the staff for a very pleasant stay. We look forward to coming back.

My husband and I chose this hotel for an overnight stay considering the nice accommodations and the convenience of catching the Shinkansen(bullet train) the next morning for our trip to a resort. It did not disappoint. Check in was quick & everyone was friendly and efficient in assisting the guests. The hotel is directly connected to the train station from the ground floor. There is a department store (Daimaru) located near the Yaesu North Exit where you can enjoy strolling & browsing around. Kitchen Street is a place in the same area where you can dine or shop for food items. The hotel also has an entrance/exit midway to the Yaesu North Exit for a shorter walk. The rooms were very clean & comfortable. And so with the bathrooms. Pretty much updated. Would stay here again should we need to go by JR Trains.

The hotel is superbly located for easy access to Tokyo metro and Tokyo Station. The rooms were a good size and beautifully decorated and presented. Staff were welcoming and most helpful. The breakfast was amazing!

Our travels this year to Japan included attending the Shinto wedding of our son and daughter-in-law with travels afterwards to Kyoto and back to Tokyo. Finding a central location in Tokyo was important and by all accounts the Tokyo Station Hotel fit the bill. Upon arriving at the train station on the Narita Express from the airport one has to navigate 5 floors and literally thousands of people in a maze of corridors to find the way to the hotel entrance. Luckily our daughter-in-law is Japanese and was the perfect guide. The hotel itself is operated by Japan Railways (JR) and will be somewhat familiar to those who have stayed in similar properties once owned and operated by the Canadian National Railway in locations such as the Chateau Frontenac in Quebec or the Chateau Lake Louise. All of these properties including the Tokyo Station Hotel harken back to a day when train travel was romantic, exciting and sometimes even thrilling. While the actual train station associated with the Tokyo Station Hotel has undergone vast expansion to accommodate thousands of daily commuters once you step into the Hotel you are transported into another world of quiet confidence and luxury. Our rooms on both ends of our trip to Kyoto were spacious and well appointed. Service was impeccable especially that of Yoshiki Kamata, the Duty Manager at the Hotel. Front Reception Supervisor Tatsunori Watabe was a true professional and worked out last minute arrangements for us. My suggestions for the hotel are as follows: provide your guests with seating areas to sit and relax. The two hotel restaurants were restricted to those eating and drinking. A $15 cup of coffee was, I was told, intended to prevent guests from lingering. That is nonsense in a hotel charging on average $500 per night. The workout room was closed the weekend I was there and opens later in the morning usually. A international hotel of this stature should provide hours of operation more in tune with travelers needs. All is all the location could not be beat, a short walk to the Ginza area as well as the Royal Palace. We look forward to our return.

We stayed 2 nights at this wonderful hotel and we were so glad we did. The service and staff is outstanding. They have a "meet and greet" service they offer ( free) so they meet you at your train car when you arrive at crazy Tokyo station....so wonderful not to have to negotiate that bewildering station yourself. It was so nice to see a smiling ,white-gloved hotel person with a sign with our name on it as soon as we stepped off the train from narita. Same when we left Tokyo,...they escorted us to our train.our room was so large, huge bathroom...amazing comfy bed. We did not eat at the hotel so can't speak for the restaurants. Tokyo station is attached to the hotel so there are so many food options available right at your location. It s an easy place to arrive and leave from and the staff is top notch service and luxury. We felt pampered and relaxed for our short stay in Tokyo. They will help you do everything you need to do.

Can't beat this hotel for location. Directly above Tokyo main station. So easy if travelling to or from the airport or anywhere else in the city or further afield on the shinkansen. Hotel is beautiful and service is superb at the front desk and in the restaurants. My only criticism would be the layout of the room which made it impossible for us to have both suitcases open and not have to step over them continually.

beautifully decorated, comfortable hotel with boutique atmosphere, although quite big. Very well located and well connected to the whole of Tokyo. Very friendly and helpful staff. Large soundproof rooms and bathrooms. Beautiful spa and gym facilities, which should be free of charge at this high price level of >€650/ night. Very complete breakfast, but be aware it gets busy and you might have to wait 15-20 minutes before you can get a table. One of the best hotels in Tokyo, without snobbism, but with a personal touch.

The hotel is not only amazingly beautiful and very centrally located, but the entire staff is amazing when it comes to service.. The concierge help us to book a private tour and went out of their way to help us in many ways. I strongly recommend this hotel for anybody looking for the best in Tokyo.

This hotel is not noted for its views, as it is long and short, and you might find your window looking into a blank wall. Otherwise, it's a great place to stay--the rooms are fairly large by Japanese standards, and very clean. The location is ideal for getting around Tokyo or if you're heading out to other cities. The buffet breakfast, though expensive (it's Japan) is excellent. Best of all is the hotel staff, who were unfailingly friendly, courteous and eager to be helpful.

In the beginning of this year we had the opportunity to stay in this beautiful hotel twice. We were super welcomed both times and amazed with details and genuine care from the staff. Apart from the great location and beautiful building you will enjoy every moment of your stay starting with breakfast ! unforgettable ! Selection is superb but presentation was above expectations. My husband and I are hoteliers and I must say that making a breakfast a special moment nowadays is more and more difficult, eventhough this team made it! Porcelain with baby decoration for Emma (my daughter of 3 years old) was a small but very thoughtful touch, the colors and patterns were planned in advance, somehow different from all the rest I saw before. Matheus my son of 5 years old was allergic to soya and it was impressive all the efforts everyone did with no exception in order to protect him from a crisis. In japan being allergic to soya is really a nightmare but again Japanese people made us realized how professional and amazing they are. Before wishing a nice day they delivered some really nice cookies for later in the breakfast room. Another nice detail. The Bellboy went all the way to the train station to make sure we would not face any inconvenient with the train to Nagano!! always with a smile and 2 very heavy bags (once you are in Tokyo Train Station you understand better this comment). I could write more and more but you have to experience. A special comment about Marie Antoinette Mori ... a super Guest Relations Manager that will make everything possible to please you.

Larger than usual (for Tokyo) rooms, very comfortable room and well appointed. Stayed in dome king room overlooking train station entrance in a heritage building. Breakfast was held in a lovely room at The Atrium. Wifi speed was excellent. Customer service was very good.Lack of facilities - fitness and spa centre is not complimentary for hotel guest. Should consider more variation to breakfast menu each day.

We decided to book because of the convenient location but the hotel exceeded our expectations.Very special mention must be made of the services provided by the concierge Ms M Mori. Simply splendid.Hope we have the opportunity to stay again.

Here for a business trip and my Japanese colleagues had arranged a stay in this hotel. Was here last yearbut utilised its banquet hall facilities. Even then I was impressed by the majestic setting in such a historical building. Rooms were of a right size and with good facilities. Fantastic staff - would love to stay here when i visit next.

Had a night to celebrate anniversary. Excellent hotel room! Small I had with the dome king, however, love the washroom very much! The breakfast upstairs is recommended to try! Only stay in person to have the breakfast as needed the key pad into the restaurant. Definitely will visit again with any chance to come Tokyo!

Choosing to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel was a great experience for my wife and me. I have traveled to Japan four times now, and the Tokyo Station Hotel will be where we stay while visiting Tokyo in the future. The price was reasonable; the rooms and facility are beautiful; the staff was helpful and courteous; and you can't be more conveniently located than staying in one of Tokyo's main transportation hubs.

Only stayed for 1 night en route from Singapore to Osaka & Kyoto, but enjoyed every moment at this wonderful property. Very conveniently attached to the Tokyo Station, check in was efficient and kind, just like always in Japan. The room was small but very comfortable with luxurious bedding. Loved the bathroom and toiletries, huge ceilings, just beautifully remodeled. Would highly recommend this property. We'll definitely be returning.

This was a grate location for Tokyo. Beautiful hotel. Sadly the facade was not visible and there was considerable construction when we were there in August. Our room was very nice, bathroom quite amazing. We did the breakfast that offered no al la cart but buffet our first morning at a cost of c. $40. Lovely tho it was, and the setting wonderful, that seemed high to us.

My Hubby and I stayed here from 23rd Sep to 1st Oct.... had a fabulous stay... let me list the pros and consPROS- Most staff spoke fluent English so it was easy to communicate - breakfast spread was excellent - Service was beyond my expectation, we celebrated our wedding anniversary at the teppanyaki restaurant, they really took good care of us and even provided a complimentary cake n sparkling wine, and photo greeting card for keepsake... very thoughtful - location of this hotel is great... right above the Tokyo JR station, super convenient to go everywhere - We could take a short 5min walk to imperial palace part for our morning jogs, love it...CONS- since we needed a smoking room, only a queen bed room was available, in fact we checked and they only had queen rooms or 2 bedroom suites.... would be excellent if they converted a king bed room for smoking in futureWill we stay here again.... Definitely yes

The hotel is very European in style. The location is perfect. Direct access to the railway and subway system. The standard double rooms are beautifully decorated but very very small. Not enough place to open your luggage. The breakfast is good with many options.

We very much enjoyed our stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel which combines the amenities of a top class hotel with a fantastic location from which it is easy to get to most areas to visit in Tokyo. The staff was friendly and helpful and made sure our stay was as comfortable as could have been.Most of all, we wanted to extend a big thank you to the Concierge desk - Mrs Mori and her staff. Not only did they manage the impossible by booking us a table at a restaurant where reservations are difficult to obtain, they also managed a bit of magic when the babysitter we had booked for the evening didn't turn up at the last minute.We were faced with the prospect of losing the reservation and having our evening spoilt, but Mrs Mori speedily (and miraculously) made arrangements for the kids at a daycare nearby. She immediately led us there and helped us check them in (they had a wonderful time and were very well taken care of), then quickly put us in a cab on our way to enjoy our evening. Mrs Mori and her team are a model of efficiency and a true credit to their profession. Thank you again and hope to be back soon!

We stayed here for just one night at the end of our two week Japan jaunt last month. We would definitely return here without hesitation.The hotel is just the type I like - new and fresh but in a heritage building oooooozing style and character. Absolutely loved that. And after catching the shinkansen all day up from Kyushu way down south, so great to walk off the train and head up to the hotel right there, so easy!The place is stunning. Absolutely gorgeous. We visited the Mandarin Oriental earlier in the trip which was spectacular; but I still far preferred Tokyo Station Hotel. It was so much more interesting than just another luxury high rise (stunning though it was!).The staff were above and beyond. I have to give HUGE thanks to Marie at Concierge! She deserves a pay rise and a promotion. Absolutely brilliant. We were in touch on email several times in the weeks prior to our stay - she got us a hard to source restaurant reservation we were seeking and provided other assistance above and beyond. My partner and I were so impressed with her professional and friendly service. The hotel is lucky to have her. We were happy we also got to meet her in person on check in which was nice after so many emails!Our king room, on the palace side, was really large and had soaring ceilings and a huge bathroom and amaaaazing comfy king bed as you would expect - after three nights on a futon in a ryokan with dodgy pillows, we slept like two kings (or queens, as the case may be haha).Finally, on departure, I asked what direction we needed to go for the Narita Express. A delightful lady from concierge walked us the entire way to the platform....which actually was very involved and took at least ten minutes. What service! Thank you Tokyo Station Hotel....we will be back! Don't hesitate - book your stay here STAT.

The hotel is in a great location and is pretty comfortable with helpful staff and would be ideal for tourists, but is less suited to the business traveller. The rooms were a little small and dark. I will probably not use it again for work purposes.

The location is perfect, right in the train terminal. And, amazingly, my room wasn't very noisy. The facility is beautiful, world class. The staff is attentive to your every need. The room was lovely but a bit small. The food was excellent. The buffet breakfast was unrivaled. The hotel has an exquisite spa. And, my favorite part of my brief stay is that the concierge insisted that his porter take my friend and me and our luggage all the way to platform of our train. The Tokyo train station is huge and can be extremely confusing, especially with a language barrier. We were going to Narita Airport on the Narita Express and didn't need the extra anxiety of traversing the confusing train station. The escort was invaluable. Although the price of the hotel is high, we got quite a good deal on a Japanese hotel website, Jalan.net. Great experience!!!!

Stayed for 2 nights in this historic, grand, quiet and conveniently located hotel. Staff friendly and very helpful. Our room on the palace side was disappointingly small and rather claustrophobic, even by Japanese standards. Queen bed in the corner next to wall with barely enough space to get in that side of the bed. Only room for one bedside table, nowhere to put luggage. Should really be a single room. Would I recommend it - certainly but only in a bigger room.

We chose Tokyo Station Hotel as we needed somewhere comfortable to stay between flying in to Narita and catching a train the next morning. I also chose them because of their Meet and Greet service on the platform at Tokyo Station. Everything worked perfectly, the bellhop was waiting outside the carriage as my Narita Express pulled in! As it's owned by Japan Rail, the concierge also bought my complicated regional train tickets for me before we arrived, which took the stress out of our short turnaround. The location inside the Station is incredibly convenient, and we snuck in some tasty bento from Daimaru for a lazy and cheap lunch while we recovered from our flight. The international buffet breakfast in the cathedral ceilinged Atrium was one of the best I've had, and the restoration of this beautiful old building is wonderful to see. Bar Oak, their newly opened intimate whisky bar, is a darkly gleaming wonder and pleasantly non smoking. We would stay here again in a heartbeat, and truly hope we do!

Amazing hotel a blend of the old world and impeccable service. Bedrooms are big for Tokyo standards and the bathroom is amazing. Absolutely convenient as a base of going around since all transport options are available although a bit confusing at first. Very friendly staff specially the concierge who took great lengths of stratifying our foodie queries.

I spent two weeks in this hotel, having arrived from Kyoto. Check-in was very fast and all of the staff were very professional and courteous during my stay. The concierge came with me to fix me up with a Suica card and when it was time to travel home a staff member escorted me to the Narita Express platform. First class service!My room was slightly cramped, which also meant that there was not much shelf space but I think this is probably the norm for Tokyo hotels. On the other hand it had a very high ceiling and very high windows which made it feel bigger than it was. In addition, it probably had the best combined bath and walk-in shower room of any hotel that I have stayed in. The room was immaculately cleaned each day and all consumable products (toiletries, tissues etc.) were topped up or replaced straight away. There were also some very high tech features - a large 4K TV screen; an automatically opening/closing/flushing toilet; and a lighting setup that could be fully controlled from the bedside.A huge bonus is the hotel's location, inside Tokyo's main railway station, with the metro just outside. It was so nice after a long day's travelling to get off the shinkansen and be in my room within two or three minutes. Finally, the hotel had a nice "feel" to it. That is something you can't put into words but it does count for a lot. After two weeks it felt a bit like home and I was sorry to leave. I would definitely like to stay again and I highly recommend it to anyone.

We arrived after 10 hrs flight from Australia . Our 2 y.o toddler vomited both on the plane and the train. We looked filthy and exhausted. We arrived at 1 pm and yet to find out that check in time was 3 pm. Hotel staff responded to our request to look after a sick kid and arranged a room for us to freshen up. We were very grateful and appreciated their help. That's top hospitality and truly amazing customer care. To top that, our room got upgraded to a suite. It was humongous and the decor are absolutely gorgeous! If I ever get to come back to Tokyo I would pick this one for sure!

The people at this hotel have a true service mentality. They think of the little things, like walking me to the train ticket office to help me buy my Shinkansen ticket, walking me to the track, having my stored luggage already in my room when I got back--before I checked in. Thanks, Otsuka-san!The location is so incredible if you are using the trains, and the hotel is impeccably restored. The restaurants and good and not too crowded, the gym and spa are nice.Right now, the rates are terrific--I shouldn't be so flattering; I want them to stay that way!

It's an SLH hotel (small luxurious hotel), but there is nothing small about this one.A wonderful rebuild on the classic central station in Tokyo, with impeccable manners above even Japanese standards and absolutely every detail taken care of.My stay was with colleagues who all enjoyed the visit and the service as well as our mad western breakfasts, mostly with either waffles or bacon and chips !!!!Gym time on return to get over the wonderful cuisine, well done Tokyo Station Hotel.2 grumbles - they had building works in front of the hotel that were not noisy but full scale and the prices even for Japan were a little excessive relative to the hotel amenities. Superb venue for downtown staying.Fab

Kamata-san (Lobby Manager) and his staff welcomed me to the property with heartfelt hospitality and detailed arrangements, eg check in/out and concierge. They made my visit in Tokyo felt less foreign with fluent in English. Hotel reception counter offers Currency Exchange with fees- very convenient if you in case did not exchange enough at Airport Exchange or from your foreign banks. Their breakfast at the Atrium is impeccable with a wide range of Japanese and Western style breakfast. You might find more Japanese locals than foreigners- which also is a very distinctive indication that the Tokyo Station Hotel is a gem the locals approve of. I cannot wait to spend my many more visits with them.

The hotel is massive, it stretches the entire length of the station so the corridors are seemingly endless but the rooms are gorgeous. Don't miss the wonderful Japanese prints along the corridors, these are incredible works of art. Our room had original double-height windowss, probably 2 metres tall. The room was fitted in a traditional English-style, with plush furnishings giving it a feel of the glory days of travel and luxury. Like everywhere in Japan, the service is impeccable. It's very close to great eating on the streets and in the station, an easy stroll to the palace and wonderful parks.

Stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel for one night in April 2016 (wish we had booked for further nights). We chose this hotel as it was located right at Tokyo Station and we were on an early morning bullet train for Kyoto. The staff were extremely helpful and stored our cases for us even though we were not coming back to stay and they also had a staff member walk us to the correct platform to catch our train. They could not have been more helpful and pleasant and we were very happy with the service they provided. We would recommend this hotel for anyone staying in Tokyo as it is central, close to the transport hub to explore Tokyo and is within walking distance of many many shops, department stores, excellent restaurants and bars. We will definitely stay here again. Thank you Tokyo Station Hotel staff.

This is our 4th time with this hotel. Apart from the excellent location and amazing decor and service, the concierge at this hotel, Mori san, is the best thing that can happen to the foodie that want to explore the culinary gem of Tokyo.Since our first stay in 2014 up till now, Mori has been assisting us to booked some of the most difficult to reserved restaurant in Tokyo but this time, she really pulled it off with 2 of the most difficult restaurants in the world in one stay and other Michelin Stars restaurants that requires much effort if you have to book them yourself;- Sukiyabashi Jiro Honten(3 Stars Michelin)- Sushi Yoshitake (3 Stars Michelin)- Quintessence (3 Stars Michelin)- Tempura Kondo (2 Stars Michelin)Take in to the account that my period of stay was just 5 nights, it was very difficult to get all of this restaurant into one trip since the reservation period opened for these restaurant were all in the different time but she and her team still pull this off with other 2 Iron Chef restaurants, Michiba and Chen Kenichi.As soon as I got back home, I instantly booked for another stay on next Feb 2017 with the request for the most difficult to reserved sushi restaurant, Sushi Saito, and along with other 3 and 2 stars restaurants for our next trip and how I delighted to say that the hotel got my Sushi Saito seats covered already! :)Definitely coming back again and again for sure.

Stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel July 29 thru August 2 of this year. The Hotel staff was terrific. Always with a smile, willing to answer questions or provide directions. The location above the subway station was perfect for navigating the city. Plenty of great restaurants in the immediate area. This hotel is the old Tokyo train station that has been completely restored with all the modern amenities.

Wonderful hotel and service. We stayed a total of 5 nights checking in 3 times as we traveled around Japan. Pros- Tokyo Station Hotel is located a the train station--easy access to all trains and subway--as well as taxi access.-Staff were courteous and extremely helpful-Provides escort and baggage transport from narita express arrival platform to hotel-much appreciated after a long tiring flight-Provided additional luggage storage while we visited other cities.-Buffet breakfast had an excellent selection of local and western foods.Cons-Internet access was essentially nonexistent--both in our room and in the hotel lobby.-We stayed in 3 separate rooms which were markedly different. Make sure to request the palace side for larger rooms and an open room layout. The king room on the dome side was cramped/oddly laid out and the window looked onto the train station. Prices for all 3 rooms were comparable--

My wife and I stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel August 21 - 24 for three nights and it fully met our expectations regarding location, staff courtesy and assistance, comfort, and cleanliness. Upon our arrival at Tokyo Station from Kyoto, it was a very simple walk to the hotel reception which we later learned was directly accessible from the station via the Marunouchi South Exit. Our check in was very pleasant and easy with excellent English spoken by the staff and we were escorted to our 3rd floor Superior King room on the palace side by a staff member who brought our bags on a cart. The room created a very favorable impression upon walking in, the 430 square feet was quite large by Japanese standards, the bathroom and shower were outstanding in design, comfort, and cleanliness. The location was perfect for accessing the Tokyo subway system for day trips to outlying areas as well as taking the Narita Express to the airport upon leaving. We walked around the area as well, visiting the Imperial Palace Gardens and other areas. I will definitely stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel should I return to Tokyo and do not hesitate to recommend it to others who are unsure of where to stay. The location, staff friendliness and courtesy, comfort and cleanliness are outstanding.

We spent 4 nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel at the beginning of August 2016.The property is just as you can expect from a hotel of this standard: wonderfully convenient location, nice decor, good and friendly service, etc.We were in a double room which is, to be quite honest, a bit compact for two, but nevertheless nice and with a beautiful and spacious bathroom.Breakfast is just great and all the waiters and cooks are simply wonderful!!Service is generally very attentive: they were really helpful in sending our luggage to our next destination.Location is hard to beat: is not Shijuku, but for those who travel by trail on JR pass is the only place possible with access to airports, local JR lines and of course Shinkansen!!A truly excellent hotel!!

This marks my 4th stay in the hotel within just a year. It always makes me feel at home and relax whenever I visit Tokyo.The staff here are extremely helpful! It seems that they can always achieve any "mission impossible" I request, regardless of helping me with heavy luggage and showing me the way to the platform and seeing me off until the train closed the door, or making a bus reservation to Fujitsu Highland.Without their assistance, it was not likely for me to take train to Narita Airport when typhoon hit Tokyo on Augusy 22. I want to especially show my sincere appreciation to Mr. Otsuka and Ms.Hisakura for their help. Thank you for your professional assistance and warm friendship! Hope to see you soon again!

One of my favorite hotels in Tokyo. It's location above Tokyo Station is extremely convenient to go almost anywhere in Toyko, except maybe Shinjuku. Even though it is directly above the station, it is quite. Rooms are nice, get one with a king size bed (most are twin). Good breakfast buffet. Great concierge service!

Stayed here for work as it's a 5 minute walk to Oazo, Shin-Maru Bldg and Maru Bldg. Proximity to the station cannot be beat - the hotel backs the Chuo Line platform but due to the soundproofing, you will not hear the trains. It is decorated in a style that may have had the Orient Express in mind. Room was large enough for a work trip and bathroom was reasonably spacious for Japan.Beware that it spans the length of Tokyo station (ie, 10 car commuter train length) and there are only two entrances (one requires a room key card) so it may take longer to exit the hotel than you think. It didn't bother me but may put off some.

I was slightly disappointed when the travel agent suggested this hotel. I wanted somewhere a bit smarter, but when I arrived I realised that he had made a perfect choice. This hotel was extremely smart, the staff were extremely helpful, friendly and courteous. We were upgraded to two x 2 floor suites. The suites were beautifully appointed with living rooms and hexagonal bedrooms. The breakfast area was bright and attractive and it served a varied selection of Japanese and international breakfast favourites. The location of the hotel was perfect for us, allowing us to walk to nearby attractions but cabs were always available outside whenever we needed them. My only slight disappointment was that the gym opened at 10am on the day that I wanted to use it. I have never heard of a hotel gym opening so late. It looked very nice but I can't comment on it. If you are looking for a hotel in Tokyo, don't waste your money on the so called Luxury brand names, stay here instead. Although we were lucky with our rooms be prepared for small rooms if you haven't opted for a suite. Tokyo hotel rooms are generally small.

Flawless twin room overlooking the street. Amazing design and comfortable beds. Impeccable breakfast spread ranging from Western food to Japanese food. The staff are quite welcoming and respectful. The hotel was right above the metro station with trains that easily transported me to other neighborhoods like Shibuya. I would stay here again!

We only had one night in Tokyo before we flew back home in our 2.5 week trip in Asia, and we stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel. This hotel is wonderful in all aspects. Best of all, the concierge was able to secure a reservation for Sukiyabashi Jiro Roppongi Hills for us. Many thanks!

Located at Tokyo station, it offers great convenience to explore Tokyo by JR line or access to Shinkansen (station next to hotel). Room is clean and offers good amenities. Like typical hotel in Japan, don't expect any window view though. WiFi connection is good. Staff are helpful. Buffet breakfast spread is great with wide selection of continental and Japanese options. Hotel can be on a pricy side but all worth it.

Very elegant, 5 star staff and oh so beautiful rooms!!!! You would never know that this was located on top of one of Tokyo's most famous train stations. With restaurants galore, 5 star food and easy access to a fantastic city below the train station, we were amazed at how much food and how busy it was below yet it was so quiet!

Wow! Loved our stay. This was our first introduction to Japanese hospitality and what an amazing experience. From our first request to meeting us at the station from Narita- a welcome relief (we would have been lost) to other unexpected requests for assistance that arose- the staff were amazing! Never thought we would have needed help!! Service- have I mentioned how amazingly helpful the staff are? The extremely helpful staff assisted with purchasing Suica card and some difficulties we had when using (think flashing red light, alarm and gates closing! Fine ensued! :) cannot thank staff enough!! ( We recommend just using the JR Railpass. Too easy.)Staff - Just wonderful, helpful staff. Greatly appreciated! The Room- first impression - not spacious ... But absolutely amazing use of space, Think decor and amenities! Beautifully furnished and finished. Luxurious bathroom. Waterfall shower, :) ahhh!! beautiful bath, pyjamas :) lovely bed. We stayed palace side (yes, construction at the time). Very, very long hallways to room. Great photo and exercise opportunity :) Location - within the Tokyo Station Precinct - trains, buses and taxis at your doorstep. We booked the JB Dynamic Tokyo tour (Excellent Tour- convenient pick up point, decent food ). Location- Plenty of food/drink options, nearby. Wandered several streets away into a busy salaryman bar - fantastic prices and experience. Will post photo - don't know what the name is...would love to know the English translation...Tip - Regularly check prices/Book early - prices varied widely and were more far expensive closer to stay. We paid AUD $750 for two nights.

Had an 8:30pm arrival flight into Tokyo and wanted a nice hotel easy to get to from Haneda Airport at night for a 3-day layover waiting for a cruise around Japan. It was a simple monorail ride from the airport and then a transfer to JR Yamanote line to Tokyo Station. Go towards the Marunouchi exit and you will see (small) signs directing you to Tokyo Station Hotel right after you exit the JR system but not leaving the station building. Since rain was predicted in the long-range forecast (it was the "rainy" season and I booked about a month out since this was the last part of a 5-week trip) looking for a fully covered transport option was critical. It was a tad expensive (think South Beach FL) but the room was large and had a very nice bathroom. A luxury hotel on par with any Ritz, Peninsula, or other luxury brand. I think when you consider the cost of a taxi to/from airport, the expense balances out taking the train and spending more on the room. Note that when you get a "palace side" room you can only see high-rise buildings since this is a couple blocks away from the Palace; not an issue unless you think you will actually see the Palace from your room.

Nice hotel in a very busy part of town. We were only in Tokyo for about 24 hours so selecting a location literally connected to the train really saved on time (and mental anguish).Facility was clean (typically Asian sized) and staff were very helpful.In spite of good planning I would have benefited from better directions as I moved from the train to the hotel (but that's not the hotel's fault).

We finished our Southeast Asia trip to Cambodia and Vietnam and hope to enjoy a night's stay at Tokyo once again for their cuisine. We had stayed at the Peninsula and the Mandarin Oriental before and we have walked into the Tokyo Station hotel about two years ago when it first opened and saw it was nicely décor to our taste. Being at the Tokyo station, it was probably the most convenient 5 star hotel with the lowest price we can get apart from the Shangri La and the Four Seasons. The service was nonetheless, one of the best and "Top Notch" we had experienced! They use "Bell Girls" instead of Bell boys and we were escorted to our room through the long corridor on the 3rd floor. The room wasn't big like the other 5 stars but the bathroom was quite large for it's proportions and it has a walk in shower for two persons plus a tub as well. They even had pyjamas for us to use, lots of nice amenities, etc. Upon our check-out, the Concierge walked me to buy the Narita Express tickets which the booth was located right next to the hotel's side door, they have also sent 2 "Bell girls" to escort with us and our luggage all the way down to the train station platform, felt like we were really treated like "VIP's" and I would definitely stay there again in my next visit to Tokyo.

This is definitely one of the best properties in Japan.Feel the timeless elegance from beautiful architecture and Japanese understated hospitality.Hotel staff were gracious and helpful as if they were your long-time friends.You can choose luxury rooms with Marunouchi city scape view (a night scene is especially so brilliant) or guestrooms positioned along the North and South Cupola domes of Tokyo Station. The most good location hotel in Tokyo, thew are right inside Tokyo Station.You don't need to feel any stress of the acces from/to Narita or Haneda international/domestic airport. Can ride a bullet train (Shinkansen) which is the state‐of‐the‐art Japanese technology, like as door to door! The meeting place of Hato-Bus (the most famous sightseeing bus tour company in Japan)is near and Taxi stand is right front of the hotelGood balance of a sense of security and excitement to coexist.Very highly recomended!

After several attempts finally managed to get a booking at this perfectly located hotel. Right above the Tokyo JR Station, you cannot do better if you base Tokyo as your starting point to eg Karuizawa or even Kanazawa, or in our case this trip, the Izu peninsula. Decor is classic and elegant, service impeccable and the room cosy (with nice bathroom and walk in closet). Will definitely come back (if we will be able get a booking again, and can still afford it)!

Tokyo station is a very beautiful building. It is only 3 stories high and wraps around one side of the station, so the rooms are very spread out. Walking the corridors the first day we got a little lost. Each room has double glazed windows so very little outside noise gets in. All the staff a extremely polite. Every single staff member you come across greets you. I would have given the hotel 5 stars if the breakfast had not been so expensive. I only felt like a bowl of fruit and maybe a pastry, but there was no a la carte menu, so at around $50 Australian my bowl of fruit was outrageous. The other reason for my score was our room very small and directly overlooking a building site. I know that is out of the hotels hands, but the site was not a pleasant view. The room would have been more suitable for one person. (It was a queen palace view.) This was the last leg of our journey and all our rooms had been quite a bit larger. As other reviews have noted, the bathroom was very luxurious. I enjoyed several lovely baths. All in all a beautiful hotel with outstanding Japanese service.

Gorgeous hotel, brilliantly located on top of Tokyo station and exemplary staff. We arrived with our toddler triplets for the first of three stays over the coming three months. The staff were incredibly helpful making our toddlers feel appreciated with cute gifts left in the bathroom. Absolutely spotless and charming hotel. Thank you to the great staff for making our first stay so enjoyable. We will be back!! Cheers, Scott

Fabulous hotel at Tokyo Station. We had been travelling round Japan, staying in perfectly adequate, reasonably-priced business hotel but knew we would be in need of a good night's sleep after a long journey, and before a long-haul flight the next day. So we chose this hotel as it was obviously easy to get to from the station (as in, right on top of it!) and booked the least expensive room we could find. We ended up with a small, unusually-shaped, but extremely comfortable, room overlooking the station concourse. Sound proofing was excellent, so we were not troubled by station announcements, mattress was superb, so we had a great night's sleep.The highlight was the large bathroom. It was worth the stay just for that! Massive bath, separate large shower room, separate WC and central area with sink, mirror et al.Breakfast was expensive but wonderful. Top notch service, huge variety of Western, Oriental and Middle Eastern foods on offer - plus anything you wanted to order...The central location of the hotel means all the sights are within very easy reach. It's also an extremely handsome building, which we didn't think we'd care about, but having stayed in extremely functional/brutalist-looking hotels everywhere else, it did actually add to our enjoyment.So - this is a luxury hotel, and you have to pay for it. However, you will get what you pay for: it's definitely worth it.

We were lucky enough to secure a Palace Side Room for the final four days of our Japan holiday at Tokyo Station Hotel. Whilst pricier than other places I ordinarily book, this hotel is worth every single cent! The entire property is elegant and luxurious, with our room even fit with a chandelier. The highlight for me was the enormous bathtub inside the wet room which I spent many hours in (I seem to always have baths while I'm in Japan!) If you want an extra splurge, the optional breakfast buffet was simply delicious too! The hotel also has a secret passageway into Tokyo Station, which was perfect when we needed to catch the train back to Narita without having to venture into the March cold! I could not recommend this hotel enough as it was just gorgeous. There are quite a few people saying that the hallways were long - Yes, I have to agree that the hallways were quite long and we did get lost inside the hotel a few times (they do provide you with a hotel map though!) For those who are unable to walk for long periods of time, I would recommend asking for a room near the elevators.

I have had an amazing stay at one of the best hotels in Tokyo and was pleasantly surprised with an upgrade to a suite. While some renovation works were going on in the vicinity during the day, it didn't affect my rest.Kudos to Mr Tomonori Otsuka who was most helpful in securing a seat ahead of my arrival at a wonderful sushi restaurant - Sushisho Masa, and giving the cab driver the directions to the restaurant.

We chose this hotel based on location and convenience and received the benefit of so much more. Professional, gracious staff. Excellent restaurants. Beautiful and comfortable decor - high ceilings, plush furnishings and fixtures. Wonderful breakfast room. We felt welcome and well cared for throughout our stay and we will definitely be coming back. Our only criticism would be room service - it was prompt and thorough, but we did not enjoy what we ordered. Given the excellence of the restaurants (especially Blanc Rouge), this was surprising, but it would not dissuade us from staying again. This is a beautifully run and exceptionally well designed hotel!
user_name:
MeandHeTravel
New York City, New York

review_body: Rooms are spacious, comfortable, well-equipped and very quiet. Service at reception, concierge and check-out is excellent.We paid extra for a "Palace Side" room but even normally what you see isn't worth the extra and at present the whole area outside is a large building site. You cannot hear any of the work but ...Also, there was supposed to be a discount for Japan Rail Pass holders but I think we missed out somehow so take care there.If breakfast isn't included in your rate then beware because the cost is one of the highest that I have encountered in a luxury hotel.The entrances are well camouflaged so unless you make a note of where they are you can spend a good few minutes walking outside the station building trying to find the hotel entrances.

Been here everytime when in Tokyo. Great service and great location. The suites here are beautiful, offering a good view of the atrium at Tokyo Station. Concierge are very helpful and can help in many matters regarding the trip. Lots of good places to eat in the vicinity.

Incredibly convenient and stylish hotel. We stayed for the first 4 nights of our Japan trip and returned later for 3 more nights before heading home. We stayed in a Superior King Palace side room. Very spacious and clean with a wonderfully large bathroom and shower/tub. Took the Narita Express in to Tokyo and were greeted at the train and whisked to the hotel lobby. Very efficient and friendly staff. The process of forwarding our luggage to Kyoto was handled flawlessly. Fantastic breakfast every morning in the Atrium. The Tokyo Station location is wonderful. Incredible array of food options and easy access to all modes of transportation. It's so nice to return from a day of exploring and have your hotel right there. The Imperial Palace and Ginza are within a short walking distance.The Hotel spans the face of the Tokyo Station and has very long corridors, but don't be intimidated. There is a "secret" guest only elevator/entrance near the North Gate of the station that will save you a lot of time. Be aware that Palace Side is not necessarily Palace View. There are numerous high rises on that side that obstruct the view from some of the rooms. There is also construction going on out front, and while not pleasant to look at, did not bother us at all with noise. The rooms were very quiet.We would definitely return to this Hotel in the future.

A beautiful hotel with faultless service that is located inside Tokyo station. It really is a perfect base for exploring Tokyo.We were here for three nights and loved every second of our stay.I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone passing through Tokyo.
user_name:
Daniel P
London, England, United Kingdom

review_body: I stayed here one night at the end of my trip to Japan. I booked one of the cupola rooms which looks out to inside of the Tokyo Station train station. I thought that the room was quiet but I would not recommend booking it for more than 2 nights due to its small size and having an inside view. The room was in excellent condition, very comfortable and nicely decorated. The hotel itself is well decorated however it is a sprawling hotel that you actually need a map to get around and it also has unusually long waits for elevators. The staff was helpful and friendly however I found that for most of them their English was limited which is fine (I still got the information that I needed) but may be a concern for some people. The breakfast buffet was very good as was the Bar Oak.

We decided to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel as we needed to catch a train the next morning and made the booking without knowing much about the hotel.What a surprise that the hotel was the in the old station building itself that dates from the 19th century period when Japan was undergoing a rapid modernisation. A beautiful building, with friendly and very helpful staff - nothing was too much trouble.The hotel had been renovated a couple of years ago, but it has been a sensitive renovation and the wonderful sense of history has been retained after the update.The room we stayed in was a little small (by Australian standards) but was well-appointed and had one of the best hotel bathrooms I had ever used. I could have stayed under that spacious shower for hours, if we weren't keen to get out to explore.The hotel is centrally located and only a short walk from the Imperial Palace and other destinations. A great choice of restaurants and bars is close by.Thanks for a great stay and look forward to coming back.

We started our Japan trip with three nights here. We LOVED this hotel. They just get everything right. We loved the intimate scale in the middle of everything. We loved the spacious room with a lovely view. We loved the low key but spot on service. We loved the atrium breakfast room and the buffet. We loved the helpful concierge and pleasant staff. We loved the ice machines on every floor (yeah I know, kind of a rarity in first class hotels these days but there are times I just feel awkward calling for ice and I'm happy to get my own).It's a bit of a struggle, the Tokyo Conrad remains one of my favorite hotels in the world (and we concluded this trip there) but I have to say, I'd chose the Tokyo Station Hotel for my next trip.

Stayed at this hotel with my friend. We both always admired this classic hotel and wanted to stay for a long time. This was my second stay, my first was before the major remodel. It was absolutely fabulous from warm welcome to the guest room that was absolutely clean and updated. It was great that the bathroom and toilet were separated and I loved the big bath tub. The light in the bathroom was adjustable so the atmosphere was very relaxing. We stayed at the dome side room where you can look down the Tokyo station exit. It was interesting seeing people coming and going at one of the busiest station in Japan. I would say this is the best and most convenient hotel in Tokyo because it's located inside of Tokyo station. You don't even get wet when it rains. Definitely want to stay again!

We have stayed at some pretty fine hotels over the years and I would rank this among the best anywhere. It has been completely renovated and the bathroom was as big as many hotel rooms in Japan. The staff is extremely accommodating and the location could not be improved upon. At the moment it is my new favorite hotel. We were in room 3082 and I would request it again. It looks across at the Kitte building and a crosswalk. Each morning we would look out at the crowds and assess the weather by how they were dressed for the day.

We visited Japan for the first time mid May arriving in Tokyo and staying at the Tokyo Station Hotel for 3 nights. The level of service and quality of accommodation is excellent. We had two rooms for a family of 4 and each room provided every amenity we could ask for. The location at the Tokyo Station is superb as you have all the rail and subway options you could ask for. Although the station itself is quite hectic, the minute you step into the hotel and your room it is list an oasis. The one recommendation is better signage for finding the hotel once you arrive at the station. Our family got separated and it was a bit stressful getting everyone back together to check-in.The breakfast buffet is also excellent and truly worth the additional fee. We enjoyed our initial stay so much that booked rooms for our return trip to Tokyo before our flight back to the USA. The hotel will definitely be our 1st choice for any return trip to Tokyo.

So glad we spent our first night in Japan here. We arrived from the Narita Express and were able to immediately go to our hotel and refresh after a long trip - without even leaving the train station! The convenience of the location would be enough for a high recommendation, but it is so visually stunning and sumptuous that it would appeal to anyone who loves luxury or boutique hotels, irrespective of its location. The amenities were second-to-none and it almost felt like staying in a spa, just being in our room. The lounge looked cool and was clearly popular, but alas we were there for one night only and opted to make the most of it by exploring a festival in Akusaka instead. Only tiny frustration was they do not charge your card automatically like in US and Europe - if you don't physically check out they cannot charge your card and you have to fill out several forms afterward to authorize it. Wish we'd known that before we left at 5am for our next stage of the journey!

We stayed in the hotel after a long flight from the US and then an hour on the train into Tokyo. This is an older property, but had been totally redone just a few years ago. Rooms are about the same size as you find in the USA, well appointed. One of the nicest hotels I've been in Japan.

Stayed at Tokyo Station Hotel in May 2016. Stayed one night and stored out baggage while we travelled Kyoto for a couple of days and then came back. really convenient for transport as all trains, including bullet trains, leave from under the hotel. Really quiet, beautiful rooms and bathrooms and great service - special thanks to all the wonderful staff we encountered. Highly recommend. One thing, you can get a bit lost in the long corridors which circle around.

We stayed here for 4 nights at the start of our trip and for one night at the end. Everything about the hotel is lovely, the staff are so wonderful, our room, just a classic room, was lovely, comfortable bed, lovely bathroom and looked was nicely decorated. The breakfast was lovely with enough choice to satisfy everyone's tastes.The hotel is charming in every way.Would happily stay here again and highly recommend it, added bonus being the station is a step away!

We stayed here for 2 nights as our first stop on a 2 week holiday of Japan. As our flight from Australia arrived early in the morning, we booked an additional night so we could use our room straight away and were glad we did. Our king room was on the dome side of the hotel which was very comfortable although small. Being a heritage hotel furniture was reasonably large taking up some of the room space. Good sized bathroom with lovely toiletries as you would expect in a hotel this calibre. Loved the heated toilet which was standard throughout all our hotel stays in Japan. Wi-fi reception was excellent.We tried both hotel bars, the Oak bar with it's extensive whisky menu and the Camella bar which made an excellent martini. On our first evening we dined at Ken Takase's Cantonese restaurant which was very good and worth a visit. Food and service were excellent. As we wanted something lighter on the second evening, we enjoyed some fish dishes in the Camillia cafe and bar.As other reviewers have commented, you had to walk a long way to get to the main lobby or outside the hotel and it did get a little confusing - we didn't mind the exercise though. Staff were very professional although many only spoke limited English. We enjoyed our stay as the hotel was central to everything and thought it was an advantage being right over the train station. Would stay here again.

The hotel is above the Tokyo Station, so it is very convenient to stay at this hotel. It is very elegant, unique, and long history hotel. The view is also great. We can see the palace from the hotel room window. The staffs are kind and professional, especially Ms. Marie Antoinette Mori. When we told her we will like to buy some special sake, she provide us the good vintner where can try the sake. Next time when I come to Tokyo, the Tokyo Station Hotel will be my best choice.

Love that this hotel is literally part of the Tokyo Station. Didn't love the noise of living at the Tokyo Station. They are doing some extensive construction just outside of this hotel when we stayed there in March so very noisy early in the morning. Also you are able to hear the trains in certain rooms (dome side for sure). If your room is dome side, you are also very very far away from the front desk/reception area. Rooms are not very big but the amenities are very complete. Rooms are beautifully designed and super clean.

We booked for one night while in transit through Tokyo. The hotel is certainly convenient to Tokyo station. It is a heritage hotel and lots of old fashioned charm and the rooms are well appointed. Staff were friendly and helpful.On the negative side, our room was tiny and over stuffed with furniture which meant there was little room to move. The hotel is a veritable rabbit warren and we could only find our room by exiting and entering through an alternative entrance. From the lobby we were lost without a staff member in the lead. To be honest, for the cost, it was not worth it.

I just spent a week here and thought it was perfectly located for exploring the city. The hotel sits right on top of a major subway and train station, and hence getting to various restaurants, shopping areas, museums, etc. was a breeze. The concierge and lobby staff are terrific and are eager to share their knowledge. In fact, we were able to eat at several top restaurants in the city because the concierge expertly handled reservations prior to our arrival. The rooms are pleasant but fairly standard. The Gilchrist and Soames products leave a little to be desired, but the hotel makes up for that by providing other amenities such as toothbrush/toothpaste and scrubbing cloths. The breakfast consisted of many high quality Japanese foods and some awesome French Toast, but the juice selection could be improved by serving something freshly squeezed. The selection also can get redundant if you have breakfast over multiple days because the dishes don't really alternate, except for one soup. Overall a really nice place to stay although fairly expensive.
user_name:
ryeguy99
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Lovely hotel in the historic Tokyo Station. All the modern amenities matched with baroque design and 16 foot ceilings. Exquisite crown molding. Nice waking up under a gorgeous chandelier. Good for romance. Excellent staff and spa. Had a king room with a view of the south dome.

The service at this charming, historic hotel cannot be faulted, nor can its level of comfort We stayed in a queen bed classic room for one night and wish it had been a longer stay. The room was very small, making it difficult to get in and out of bed because one side was pushed up against the window. This was the only negative. The room was spotless and tastefully decorated in keeping with the era of the building. The bathroom was large, with high quality fittings and a terrific rain shower. The bed was unsurpassable, I felt like I was sleeping on a cloud, just what I needed after a long sleepless flight. The location is so very convenient for travellers who are using the rail system.

This is a well located, lovely hotel in an historic building. The staff was very kind and helpful and the room was very comfortable. A perfect location for a very early train, just right next door. In addition it is very nicely located for sight-seeing in Tokyo.

My husband and I stayed here for the last night of our honeymoon and it was really great. The hotel is beautiful and the staff are so friendly and willing to help. We definitely received the best service here compared to the other hotels we stayed at in Tokyo. The room was very clean and large.

This is the third time I stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel (see my previous reviews), and it was by far the best of the three stays. Everything went just well - staff were competent, the room was decent, breakfast was nice, and of course the location is top notch.I look forward to my next stay here!

We stayed here last December and it was an unforgettable experience for me (and my wife). The location is great as it is part of the Tokyo JR station and walking distance to Ginza. I also want to commend the excellent service from their concierge desk which helped us to make restaurant reservations.We will definitely be back here again if there is a good promotion. :)

location location location! Most convenient location - personal pick up from train platform. Best Concierge Marie Antoinette Mori!! great recommendations for restaurants, shopping and sightseeing. rooms are spacious and very comfortable.
user_name:
kingcnyc
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed four nights at the end of March, and it was the third hotel we stayed at in Japan and it stood out easily as our best experience. The hotel staff were incredibly helpful, and even arranged a booking for a special restaurant, including printing out a map and direction in Japanese for the taxi driver. The location of the hotel couldn't be better, right in the train station complex (although still private) which was great as we could use our Japan Rail passes to visit places during the day. A very short walk to Imperial gardens, and we enjoyed stopping in at Dean and Deluca each morning for a coffee! Would absolutely stay at the Tokyo Station hotel again the next time we are in Tokyo.

We booked this hotel for its ease of access to the airport express trains, based on its great reputation, and to splurge our last couple days in Japan. Expectations exceeded. The hotel was renovated last year for its centennial. Service is great and the rooms are well designed and cared for. The rooms are decorated classic Victorian with 13 foot ceilings, but everything in the guest rooms and private bathrooms is modern. The hotel has a very nice large lounge on the first floor which appeared to be well used, though we never made it in. Service was excellent. We obtained a room upgrade at check-in as I feared the classic room we had reserved would be a big city "postage stamp" room. The upgrade to a Junior Twin Suite was great and spacious to include large bath room and alcove sitting area. Bed turn-downs with treats was appreciated. One bellhop provided me a tour of the building on request and another guided us through the train station and helped with luggage during our departure. It appeared most of the staff spoke English.Our only critique of the Tokyo Station Hotel is that it did not seem like the station and the hotel were as well coordinated as they could be. When we arrived in Tokyo Station, we never saw a sign directing us to the hotel (Gate 1 of the Marunouchi Line) and it appeared to go in and out of the station to visit shops you needed a subway or train ticket (or a rail pass which we had). The hotel does give rail pass holders a discount, but I'm guessing most of their guests don't use rail passes. We will definitely consider staying here again. Be advised there is a major construction project in front of the hotel just now that can be noisy and partially obstruct the view towards the Imperial Palace grounds.

I am attracted by the grand old European outlook of the hotel and thus willing to pay the high rate to stay for one night (late arrival and early depart). However, due to the major part of the building is used for the Tokyo JR station, the lobby of the hotel is not a grand hall.There are two entrances situated at both sides. We have to walk a long corridor to arrive our room after check in as our room is located at the other end. The 1st time I need to read the hotel map in order not to get lost.The staff are well trained up to a high level of politeness while it is somewhat too much for me. Somewhat similar, I found the level of service at JR station Sapporo Nikko Hotel is more appropriate to me. But I still appreciate that.What disappointed me is that the square before the hotel is under construction work and I can't take a picture of the full view of the hotel. Besides, the modern design of the rain shelter does not match to the old building. It is not common as Japanese are good at keeping their culture and the heritage.

This was maybe the best hotel I've ever been to. Location is great, it's in the same building as Tokyo station. Staff was absolutely wonderful and room was really stylish, spacious and clean. Even the hotel bar had a nice atmosphere. Maybe a bit on the pricey side but it's understandable. I would definitely stay here again when I'm in Tokyo.

This hotel location is right in the station (the hotel name tells it all..), very convenient location for family travellers from narita airport using narita express train with 2 heavy luggage and a stroller :) . The check in is very quick and the staff accompany us to our room after our check in (it's rare experience for me as mostly we go to our room by ourselves and have the luggage delivered later).We pick Dome side room (looking inside the busy train station) because the palace side room view are block by construction going on in front of the hotel. The room itself is medium not too large but not too small. Amenities is excellent, they provide separate amenities for my children (Shinkansen cup, toothbrush, etc) and you can bring it home. They also have pyjamas for my children as well as for adults with shinkansen emblem. The bathroom is excellent with very good rain shower and deep bath tub. you can have a relaxing bath after long hours in flight and train.This hotel is convenient also for travellers that want to ride shinkansen to osaka or to any other place. The shinkansen ticket reservation and the gate to shinkansen platform is right below the hotel. Combini is everywhere and a large mall is very near. Imperial palace is also very near. The check out is also very quick and the concierge is helpful and can speak english :) . We can also put your luggage after check out so we can wander around a little bit before our train depart.All in all, this hotel is a classic yet a modern hotel. My only down side is for me to stay only 1 night at this remarkable hotel, it should be minimal 2 nights i guess, cause my child keep asking me when we are going back to this hotel.

Love The Tokyo Station Hotel. Their service is excellent! Besides the normal good day greetings that we receive from most hotels, this hotel remember their every guests, our needs and greet us by our last name. The room, sitting areas and hallway are neat, tidy, comfy and clean. The location of this hotel is perfect for shopping and travelling to any place in Tokyo is convenient. We also had dinner at the hotel - Cantonese "en" KEN TAKASE restaurant, the food is refreshing and healthy; a blend of Cantonese with Japanese touch.

The hotel was lovely loved the history staff very helpful and nice. Room was great and lovely to have the Australian Asian Channel (via ABC) on television. Enjoyed the lobby lounge and breakfast but food was rather expensive.

The hotel was reminiscent of grand old European hotels. The staff were very warm and helpful and the rooms were immaculate. The design of the room makes it feel spacious with a totally seperate bathroom area off a hallway entrance. The high stud and big windows added to the feeling of space. The location is very convenient, we were overnighting on our way from Hiroshima back to Auckland so we maximised our time by being able to walk from the shinkansen to the hotel and then to the Narita Express the next day. The Station itself has lots of good places to eat and places for last minute shopping.

We were in a classic twin room with no view (not needed here in my opinion). Simple but had the retro feel, reminiscing of its early days in the 1920s. Facilities in the room were in all the right places. Service level is excellent throughout the stay of 2 nights. The highlight was when, Tanaka-san, the smiling porter, brought our luggage and guided us, from the hotel all the way to the track of the Narita Express. It was a difficult manoeuvre, considering he was pushing 2 luggages and it was in early morning rush hour. Breakfast was a special treat here. They served ikura and melon, two japanese specialities which my wife loves. Very nice indeed!

The staff is incredibly accommodating, warm, and friendly. They could not do enough for us. Although the rooms are small, they are adequate and comfortable. The bathrooms are almost the size of the rooms with great showers and Toto toilet seats.

We stayed for 5 nights. This hotel was fabulous great location and customer service the room was small but thats to expect for Tokyo! The only issue was we hoped we had a fluent English spoken person at reception that would have been great. overall was great location close to station and taxis.

We had one night in Tokyo before heading off to other parts of Japan and decided to spend that night at the Station Hotel because if it's convenience. The rooms were a tad small but perfectly comfortable and modern. The hotel was originally built in 1915 but they completely renovated in 2012. The fact that this hotel is attached to Tokyo Station is very handy; we took a train directly from Narita to Tokyo station during a rain storm and never had to step outside. That said, Tokyo station is huge and it took us a while to navigate our way to the hotel. I strongly suggest studying the hotel direction before you embark on this journey. Tokyo Station is not only a large and confusing train station, it's also a huge mall and very crowded. I suggest avoiding/departing during rush hour, also if you plan to depart the station by high speed rail (Shinkasen), buy your tickets early and give yourself extra time to find your platform. The Station hotel is located right next to the Imperial Palace, it was closed on the day we were there but we there but had it been open we would have loved to walk through the gardens before catching our train to Kanazawa. The breakfast buffet was pretty good, they had a large variety of both western and Japanese style foods.

I have visited Tokyo many times in last 5 years, and have always loved the Tokyo station. This is the first time I have stayed in the hotel. This is an historic 101 year old building renovated over the last few years. Meticulous in detail, clean and zen. It is a marriage of ancient and modern. Very friendly staff and an unrivaled location for transiting by rail or doing business in Marunouchi district.Drawback is that the physical structure of the building is 101 years old, and the rooms are connected by a maze of corridors stretching over 300m. The three floors stretch for most of the length of the classical station, and the entrances are a bit confusing. That said, the staff are excellent, the rooms are great and very well apportioned. The walk to room from reception takes ages, but this is the only complaint. Check the Internet for last minute deals. We paid 30,000 yen when other hotels in neighborhood were quoting 60,000 for similar due to tight availability.

This hotel is in a perfect location. Its located inside the JR Tokyo Station. When you arrive at the station head towards the Marunouchi exit keep going and then you will see the exit for Marunouchi SOUTH exit. That's the exit you want. The hotel is tucked away on the right side next to a JR ticket office. We decided to stay at this hotel at the end of our Japan trip. Our last night was in Tokyo and I wanted to be inside the station so we could have a no rush morning heading to the airport. Its about a 7-10 minute walk to the Narita Express. Perfect! The hotel is very nice and clean, actually shiny. The moment we walked into the hotel someone was there to greet us and show us to reception. Checking in was quick and easy. The hotel offers complimentary WiFi in the rooms which works great. We stayed in a King size bed Dome room. The room was very nice, but smaller than I expected. It was actually the smallest hotel room we stayed in during our trip. The room is not big enough for a rollaway bed nor is there a sofa couch. They put side guard rails on the bed because we had to share the king size bed with our 9 year old daughter. For 1 night this was fine, but there's no way I would have done more days with1 bed. The hotel probably has bigger rooms for families. When I booked the King Dome room was the only room available. The bathroom was big. They had a variety of toiletries and a set just for children, toothbrush, cup, and slippers. The room also had bathrobes. The room has 2 complimentary water bottles. We decided not to have breakfast at the hotel for 2 reasons, it was outrageously expensive ($20 for a child, kids barley eat that much) and there are a ton of places to eat in the station. If you are looking for a luxury hotel and plan to be in and out of the station this is the hotel for you. If you aren't planning on using the trains you really should be. They aren't expensive and they go everywhere. Some of the best transportation I've ever seen! Taxis are expensive.

...and I've stayed at some nice hotels. Elegant, tasteful and top notch. Perhaps the nicest bathroom I've ever used. in room available glassware was excellent quality and presentation. Curtious, friendly attentive staff were able to help with our multiple requests throughout our stay. Location is fantastically central for Tokyo, walking distance from Ginza. It's not often you get to stay in a historically important building. If you have the means, I highly recommend it. Would love to return if/when I am ever in Tokyo again.

Service staff very helpful and spoke English very well. First impressions on walking into the hotel from the train station, unbelievable. Room was beyond expectations. Comfortable bed, nice coffee and tea service in the room. Bathroom was large, with several amenities, the shower was luxurious and spacious. Wish we stayed a few more nights.

We chose this hotel because of it proximity to the station for an early departure by Shinkansen for Kanazawa.We were in no way disappointed in the facilities of the hotel. We had a beautiful, modern suite , overlooking the front of the Hotel. Although lots of building works were being done at the front of the station this did not create any noise in our suite. We had decided to have dinner in the hotel . One of the concierge staff came to lead us to the dining room which was a far distance from our suite. This involved walking round a balcony which was in the dome of the station. We were able to look down on travellers as the crossed the floor on their way out of the station. The dinner was excellent. We chose the French menu. Each of the courses was beautifully served and of a high quality. Breakfast in the morning was served in a huge dining area. It was buffet style with lots of choices.We were taken out of the hotel by the station exit which lead immediately into the station.

Room was a bit small and only had a queen (not king) bed, but otherwise it was a fine overnight stay on our way out of Tokyo. Staff was excellent. Good but not outstandng breakfast buffet. Our 'view' was of a wall about 3 feet away though.

Conveniently next to Tokyo station (although finding the door next to Marunouchi South exit can be challenge), which doesn’t seem as large as some other stations but has a lot of conveniences and provides easy access to other parts of the city. The hotel is somewhat opulent but doesn't really wow you and doesn't make great use of its historical value. Common areas can get overcrowded.The room definitely looked good, even if the view towards the castle grounds was mostly over a construction zone (I think I prefer being in a tower for cities like Tokyo). Very quiet due to double windows. The room is large (by Japanese standards) with a good bathroom including a great shower area next to the bath offering rainfall or normal showers.
