Check out time is a pleasant 12pm.The much-trumpeted breakfast had an extensive range of interesting food, and some was clearly higher than usual quality (especially the grilled fish) but the cooked western items seemed very sugary, plus they serve tepid tangy filter coffee (although it might well have been kopi luwak or something silly like that).Overall it’s certainly a good hotel - the best I stayed at in Japan - but it's just what you’d expect from the price (after you account for Tokyo’s high prices).

The lobby is stunning, and the rooms too, with a colonial design, wonderful decorum and a real attention to interior design detail. The bathroom is rich with its Italian faucet and British soaps and shampoo, with marble top sink and bath tub. A single drawback is that noise from toilet can be heard in bedroom, due to non-heavy wood doors. Also, walls in bedroom are not thick, can hear alarm clock in room next door. But sofa, desk, beds are all exceptional quality and design. Ceiling is very, very tall, and possibly, too tall. Breakfast buffet is lovely, both classical and modern, with a grand array of items. Wall sconces in the hallways are a modern interpretation of classical wall lamps. And this wonderful design is all throughout the hotel public space leading to our room - and in the room. BUT, most amazing was the service; the hotel allowed two staff members, to escort us to the Bullet Train platform, with our 6 rolling bags. And this is no small feat, with all the winding turns and difficulty in language of signs and amongst throngs of commuters. This was truly above the call of duty and I would highly recommend this hotel, for this reason alone!

That is a great hotel when you travel in Tokyo, just next to the TOKYO Station and easy to connect with different location around in Japan (The biggest station in Tokyo). Have a great restaurant and with the underground shopping mall as well. If you feel tired, you can try to enjoy their spring with their hot bath facilities, that is so nice and clean but that is not free.

Great to stay in if you need easy access to the station (e.g. arriving late, leaving early), but we found it rather impersonal compared with other hotels we have stayed in, probably because there are multiple ways to access the hotel and there are a lot of people using the bar/lounge etc who are not residents.We did like our room (maisonette!) very much and everything was as it should be, but for an enhanced (and probably cheaper) experience would suggest staying at the Palace Hotel just up the road.

We stayed here for one night upon our arrival in Japan and will be returning for a few nights at the end of our trip. We had a King room which was nicely appointed and spacious. This hotel has it all and does everything first rate: It's immaculately clean, offers every amenity and comfort, and a has helpful, efficient staff. And to top it off, the location couldn't be better. While it's not exactly for the budget conscious, it's worth every penny they charge.

An exquisite hotel and incredibly luxurious! A true five star experience although I felt the staff were a tad uppity and that has impacted my score. At some points it felt as though they were surprised we were guests of the hotel, perhaps thinking we had come in from the street and gotten lost! That aside, the hotel is exceptionally beautiful and I wish I could have stayed longer than two nights.

We chose this hotel mostly because of its location - obviously making it easy to get to and from, and with many attractions nearby. This was perfect as we only had a couple of days in Tokyo on our schedule.The room was superb and quite roomy for the two of us (a maisonette with an upstairs bedroom and downstairs lounge area). There are several restaurants in the hotel - and lots of food options nearby. We also made good use of the spa, and also of The Oak Bar, which boasts a great selection of scotch! Will definitely return.

It is hard to find fault with The Tokyo Station Hotel. It truly is a luxury oasis in the middle of Tokyo. From the moment we first arrived and being shown our room, to when we left 3 days later, we were very well looked after. The staff were particularly attentive and their English was very good. The buffet breakfast in the Atrium was excellent, catering to all cuisines and dietary requirements. Our Queen room, while small, was functional and luxuriously appointed. And in terms of location, it is hard to beat; just a short walk to the subway and JR lines. Highly recommend.

I had such a nice time at this centrally located hotel. You could not ask for a better location. The employees are the most kind and respectful. I went to Tokyo for my Honeymoon. When i arrived at my room, there was a fruit basket and card acknowledging my honeymoon. They also took a picture of the both of us under the beautiful atrium. The staff also met me at the tokyo train station at my actual train to carry my luggage to my hotel. This service is free.

What a wonderful place to be situated! We had eight nights here, with Tokyo station right outside the adjoining door. We did a lot of train travel, and the tour pickups were just down the street too. We had so many choices for meals, right on our doorstep. The hotel itself was delightful - the room was a little small with only one rack for a suitcase, but apart from that it was just lovely.

Stayed 3 nights with spouse and a 5 year-old at their King Mansionette. It was a very large room by Japan standard. I think it's about 65 sqm. The building itself is full of character, being remodeled from the old Tokyo train station. There's a full bath - toilet, shower, bathtub - and a living area with a TV at the first level, with ample wardrobe space. The stairs lead to a very comfy king bed at level 2. There's also a toilet so you don't have to walk the stairs if you need to do your business at night. The service was impeccable. Knowing that we have a child with us, they prepared kids toiletries, bath slippers etc. Everyone we met was extremely polite and professional. The breakfast was delightful with fine food both Japanese and continental.The location is best part. It's situated right beside the Tokyo train station! And one can actually spend a full day to shop and dine and the shops in this station. Very very convenient! It's not exactly cheap but if you are willing to spend this budget on a Tokyo accommodation, I'd highly recommend this hotel. For me, I'd stay in no other place the next time I'm in Tokyo.

Perfectly located right in the Tokyo Station which is extremely convenient for daily traveling by trains & buses.The breakfast here is exceptional ! Very good quality & variety.The staff is super nice & very helpful, they were so nice that once they knew that after checking out we had to travel by Shinkansen (bullet train) - they helped us with all the luggages up to the exact train we took !The only negative thing I could find is that the very very long corridor, it has been quite a long walk when our room is located right at the furthest end of the building.All in all, we would definitely stay here again !

I recently spent 5 nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel, the first 3 of which were for work, and the last 2 were for leisure. It really is the perfect hotel for either. For work, the location is incredible because of proximity to the train as well as central business districts. For leisure it's incredibly convenient if you want to go to any of the popular neighborhoods, usually they're all accessible via subway without having to change lines. The station itself has some great restaurants and things to do, including a Diamaru on the other side, which is a great place to eat and shop.The hotel is very beautiful; they said it underwent a 6 year renovation, and you can see the attention to detail that other hotels just do not have. The bathrooms in particular are really fabulous, especially compared to what you normally would get at a hotel in Japan. Fresh flowers everywhere, beautiful furniture, helpful staff. It was a top notch experience.

I travel to Tokyo regularly for business and on my last two trips have stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel. I have stayed at most of the luxury hotels in Tokyo (Mandarin, Four Seasons, Hyatt, Imperial Palace, Okura, Conrad, etc.) and would say the Tokyo Station is the best value for money when taking quality, location and price into account. The rooms are very nice and clean, are relatively new and have good bathrooms. One complaint is the rooms can be a bit small. On my most recent visit I was given a room that must have been one of the smallest. It looked into the south entrance to Tokyo Station (so not outside) and was in the corner so everything was squeezed in. Perhaps my travel agent booked me a cheaper class of room as on my prior visit the room was more spacious. The concierge is also very good at Tokyo Station. Marie Antoinette has helped me during both my visits and was very knowledgeable and helpful in booking restaurants. Most of my meetings tend to be walking distance from the hotel which is a plus. If I was traveling for leisure I may consider staying in a different area as a bit more lively at night in places like Shibuya, but for business the location is perfect. The train to Narita also departs from Tokyo Station. This is very convenient when after a day of meetings I need to rush to pick up my bag and then get the train to Narita for the last flight out of the day.All in all I highly recommend the hotel.

The Tokyo Station Hotel stands out as a luxurious hotel in an historical building with a very convenient location and best of all, superior service. The Hotel is on the west side of Tokyo Station, literally over, and just a few minutes walk to, the Narita Express. The façade is classic and memorable, as is the interior restoration. Our room was very solid, with absolutely no noise from either trains or the street; it was beautifully decorated and had every modern technological feature. The marble bathroom was most spacious, architecturally pleasing, and well-appointed. Breakfast was a gracious buffet, arranged delicately on several tables for an aesthetic rather than over-whelming experience. The selections were international, with an emphasis on Japanese, and providing dishes one may have longed to try, as well as large bowls of delicacies one does usually not see in large bowls (such as ikura). The quality of the food was excellent, and the overall breakfast experience was at once relaxing and invigorating. We expected a five-star hotel, but it exceeded even that. Traveling with a child, she was delighted with a perfectly-sized yukata and slippers that fit her feet. Her toothbrush in the bathroom was just her size and her toothpaste was bubblegum flavored. Small details like these anticipated what would make us most welcome and comfortable, a mark of true service and quality.

After Staying another SLH hotel in Cappadocia (Ariana Luxury Lodge) I decided to explore more SLH hotels and Tokyo station was one of them, It has a great location, excellent and warm service and many detail touches, Breakfast is great and I also suggest to try the Sushi restaurant in the property.

We spent two nights on the way to Okushiga Kogen for a week skiing. We arrived late evening, somewhat tired but the process of checking in was seamless. The Narita Express almost delivers you to the door.The two young people who took us and our luggage to our room were very courteous but even more important they seemed proud to be working there.The room was large by anyones standards and the bed was a delight. All the facilities you would expect from a member of the Best Small Hotels of the world group.We dined that night at the Japanese restaurant within the complex and the quality of the Sashimi was excellent and the service comprehensive.The breakfast buffet was overwhelming in its size, and as a light breakfast eater probably over priced. Quality of the Coffee was ho hum but that's a minor quibble.On the morning we left it was raining and the doorman insisted on walking us to the Shinkansen entry one at a time under his umbrella, smiling the whole time.Definitely will stay here again.

From the moment we stepped through the hotel entrance, until the time we checked out, the staff at the Tokyo Station Hotel were delightful. We were offered a classic tour of the hotel, and one of the staff provided a very knowledgable history of the hotel and of its renovation which has restored the hotel to its original glory. Our room was beautiful and, although rather small in some respects, it was comfortable and the bathroom/wet room was fantastic.The Concierge was extremely helpful. My husband left his glasses in one of the hundreds of Tokyo's taxis. The Concierge managed to track down the glasses and arranged for their safe return.The hotel was well placed for travelling to other areas in Tokyo, either by the JR line, the subway and we were even within walking distance to the Sky Bus open-top tour bus.We can thoroughly recommend this hotel for a special occasion; it is a little pricey.

I've stayed in many hotels in Tokyo over the past couple years as I occasionally travel for business there. The other day when we arrived at the hotel, upon checking in, the front desk demanded we put down our room deposits in cash which was ¥350,000. We obviously were not prepared for this and did not have the money available. This was the first in history that a hotel had asked us to pay them cash for a room security deposit, which in most occasions you put down a credit card for incidental and everyone walks away happy but no, they felt the need make us use cash. On top of that, they were completely rude and ignorant of the situation and it was until I demanded to see their manager that were able to sort this out. In the end, I was told very harshly that I was not allowed to charge anything to my room or use the minibar in exchange for them allowing me to use my credit card for incidental charges. I will never come back here or refer anyone to this place. Last thing my family wanted was to deal with this after a 14 hour flight. They were the most rude people I have ever dealt with in all of Japan. There are many other hotels that are better serviced and price. Do your research and you'll save yourself some headaches.

We stayed at this hotel for three nights and loved it. This was our first visit to Tokyo and we were concerned that the room would be extremely small. It was a good size and beautifully appointed - including an iPhone charger! The toiletries provided were much more extensive than we have seen at other hotels ( hairbrushes, toothbrushes, toothpaste, hair bands as well as the usual stuff). The location in Tokyo Station was great. All staff were very polite and helpful. One tip is to request a room close to the elevator nearest reception. We were in room 3108 and it was quite a long walk down the interior hallways to reach the elevator. There is another elevator that was much closer that took us to an exit that would get us to the north entrance to the train station. Also our room looked out on the large construction area in front of the hotel. We did not select the hotel for the view however so it was it an issue.

Part of Tokyo Station, this hotel is at the spectacular location, especially if you are traveling by shinkansen (bullet train) and/or by Narita Express to/from the Narita Airport. The most courteous and helpful staff. They provide porter service to the platform where you get onboard for Narita Airport. They also stores your baggage. Both totally free of charge. Rooms are elegant with high ceilings and fabulous bathrooms.

We loved the Tokyo Station Hotel - it has a great situation, convenient for all the station shops and several upmarket 'malls' with a great variety of good and interesting dining options close by. The staff are friendly and efficient without being too oppressively 'in your face' (as we found at another 5* hotel where you couldn't move without several staff pouncing on you in an unhelpful 'overhelpful' manner). The room (Palace Side, Kingsize) was gorgeous with a fantastic, spacious, bathroom & attention paid to detail in lovely shower gels, shampoos etc. (We also returned and stayed in a classic twin room which was fine and comfortable but not quite so gorgeous). The best bit however was the breakfast buffet. Fabulous spread of Japanese, Western, and Chinese food all of it extremely good quality. Staff in the buffet were also friendly without being officious. The building itself is very attractive and makes a nice change from the high rises around it.

This 100 year-old hotel, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, and recently renovated, is a great and central place to stay. The floor plan is like a skyscraper laid on its side - it only has 3 floors, but the halls go on and on and on. The hotel is attached to the Tokyo train station, but it's quite a task to find it as the station is so big. But it's worth the plight. The rooms are very up to date, but still retain their original charm. And despite being right on the street, there is no noise from the street. Wifi is really good everywhere. And free. Breakfasts are expensive. But so is the hotel!! If you can afford it, stay here.

Comparing to nearby four seasons hotel, this is relatively cheaper.My wife wish to stay this historical hotel. I get 3 rooms reservations for 3 nights(not continuous) through hotel direct web site, hotels.com, booking,com and Rakuten.com. So, you get an idea about how we want to stay here.Photo taking this hotel from Kitte building is good. Ideal time is between 4:45pm to 6PM. The photo at night will looks better when the roof light is on. I'm not sure but it seems to me the light to the main roof is not on until 6PM.Maisonette suite is not really big enough for a 6 adult family meeting together.Nice breakfast at roof restaurant. But we try to having dinner outside since we are at Tokyo, there are many choice.The room is clean. Service is reasonable good. It is very quiet in the room, you don't feel you are actually inside the big city major train station.There is no shortcut to visit Yaesu shopping mall. It seems to me that that side of the train station has more shop and store, which means more fun to visitor. You need go through north gate from outside of train station. JR gate does not allow us just passing through different gate within same Tokyo station.

Tokyo is a marvelous city and to be able to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel makes it a double bonus - can't get over the gracious hospitality of the staff , every time , every day . The best breakfast at a great place - the atrium . The place was so great even the earth shook ( yes, we experienced an earthquake )

The hotel is in an interesting western style building,above the tokyo train station, and surrounded by an upscale trendy section of the city. It is the most convenient place to stay to see all of tokyo. The room was very large even by western standards. Wonderful bathroom and breakfast was superb! The staff is top quality and very helpful. The jr ticket office and full shopping, food and every train are right below the hotel! Certainly THE place to stay in tokyo!
user_name:
ks358
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed for four nights in Tokyo. The hotel, the staff and the morning buffet was outstanding. We had a upgrade of our room with a spacious suite and a beautiful bathroom. The location was ideal to explore Tokyo. The shopping district "Ginza" was just around the corner. We will definitly come back to this place !

My partner and I stayed at the Tokyo station hotel for 4 nights and could not fault any aspect of our stay. We were so surprised and grateful to be upgraded and could not thank the staff enough for making our special occasion that much more memorable. Staff where so attentive and helpful, booking restaurants months in advance and then printing out brochures about the restaurant and how to get there. They even took the time to walk us through Tokyo station hotel to find the train to get us to the airport, it would have taken us twice as long to find it. The room and facilities were the best we have come across and I can not wait to return in the future. Stefan and Jessica.

Visiting Tokyo for a 6th time, trust me, there will not be any hotel in a better location to explore Tokyo. This hotel is located right in the heart of Tokyo, on the Marunouchi side of Tokyo Station (entrance near the south end), where you will be spoilt for choice over the options of transportation available. Underneath, there are numerous subway lines, as well as Shinkansen lines connecting major cities in Japan. The hotel is also conveniently connected to the two Tokyo airports via trains or buses, and there are highway buses nearby which go to other major cities in Japan as well.Tokyo Station Hotel underwent a major facelift since 2006, and only re-opened in 2012. Eager to retain designer Tatsuno Kingo's design essence, there is absolutely no way the hotel were allow to expand vertically drastically, hence due to space constraint, general hotel facilities are limited. Swimming pool is a notable absence, don't expect any in-house garden, and gym is chargable. However, on other (basic) aspects, they easily matched any top hotels you can think of. And of the limited available facilities they possess, the restaurants and bar are class act. The in-house decor are tastefully refurbished, and in-room furniture looks as good as new. We had a palace-side twin room, it was very roomy, clean, and most importantly, comfortable. The bath room is quite big, with split showering and bathing area. All the staffs I spoken to, speak reasonably good English, including waitresses at the restaurant, though I never tried speaking to any cleaner. The entire hotel, right from the moment I step in, until I check out, every spot I came across oozes class. As for services, I couldn't fault them at all, all I can say is, they go within reasonable boundary to please their guests' request.Bottom line, this is an excellent hotel if you are not going for their facilities. In addition, if you stay here, you shouldn't just make use of its convenient location. Do spend some time appreciating the hotel interior that they painstakingly restored, and maybe also view it from a distance at one of the tall buildings' viewing deck nearby. The night view encompassing the entire Tokyo station is absolutely spectacular!

I recognize this hotel as kind of an irreplaceable symbol of Tokyo although I've been living in Tokyo for a long time, and guess many other people feel the same. The room we stayed for the first time was not quite big but equipped a spacious bathroom and a high ceiling, cleanliness and remarkable quietness. Breakfast in the atrium has a wide variety, especially Western buffet was superb (the chef at the egg station was such an entertainer, so you might wanna enjoy talking with him!) Needless to say, location couldn't be better, of course it's perfect for an afternoon stroll around the imperial palace, an evening wander through Ginza, or if you leave on an early Shinkansen or Narita Express train.

Stayed in a superior king room booked from hotels.com.The bed was very comfortable and the bathroom spacious.The room was beautifully appointed, with ample natural light coming through from the windows overlooking the main entrance to the railway station. No noise whatsoever from the station below. Unfortunately no high rise view but knew that before booking. The location is excellent - walking distance from the palace and there is a shopping mall diagonally across from the hotel.Rose Bakery and Dean & Deluca are also a short stroll away - good options for a non hotel breakfast.A night cap at the Bar Oak was a perfect way to end the night.

The renovation of this historic is brilliant...understated luxury at it's best and true to it's historic roots. We only stayed one night as were in transit but the location in the Marunouchi district is perfect, the service was exceptional and our room the best we have ever stayed in!

Fantastic!!!! First time in Tokyo, Staff very friendly and helpful.We had a room facing the Imperial Gardens, Very clean and comfortable . Great view looking down the street. We didn't hear a train in a 4 night stay. We will be back when we revisit Tokyo.

This hotel is very beautiful, with a lovely sun-filled atrium breakfast room. However it was very expensive and for our money we got a room facing a wall which was fairly small and only had one drawer that we could unpack into so it was hard to keep the room tidy. We had previously stayed at the Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo which was much better value, had a Nespresso machine in the room, and had a larger lighter room with more storage.While the wifi is free it needs two passwords so is a bit of a palaver to get into.

I recently stayed here for 6 nights. Traveled with a family with small children, but stayed in a single room alone. My dome-side hotel had great views of Tokyo Station, but was very small. The bathroom, however was adequately large. The rooms were clean and comfortable. The location was perfect for travel on Japan's extensive rail system, and is also connected to the subway network. Be warned though, some platforms were up to 20 minutes walk away, and there were frequent short flights of stairs some without accompanying elevators.We had breakfast once, which had an OK, not great, selection. My main disappointment was the rather rude "Customer Service" staff.

Perfectly placed at Tokyo's main rail/metro/Shinkansen terminus, historic building with modern facilities (Japanese toilets are THE BEST), impeccable service, top-notch facilities, what improvement could one possibly suggest? A heated bathroom floor! Decadence indeed.

The service provided was the best I have experienced throughout the world. Location perfect for us with kids (age 5 + 7) - a reasonably quick and simple train trip from the airport then a (very) short walk to the hotel.An excellent base to explore Tokyo and wider Japan (specifically for us via Shinkansen to Kyoto).

My experience with Tokyo Station Hotel started with email correspondence with the very excellent concierge, who helped me make a restaurant reservation. The location is unbeatable. I experienced two rooms, one dome facing and one maisonette room. I did not sleep very well, but it may be because I am slightly too hypersensitive, as it was definitely not noisy in the rooms ( on the contrary, it was actually very quiet, almost too quiet because of the double glazing, although I did hear faint station announcements at one point in the dome room), and I suspect my poor sleep was possibly I was near all the train tracks and experiencing minute vibrations? This did not really dent my experience much though, as the rooms were plush and comfortable. The room service Japanese breakfast was very yummy ( I especially liked the mentaiko) and I regret not having time to have breakfast at the lounge! I am looking forward to my next trip in the near future!

Classical Hotel and yet modern... dont know how to describe properly but best of all, we had the best comfortable base in Tokyo for our trip. Easy to come from a long and tiring airplane ride, just take Narita Express and 1 stop, you are in your hotel right away. Going to ride Shinkansen in the morning and be back in the evening... quick and easy.. you can even sleep walk.. i strongly recommend this hotel in Tokyo.

It can be confusing coming to Tokyo for the first time and locating the entry to the hotel from the railway station. But it is this location that is one of the advantages of a stay there. We used our Japan Rail Pass to go easily from the hotel to station platforms, and to access shopping areas on the other side of the station block - the hotel is perfectly located above.And it is lovely, with an old world grace, elegance and attention to courtesy. Our room was small, but comfortable - especially the bed and pillows - heaven to come back to after the cold of Tokyo's winter. Our favourite place was the Camellia Bar & Cafe on the second floor. The staff there were so welcoming and we especially thank Takuji Ono, the Assistant Manager, who made our stay in the hotel a happy experience. On the bar menu we did not expect to find fish and chips, but they were delicious, oishi.We recommend this hotel and hope to return.

We spent the last 2 days of our honeymoon at the Tokyo station hotel.Great hotel, great location, great staff!We loved it!The beds are very comfortable, bathroom with a huge bathtub and all accessories available. The breakfast is really good (western style and Japanese style)Don't hesitate, everything is great!

Love everything about this hotel. Location is super accessible being at the station station. Service is absolutely thoughtful and superb, even for me coming from Thailand where service is supposed to be good. The intricate attention to every single detail by the Japanese is shocking. The rooms were super comfortable and very clean.

If you are traveling business in Japan, needing to visit many parts of Japan such as Osaka, Kyoto without mentioning many cities in Tokyo, then it would be difficult to find more convenient hotel than this hotel. This hotel is a historical building (looks great) and part of Tokyo station. The service is very good and breakfast is also great. The downside is that you might hear or feel some noise of the busiest train station in the world. Also I do not recommend for holiday people. There are many more reasonable and fun places to stay for holidays in Tokyo.

I had always wanted to stay at this hotel after watching an NHK TV documentary about its 100 year anniversary. Finally in January 2015, my wife and I managed to book a 2 night stay which turned out to be one of the finest hotels we have stayed at.The hotel is on top of the Tokyo station itself, but since it was recently renovated with some incredible engineering and architectural technologies, the room, at least the one we stayed at, was extremely quiet considering there were trains speeding below you. The rooms were very well appointed and the design is very European in style. As we were traveling in winter, the room came with its own humidifier which was a pleasant surprise. They also have an in room safe that is large enough to fit a 15 inch laptop. In general, the rooms and bathrooms are spacious for hotels in Tokyo.The hotel offers a breakfast buffet. Although pricey, it is well worth it. They offer an international selection which the restaurant does with great detail and authenticity. There is a Japanese buffet line that offers exclusively Japanese delicacies, but for us, we enjoyed the European selection. The eggs Benedict they served here as part of the buffet was out of this world. They also offer a fine selection of cheeses and a huge choice of fine breads. I generally avoid buffets, but this was one buffet experience I could not pass up.In general, a very nice stay in every way.

Tomorrow is our last day in Tokyo. We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel. The location of this hotel is just perfect. Sitting on top on the Tokyo station, you can go all over Tokyo using the extensive train network. There are good eating joints around the hotel and the most amazing thing was an Indian restaurant (Dhaba India) less than 1 Km from the hotel. The room service menu can be better when you are travelling from outside of Japan with kids. But otherwise the service was exemplary. One of the best hotels that we have stayed in a big metro.

I would have loved to stay longer at this enchanting boutique hotel owned by JR, not just because of its beautiful rooms and immaculate service, But also due to its location at the Tokyo Station itself which has shops, restaurants, and to top it all a 5-10 minute walking distance to Imperial Palace Gardens.As I had left for Kyoto prior to checking into the hotel, my luggages were left there without any difficulty and with such attentiveness and care, I must say!The atrium where the breakfast buffet was placed, was just stunning!When we left the hotel, we could not help but felt humbled by the care of three bellboys/girls that took all our huge luggages to the taxi in waiting about 5 mins away from the hotel and remained there till we drove off.The courtesy given was a truly an exquisite Japanese experience!

We sayed here for two nights and booked through JR line. Be aware that if you do that and are a member of SLH program you will not be given points. Yes, this is part of the SLH group of properties and is very very nice. It is located, as would be expected given its name, within the rail center of Tokyo.As with anything in this area it is expensive and will cost you a bit. Breakfast is around AUD$40 pp. A nice selection of both western and traditional meals are on offer.The rooms are all stunning and when work has been completed at the front of the building will be even better. We stayed on the 3rd floor and the rooms are a little smaller but still well furnished.If I had one bug it was that the tea room and breakfast areas are all open to the public and I was not able to have tea in the lobby lounge at all. There should be an area that is restricted to residents. I dont like the idea of being forced to wait or worse, having to go out into the station to have a cup of tea while non residents use the facilities for business.That aside it was a nice comfortable stay.......althought I will be trying other places if i'm not overnighting from a flight into Tokyo.

So much of recommendation of this hotel, and right, it was fantastic. The service crews were all ever ready to provide assistance whenever needed. We stayed for 4 nights, the Palace Side is spacious, charming, and have the elegant European style. The underground shopping, the Shinkansen train, the JR subways lines are just few-steps away, very convenient.The only set-back is that there is no shuttle bus service from this hotel to Haneda Airport. But is not a big problem as is cost only around JPY6000 by taxi for an approximate 20 minutes ride to the airport. You can ask the Concierge to help you to arrange an MPV which cost around JPY7500 if you have more than 4 paxs and luggage.
user_name:
Vincent E H L
Singapore, Singapore

review_body: Our 4 day stay at the Tokyo Station hotel was perfect. Easy access via Narita Express from airport to our Hotel. The underground rail system can be a bit confussing but there is loots of signs and maops to guide you through. We found a few locals who spoke english and they were very helpful. Our room overlooked the front of hotel so we saw the hustle and busell of the city. Luxurious bathrooms and wonderful staff at concierge desk.we found everyone helpful.

The location of the Station Hotel was perfect for us being first timers to Japan. The Narita express dropped us at the door. Where ever we found ourselves there was a subway nearby with a train to take us back to Tokyo station. The hotel is grand indeed. The room was not large but beautifully appointed. The bathroom glamorous. We didn't eat or drink at the Hotel. Prices a little high for us and why would you with so many opportunities to experience Tokyo nearby.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is amazing. At 100 years old, you do not feel a single old bone in the building or its service. Rather, you experience its wisdom (having been around for so long) and youthfulness (having just remodeled). If you have a chance to meet Duty Manager Mr. Kamata you are in for a treat. He has years of experience and can provide solutions and suggestions to your stay.Location is fantastic - right above the JR train station and walking distance to shopping in the Marunouchi shopping district.The only downside of staying here is that they charge you extra for using the gym and spa facilities. Otherwise, everything else was perfect!

The Tokyo Station Hotel provided service way beyond anyones's expectations!!!!!First, the bell hops refuse to let you carry a thing.The concierge will purchase tickets for you on the JR line for your day trip excursion. Then will have you escorted to the train cars's exact location, wait for you to board and leave before she herself returns to the hotel. All of this to make sure you get to your destination on time without worry . The staff provided this service twice on our trip.In Tokyo, walking is an absolute must. Because one of my members could not walk easily , we were provided a wheelchair at absolutely no charge. What a service that turned our trip from a nightmare to a great trip!!!Location, Location, Location!!!!!This hotel is perfect for getting on JR lines and subways since you are at the station itself. Want to shop? 10 minute walk. Want to catch a subway? 10 minute walk. Want to go back to the room to rest an hour or shower?10 minute walk!!!!The hotel was thoroughly remodeled three years ago. Although not as overwhelming as the Palace Hotel Tokyo where we stayed last year , We will return to this hotel.Service, location, and pricing will bring you back to TSH.

We first stay in Tokyo Station Hotel in 2013 and has been coming back since in 2014 and 2015. From the moment of arrival at Narita Express Track under the busy Tokyo Station, the staff will wait for you at the exact car you came with and assist you with the luggage transportation to the special entrance literally in Tokyo Station itself.The room and the location could not be better for me, especially in the very heart of Tokyo at this price where in front you have a massive, elegant red brick building facing the long stretch road to the imperial palace and just turn back and you are entering one of the most busy transportation hub in the world. There are literally hundreds of restaurants and department store in the area of the hotel so no worry about your daily shopping and gourmet needs.But the really amazing thing about this place is their concierge and services. From the first time I stay here, they helped arranged everything from the transportation to restaurant reservation. Especially the last time where we could get into one of the most difficult to access restaurant in the world Sukibayashi Jiro Roppongi and Chateau Restaurant Joel Robuchon, Tokyo Shiba Tofuya Ukai, and Kaishoku Michiba.At the time of writing this review, I've just completed the reservation for our 4th stay in 2016 already :)

I recently stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel and words cannot describe how magnificent this hotel was. From the moment one checked in, the staff, which were all wonderful, wanted to help you and to make you feel at home.The hotel was very elegant and immaculate with an European classical decor.The room itself was very spacious and so neatly decorated that made the stay even more enjoyable. The bathroom was very spacious and had a gigantic bathtub and shower. All toiletries and amenities (including Pyjamas) were provided.Overall, my stay was a magnificient one. I highly recommend this property and the next time I am in Tokyo, I will, without a doubt, stay there again.

We stayed at this hotel on Nov.9 for over night with friends. We went to the lobby lounge for the coffee 40 min before closed. The waitress was not attentive and we had the lukewarm coffee for 1300 yen. She totally ignored our request of the refill. I thought it was quite disappointing since the room was quite comfortable and the breakfast was very good.

I stayed at Tokyo Station hotel for 2 nights recently. The experience I had during my stay has been great. The hotel location is very good; practically in Tokyo station. The staff were super polite. The room is big, new and ad a ic design. The bath room is super big. Hotel security was also good. I really enjoyed staying at this hotel. Booked the hotel on line and with JR pass package. Highly recommended

I'm not sure why this hotel is not in the top 5. The hotel is beautiful, it's right by the station (don't worry, there's no train noise), the location is fabulous being close to nice restaurants and the Imperial Palace. The staff are amazing and cannot do enough to make your stay delightful. The room, and especially the bathroom, were spacious, state of the art and new. We explored the city and did not see anywhere else where we would have rather stayed. The breakfast is overpriced but very nice.

I arrived, tired and jetlagged, late in the evening and it was a delight to be immediately looked after by all staff. Not only that, but although I had booked only a standard room, for some reason they upgraded me to the Ambassadors' Suite, which was amazing and spectacular and so luxurious. (I'm assuming that they did this because I arrived late and was only staying one night?) Anyway, the room was fab, the hotel bar in which I ate sandwiches was atmospheric and chilled, and the breakfast buffet the next day (although expensive) was fantastic. Wish I could have stayed longer - 15 hours was not enough!

We've visited Japan 3 times with our 3 year old son and the Tokyo Station Hotel was by far the best in terms of convenience and service. We stayed at TSH for 7 nights total and had their breakfast at the Atrium for 5 mornings, all of which were amazing and strongly recommended. the staff were courteous and spoke fluent English. We had to arrange luggage delivery services to the airport and had to store our luggage there for our one day trip to Hakone. the Hotel was very helpful in all areas. The location is more than convenient for us because we took Narita Express from Narita Airport and Shinkansen bullet train to/from Kobe. the hotel was right above the platform so you also save on taxi fare to the station. They also have a meet and greet service too if you need guidance to the exact location. Living in the station also means that you never run out of things to do/eat. Overall, great hotel and perfect for families with luggage to haul.

A bit expensive but worth it. We had a king room overlooking the street. Double glazing made the room silent - fantastic after a long flight. Very well appointed, great linen and tasteful furnishings. Amazing shower and top toiletries. The convenience was great as you really are at the main station. Staff were helpful and spoke excellent English. We didn't eat there, though,as it was too dear. Lots of small shops nearby though, including a good coffee shop.

Room on second floor. Twin beds very comfortable. Toilet--very nice Japanese, warm seat, etc. Coffee maker. Quiet due to 4x glass in windows---do not open. View out the front of the hotel is a large construction site---not great but there was NO noise at all. We could watch the entire construction crew perform their typical group Japanese warm up/stretch routine at 8.00 am. Good idea for team work and injury prevention!The hotel staff are uniformed with round pill box hats. Charming. They ALL bow and SMILE everytime we passed. We bowed a bit too. Lovely!Breakfast was not included in our rate. We paid $80 for two people. It was quite nice with a chef making omelette, etc. but seemed too costly to us. Only ate there one day.Location is very central. The Kitte Building next door has every dining option---from $90 for dinner right down to Lawson's (a 7/11).Fancy shopping (a la Rodeo Drive) walking distance.The staff are all terrificly customer friendly.Take the Narita Express train from the airport and you waltz right into the hotel. Big advantage !

In the Musée d’Orsay in Paris, there is a hotel room preserved as an exhibit. Small room with a fireplace, overlooking the Seine, daintily decorated and somewhat kitsch in a fin-de-siècle kind of way. The museum was a major train station in the late 19th, early 20th century. In those days hotels were a still a fairly new concept while train travel was rapidly expanding. People suddenly could go places but once arrived, there were few places to rest their heads. Train stations filled this need by incorporating hotels into their buildings. Tokyo station was built in 1915 during the Meiji era when Japan was frantically and almost blindly copying Western ways. And indeed, the architecture is thoroughly Western even though the architect, Tatsuno Kingo was Japanese. He studied under Josiah Conder and clearly did his best to produce the most Western design possible. Thus Western ideas not only manifested themselves in the physical look of the building but also in its mode of operation: The station includes a hotel in its midst. The entrance is on the ground floor, close to the dome on the right as seen from the Marunouchi side. The rooms are on the second floor, lining up from one dome to the other. Some rooms looks out towards the Imperial Palace. Mine looks inside into the space under the right dome. This makes for a somewhat surreal feeling as there I was in my comfortable room, watching the masses of travelers and tourists rushing to and fro below.This is a luxurious place. The recent renovation has endowed it with all manners of fancy, expensive items. The shower and bathtub are roomy and pleasant to use. I am not much into soaking but my Japanese girlfriend who must have her soaking every night thoroughly enjoyed the tub. We did not have time to sample the food at the various restaurants and cafés but they all look quite deluxe and delicious. While the hotel definitely inspires luxury, it misses one component that luxury must always have, which is spaciousness. In a place like Tokyo where space is at a premium, roominess is all the more crucial in projecting luxury. Sadly, this hotel is short on space, inside and outside the room. The lobby while very pleasant feels cramped and crowded. My room feels overstuffed. In spite of its smallness it is filled with all sorts of knick-knacks for that’s what luxury demands. The sink area overflows with amenities, so much so that I had a hard time finding space for my own few items. The same is true with the little desk where the TV is. Finally, since a king bed is de rigueur in this sort of establishment, there is little room left. In fact, one side of the bed is almost against a wall so there is no way to climb on the bed from that side. All that said, this is a hotel inside a train station. If one wants to keep the original design, that’s how tight things will be.In the end, what I appreciate most about this hotel is its location. I only stayed there one night on my way back to Tokyo from Hiroshima before flying out the next day. The Tokaido Shinkansen terminus is at Tokyo Station, my Narita Express train also departed from there. The Marunouchi and Yaesu areas around the hotel are pleasant. I only had to drag my suitcase up a few elevators when I got off the Shinkansen and down a few elevators to board the Narita Express the next day. I will stay here again when I need to be in Tokyo one night before flying out.

For starters, you can't get a better location for tourism than staying inside of the world's busiest metro station. Easy to get anywhere from the hotel, and, perhaps more importantly, almost all roads lead to home. The concierge is very attentive, he would print out info about activities we talked about and slip them under our door in case we forgot anything. Breakfast is great as well. It's buffet style with full American and Japanese options, so you can definitely eat your money's worth. The building itself is also beautiful with white marble everywhere

This is my second time at the Tokyo Station Hotel. Overall it's a solid good hotel. The hotel lobby is small but charming, the rooms are medium-sized and good. Staff are friendly and courteous (although some struggle with English). Breakfast is OK.

The concierge Mr. Tomonori Otsuka made my stay in Tokyo a wonderful experience, he gave me insight on how to best interact with the Japanese people I would me during my stay and some of his favorite places to eat and when I was overwhelmed by city life in Tokyo, He also booked me a fabulous room at the Bennesse House on Naoshima Island. It was an experience I won't forget anytime soon

This hotel is amazing in location, comfort, service, breakfast and spa services. From our arrival, the reception staff where really friendly, and the bell girl even tried to speak to us in Spanish (we are Mexican). Our room was a bit small, but that was the only downside, because bed, pillow and linen comfort was the best, the sower and hot tube they had was simply amazing. If you're there you need to try their breakfast in the morning, japanese or occidental (we had both) are amazing. Location is just perfect, being inside the Tokyo station, you are simply in the best place to move around.

Beautifully restored, classic and well-appointed. Shower room and bathtub are excellent. Breakfast in the Atrium is lovely and the selections varied (Japanese and Western style) and delicious. Coffee was really good! Perfect for the weary traveler after a 10 hour flight and 90 min train ride. Get off the train and walk right into your hotel lobby.

Great location as it is located right at the South Exit. Beautifully decorated. Shower room is huge and very comfortable. Staff services are excellent. The only drawback is the long walk if you get the room at the other end of the corridor, however there is another access for the guest close to Central Exit.

Loved this hotel. Rooms were large and very clean. Hotel was recently renovated and it shows. Only three stories high which is very rate in Japanese hotels. Sits on top of Tokyo Central station which was amazing - albeit confusing. Ginza very short walk. Would highly recommend this hotel.

Are you a fan of downtown abbey? To be fussed by white gloved service staff and surrounded by beautiful furniture and linen, then this is THE place to stay. Conveniently located at the Marounochi end ofthe gargantuan Tokyo station, you can get to any where. Or walk to the imperial gardens. The guests here are so discreet I didn't even see another guest in the hallway and the hotel is full! I probably got the smallest room in the hotel but by moving a couple of chairs around I still managed to open 2 large suitcases. Tip: book early. I got a great pre-paid deal via hotel travel dot com and paid about usd300 per night. Being an absolute cheapo I chose a package without breakfast. There are enough cafes and convenience stores in the station to keep your gastronomic tummy bulging and satisfied. Oh there is a walk passage at the western end of the station that links you from yaesu (north side of station where bus terminal is) end to Marounochi (south side of Tokyo station). So rather than pay usd30 for the NEX, I took the usd10 accessnarita bus from narita to Tokyo which ends at the yaesu side. Be sure to check out the basement of the station for food and shopping. Look for Mr Watabe, a handsome supervisor at the front desk who will be able to assist you perfectly, whether you need extra complimentary drinking water or other amenities.

There's absolutely nothing at all that can be faulted with this hotel. After countless days of research, my partner and I chose The Tokyo Station Hotel as our base in the city for our anniversary trip to Japan, and we have nothing but compliments for the property and staff. As tourists, Tokyo Station Hotel absolutely cannot be surpassed in terms of location. I cannot emphasize enough how reassuring it was to know we could always very easily get back to our hotel simply by the fact that a number of rail networks converged at the train station below. The fact that many intercity rail lines, the NEX train from Narita, and all shinkansen lines out of Tokyo all converge here make this the perfect place to begin exploring not only the city but the rest of Japan. Amazingly, despite all the transit associated with the property, the hotel was always very peaceful and gave no indication of being just floors above Tokyo's major train station.Having gone through a recent renovation, the hotel property and guest accommodations are beautifully modern, impeccably clean, and spacious. The beds are very comfortable with room controls for lighting and automated window shades right at the bedside. The bathroom is cavernous, and the deep soaking tub and huge rainfall shower head were a total point of relaxation after long hours in the city. Every space encountered was clean and spotless.Above all, I cannot compliment the staff enough for all of the assistance they provided both before our arrival and during our stay. The chief concierge, Ms. Mori, was incredibly patient and helpful in arranging a number of points in our itinerary before we even arrived by booking impossible restaurant reservations and securing great concert tickets, and her colleague, Mr. Otsuka, was an indispensable resource of information and help for us during our stay. The amount of patience and willingness to help from the concierge and the entire hotel staff elevate this property to true luxe levels. From the moment we stepped off the train from Narita and escorted to check-in with white glove service to our check-out where we were again escorted to our train platform with the same amazing bell staff, everyone that works at Tokyo Station Hotel treated us to absolutely royal service - always present, always polite, always anticipating. The Tokyo Station Hotel is a true luxury property and an absolute choice hotel.

Everything about this hotel is excellent. The gym is the best of any hotel I have stayed in. The Chief Concierge, Ms Marie-Antoinette Mori, was extraordinarily patient, knowledgeable, and pleasant. The level of service is world class.

This is a full-service, well-run luxury hotel. It was perfectly located for my one-night stay in Tokyo at the beginning of my Japan journey. After the long flight from the U.S. & a trip on the Narita Express from the airport to Tokyo Station, it was a relief to settle in, & not have to navigate anything else. The following morning, after breakfast I continued my journey to Kyoto, & even saw Mt. Fuji from the train. The hotel staff was exceptionally helpful, providing via email specific walking directions to the hotel from the Narita Express platform (Tokyo Station is HUGE & could be confusing to a novice) AND, at my request, walked me the next day to both the Shinkansen ticket office next door and to my train platform.

After traveling 14 hours to get to Tokyo, it was such a pleasure to check into this beautiful hotel. It was so convenient to come out of the train station and be right at the hotel. What impressed us in addition to the magnificent room and bath (5 star worthy) was the helpfulness of the staff. Marie was a terrific concierge. Someone from the hotel personally accompanied from the hotel lobby to our train platform at 6:30 on the morning we left Tokyo for Kyoto. That's service! The breakfast buffet was outstanding! I was concerned due to the location that our room might be noisy, but it was very quiet ... no street noise. No complaints...it was the perfect hotel to begin our vacation.

My first time staying at Tokyo was great with this hotel.Center of Tokyo, just next to Tokyo station where you can go anywhere in Japan with Sinkan-sen, fast train, very convenience.High business building around and business people wearing suits going around.Many fabulous restaurants with amazing view are around but costs high too.

The hotel is 100 years and in a classy historical building. The hotel inside however is newly refurbished with nearly every modern facilities including excellent wifi in guest rooms. The guest rooms are of very good size for Tokyo. The location is perfect, two minutes from JR Tokyo Station, 10 minutes from Ginza on foot.The concierge was very helpful, she gave me excellent advice on restaurants, patiently booked three top restaurants (all 3 stars) for me which I would not have been able to book by myself. When I arrived; maps of the three restaurants, time to get there, taxi fare, subway fare were all presented in detail and clearly. I recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a city hotel in Tokyo.

Visited for 2 weeks and everything was spot on. Room size was certainly ok, bearing in mind this is Tokyo.The area is just a 5-10 minute walk from lots of Izakayas so perfect for some evening food and drink!By far the best hotel I have stayed in, in Tokyo!

This is an excelent hotel in the heart of Tokyo, Built on the Tokyo Station. The rooms are excelent and well appointed.The staff are so polite and helpfull. Even to the extent of the porters taking you to your train and loading your baggage onto the train carriage. All the ameneties are very good, the rooms very clean and have all the facilities a traveller would want

This hotel is gorgeous! We stayed for six nights in September in one of the rooms overlooking the train station. You do hear a little bit of noise at times from the station, but nothing that would disturb you. It is silent during the night and early morning hours. It is very interesting looking down into the station and I would definitely pick this room again. It is beautifully appointed with very high ceilings and a lovely chandelier. The lovely bathroom had a separate toilet area with both shower and very large tub. This room was so clean, I don't think I have ever stayed in a cleaner hotel room. The staff were so helpful and polite. The Duty Manager, Yoshiki Kamata went above and beyond, helping us with our luggage arrangements when we came back to Tokyo enroute to the airport after being in other parts of Japan for five days. We had an excellent dining experience one night in the Shichi Jyu Ni Kou restaurant. The chef, Masahiro Ishihara, prepared our meal in front of us. He was very personable and made for an entertaining evening. The location is perfect with the train station and the Kitte shopping mall with many restaurants directly across the street. Our stay couldn't have been more perfect.

The hotel is conveniently located at Tokyo Station and definitely served as a great base of operation for my trip with all sorts of transportation and food options nearby. The tsukemen place mentioned by David Chang in Mind of a Chef is just a few minutes walk away and a must try.As great as the hotel and location are, the concierge service is possibly even better. About two months before my trip to Japan, I contacted the concierge in a vain attempt to get reservations at Jiro. Within a week, I was informed about the successful reservation!Tipping is not customary in Japan but I have to leave behind this one tip, definitely consider staying at Tokyo Station Hotel.
user_name:
Terry C
New York City, New York

review_body: The first impression while entering the Tokyo station hotel is the sense of grandeur.Like many other reviewers said from the huge chandelier to the design of the lobby already takes you to luxury.Our room that we booked was beautifully decorated and we were happy to find towel folding and even a plate of fresh fruits.These little details shows that they really do take great care of their customers.The room even if small to my liking had all the best amenities that you may request. Well our stay would have been perfect except for one little issue :even if we got an apology upon check in it is the mail that one of the staff members sent me prior to my arrival asking me to refrain from taking pictures at the hotel due to a private wedding. Which i do understand but for me this email was just misplaced .Anyway i would recommend this hotel to anyone going through Tokyo.

I recently had the privilege of visiting the Tokyo Station Hotel on my vacation. The hotel was absolutely classic. The rooms are beautiful and Neo classical, the staff is friendly and helpful especially Mr. Tomonori Otsuka from concierge he was exhibited great service and was extremely helpful.Truly phenomenal from start to finish.

Serendipity had it that we stayed here. My 5 year old daughter and I had been traveling for a while in Japan, and literally came out of the train station and found this hotel using TripAdvisor's "near me now" feature.When we entered the hotel I was immediately impressed, but my tired, cranky and embarrassed to say slightly spoiled daughter only wanted to know if the hotel had a pool. When we found out it didn't she nearly had a meltdown on the marble floor of their very finely furnished lobby. Mortified, I asked the concierge if we could sit down while I figured out another hotel to book. The hotel staff and concierge were totally gratuitous, and even helped me by answering questions about other hotels I found in the area on my TripAdvisor app on my phone. Finally my daughter calmed down after we ate dinner at a nearby Italian restaurant that the concierge recommended and I was able to talk her "highness" into staying at this amazing hotel despite the fact it lacked the pool for her to splash around it.We were offered an upgraded room with a view of the train station. It was gorgeously decorated. And my daughter decided she liked the hotel after all since she felt like a princess in the lavish room.Whew.Anyway, the hotel was 5 star from top to bottom, and the location was excellent. Of course we were able to hop on trains and taxis just outside of the hotel doors. We loved the remodel that they did on the classic historical rooms. They were very high end from all the fixtures, to the furnishings, to the linens, and on and on. The room was stocked with plenty of extras. They even had some special gifts for my slightly spoiled daughter waiting for us when we went up to our room. And tiny slippers in just her size, plus special soaps, shampoos, etc. etc. etc. just for her, in addition to all the other lovely amenities. The staff was top flight all around, even charging my nearly empty battery on my phone in the security luggage room for me while my daughter and I went out to dinner at an Italian restaurant, prior to even deciding to stay at this hotel! The service was over the top before we even spent a dime... that says a lot, especially since we looked really disheveled after traveling all day, and my daughter basically caused a small scene in their very fancy lobby full of well dressed guests. We stuck out like travelin' hillbillies, but they were just as kind and gracious to us as any of the other guests. This was our favorite hotel while staying in Japan, and we found it by lucky happenstance.If you thought this review was helpful, please check the little button that says so. It makes me happy to know I am helping fellow travelers. Especially I am hoping I am helping others traveling for tourism/culture and with their families including small children.P.S. I will do my best to upload photos when I have time. I did take lots of photos at this hotel.

This is the best hotel. Period. The concierge went way above and beyond all expectations, including helping us sort out the Japan Rail Pass and showing us how to use the train/subway system. This assistance will make our entire 2 week stay in Japan a breeze. For example, when we travelled to Toyota yesterday, we had no issues navigating the 8 trains we took to visit two museums in two different cities. We probably would have had significant difficulties if not for the time he spent with us on the day we arrived. He also made us a beautiful gift for our honeymoon and the concierge staff provided significant assistance by email before we ever left the US. The room was perfect. I would not change a single detail. The location is amazing. It is inside the train station! All common areas are beautiful and perfectly maintained. All staff have been friendly and helpful. We do not speak Japanese, and that has not been an obstacle at all. We never made it to the spa and fitness area, but I cannot imagine that they are anything less than fabulous. I NEVER want to leave.

This is a very special hotel which has a terrific, central location and a phenomenal staff who are very helpful and go out of their way to make one's stay not only at their hotel but in Tokyo an extraordinary experience. We stayed here for a total of 6 nights, each in 2 night stints. The concierge team helped me make reservations for tours and dinners and provided maps and tour information that allowed us to have a wonderful experience. This was our first trip to Japan and it can be daunting but this hotel made all the difference.

Venue: the hotel could not be located better. Good access to central Tokyo and a few steps from Narita Express.Appearance: pristene and stately, a 100 year opld, very well restored jewel.Service: competent and courteous.Noise: minimal - a real achievement considering it is inside the Tokyo Station.

Ask for a room near the elevators which lead to Reception. Otherwise, you'llwalk endlessly, and be near those which go elsewhere. Same limited, boring,''late night'' menu (only up to midnight) as other Japanese hotels.If you arrivelate, the staff could direct you to the Maranouchi Building across the street, whose 7th floor has several restaurants, the best of which serves mediocre food, amidst loud rapmusic.The dishes at the hotel's large breakfast buffet looked overwhelmingly insipid. If you define a ''luxury'' hotel as one in which the toilet seat rises automaticallyas you enter the bathroom, this place is for you. I found it incongruous in a country which conserves energy. At 530am a faint pounding somewhere inthe vicinity; odd for a Sunday.
user_name:
salutary1
New York City, New York

review_body: My husband and i stayed at the Tokyo Station hotel for 3 nights in early October on our first trip to Japan. We could not recommend this hotel more highly. The location and convenience factor absolutely cannot be beat. You travel around the city almost exclusively by train (and this is coming from nyc people who take cabs everywhere there - but here the taxi drivers do not speak much English and even with screenshots of addresses in Japanese we would usually be left off somewhere wrong). Having one of the most central train stations right there just made navigating a cinch! Also, the NEX (narita express train) connects you directly from the airport to the hotel in 1 hour. (Another side note: last NEX train is ~9:45pm so of you have a late arriving flight like ours, you cannot use the NEX. The Limousine Bus, though, has departures until 11pm and also goes directly from airport to Tokyo Station).The hotel service was also fantastic both before we arrived in Japan and while we were there. All emails were answered promptly and they helped us secure a reservation at a hard to get sushi restaurant. While we were there, everyone was so helpful and friendly. They helped us forward a large piece of luggage to our next destination via Ta-Q-Bin when we realized how tough it would be to lug it on the trains.We stayed in a "classic room". It was small but very nice and modern. Bed was large and comfortable. Bathroom had all amenities and was pristine. The only thing missing which didn't really bother us was that there weren't really any drawers to put clothes into (there was a closet with a shelf on top though). We didn't get the breakfast package but purchased breakfast there one of the mornings in the Atrium which was lovely with Japanese and Western options in a large buffet.All in all, we had a fantastic stay at the Tokyo Station hotel and would definitely stay here again. It is a perfect home base for travelers exploring Tokyo.
user_name:
Brooke S
New York City, New York

review_body: If you're looking for a gorgeous historical gem of a hotel with excellence service and easy walking distance to shopping, restaurants and transportation, look no further than Tokyo Station Hotel. The rooms are spacious with very comfortable beds and LARGE bathrooms. Such a pleasant surprise to see the size of the rooms! The hotel restaurants are quite expensive so we decided to explore the area and find restaurants near by--there are plenty! (There is a nice pizza place with outdoor seating in the Marinouchi building area--beautiful al fresco dining. The concierge pointed us in the right direction) The hotel is truly beautiful and quiet! Highly recommend.

During the planning phase of our Tokyo trip, I spent a lot of time trying to figure out where to stay. Originally I was thinking of spending less money. However I decided to increase the budget and spend more on the Tokyo Station Hotel. My husband and I did not regret it. We recently spent a total of 6 nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel. It was a wonderful experience. The service was excellent. The location was perfect. And the rooms were quiet, beautiful and immaculate. The hotel sends bellhops to meet guests arriving on the Narita Express. There are numerous fine restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. In general, the hotel has the quiet elegance of an upscale, boutique hotel which was exactly what we wanted. We especially appreciated the concierge team consisting of Ms. Marie A. Mori and Mr. Tomonori Otsuka. Finally dear Mr. Yoshiki Kamata, Duty Manager, became our new best friend. He was very helpful and welcoming.
user_name:
saulmax
New York City, New York

review_body: How you can feel like Japanese royalty, well all you have to do is book yourself a stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel.The rooms are spacious, the suites lavish, the staff graceful and cuisine exquisite. You don't need to be royal but the way the hotel treats you like one.My wife and I had our Silver Jubilee honeymoon stay here and the experience was beyond words can describe. Our suite was out of this world, service was impeccable and experience - almost divine. Will we repeat the experience- Absolutely yes. Its not everyday you get to stay next door to imperial palace and be treated like royalty too.

We spent two nights in this hotel before joining a cruise ship in Yokohama. Cannot find any faults in location, services and amenities. What we enjoy most is the buffet breakfast at the Atrium, so classy. I will just return for their red-bean buns! Don't forget to visit their mini-museum on the mezz floor which tells you stories of the Tokyo Station.

We loved this hotel the most out of all the hotels we have stayed in in Japan. It is so gracious, cosy and yet so elegant. We were allocated a magnificent room for our first three nights. It was large, tasteful and very comfortable with a superb bathroom. We had to break our stay to visit Hakone. On our return, we were allocated a much smaller room, which was. OK. The hotel has lovely restaurants. We loved our delicious breakfasts in the lovelyAtrium under its huge canopy. The staff were perfect: so friendly and helpful. If we ever return to Tokyo, we will definitely stay in this beautiful hotel again.

After a multi-year and very expensive renovation, the Tokyo Station Hotel is a real gem set in a beautiful, 100+ year old train station. We saw several groups getting a tour of the hotel and station.It is the perfect combination of a European Grand Hotel feel (crystal chandeliers in the bedroom), with the best of brand new Japanese accompaniments. The bathrooms have the usual high-tech commode in a separate room. The star is the tub/shower glass "room" that has the best rainfall shower we have experienced anywhere.The lobby lounge is beautiful and quite large--but go early, it was 100% full several days by late afternoon. There is a nice harp performance several times in the evenings.Food-wise, the in-hotel options look nice, but are quite pricey. The business area in which the hotel is located has a plethora of shopping and dining options. There are authentic "local" places along the train tracks heading south, a wide variety of places in the surrounding office buildings, and decent options in the station, itself. We had a Japan Rail Pass and so could go in and out as we wished; but some of the station options are on the other side of the ticket barrier.Being physically within Tokyo Station makes train travel especially convenient--although there is only one Tokyo Metro line (Marounochi). Connections are typically via the JR Yamanote line. All in all, this is a great option in central Tokyo.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is attached to the central train station (having an entrance inside the train station). It is a great luxury hotel with nice restaurants, bars, and rooms. I stayed here for just one night but was pleased with every aspect of my stay. The room was very comfortable and the bath was clean. For the money, this hotel is a better deal than the Shangri-la and Four Seasons (the other luxury hotels attached to the train station). I will certainly look them up the next time I am in town.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel on our last night in Tokyo. I thought it was absolutely beautiful - the rooms were comfortable, spacious,and clean, and the bathroom was one of the nicest I have ever had at a hotel. Other strong points were the staff, who were so courteous, and the location, which being attached to Tokyo Station was super convenient. There is plenty to do within walking distance, and we walked back and forth to Ginza also, which was about 20 minutes or so. Should I return to Tokyo I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

Excellent hotel. Excellent service. Fantastic staff from room cleaning, concierge and duty manager. Could not fault it. Airline lost our luggage and the hotel did everything to help to get it delivered to our room.

The staff here speak English and are extremely helpful. Me and my boyfriend spent our first night in tokyo at this hotel, it was very nice. They took our bags to our room for us and made us feel very welcome. We stayed in the king dome suite, the bed was very comfortable and the pillows were a dream. The next day when we were leaving for our next hotel we were able to leave our bags at the hotel after check out time (12pm) while we wandered around killing some time until we were able to check into our next hotel.

After visiting a friend in northern Japan, we spent a night at the Tokyo Station Hotel before heading to Narita and home. It was a splurge for us, but one of the best splurges ever, in part because we were upgraded to possibly the most luxurious room I've ever seen in a hotel.Highlights included a ginormous walk-in closet; a bathroom with two sinks, a roomy Jacuzzi tub with a built in TV set and waterproof remote; a "washlet" (i.e. toilet/bidet) that raised its lid when I entered the room and flushed itself when I got up; an alcove with a desk; good Wi-Fi and clear instructions for accessing it; Bulgari toiletries; soft, fluffy terrycloth robes... the list goes on.Service was great, but of course it usually is in Japan. The decor was traditional and the staff uniforms reminded me of the ones in The Grand Budapest Hotel. In short, I have nothing bad to say about this experience and I'm not surprised this hotel has proved so popular here.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is a beautiful hotel with wonderful service. I stayed there after returning from Kyoto and before returning home. It was perfect because you walk out of the hotel and right into the station to take the express train to the airport.The rooms are beautifully decorated and the amenities were lovely. The bathtub and rain shower were pretty spectacular. It was by far the most comfortable bed and nicest linens I slept on during my trip to Japan. The area isn't the most exciting area, but you can take the train and get wherever you want to go very easily. The dining room off the lobby is lovely, food was great and the service was fantastics.It was very hot when I was there so I didn't have the opportunity to visit an onsen. I opted for the Tokyo Station Hotel Spa. Their baths, sauna and steam room are wonderful. It is a beautiful spa and I loved the baths. I also had a massage and it was fantastic. I can be picky about a spa visit and there isn't anything I would have changed about the experience. The staff could not have been more attentive, the products were great and it was really lovely. It would be a great way to overcome jet lag!I loved this hotel and highly recommended it!

Again, the Tokyo Station Hotel was a delight. The location is great! My wife and I are very much into electronics and games, and Tokyo Station is only two stops away from Akihabara (Electric Town). Of course, the Tokyo Station Hotel is in the same building as the Tokyo Station itself and most of the trip can be made through the cool air conditioned halls of the hotel. So nice during the hot Tokyo summers...! This time we got a wonderful view out of the front of the station. There was a walled off area of construction that we could see into which wasn't the most beautiful, but the cityscape above it was gorgeous. The room itself was also very spacious with a great bathroom with an ever greater bathtub. The restaurants in and around Tokyo Station are great, too. If you want to pay the $1.25 for an entry ticket to eat inside Tokyo Station then you don't even have to go outside into the hot air. Of course if you want to eat on Ramen Street or at a restaurant in the huge Daimaru building you'll only have to walk a minute or two outside to get there.The concierge Marie was again able to help us getting reservations at some of the fancier sushi joints, and of course also helped us with directions around the city and with recommendations for places to go and things to do. The staff itself was very courteous and all spoke more than enough English to help us with whatever we needed. We will definitely stay there again.

Everything was perfect, service is outstanding and accommodations over the top. I got a room with view to the imperial palace and it is not necessary worth it, all rooms are excellent.If you are new to Japan the hotel offers a service were they pick you up at the train station so you don't get lost.Use the concierge service for difficult reservations they are extremely efficient. Expect room service and food to be expensive but very good.

I've stayed it last November and loved it profusely that I decided to stay here again. While there are many other newer chic hotels that have erupted in Tokyo, and that Shangri-La Tokyo is just a block away from this hotel, I've loved the majesty that this old school hotel beckons. The rooms are large. It's surrounded by the high rises of Marunouchi, the train station is right below you, Daimaru is at your back (as are the many eat streets within the train station itself), it's a short stroll into Ginza, the Imperial Gardens are right in front of you, and there's always waking up to the splendor that is truly Tokyo!Since this hotel reopened three years ago, I've been curious as to what the hype was all about. My stay last November confirmed that it wasn't a hype. The reviews are not enough to describe how much you'd want to re-experience the ambience and elegance of this hotel over and over again. To me, this is home in Tokyo. Over and over again....

This hotel has it all - excellent location for sightseeing, beautiful building, rooms and amenities and - of course - fabulous service.The hotel is attached to the enormous Tokyo Station, meaning you are only footsteps away from multiple train lines (including bullet trains, subway and JR lines) as well as dozens and dozens of dining and shopping options. It is incredibly convenient for sightseeing, as you can very easily get anywhere from Tokyo, and it's lovely to get home at the end of a long day of walking and have your hotel only be a few moments walk from the train platform. It's also surrounded by some lovely department stores, as well as being very close to the Imperial Palace.
