Despite being attached to a station, once you enter the Tokyo Station Hotel you are immediately removed from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo and enveloped into its serene, classic decor and quiet calm. The building is in immaculate condition and the foyer, restaurants and guest rooms are beautifully decorated in a neo-classical western style. They have done a great job with the acoustics as you barely hear any of the station noise, and we had a room with a window overlooking one end of the station.The level of service at the Tokyo Station Hotel was exceptional. Every single staff member we encountered,from the door man, to the front desk to the housekeeper, was amazingly friendly, helpful and courteous. Service in Japan is generally amazing anyway, but even more so at the Tokyo Station Hotel.Our room was beautifully appointed and super clean with incredibly high ceilings, lovely big bathroom with huge tub, rainfall shower and lovely amenities. Big, comfortable bed that made for a good night's rest every night. I am pretty fussy, and I literally could not find fault with the Tokyo Station Hotel. Yes, it is at the more expensive end for Tokyo (although not as expensive as the Park Hyatt) but worth it. We enjoyed our stay immensely and were sad to leave. It made our week in Tokyo so pleasant and easy, and if I ever return to Tokyo I will absolutely stay here again.

stayed at this hotel for 3 nights in July, dome room was recommended by the hotel,i was worried about the noise by reading some reviews. I am a light sleeper, noise and bell sound will certainly interrupt my beauty sleep. but i decided to take a change because the dome reminds me a bit of florence. my decision was right, the bed was firm enough for my back but not hard to sleep on, we stayed in a king room, size is a bit small but i did not need to crawl to the other side to bathroom as other review said. hotel might did some re-arrangement. space is enough for two, and the bathroom was big size, with toilet and shower in separated section. staffs were helpful and nice with smile greeting you in and out. a gentleman even took us to the train station for narita express to airport. where can you find such good service? I am going back there in November and changed my reservation from 3 to 4 nights. i really enjoyed the stay, location is very convenient to shop, restaurants, trains. lots of english channels to watch, we watched soccer every night.

I had a wonderful stay at this hotel from the time you arrived till you departure everyone on the hotel welcoming you so polite, friendly & you feel like at home, the rooms & the service was more than excellent, even the duty manager is welcoming you in personal on your arrival & departure to make sure everything went ok. The location is the best in Tokyo the hotel located on the Tokyo Station they have gate to the station to access. Everything was more than my expectations. If I will be back again to Tokyo sure I will stay again on the sahotel.

Tokyo Station Hotel is undoubtedly one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in my many trips abroad. Located in a historical building that has completed 120 years of existence last year, the hotel itself commemorates its 100 years of operation in 2015. Emerging from a thorough restaurauration works that highlights its classical atmosphere, the rooms are quite comfortable and the service is irreproachable. I was given a privileged room with a view to the road to the Palace of the Emperor. next to the Royal suite (I suppose in the old times the foreign envoys and noblemen would arrive ato Tokyo Station and take a carriage straight to the Imperial Palace). The staff is very kind and accommodating to your specifics needs (e.g. they provided me with a wheelchair 24 hrs a day and even allowed me to use it to go to nearby shops) and the conciergerie, under the command of the most friendly and efficient Ms. Marie Antoinette Mori, attends to all your requests with grace. The hotel is, of course, in the Tokyo Central station, making it a most convenient place to take trains and subways to all over Japan, including the bullet trains. The underground mall of the Tokyo Station is also a huge place where you can find most everything, among wchich the famous "ramen street" and the posh Daimaru department store. Overall, the Tokyo Station Hotel exudes elegance and refinement, and is one of the most convenient and comfortable places to be a base for your stay in Tokyo.
user_name:
Edmundo F
Seoul, Seoul, South Korea

review_body: Stayed again this June and got help from my personal favorite concierge Ms Mori on securing me a seat at the SUKIYABASHI Jiro Ginza again-map and tips were provided upon checking in.Everything was great as expected. :)

This is one of the best hotels in Tokyo. Before our trip, the concierge assisted us in making various dinner reservations. When we arrived, the reception checked us in an efficient and professional manner. They also provided us the detailed dinner reservations with map and transportation assistance. All staff were friendly and carried a great smile on their faces at any time (esp. we checked in at 2am on the first day and checked out at 5am on another day). The concierge also allowed us to leave our luggages in its storage room during our side trip to Okinawa, and when we re-checked in again, our luggages were already inside the room. The room was nice and decent sized; the lavatory and the bathroom were clean and with sufficient towels. Location is awesome as it's less than 10min walk from Narita Express Station. I highly recommend this hotel to tourists visiting Tokyo.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is by far one of the best hotels in Tokyo. The staff is very accommodating and helpful. The attention to detail from the lobby to the hallways and especially in the room are by far to be admired. My wife and I have been back to the hotel recently and truly loved the service and the location. For those of you who have never been to Tokyo, and are looking for a hotel to stay at, you must try the Tokyo Station Hotel!

best thing about this hotel is not only the greatest location which is just perfect if one has to move in and out of tokyo being right at the train station, but it is also the staff, service with a smile, which you usually get in japan almost everywhere, but here its very much visible, good food! everything is good, no complain at all, except just one thing, the room which i got had two levels, bedroom on upper level is bit tiring, only if they could tell me in advance, because i usually have knee pain climbing up stairs, so i have only this complain that they should have told me in advance, i hope they have rooms having bedroom on same floor, i assume there should be...

Great experience, location is absolutely wonderful, well worth the price. A wee bit snooty but quite easily overlooked with the attentive staff & downright beautiful hotel! As I learned on trip in Tokyo, much attention is given to detail, cleanliness & food! Hotel was on point on all counts.

Housed within the station building, this iconic hotel is top class. Very attentive staff, beautiful room with fabulous bathroom ensuite, wonderful breakfast which included European and Japanese selection. We chose this hotel primarily because we could catch the bus from Haneda airport direct to Tokyo station, knowing that next morning we would be in the right place to catch the Shinkansen train to Kyoto. Our first visit to Japan, and it made for a very straightforward start to the trip. Would certainly recommend. Not the cheapest option, but certainly well worth it.

Everything was on point. I chose the dome side room which has view of the station, if you look down you'll see people walking around. Quite a view indeed. Not to mention the hotel was right at Tokyo station- in the middle of everything really. Large room with beautiful chandelier and full size shower and bath rub. Service was great, everyone speaks good English too. Concierge was able to book us into most of the restaurants requested (and we only booked the room 2 weeks in advance- for some michelin stars one required longer notice). I just love the hotel and would definitely go back.

I stayed recently for business last eek. Easy access as its located right next to the main Tokyo train station. The staff are amazingly courteous, polite, and helpful. Excellent breakfast buffet serving both Japanese and Western selections.

We just spent 4 night at the Tokyo station hotel First we had a room with the view of the dome. The room was small but the amenities were 6 star quality. This size room is appropriate for a big city hotel . It was as nice as the Four seasons or Ritz Carleton we have stayed at. The bathroom shower was spa quality. Service could not be better. The chief Concierge , Marie Mori , went above and beyond any service I have received from a hotel. After a hard day of touring we went to the hotel spa for massages and to sit in the hot mineral baths. This is a world class spa that is tucked away in Tokyo. Great buffet breakfast and the staff knows enough English to take care of any needs. I plan to stay there again on my next trip. The location can't be beaten. You have every subway train and taxi at you door step .

i personally prefer this to the Peninsula hotel. P does have much bigger closet and TV area w coffee table. Since i normally spend most time outside of the hotel, the added space would be a waste. the room in TSH is very clean and nice deco. service from all staff are extremely good. very conveniently located for train and shopping and eating.

I called the concierge and asked where we could get a massage, because the spa was already closed. She was able to book a couple of therapists to come to our room that same evening! We asked about taking a side trip outside of Tokyo. She recommended Kyoto and she herself walked us to the train ticket booth, and helped us buy 2 tickets. The next morning, she arranged for a hotel escort to walk us to the train station where everything seemed crazy and confusing and we would had been lost for sure without the escort. The escort also took us to buy a Bento box for breakfast to enjoy on the train, like what Japanese people do. We asked about shopping. She knew exactly where to send me and my teenage daughter. We wanted fine dinner and she made reservations at a very interesting restaurant. The list goes on and on. And she always followed up with a typed note slipped under our door. He name is Marie Antoinette and she was magnificent! She made our trip so enjoyable. Thank you!Other than the great concierge service, the hotel appeared new, the room was nice, and breakfast buffet was sufficiently good. The location is fabulous if you need to take a train (the station is right next door), and there are lots of local shops and restaurants around also.

Hats off to Tokyo Station Hotel for incredible service. We stayed here for a few days at the tail end of a long Japan trip and it was the literally perfect place to stay. The accommodations were great, in-room massages wonderful & the breakfast room & buffet were a great place to start the day - especially a travel day. They packed up and shipped all of our luggage for us so we were able to travel light -- and when there was a complication at customs with our bags (because we had packed aerosols) they took the bags bag, repacked and made sure they got out again in a very timely fashion. Before our flight they walked us directly to the Narita Express making the transition incredibly smooth. Overall, an excellent stay and top-notch service. Highly recommend!

This is a culturally significant historic property within walking distance of the Imperial Palace and garden. Convenience of the location to Narita Express train and local subway system is simply perfect. It's still a train station underground, but quiet in the custom of the country. Inside and out this red brick station building has been tastefully renovated. Beautiful rooms with high ceilings, crown moulding and decorative nods to the early 1900s are well furnished and loaded with top notch bed and bath. When you visit the bar lounge and restaurant, and you must, you will not want to leave. Breakfast buffet is a bit pricey - splurge as it is so worth it. This is truly a clean, comfortable quiet classic Tokyo hotel. A great find, I plan to return.

This is the most thought-out hotel, in terms of guest comfort, that I've ever stayed in. Every detail is considered: spacious closets with lots of hangers, spacious bathroom with plenty of counter space to lay out all toiletries, super comfortable bedding, lighted makeup mirror, easily accessible power outlets at BOTH sides of the bed with reading lamps, great lighting everywhere with intuitive lighting control scheme, small leather tray to place miscellany as you enter the room, perfect shower water pressure, etc etc. Basically everything felt just right as soon as you walked into the room.Service was SUPERB, efficient, friendly, and very helpful. The concierge Mr. Tomonori Otsuka was so patient in helping us with train tickets (we were going to a small island that involved taking a high-speed as well as local trains and then a ferry), and when an accident on a train in front of ours caused a (extremely rare!) 3-hour delay on the Shinkansen, he even sent an email to see if we'd be able to arrive on the island in time and to see if he could be of any assistance. Very kind & personal.Design was luxurious & elegant -- old-world European in style but without fussiness; everything was new and pristine. The room had high ceilings and was very bright and airy, with blackout drapes to ensure a good night's sleep.Unfortunately I looked into bookings very late, and could only get one night at this hotel. Next time I will check earlier.

We stayed there for five days at the beginning of the Summer of 2015. The location is perfect--away from the hustle-bustle of the touristy areas of Tokyo. Each day we headed out to tackle a different area of Tokyo and we were always happy to escape back to the hotel at the end of each day. The staff is impeccable, the rooms are quite large (by Japanese standards) and well appointed (contemporary/modern). The proximity of the hotel to metro and regional trains is ideal. The hotel underwent a substantial renovation recently and thus it looks and feels brand new inside and out. My only "meh" moment was the breakfast. It is served in a luxurious dinning room but the selections (both Western and Asian) are paltry. It was surprising that the selections were not more varied or interesting, especially given how easy it is to provide breakfast choices. Overall, however, I would recommend this hotel and definitely will return there.

Loved this hotel and its location. We stayed in a Dome room. It was sound proof, plush, with a great view below of thousands of people coming and going from the train station. About 4 long blocks to the Imperial Palace Grounds. The atrium dining room was spectacular, and the lobby tea room with its afternoon harpist was a perfect wind-down to a long day.

Tokyo is expensive. Hotels are very expensive. My daughter and I had 36 hours in Tokyo and decided to splurge and stay here. Worth every penny because of the location. In the Tokyo train station, metro station underneath, Imperial Palace a block away and an amazing 5 story food court across the street. If you Re looking for anything near "budget", ignore this post. If you want the best value and location $400 can buy in Tokyo, stay here.

The hotel was very nice, the staff was excellent, and even though I felt out of place when seeing the other guests the staff did their best to make us feel at home.The room was exactly what was pictured on their website. It was very comfortable and felt up scale. I personally would try to avoid a dome side room at all costs, we checked every day leading up to our trip to see if we could change rooms, but unfortunately no other rooms were available. There is no natural lighting or outside facing windows in the room. The only view is of the inside of the train station, we left the curtains closed for the entirety of the stay. The in room WiFi was very fast and stable, it didn't drop once throughout the duration of our stay. The location is great, the hotel is a part of Tokyo Station, making travel very easy. The bathroom was amazing, it was by far my favorite part of the room. The rainfall shower was so relaxing that I could have just spent hours underneath it.

This is the first time that i have stayed at a hotel where its better in person than the pictures . WOW WOW! I stayed in the king size bed dome room . Amazing view of the train station . The room was spotless .....cleanest hotel ever! And the staff was amazing . Best Front desk and Concierge staff ever . They had my restaurant reservations scheduled from overseas and when i arrived they had the map with my name on it as well as all my packages and extra pillows as requested . They also walked me out to the taxi each time to make sure the taxi driver knew how to get to my destination  . But the one thing that put the service over the top was when the staff walked me to my train and waited 30 min for it to come so they could carry my luggage on board and make sure i was in the correct seat then she wrote in english how many stops i had until my next train exit . WOW!!!That is what i call 5* SERVICE ;O) ...........also a tip....please try the breakfast! most amazing french toast with maple butter ! i miss it already! This was my 1st hotel..... after a 20 hour flight and it was perfect , central location and quiet !

Beautiful building, nice rooms and unbeatable location. We had a queen room, cheapest category but it was still great. True, the bed is next to the window and you can't get out that side but that's probably the only thing I didn't like, and maybe a bit too much furniture for such a small room. Windows are double (or triple?) glazed, you get a view of the street which is nice, they were upgrading the whole square, but there was no noise. Bathroom is fantastic, as big as a room and it has everything you would expect.You can get from the hotel directly into the station, without going out, there is a passage from reception, hotel is really big, it takes a while to go from one end to the other. One of the best things were staff who actually came with us to the station, bought for us airport train ticket (Narita express has reserved seating), then help us with a luggage all the way to the train, in front of our car. We did ask only if they can help us with the luggage but this was beyond, I haven't experienced such a service from the hotel except in India. We didn't eat in the hotel as there are other places nearby, restaurants on top of shopping malls in front or small yakitori places under the train tracks (behind the hotel) which we preferred.

This hotel ranks among the very best of the best. The location alone is superb as it's actually inside the station itself, making local and long distance travel a breeze. It's also very convenient for the Narita Express which goes directly to the airport. The room was quite spacious (we booked the Palace View side) and serenely quiet. It came with high-end toiletries, coffeemaker, slippers and kimono, as well as a recrigerator, and daily newspaper. Really wonderful rainshower in the immaculate bathroom. We opted to not have any meals there as the station itself has literally hundreds of restaurants serving everything you could imagine from french pastries to Japanese tempura. Coffee shops everywhere. We would not consider staying anywhere else.

Staffs were polite and helpful. We arrived the hotel around 2 pm, the reception told us the room is not ready yet, we will have to wait till 2:30, so we decided to go and have lunch first. Came back at 3 pm, the luggages were all in the room already and they even upgraded us to a bigger room for keep us waiting. Love the decor and high ceiling in the room.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel on the last night of a 2 week trip to Japan. We stayed in a lot of nice places, but this hotel was probably our favorite. You cannot possibly get easier access to the train, including Narita Express back to the airport. The staff spoke good English and were very accommodating- on both sides of our stay we needed to store our luggage for a few hours, and they didn't even give it a second thought. One last point- the bathroom was pretty amazing.

a superb hotel within Tokyo station, all lines there including the shankasan/bullet train and subway. Rooms are very good, well equipped and staff very polite and helpful, in particular MS Mary and her colleague at the concierge desk.Will be there, in same hotel if will visit Tokyo again.

We booked the Tokyo Station Hotel for our first trip to Japan in April for three reasons. Firstly my wife, who was to celebrate a significant birthday, adored another restored railway hotel (St Pancras in London). Secondly I read on this site that the head concierge Ms Mori spoke fluent English which I though would be most helpful as we speak next to no Japanese. Thirdly we were to travel to Kyoto by Shinkansen and I felt this hotel might be very convenient for that purpose.Well, my wife did love the hotel which has been restored beautifully. We have three boys aged ten to fourteen and the rooms are plenty big enough even with an extra bed. If you like old and low rise you really should stay here.They are building an underground car park in the forecourt, but there is no noise and our rooms had a view over it towards the Imperial Palace. The bathrooms are lovely and heated Japanese toilet seats should go global.It is minutes to the train platform and a staff member showed us there with grace and charm. You can stop for a bento box en route.So the whole experience is glorious and you will probably enjoy Tokyo hugely as a result (we did), But I haven't written about the front desk staff. To say that Ms Mori and her concierge team are friendly and capable is like saying Lionel Messi and Barcelona can play football a bit. I have never, and i mean never, been treated as well as this. Want to celebrate your wife's birthday in style but aware this is a smart hotel and five Australian and Japanese kids in the hotel lobby might be frowned upon? Ms Mori will consult the general manager who will allow the use of a small private dining room off the airy atrium where breakfast is served. And without being asked, the waiter will take a picture of you all and present it to you five minutes later in a photo-folder embossed with the hotel crest. And when you return to your room there will be a beautiful flower arrangement for your wife and a bath towel folded into the shape of an elephant we christened Bertha.The lovely staff at the Tokyo Station Hotel made it very easy for us to enjoy their city, and they took, I think, genuine pleasure in doing so. I must ask Ms Mori to send one of her team down to Australia, because I'm quite sure they would organise my business and personal life a heck of a lot better than I do!

We stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel May 20-23, 2015 and had a delightful experience. First off the Meet and Greet Service at the Shinkansen platform was most helpful, and although I failed to get the name of the young woman who assisted us, she left a wonderful first impression of the service we experienced throughout our stay. Every person on the staff who we had contact with was efficient, friendly and went out of their way to help us have a great trip. Were it not for Marie Antoinette Mori and Tomonori Otsuka, we might still be out wandering the streets of Tokyo looking for our sometimes obscure destinations! My special thanks to Tomonori for being so helpful, patient and kind to us during our stay. I looked forward to our encounters with him - between he and Ms Mori, definitely one of the best concierge encounters I have experienced in my travels. The room (along with the entire Hotel) was impeccably spotless and gorgeously maintained. The bathroom was the best of the five hotels in our Japan trip. It had a lovely huge soaking tub and a fantastic rain shower that was perfect for relaxing after a long day walking around. We also greatly enjoyed the convenient location of the Hotel for ending our trip and going to Narita Airport (again, where the very helpful young woman and a young gentleman helped us get back to the platform with our luggage). All in all, one of the very best hotel experiences we've had - other hotels should take a course in The Tokyo Station Hotel way of professionalism with their kind, patient and helpful attitude of everyone on the staff (other hotels , although very efficient, were a bit stuffy and abrupt). Our trip ended on a very high note because of this great hotel experience. Thanks to all! JT

I stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel during May 17th - 19th 2015. There are many factors that cause me to want to give it a full mark. 1. Location : Being right at Tokyo station was very convenient because you have both Metro and JR train to choose plus when you email the concierge at least 24 hours prior to your arrival, they will send you instructions of how to arrange the Meet and Greet service at the Narita Express platform. 2. Service : Let me start from the legendary Ms. Marie Antoinette Mori, I read from Tripadvisors before I chose this hotel that this Chief Concierge Lady would do all she can to make it happen for the clients. And she did it for me as well. She managed to book me two Michelin Star restaurants that one of them was quite hard to book. I only realize how hard it was to book the restaurant only when my friend told me that she tried to book this restaurant two months in advance without success, but I only wrote about three weeks before I arrived and Ms. Mori made it happen for me.  Other staffs were mostly equally enthusiastic and I need to specially thank Mr. Yoshiki Kamata the Duty Manager on May 17th 2015 that kindly took me to the room personally to make me able to refresh as soon as possible to continue on to my dinner appointment. 3. Comfort and Quiet : My bedroom window was facing the interior of the hotel I could even see people on escalator in the train station through the grill butI could not hear any noise coming in. 4. Breakfast : The food, fruits, coffee, service... everything was just perfect. 5. Perfection : Did I mention everything was perfect. Just let it be known and I'm certain the staffs at The Tokyo Station will try to make it happen for you in a very classy manner. P.S. I forgot my iPhone chargers at the room and I emailed the hotel from the airport. The next day they were already posting my chargers to be waiting for me at the hotel in Fukuoka that I'll be staying at. And they even offer to pay for the postal despite me asking them to charge my credit card. Thank you all the staffs at The Tokyo Station Hotel. You really can be proud of your work. Thank you for everything. Best regards,Dr. Ukrit

I especially appreciated the two people working as Concierge: Marie Antoinette Mori and Tomonori Otsuka. They both were very helpful. They gave perfect directions and wonderful suggestions on where to visit and eat. Very good buffet breakfast for $35. Great bathroom facilities. Bed very comfortable. I was surprised that many Japanese do not speak very much English. It was a bit difficult to communicate with people, especially with those in positions that are suppose to be helpful to visitors.

Excellent hotel with great service and location. Hotel room is clean, spacious and very quite. Wifi is free and stable. This is a very special experience to "stay" in this historical station. Will definitely stay at this hotel on our next trip.

We had stayed at TSH once before in Jan 2014 and decided to stay again primarily due to the convenience factor. We were only staying one night, coming in from Kyoto by train and leaving for Narita airport next day.We were quite disappointed this time our room did not have much of a view, even though we booked a palace view room.The room we were in was also very loud, firstly we could hear trains rattling below us & second there was construction work directly outside our room which ran until midnight on a Saturday evening.When we rang the front desk to ask if we could move to a quieter part of the hotel, we were told only if we were willing to pay for a full upgrade. Given it was 10pm and we were checking out the next morning & we were given no warning about the major digging happening directly outside our window - this is really poor service. If they had a better room on a quiet side of the hotel vacant anyway, they would have lost nothing letting us move there for one night given the problem we had.We stayed at the Capitol Hotel when we first arrived in Tokyo & they had a notice in the rooms warning of any construction work during May and which parts of the hotel it may effect - we had zero warning at TSH. Also quiet envious of all the reports of help finding the narita express platform and help with luggage...after not much sleep we got no such offer at checkout / though we did ask for directions, what we got was not particularly helpful. Wondered around for about 15 mins before we found it.
user_name:
Neil M
London, England, United Kingdom

review_body: We booked a Dome King room overlooking one of the Railway Station Hotel concourses for two nights. It's bigger than their standard room and not much dearer. We had bought JR train passes which also gave us a 10% discount on the hotel. All our trains arrived and departed from this station making it very convenient. No need for taxis - wheeling luggage from and to platforms was fine. Plenty of small eateries and convenience stores in the actual station itself. Staff service was excellent - the best we have anywhere. We arrived in the morning from a cruise, dropped our luggage off and went out to Disneyland. On our return, we were escorted to our room. Very well appointed - won't spoil the surprises with details! Our luggage was already there and we were shown where things were. Next day they tried to help us print boarding passes but our airline's website kept crashing. On departure, they offered to help us with our luggage to the Narita Express platform. We rate this hotel slightly ahead of the Fairmounts of Canada (Banff Springs, Lake Louise, etc) for room comfort and customer service. But hey, we'd be happy back with them as well, especially for the views! However, the Tokyo Station Hotel wins on price. It was also way less than other five star hotels near Tokyo Station.

Picked this hotel as a treat to end our stay in Japan. Also because of it's location for easy access to the narita express to the airport. Beautiful restoration of the old hotel. Lovely ambience. The staff are well trained and very attentive. Room was not large but well appointed. Had dinner in their iltalian restaurant as we tired of japanese food, and found the price quite reasonable, and food good quality. Good choice for central Tokyo.

I visited the hotel with my elderly mother. The room was gorgeous with every amenity possible. The breakfast buffet is amazing. The staff were incredibly friendly and helpful. They helped us buy our ticket for the train to Narita and arranged for a porter to help us with our bags and guide us all the way down to the right platform. While on the train my mother lost her purse. When I got home I contacted the hotel and Marie, their concierge, tracked the purse down and had it shipped to us with everything still in the purse! Marie was also superb in arranging for luggage transfer services and transportation from our cruise ship to the hotel. Her service and that of her staff was five stars!This is a boutique hotel even though it looks huge from the outside, so don't expect massive lobbies and common areas. But it's location at the train station is great and you can easily walk to the imperial gardens and the Ginza area.This place was five stars and definitely worth the cost for us.Pierre from California

At the end of a long day of a coach tour to Mount Fuji, my friends and I decided to end the evening with a cup of hot chocolate, coffee and cake. We decided to do it in style at the Tokyo Station Hotel and headed to the ground floor lounge which had unfortunately closed for the evening. But the Captain on duty very kindly called another lounge that served coffee and cake to ensure that it was still open. A waitress showed us the way and found us a comfortable table.It was my birthday and one friend had whispered that fact to the waitress who took our orders.When the slices of cake arrived, one had a candle on it and some of the staff joined us in singing the birthday song. Then the captain took a photo of my group and presented the picture to me in a little card frame.These were lovely touches to end the day.I'd just like to thank the staff at the hotel for being so gracious and wonderful. They were faultlessly courteous and made everything feel so special.Thank you, Tokyo Station Hotel.PS--we did not stay at the hotel, we were merely walk-in guests. But the service made us wish we were staying there!

I expected a more grand experience based on the price and reviews. There really isn't much of a main lobby, and the restaurants/bar aren't on the main floor. The staff was friendly enough, but the fact that they couldn't print a boarding pass for us and instead directed us to the business center where we had to insert coins into the computer doesn't really reflect the caliber of hotel they claim to be. The room was very nicely decorated and well appointed, however it was the smallest we had while in Japan. The location at the train station was convenient as a stopover for one night from Kyoto to Narita, however, the area around the station isn't very lively at night and the crowd at the hotel itself was much more mature (we are in our 30's).While the hotel is nice enough, I thought it was too pricy for the experience. I wouldn't choose this property again, nor would I recommend it. We had a much better time at the Hotel Century Southern Tower in Shinjuku.

The hotel is actually inside the tokyo station on marunouchi exit side which is closer to narita express train from the airport and also convenient to the JR ticket booth. There are several shop and take away food inside the tokyo station. When I first enter the hotel the staff are very welcoming with the polite gesture and smile. They are very helpful with everything you ask for. The hotel give you contemporary but still in classical feeling. I stay in the maisonette room which you had the bed on the upper stories and living space, bathroom on the ground level however they have another WC on the upper stories too. I found it very nice for the perfume they use when i open the room i always smell pleasing scent I believe it bvlgari the same amenities they use in the bathroom. There are 2 tv, dvd player, refrigerator, coffee machine, kettle. etc as hotel standard. For breakfast there are varieties of juice in the glass container, a wide variety of japans breakfast but little corner of american breakfast but there are still bread bakery and egg station. I found that the staff in the restaurant are not really welcoming but they didn't be rude just the un friendly feel however still in good gesture. Overall I am satified with the staff and the hotel.

This hotel is great for exploring Tokyo as it is right in the central station building: the main hub where all the JR lines and metro lines go through. Although the Chiyoda area itself is quite a quiet business area so it's not super noisy at night like some of the more livelier areas of town, there are still plenty of places to eat and karaoke bars etc nearby so you don;t have to get on a train to entertain yourself. The hotel itself was beautifully done - we had a dome view room which looked onto the inside of the station, so no views over Tokyo - that is really the only downside of this hotel - it's only about 4 storey's high so you don't get views. The staff were great, we arrived tired and jetlagged on a rainy day 3 hours ahead of check-in time and they took us to a dressing room so we could change, took our luggage, loaned us an umbrella and gave us a map of the nearby area, pointing out places we could get some lunch. When we got checked in they brought us a fruit platter and took our photo (it was our honeymoon) which they then presented to us along with a book about the hotel. We didnlt eat in the restaurants in the hotel, but we had cocktails and whiskey in the tiny 'oak bar' which was very cool and had a great atmosphere.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is one of the most luxurious hotels in Tokyo. The service is impeccable and the design is exquisite. Complimentary meet and greet service at Tokyo Station was extremely helpful since Tokyo Station is fairly large and most of the railway staff don't speak english. The purpose of my visit to Tokyo was actually to try out Sukiyabashi Jiro. Since the restaurant only had ten seats, it was extremely difficult to secure a reservation. Despite all the challenges, Mori, Chief Concierge at the Tokyo Station Hotel made the impossible possible. She was really helpful and courteous and offered many other michelin restaurant suggestions for my upcoming visits to Tokyo. I would recommend anyone who wishes to stay at the hotel to contact her if you want reservations at popular restaurants. All of the staff stopped and bowed whenever I walked through the hotel lobby and hallways; it was more like staying in a palace than in a hotel! The only problem I had at this hotel was that I was originally booked into a Dome side room. When i made the reservation the staff told me that the rooms are overlooking the station but there won't be any noise in the room. Upon arriving to the room i could hear railway announcements coming from the station every 5 minutes or so. I requested a room change however the hotel was at high capacity. I was offered 2 options, to downgrade to a lower category room at not charge, or to pay 3000 yen in addition to switch to a slightly larger room of the same room category. I already paid a fairly amount of money for the Dome room so of course of chose to upgrade the room. When i checked out, the front desk agent apologized about the extra charge and told me again that they charged me because the hotel was full. I was confused about why they charged me extra when it wasn't my fault that the hotel was full and that my original room was noisy. Standard procedure should've been an upgrade without charge. But other than this minor billing issue, everything else was fine.

I stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel for a night during my recent trip. Although the location is excellent, it took me quite a few minutes to make my way to the hotel. Located on the Marunouchi side of Tokyo Station, it is not as easy for make your way there from the ground floor, if you're not familiar with the labyrinth that is Tokyo Station. It was only after navigating the underground pathways that I managed to make my way there. Thankfully the concierge later pointed out a short cut if I'm on the ground floor. There's a direct pathway from the Yaesu North side of Tokyo Station to the Marunouchi North side, and from there it's just another minute's walk.The hotel itself is a wonderful combination of colonial and modern design elements. It certainly feels more like a boutique than mega hotel, very much in line with it's membership in the SLH group of hotels. They were out of single rooms the night I stayed, as such I made do with a twin room. The size is just nice for two people, very cosy. The beds are quite comfortable and they somehow managed to include a little seating area despite the room's size. The bathroom area is just right and even includes a bathtub. Water pressure was good. The staff are very helpful, always greeting guests with a smile and providing as much information as possible. With it's unparalleled location at Tokyo Station, you can get to almost any of the train platforms within 5 minutes or so. Access to shopping and food is also a few minutes walk away, with Daimaru at the Yaesu side of Tokyo Station. Although my stay was just one night, I must say that I would be more than happy to reside there during my next visit to Tokyo.

I and my husband selected this hotel for our Birthday celebration. We loved shopping and tried Michelin-star food in Tokyo. I contacted conciege for restaurant reservation for Jiro Sushi ( 3-star michlein and very difficult to make reservation) and some other restaurants. Marie Antoinette Mori, Chief Concierge, replied me and she was very kind and helpful. She finally made my dream for Jiro Sushi come true. When I arrived the hotel, I met her and she was very nice and always assisted us. I was very impressed and happy. I love everything in Tokyo Station Hotel, decoration, service, very good breakfast, nice room, perfect location. I felt like home. I will definitely come back to this beautiful hotel again. Thank you for making such an unforgettable memory to us :)

The hotel is right above the station but absolutely no noise! It was fully restored in 2012 , even keeping the very ceilings in the bedrooms. It is a great location for most tours and opposite many, many restaurants as well as a minimarket.

Beautiful & sophisticated hotel, great location at Tokyo train station. Staff were lovely & polite! Rooms were gorgeous, comfy bed, clean & large bathroom area with bath & big shower. Really comfortable & enjoyable stay. A highlight of my trip in Japan! Highly recommend for comfort and location. Stayed end of April

Wonderful hotel, great location at Tokyo Station. Very comfortable room with probably the best hotel bathroom I can remember - large bath, huge rain-shower (separate). We didn't get a chance to try the breakfast in the great looking room on level 4. The reception area is comfortable with lots of loungechairs, the staff very attentive and of course the entire hotel is immaculately clean. Impossible to fault this hotel.

Surprise surprise! From the great service and detail decor, I enjoyed every bit of the time in this hotel. The bath is amazing. The luxury of using the washroom was worth all the money spent but well worth it. I love the spacious room according to Tokyo standard. High ceiling height and feel so good. Walking outside of the hotel is all the convenience of being right at the Tokyo Station. If you use JR pass, this is a great place to hub in Tokyo for a night.

I stayed at the Tokyo Station hotel for 4 nights. The hotel is conveniently located above the Tokyo train station. Access to all if Tokyo's tourist spots are within reach.There are 3 buildings across from the hotel with a variety of food options.Service was fantastic and staff couldn't do enough for us. Rooms were amazing and beds were very comfortable.I'd definitely recommend to others

This hotel is conveniently located in the Tokyo train station, by the Marounouchi south exit. The services (front desk staff to guest services such as luggage handling) were efficient and friendly. The amenities/decor in the room were well appointed. It's quiet as the windows are double-paned (our room faced the street but absolutely no traffic noise!), beds were more than comfortable and above all it's clean. Given the hotel was recently renovated, close to three years already but the maintenance of the hotel is meticulous as there were hardly any dents or scratches on the walls or on edges of door frames.One of the attractions of this hotel is its location. Given it's at the Tokyo Train station, there isn't far to go to catch the Shinkansen (bullet trains) or other JR trains that service either Narita or Handea airports, as well as several of the Tokyo subway lines.The only minor complaint is that the blackout curtains are not quite catching the ceiling so lights comes through when the sun rises. If Tokyo Station Hotel can address this minor issue, this hotel is a ten in my book.We didn't have breakfast at the hotel, as it costs approx $40 pp. There are plenty of restaurants in the area so one could always eat elsewhere.

By expensive, I mean $425 a night. The reasons for the "but," are three: 1) Given the elegance and the price I was surprised that the didn't have turn-down service; 2) The concierge service was spotty, the desk not attended throughout the day; and, 3) Their only breakfast offering is a full buffet breakfast at $35.00.

I usually don't write bad reviews. This is because I make a thorough examination prior to reserving hotels. This time I wasnt satisified.We were greated coldly and unpolitely by the recepsionist. No greatins no explanations nothing. Then escorted to our room a king dome. The employee escorting us said you will need to exercise. It was a half kilometer to our room. Un reasonable!!!. The room was tiny and one side of the bed was attached to the wall. So if one of us needed to go to the bathroom he had to wake the other. I refused to accept the room and again after a thorough unpleasent discussions they provided us a tween room which was better.The breakfast is very expensive so we skiped it.After 2 weeks in Japan mostly in 4 stars hotel this was our worst experience in this 5 stars establishment.Notice that there is also large construction work in front of the hotel.I didnt find the location comfortable too. It is 15 minutes walk at least to Ginza.I can't reccomend this hotel

This time I had two nights in Tokyo so I went back to my ever-reliable choice, the Tokyo Station Hotel. As usual, all staff were extremely polite and warm. I stayed in a different room this time (the last two times I stayed in the inner room and the dome room), the imperial palace-facing side which I highly recommend. It is definitely more spacious but it is slightly higher-priced than the other rooms. That said, with such a great location, excellent service, fantastic food, and a diverse whisky range in the mini-bar, what's there not to like? The free WiFi is also super fast and reliable. Bathrooms are so luxurious, you feel like you can live in them. You really can't go wrong with TTSH!

has a lot of character, chic, modern yet classical, clean, light and airy.... ultra convenient location... pricey but worth it. i had considered staying at the Hyatt with the influence of "lost in translation" but so not regretting my decision to stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel. Staff amazing - perfect combination of friendliness and distance.

We took a long time deciding on a hotel in Tokyo for our 6 day stay and after reading Trip Advisor and doing research we decided on Tokyo Station Hotel...and what a brilliant decision.The staff met us at the train and weaved us through the train station which was in full working mode as it was peak time...it was done with consummate ease..and within minutes we were in the foyer where the staff greeted us like welcome friends..check in was wonderful and the duty manager was so forthcoming with information -we just knew this holiday was going to be one to remember.Of course I had been communicated with Marie Antoinette Mori and as expected she too was just divine....so calm and wonderful and as with all staff at the hotel things just happened with a minimum of fuss and done even before we knew that was what we wanted.The location-- perfect is an understatement...right next to the Tokyo Station so you can jump on trains, subways and buses with such ease and be at one of the thousands of places we had on our must do list.....and like homing birds we knew we just had to get back to Tokyo railway station and we could get back to our rooms and relaxThe shops around the hotel are excellent- mind you a bit expensive but Kitte was the stand out for that special gift for that special person.Back to the hotel..the rooms were most spacious and we had a Palace view room...the beds are perfect...for that well earned night's sleep..the bathrooms were sumptuous..with the best wet room I have ever had in a hotel...a large shower over head as well as a normal shower and bath so deep that you can pamper yourselves.Have to mention the great coffee that you have in the room. The coffee is one off filtered coffee and it was so nice..so much better than the instant coffee you normally get in hotels. It was just these small touch's which just added to the perfect ambiance of this excellent hotel.Yes happy to say the corridors are long but there is a great lift half way along the major corridors and this brings you out onto the area in front of the railway station and was the exit and entrance we used each day...so really so easy.We had lots of meals at the enormous array of restaurants underneath the Tokyo railway station lines....best places to eat..so many options and of the 5 places we tried not one of them let us down. Walk out the door of the hotel and go either right and left and walk down the side of the railway and just find restaurant after restaurant all with delicious food and sake....and just so much fun.....and food was so tasty.There are great supermarkets in the bottom floors of Marunouchi buildings and the alcohol is cheaper in these shops than at duty free....which amazed us so muchWould I stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel again...yes within a heart beat....it was a serene, lovely haven, so comfortable and the rooms were spotless, superb and completely comfortable....and the staff always there to resolve queries. Well done Tokyo Station Hotel...you made our trip so memorable.

Being an avid traveller in Japan, I always try to book a new hotel to explore new places. And while many booking websites offer the "Tokyo Station Hotel", it's never ever available. Add to this the special location, and the "Tokyo Station Hotel" becomes a bit of a myth. When entering the station via the North or South gate one can gaze up to the rooms, but little have gazed down from those rooms.So when the "Tokyo Station Hotel" was available using my favourite booking site, I took my chance! From the moment I checked in to the moment I left, it lived up to its reputation. It starts with the location, which of course is very convenient. Tokyo Station is in the centre of town and of course every other place can easily be reached from the station.My room (#3031) was a mid sized room, overlooking the square in front of the station. The style is classic, but certainly not old or outdated. Everything looks so clean that one thinks he/she is the first person ever to stay in that room. The bathroom is positively huge, with a big bath, hand shower and rain shower. The safe is big enough to hold a laptop and a DSLR camera. The beds are big and comfortable, with good pillows.If I have something to complain, it has to be in the minor details. The shoe shine service is just a courtisy of the staff, while some other high class hotels hire professional shoe-shiners to do the job (the difference in the result is obvious). Also, the bar closes quiet early (22.00) and that seems a bit odd for a bar.Other than that, this hotel leaves little to be desired. Thanks to excellent sound insulation, one can sleep in late while tens of thousands of workers move in and out of the station underneath travelling from and to work. And this is the magic of the "Tokyo Station Hotel": it gives the very priviliged feeling of being in an exclusive bubble, an oasis of peace and quiet amidst the hussle and bussle of Tokyo Station.

We stayed here just over a week ago for our last two nights in Tokyo before flying back to London. We had high hopes for the hotel given the reviews and the pictures, but were disappointed during our stay. Having stayed at The Capitol on our arrival in Tokyo we felt there was a big dip in service and quality. The room was smaller than we expected and laid out in a very strange manner, over stuffed with furniture leaving little room to move around. All the restaurants were already fully booked until late and the room service menu was pitiful. I expected it to be on a par with a Ritz Carlton or a Relais Chateaux hotel but it wasn’t the same by any means. The two best things about the hotel are the original architecture and the location. It was at least perfect for when we had to leave at 6am to get the express train to Narita. Very disappointing for our last two nights after an amazing two week stay in Japan. Would not stay here again. For over £600 GBP we expected better.

Love this hotel. It's classic but also stylish. The hotel staffs are very well trained - professional and very friendly. The concierge service is a big plus. They responded to my requests very quickly and kindly helped me to book the restaurants & Shinkansen ticket. The place where I had my breakfast was also lovely. I'll definitely come back to Tokyo Station Hotel when I visit Tokyo again.

in short, what a bea-uuuuu-tiful stay we had at TSH! ... the perfect place, and prettiest area, to base yourself at when exploring tokyo over a few days... more details will spoil the beautiful surprise awaiting future guests... special mention to takei miwa at the front desk for her wonderful service and thoughtfulness! [just a tip] : the basic rooms (i.e. classic) range in size... because of the large area attributed to the beautiful bathroom, regardless of the number of people in your party, i would not get a room smaller than 36sqm...

Perfect location for our first nights on honeymoon in Japan - so easy to find the hotel coming in from the airport. Service from the concierge lady was brilliant - when we asked where to find the ticketing office she came with us and stayed and helped organise all our train reservations for the next week! Very handy given our non-existent Japanese language skills! Easy to get to other Tokyo highlights from here as well. Room was very interesting, looking out over the station concourse inside the dome.

This is a super cool, high end hotel, right in the heart of it all. being at the train station is very convenient to move around Tokyo and japan. Its quite expensive, but well worth the stay. if you have the budget, this is a "must stay at" hotel

- Strategically located at Tokyo Station. Easy access to the hotel from the train station.- Everything is in the room is in perfect condition. Spacious room, amazing bathroom/toilet.- Breakfast in Atrium with sufficient spread and choices.- The front desk/concierge/guest relation staff here are absolutely the gem of the hotel. They are the most courteous, friendly and helpful staff I have ever encountered.

Everything that we hoped for and more. The location is exceptional--directly on top of the main Tokyo train and metro/subway station, a direct 50 minute train ride from Narita international airport, even closer to the domestic Haneda airport and links to the Shinkansen Super-Fast Trains. The hotel has lovely appointments and is in immaculate condition, having been very recently renovated/refurbished and is scrupulously maintained. It is an oasis of peace, quiet, and calmness. The staff are very helpful and friendly, and quite a few speak very good english--do not take this for granted. This was so welcome to a couple of road weary, even if reasonably experienced travelers on our first visit to Japan. They cheerfully assisted us in learning to navigate the extensive Tokyo metro system, even escorting us to purchase tickets and then carting our luggage to the train platform. They concierge unerringly directed us to the "kitchen district" of Tokyo where we purchased several items of "Japanese fake food" (an ice cream sundae, spaghetti with clam sauce and a fried egg--remarkably realistic!). Last and not least, the breakfast buffet in the Atrium was a delight. It was extensive and attractively presented, had Japanese and western foods and everything was fresh and delicious--and had the best "french toast" we have ever tasted! Tokyo Station Hotel kept things manageable and enjoyable for us in a dizzy whirlwind situation. This was exactly the right entry and departure point for our first visit in Japan (spent primarily in Hiroshima and Kyoto). We would absolutely do the same again, and spend more time in Tokyo based at the delightful TSH.

absolutely the most convenient location in Tokyo - unbeatable for the air traveller; extremely efficient check inrooms were a totally unexpected surprise - spacious, luxurious, amazing bathrooms and very comfortable beds

If you want to stay at one of the most convenient locations in all of Tokyo, the historic Tokyo Station Hotel (now celebrating it's 100th anniversary) is the place to be. My wife and I stayed here our first night in Tokyo before taking the Shinkansen the next day. Due to it's location on the second floor of one of the busiest transit hubs in the world, it was hard to image we'd get a good night's sleep but it was surprisingly tranquil. The completely renovated and modernized hotel makes the most out of older, smaller hotel rooms (there was only space to get out of our King bed on the right side only!), with a more than adequate bathroom, and wonderful toiletries. Do expect a bit of walking though, this hotel is more long than it is tall and some rooms are quite far from the door, although with multiple entrances to the hotel it does help a bit. It was hard to say about the service as we were there only one night, but it was up to local 5-star standards. The amenities were minimal, with a gym which required a fee to use, and some nice restaurants scattered throughout the property. All in all, a great place to stay if you are planning to use Tokyo Station to travel or are on business.

One of the best in the world. Reminds be of the Renaissance St. Pancras in London (where the terminus of the EoroStar is located). Super Luxury. Attached to the Tokyo Central Train Station. Completely remodeled and restored in 2012. Tourists take pictures of the hotel as it is a Japanese icon. This neighborhood is great---but food is quite expensive. A lot of office buildings are close-by that are open late. Most have many, many floors of restaurants that are "hidden". Look for a directory in the lobby (like at a department store) that tells you what is in the building and where. There are even pictures of the food offered on the signs so no language problem.Two “special” doors registered guests only can use. One directly to the Station and one to the path to the Ginza. Very expensive food. Buy the breakfast package. You’ll get an elite breakfast in the rotunda room only available to registered guests. Take a bullet train from the adjacent station to anywhere in Japan. I love this place! BRAVO to every staff member I encountered.

The subject of a recent and tasteful refurbishment, the Tokyo Station Hotel will undoubtedly remain a landmark for another century. Although now dwarfed by the surrounding skyscrapers its convenient location (directly above Tokyo Central Station (exit Marunouchi Central or South)) and low-rise facade (it is just four stories) ensure that its graceful air of importance has not been lost. Built in 1910 in Victorian style the Tokyo Station Hotel was unquestionably fashioned after the grand hotels of Europe and its soaring atriums, bustling lobby cafe, and panelled 'Oak Bar' lend a certain standing to this hotel that the international five-star chains inevitably work hard to replicate. Given the extent of the refurb this is no mean feat and one feels the weight of history here as surely as in Claridges or in the Savoy.The room was generous (300 sq feet) although some look onto a light well rather than the square and the Imperial Palace beyond. Served from 06:30, the buffet breakfast is suitably lavish although North Americans may find it slim pickings with little in the way of eggs, bacon, pancakes and the like. As everywhere in Japan, service is highly prized and nothing seems to be too much trouble. Courtesy sets are Gilchrist and Soames, the one low-rent moment in an otherwise flawless, one-night stay.

Very central for our needs.Staff excellent and friendly.Access to JR trains,subway and Narita Express to airport all immediately next to Hotel and about 5 minutes walk to the platforms.Booking office for JR 5 metres from Hotel side door.Quality of Hotel fittings immaculate.Had a large room looking directly down to the Emperors Palace.Room very quiet.Son left expensive watch behind which was located and posted to our home address.Lady playing the harp each afternoon in the bar/tea room seemed a nice touch.Although reasonably expensive it sure beats those high rise office type of hotels in the area.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel in January 2015. The hotel itself is very new and in a very convenient location. We had non smoking interconnecting rooms. The buffet breakfast is really nice but the restaurants are very expensive for dinner. There is a shopping centre over the road called Kitte shopping centre that has a couple of floors of more reasonably priced restaurants. There are also restaurants in the actual station and surrounding streets. This hotel is very detailed oriented, they left us an English version of a Japanese paper outside our room every morning of our stay. The staff speak English and nothing is too much trouble for them. An excellent place to stay.

The location is great, the service is great, and the concierge is awesome.It's located right next to the Tokyo station, so you're at a great hub to get anywhere in the city. It's clean and roomy, and the staff is all very courteous and helpful. The concierge was also able to help us get reservations for dinner and book a ticket for the train back to Narita so we could catch our plane on time. We will definitely stay there on our next trip to Tokyo.

The location by the train station is great. It made it very easy to travel to and from the airport around Tokyo and to out next destination in Japan. The hotel was very clean. The service is excellent. Breakfast was very good but a bit pricey. We got the lowest category room and it was very small. No enough space to keep two suitcases open and only one draw in the room. There was no view from the window. Just some grating and beyond that the inside of the train station.

Our experience at The Tokyo Station Hotel was wonderful from start to finish. Ms. Aya from reservations made sure that all of my request (flowers, champagne and chocolates) was carried out with precision and made sure that we were greeted at the train platform and escorted to the hotel with ease. Ms.Marie from concierge had our concert tickets waiting for us upon check-in and had the train schedule and route to stadium printed out, which was perfect since this was our first time in Tokyo. The entire staff was very friendly and helpful making this one of the best stays we've had in a very long time. To sum it up: Everyone should stay at The Tokyo Station Hotel at least once in their lifetime if they want to be spoiled and pampered like Royalty. Thanks again for a wonderful experience.

We only stayed in this hotel for one night unfortunately. It is in a great location, right next to the Tokyo main train station which is a great base for getting around Tokyo and to and from Narita airport. The surrounding area is also interesting with some great restaurants and close to the Imperial Palace. The hotel is immaculate in every way, friendly staff and the bed was very comfortable. Room was small but very well appointed and the bathroom was divine. It was an immaculate hotel which amazing attention to detail. Would highly recommend this hotel.

We based our booking on Trip Advisors excellent rating for this hotel. We stayed for four nights and While this property may not have the sexiness of a Four Seasons Marunouchi or the Mandarin Oriental, you cannot beat the locaiton and the pricing is typically 30-35% less than most other Five Stars. You are literally above the the JR Tokyo Station and have access to all the nearby shopping of Ginza and Marunouchi. We stayed in a basic queen size room which is cosy and typically small for Tokyo. Beds are comfortable and quality of furnishings are what you would expect of 5 Star accomodations.Staff are incredibly hard working (including pickup/dropoff at your train), and the concierge (thanks Ms. Mori) are fabulous. They helped us to secure a reservation at Jiro - one of the toughest on the planet to be able to score.We tried the Spa Tokione downstairs and it was adequate again about 30-35% less than most of the other spas in major hotels in the area. If convenience and basic comfort are your style, you can't go too far wrong with this five star hotel on the budget/value end of the spectrum. Expect to be paying in the US$300/night range.Good luck and enjoy!!!

Location location location from here you can get to everywhere in Tokyo and even walk just down the street to the Imperial Palace. The hotel had been fully refurbished since the last time I was in Tokyo and it is a beautiful historic building. I booked a Dome room and this is an expensive upgrade I have to say the room was beautiful and looked into the large inner dome of the station. Unfortunately the room was so small that the double bed was so close to the side wall that it was impossible to get in and out of one side of the bed. After three phone calls with management and a request for an extra 6000 yen per night, which we refused to pay, we were eventually moved to a twin ordinary room. I have to say the room was a great size and very well appointed but disappointing as we had booked a Dome room and our expectations of this luxurious opulent room were dashed. Breakfast is charged at what equates to £22 per night and nothing would entice me to pay this sort of money for breakfast anywhere.

Beautiful historical building that is in a really good location. It is on Tokyo station, so it really easy to get to Shinkensan, JR trains and subways. The staff are really friendly and helpful. The room was nice. However, it is expensive and you don't get many inclusions for the price. If you are looking a quick and cheap feed, the station itself has a good selection, just go through the JR gates.

Very nice restaurant at top floor ( I only try breakfast)Others restaurant does not look attractive to me.commut is very good for sure!Not big lobby( understandable for central station)With Window but no view!

First impressions were great. We chose this hotel as we needed to be close to the station for our ongoing journey & you can't get any closer. We booked a room in the dome. It was a little strange opening the curtains to find commuters/tourists looking up to the beautiful dome but all added to the charm. Sophisticated decor, comfy bed & felt very European. Interesting to watch all the very well dressed Japanese taking afternoon tea in the lobby cafe.One thing that we were not impressed with was the breakfast. We headed to breakfast only to be told that we would have to wait 30mins for a table.....not acceptable in a high end hotel like this one. We declined & headed out to find a traditional cafe close by where we were very happy.Overall though a good stay & could not fault the staff in any way...professional, courteous & extremely helpful.

I stayed at Tokyo station Hotel for 3 nights with my family (one child) in January 2015.The location was very good in terms of access to the station. The Maronouchi area is a prestigious area for offices, therefore you can easily find places to eat near the tokyo station hotel, since it is connected to the shopping mall next to the station. However, the location is not as vibrant as Shinjuku area or Shibuya. But, in Tokyo you can find tourist attraction not just in shibuya or shinjuku, therefore access to the public transport is very important in visiting tokyo area. and tokyo station hotel is perfectly located just above the station.Room, even it is quite small, the bed was veery comfortable and the decor was elegant and it was new. we felt very comfortable in our room.The staff were very polite and it happened to all the people in Japan, since they are famously polite and nice. they were helpful and I got early check in at 1 pm (should be requested first)Overall, i would like to recommend this hotel who'd like to visit Tokyo.

Only had a brief stay over in Tokyo this time two nights , but glad it was at the Station Hotel, greeted by doorman then some wonderful reception staff , concierge , porters. Our room was fantastic , had all you need including a great big bath to soak away in. Location is as you would expect, central . Wonderful experience, thank you .

Tokyo Station Hotel lies in the dead heart of Tokyo. Just three stories high, it's hardly the typical hotel. Tokyo Station Hotel is steeped in one-hundred years of history. Otherwise, who would build a three-story structure in one of the most exclusive prime properties in Japan in the year 2012? One of the third-floor junior suites affords a perfect view of the central street sandwiched between two high-rises, with just a glimpse of the imperial palace grounds in the distance. It's a view that has changed, but hasn't changed for a century. Someone looked out a window from the old hotel in the same direction, surrounded by the luxury of those days, one hundred years ago. Perhaps they dined on a terrace. That's what makes the Tokyo Station Hotel exclusive. The hotel has witnessed two world wars and rapid economic growth, followed by a bubble economy, then a long recession. Millions have stayed there, dined there, passed through or by there. The old red brick building has greeted visitors from throughout Japan and the world for one-hundred years now - yes, some of the old centennial bricks have been plastered in cosmetically in parts of the same building. People have honeymooned there, said their farewells there - at Tokyo's central hub station - and passed by there on their way to work every day there for a century. The joys and sorrows and hopes and dreams of millions have passed through or by Tokyo Station Hotel. So long after we are gone... maybe another century later... someone will look out the same window and marvel at what has happened over the generations... it's that perspective that makes it worth staying at the Tokyo Station Hotel.

Thank you Morita and Yoshiki Kamata from Concierge for your exceptional service. We were chaperoned to the station ticket office and also to the shinkensen platform by these 2 wonderful staff members. We would have been lost for hours without their service. The rooms are beautifully appointed and it is an exquisitely renovated hotel. Dome rooms are beautiful but small and, although gorgeous, the coffee table and lounge chair should be removed to allow more space. The original design of this historic building that goes out and not up, means it is a long walk to most rooms. The harpist in the café is unique and beautiful entertainment. Best hotel location in Tokyo for shinkensen,trains, etc.

The staff really make this hotel. Great concierge and wonderful recommendations. We were amazed when they walked us to the platform of the train back to the airport and also helped us with our luggage. This would never happen in the UK! They also gave us bottled water to see us on our way. Fantastic location, don't miss the Kitte building opposite for a quirky shopping experience and also Brick Square. A very different side of Tokyo compared to Shinjuku/Shibuya where we have stayed previously. Will be back! Room was very comfortable and hi-tec although a bit over furnished for my liking, but that's just my personal preference.

We stayed one night at the very elegant and stylishTokyo Station Hotel. The staff and hotel was exceptional. The rooms, albeit small, are beautifully appointed and the bathroom is exceptional. It is superbly located within walking distance of the Ginza district where there are plenty of bars and restaurants and right next to the Imperial Palace and parks. Being right above Tokyo Station makes it incredibly convenient for any train or bus travel. The hotel was fairly recently renovated and they did an outstanding job. Happily we are returning for three more nights shortly. The staff were so helpful and polite. We can't recommend this hotel highly enough.

We picked the Tokyo Sfation Hotel for its location and the historic building.It is certainly convenient to the station and the staff are excellent but the rooms are incredibly small and far more expensive compared to the Imperial Hotel (and other hotels we stayed in in Japan). We had read reviews about breakfast indicating it was an experience not to be missed. I have to say I was disappointed with it. The room was nice but nothing overly special and the food selection was quite narrow compared to other buffet breakfasts we had on our trip to Japan.

We spent one night at the newly opened, iconic Tokyo Station Hotel and thoroughly enjoyed it. The staff and service was superb, the room was very well appointed and beautiful (especially the bathroom and high room ceiling), albeit a little small for competing area hotels like the Shangri-la or Four Seasons. However, the price was a little below these two competitors and you can't beat the iconic location. We had a room that overlooked the newly reopened dome entry for the Marunouchi North Exit of Tokyo Station, and we enjoyed being able to watch the activity without having to deal with any noise from the trains, etc. We will probably finish up our next stay in Tokyo with another night at the Station Hotel and can highly recommend it.

This a lovely hotel in the restored Tokyo train station. It is a great base to explore all of Tokyo and provides easy access to multiple train networks within Tokyo and to other parts of Japan. Rooms are small, but staff are very friendly and eager to assist you with any aspect of your stay.

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel in June, 2014, and I am a bit late in pulling together my review but here it is. We stayed in the hotel on two separate occasions. I selected the hotel for its location and historical aspects. In a city/country where service is spelled with a capital S, The Tokyo Station should be spelled with all CAPITALS. To find the hotel itself is a bit of a challenge, the first time around. For our first departure, the hotel staff escorted our party to our platform and made sure that we got on the right train and car. We have stayed in a few hotels around the globe. The key difference no matter what the architectural details are like is the people. This is where Tokyo Station shines. I would like to also compliment the team who designed and installed the hallway lamps. I can't remember ever seeing such a precision job. They were all perfectly aligned and working.Upon check-in for the first visit, there was a mix-up on my charge card and the hotel staff worked with me and kept an awkward situation from becoming an embarrassing situation. If this was the only issue, I would still have been pleased but when checking out, the another problem occurred. Again, the cashier worked with us to resolve issue as the bell staff waited to ensure that we had all of our luggage. Once the payment issue was resolved, the quickly got us to the train platform.These incidents described only address the more major assistance that we received. There were many others that started once walked through the entrance.The Tokyo Station is celebrating their 100th year anniversary. I wish I was there to congratulate them personally.

from airport to hotel via public transportation; you can check in the hotel within 30 mintues.we were staying in "DOOM" and the view is good. Room is cosy; you have bathtub and rainforest in tiolet. Bed is very comfortable. Free Wi-Fi as well. lots of restaurant located in opposite streets; open till 11pm (some even close at 3am)Service is great; location is excellent; room is cosy. Price -- simply worth the money

we stayed here in oct. 2014, 2 of us in one room, and another in a single room (which was so small i had no room for luggage). Marie Mori was very knowledgeable----but the dining room service was non existent. the waiters would never look at anyone, and just stood around doing nothing--just looking at the walls!!!!. i have never ever seen this happen in my 20 yrs. of going to tokyo!! i had to run up to the waitress to tell her to clear our table!!!----where is the manager??? we paid over $800 US a nite and stayed for 1 week!!! the eggs benedict in the dining room was the best i've ever had. that was worth staying at the hotel, even if i had to chase the waitress. BUT, across the street is KITTI building, and on the 5th floor, right next to the elevator, is a conveyer belt sushi restaurant which i went to because i read on the net that the sushi there is just as good as the restaurant in tsukiji market that people stand in line for 2 hrs. early in the morning and pay about $100 U.S for 2 people. we ate at the one in Kitti (3 of us till we couldn't eat any more) and paid US $42 for the 3 of us!!! unbelievable!!! we ate there about 3 times. every dish was so ONO. i would go back to that area just to eat there again, but will stay at the Capitol Hotel this coming Oct. the Capitol Hotel has croissants that are almost as good as the best in Paris.they also have a very good boulabaisse ?? how to spell??? don't miss the Robot Restaurant in Kabukicho, Shinjuku---it's not a restaurant, but a show ---that Anthony Bourdain said was the best thing he ever saw in all his travels. in one of his shows, he is at the RR and is smiling the whole time, which i have never seen him do. he is obviously very blase about the whole world, so when you see him smiling the whole time you KNOW you can't miss it. he said it's the greatest show on earth. the owner spent over $100 million US and obviously did it for fun, --how can you make back your $100 mill when you charge only $50 and there are only 130 seats?? be sure to go 1/2 hour BEFORE the show starts, as there are only limited seats in the lounge ---(which is mind blowing) with Versace chairs, and don't miss the toilet. some people complain about the $50 being too high!!!----if that show was in Vegas, i would pay $500 to see it and be happy-----many people are so strange. Also, don't miss the Aoyama Flower Garden Tea Room--which is on Omotesando (cross street is Aoyama Dori)--walk THROUGH the Garden shop for the tea room----you will be surprised. the specialty here is the French toast that everyone raves about. sorry i had to divert from the hotel info, but i just had to tell people about the show and the tea room!!!! most people don't seem to know about it. even the people who live there!!!

The head concierge, Ms. Marie Mori speaks fluent English which is exceptional in Tokyo. She is very knowledgeable in all things related to tourism and can get very hard to obtain reservations. We appreciate her help while staying at Tokyo Station hotel.

First time stay and was surprised by the service and how nicely decorated the room was. Only stayed for one night and had a drink at the bar Oak. The bartender is an older gentleman and was very inclined of all kinds of cocktails. Room rate was fair and I had a wonderful stay. Internet connection is free in-room but getting online seems trivial.

We travelled from Osaka to Tokyo via the Shinkansen and stayed four nights in a maisonette room at TSH. Checking-in was efficient and the staff with their warm smiles made us feel welcome. They even wiped down our luggage which was a little wet from he light rain. The location is an obvious plus with access to almost anywhere in Tokyo and also a short walk to the Imperial Palace.
