There is also a myriad of restaurants and shopping complexes within walking distances from TSH. The rooms were very well appointed with excellent amenities. The toiletries were from Bvlgari and both VIdeo-on-Demand and Wifi were free! Breakfast was a good mix of western and Japanese buffets. The traditional Japanese breakfast included miso and yuzu grilled fish, tamago, tofu with the usual rice and pickles. Really healthy! The western fare was outstanding especially the eggs benedict and the warm custard brochettes.TSH celebrated its 100th year on 20 Dec and we were privileged to have been part of it.

We were traveling to Laos and chose to spend a couple of days in Tokyo to de-jet-lag and shorten a painfully long flight. We chose well. the Narita Express take you almost to the hotel's door...it could not be more convenient. The hotel meets the luxorious / high standards it aspires to and the food options are excellent - we arrived at 8pm, went downstairs to Marunouchi 1-chome Shichi Jyu Ni Kou which was exceptional though not inexpensive. The buffet breakfast consisting of Japanese dishes and traditional Western fare was outstanding...among the best we have been to anywhere The shitake mushroom eggs benedict was outrageously good!The service was impeccable - when we asked for directions to the Narita express back to the airport, upon checkout, e.g., a bell person escorted us not just to the station, but to the very spot on the platform where our train car was scheduled to arrive.Note: the standard double bed rooms are small, but they are so beautifully appointed it did not matter to us. If we had stayed more than two nights, a larger room would have been a better option.

We were lucky enough to stay here for two nights.Incorporating a hotel into a transport hub must be a challenging job but this has been completed to an amazing standard. The rooms and facilities were lovely but what stood out for me was the superb customer service.To add to that, the location, obviously blessed transport links and being close to the imperial gardens make this an outstanding hotel.We visited Tokyo breeze restaurant which is very close by for some drinks and a meal, both of which were also faultless.

Wonderful Japanese hospitality in a beautiful hotel. This hotel delivers luxury and attention to detail in bucket loads. I had a superior room on Palace side 40 sqm level 3. This is the quietest hotel room I have ever stayed in. Proper black out curtains. Large bathroom with bath and rainhead shower . Room in impeccable condition. Location is great over Tokyo Station and city financial district. Restaurants, shopping and transport so convenient. Décor is traditional European. The best feature were the staff all of them were friendly, hospitable, knowledgeable and were able to anticipate my requirements. I travel a lot - best hotel I have stayed at this year.

Understated entrance from the side exit of Tokyo station, but once inside, you're in a different, much more upscale world. Visitors are mindful of the dress code, especially when you walk past the lobby tea room and its full with Japanese seated sedately and primly amidst intricately styled afternoon tea settings. Rooms are lush and comfortable, although wished the bathtub and bathroom could be slightly larger but then again, this is Japan. Faultless service in and out with unobtrusive staff escorts to room, politely attentive receptionist and concierge with assistance with luggage all the way out into the cab. Location is fantastic too amidst Tokyo station and its assortment of food / retail outlets. Non greenies will love the sharksfin restaurant on the 1st floor above the cute Japanese anime shops like Rilakkuma, Totoro, Hello Kitty...

I loved this hotel. It has recently been extensively remodeled and the rooms (at least my room) are wonderful (not large, but, hey, this is Japan). The attention to detail is amazing. I was concerned about the noise of the connected train station, but I heard none. The breakfast, which included lots and lots of western and Asian items, was really outstanding. Of course, several reviewers have mentioned the excellent location--if you arrive on a late afternoon flight from USA, it could not be better. I found the staff to be very attentive and helpful. I liked the hotel so well that I subsequently stayed in some other JR properties and was not disappointed. Next time I'm in Japan, this is where I'll spend the first couple of nights!

My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights as it was our first time to Japan and this was our honeymoon.Getting to the hotel from Haneda airport was very easy as we followed the directions the hotel and airport gave us. When we arrived at 10:30am in the morning we were told check in is not till 3pm so we had to go away and come back. I thought the way this was handled was very poor considering all other hotels I have stayed they have always allowed us to check in earlier and not make us wait 4.5 hours!! I mean we just got off a flight so we didn't really want to wonder around just yet. When we told them this was our honeymoon all they could offer us was to take a photo of my husband and I in the hotel? I thought maybe something more substantial would of been nice? Especially we just flew in from Korea and the hotel there gave us a free room upgrade. The rooms are tiny! barely can move and not enough space for 2 ppl! Was very disappointed in this as I thought being a 4.5 star hotel it could of been better!The location of the hotel is best thing about the TSH. Connected to the train station it was perfect. Would I stay here again? No. There are plenty of better hotels out there maybe in Shibuya where the happening is. Other than that we found this hotel quite boring and for the price we paid for, not really worth the money.

I absolutely loved TSH!Location: Great as you take the NEX right from the airport and you're off at the hotel and don't have to change to subway train.Plenty of shops and a high end food court in the station to pick up on some snacks and little bites if you need...great to walk to Ginza. From TS you can get to pretty much any area of the city without having to change trains.Service: Pure professionalism but friendly. Refined and elegant without being fussy.Rooms: The only downside I can say about the rooms compared to much other stuff in Tokyo is that they are only on the 2nd or 3rd floor...no 30 floor views or things like that. If you get the Palace side rooms you get somewhat of a view that looks over the cars entering the station and the high-rises with a little green out in the background. The other rooms' windows either look into a wall or some of the dome ones look out into the big foyers of TS.The comfort level and everything else was amazing. Very quiet! No sign you're above thousands and thousands of people catching hundreds of trains.Breakfast: Very good with lots of Western and Japanese options. I found being a solo traveler it was actually cheaper to just buy it a la carte in the mornings vs. paying the breakfast rate which is for 2.If there needs to be any convincing I'm staying another 2 nights because going to Kyoto and then the month after that 4 days to take my Mom for her birthday.
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
Justin V
New York, New York, United States

review_body: If, for your pretty penny, you expect grand lobbies and show-stopping vistas, this is not your hotel. This hotel perfectly demonstrates Japanese values - small but elegant spaces. Even the common rooms are neutrally understated, and cozy. But you can see and feel the top quality in everything you touch - the nightclothes, linens, door handles, elevators. Everything is quiet and solid and calm, albeit a very East/West thing, because the decor is totally Western. Extremely comfortable with no train noise detectable anywhere on the property.Service was quietly attentive; bellhops were both men and women, something I had not encountered elsewhere. The spoken English was readily available.Now for the REAL reason to stay here - the location. Not only is this property atop the Tokyo Station, but this particular station is essential to international travelers. It is the first station to/from Narita directly on the Narita Express, it's the terminus (and main station) to the rest of Japan on the Shinkansen, and is a stop on the popular, circular Yamanote train line, as well as being 1 subway stop (or a reasonable stroll) away from the Ginza. Hub central, so to speak. A bonus, especially in inclement weather, is that you will have at your disposal the vast underground shopping/dining mecca of the Yaesu side of Tokyo Station. Quintessential Tokyo - quality & comfort in accommodation with access to transportation & shopping.

I had been looking forward to staying at the Tokyo Station Hotel after it opened in 2012. The opportunity came in my trip to Japan this year.Right in the heart of the Tokyo Station, this was home for the five days stay in Japan. I flew in from a direct flight from Manila to Haneda, which was perfect because it was a 26 minutes transfer from Haneda to the Tokyo Station (via the monorail and a train transfer Tokyo Station).Upon arrival at the Tokyo Station, take the South Marunouchi exit and that's about it...you're practically a few steps from the hotel. For a hotel in Japan, this had all the punches and oomph in glitz, glamor and grandeur. The lobby was beautifully appointed. The access to the rooms was easy from either the main entrance or from the entrance in the central and north areas. The hallway is quiet (considering that we're just above the hotel) and the rooms have double windows and there's not a peep of noise from the outside.We were booked in a King room on the Palace Side. Upon entering the room, I was awed at the elegance of this hotel. High ceilings. A plush bathroom that had a bathtub and a rain shower in the same area. Amenities in abundance fit for royalty. A warm comfortable bed with very comfortable pillows. Drip coffee. Pajamas. Free wifi. Humidifier. A full mini-bar. There's everything in the room that would make you feel pampered.Then there's the breakfast at the Atrium. While it is one great spread, it's one expensive spread as well. Priced at almost 4000Yen per person, you can only eat so much. Food at Dean & Deluca in front of the hotel would cost you 1/4 the cost of the breakfast buffet. And the restaurants are open to the public. Which meant that whether you're a guest in the hotel or a walk-in, you'd need reservations or queue.On arrival, our rooms weren't ready yet (although it was already 3PM) and we had to wait for our rooms. Considering that there was nothing to do but eat, we romped around the hotel looking for a place for lunch, but even the lobby coffee shop was full to the hilt.Overall though, except for the glitch on check-in, I would highly recommend this hotel as it is the center point for travel to and from any point in Tokyo. It is also walking distance to Daimaru and the Imperial Palace and other Marunouchi shops in the area. Incidentally, if you go this time of the year, there's a 1.2Km stretch of lights and Disney along the Marunouchi district. Something the young ONES and the young ONCE will surely enjoy!

The Tokyo Station is a nice 5* hotel located in the financial district in Tokyo. Staff are OK (one of the receptionists was incompetent though). The rooms are nice and well maintained but fairly small.Avoid rooms above the train station entrance, unless you enjoy listening to the sound of a bell every 2 seconds (literally). Breakfast is nice, although I had to wait 15 minutes before I was seated on one day (this is the first time I experience this at a hotel, especially a 5* hotel!).

This was one of the best hotels we stayed in on our trip to Japan. An upgrade is advised to secure a large room, the entry level rooms are Tokyo small be warned, but the quality of the decor and great service were a stand out and the location is the icing on the cake - enjoy!
user_name:
Jamie35_15
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: This hotel is historical, but newly reopennned (2012). Rooms are elegant, quiet and have US plugs! Food is amazing! Tokyo Station Hotel style beef cutlet sandwich is a meal for two. And the breakfast buffet is incredible with European/American/Chinese and Japanese selections abound.Their tea (a smokey darjelling) was the finest I ever had.The only qualifier is that few materials were in English unless you request them and staff spoken less English than we have experienced at other 5 star Tokyo hotels.But service, location, food and facilities outweigh this minor inconvenience.If you can afford it, stay here.

Arriving in a new city at some odd hour is always a stressful challenge. Not so with an arrival in Tokyo with a booking at the Tokyo Station Hotel (TSH). You see, the Narita (Airport) Express stops just a minute's (undercover) walk away, and if you have made prior arrangements, there will even be a uniformed member of the concierge staff to meet you at the door of your train's carriage.The staff of this hotel are superb - extremely professional in manner, presentation, courtesy, knowledge, and right on top of their game. Pre-arrival questions of reservation and concierge staff (take a bow, Ms Mori) are responded to promptly and informatively.Although originally built in 1912 (and bombed in 1945) the TSH has undergone a major luxury refit/rebuild which was completed in 2012. The result is a high quality boutique hotel that oozes charm and comfort. Rooms are not large (at least the bedroom in the case of room 3084 - but the marble bathroom with full bath, rainfall shower, and hi-tech toilet) was spacious. Though it should be said that when we returned for a second visit Room 3085, of a slightly different design was larger. On the room plan we noticed that 3075 and 3088 might well be investigated also.Linen, toiletries, room décor are of high quality, and the hotel passed our 'elevator test' (always a good indication of attention to cleanliness and detail) with flying colours. Speaking of elevators, security is impressive with key-activated glass sliding doors keeping non-guests out of corridor areas on each floor.Not surprisingly, the '' Dome " room we booked had an internal view of one of the impressive domes of the railway station with commuters able to seen rushing to and fro. No noise at all came from the working station.Breakfast in the impressive Atrium restaurant was excellent and catered to all tastes.But above all, this hotel has a fantastic location in central Tokyo - lots of restaurants nearby, the Tokyo station is the terminus for the Shinkhansen, (and has access to all other subway and other rail lines), and the Hato bus interchange is a few metres away also (incidentally, if you are planning to visit Mt Fuji, check out the Hato (big Japanese company) prices and compare them to the other excursion companies - they kill them). While the TSH is at the South Marunouchi entrance to the station, you can exchange your JR Rail vouchers for passes at the North entrance, about 400 m away... easy.With prices for the Dome Room with breakfast at around JPY 34,000, we thought this to be reasonable for a quality hotel, the location of which cannot be beaten.

I would give this Hotel more than 5 stars if I could. Beautifully run. Spotlessly clean & very good location for sightseeing & catching the train to other parts of Japan.. It's expe but worth it. Had a wonderful meal at Sushi Aiyagi, coffee in the Lobby lounge. Staff amazing, so helpful & polite. Very comfortable beds,

Customer service by all staff was excellent. Rooms were not overly large but they were not crowded either. Everything you could possibly need was stocked in the room. Our room looked out over trains passing through the station but we felt no vibration or heard any noise-it was amazing. Narita Express arrives directly into Tokyo Station so getting here from the airport was very easy. Hotel is close to the Imperial Palace and great shops and restaurants. It's definitely not an inexpensive indulgence, but in this case you get what you pay for. It was very, very nice.

We were recommended by a local Japanese to stay at this hotel over any 5 stars hotel located elsewhere in the vicinity. While this comes with a price their service and rooms exceeded our expectations. Firstly, we commend the staff, every question we had (before and during our stay) were answered promptly and thoroughly. The staff exhibits attention to details and were very willing to go out of their way to assist you. 5 stars just for that. Secondly, the rooms were spacious by Japanese standard. We stayed for 5 nights on the 3rd floor in a twin share. The beds were comfortable and the room was well equipped. The cleaning and replenishing of the rooms were thorough each day. We also stayed 5 nights on the 2nd level in a King suite. Beautiful while it's slightly smaller than the previous room. They also have extremely high ceilings so you feel comfortable and relaxed. The room's cleanliness is also 5 stars. Thirdly, they offer free wifi in the rooms as well as around the hotel. This may seem trivial but in Japan this is not a standard feature of hotels. This is also highly desirable as Japan does not offer free wifi in many places. The free wifi at this hotel is functional and reasonable speed (we've been to many hotels where the free wifi was so slow it's obviously not designed to give you freebies).Fourthly, the location of this hotel is without doubt central and convenient. It is located at the JR Tokyo Station which has many lines and subways leading to various different locations. We found this the most desirable as we were intending to travel a lot during our stay. It is also 5 mins walk to the Imperial Palace. If you enjoy a morning walk, there's the place to go. The hotel within walking distance to a number of eateries, department stores, bookstores, coffee shops. So you literally could spend every night choosing different restaurants to dine at and shop until your legs bring you home. Love this place. If you need a comfortable central hotel, this is the one to book with. Do try and book early because this hotel is so popular it gets booked out months in advance. That's the reason why we had to split our booking into 2.

The service at the hotel is top notch. The rooms are large and luxurious and the location is fantastic. Special mention of the concierge who is extremely helpful, friendly and patiently assisted with my queries. Fantastic stay!

We made an excellent choice with the Station Hotel, only 40 minutes from Haneda Airport on the monorail and then two stops to Tokyo station.The hotel is definitely at least 5 star, with the bedrooms being spotless, spacious and the one we were in overlooked the rail station, as we were in the Dome!!!!! The toilets are very modern and have many facilities to choose from!!!Breakfasts, although a little expensive, were very good, with a lot of choice and a lovely room to eat in.While we were there the emperor and empress stayed at the hotel!The position of the hotel is excellent and it was very easy to get around from the hotel, not only by the rail but also with the underground having so many restaurants and shops.Staff at the hotel were very helpful, giving us instructions when we asked how to get to certain places and when we were leaving the staff took our luggage onto the station and put our luggage on the train!! This hotel is well worth a visit, we stayed for 5 days.

We paid a little more than we normally would but in the case of Tokyo Station hotel, it was well worth it. Our flight arrived mid evening and the next morning we were heading down to Kyoto quite early. As it was our first time in Japan we didn’t want to have to navigate too much on our first night, being tired and with luggage. Tokyo Station hotel is conveniently located above Tokyo Station at street level and we’d marked the exit (Marunouchi South Gate) on a station map before we left home to make the transition up as simple as possible. From down in the station it was easy enough to follow the signs to get to where we needed to go. I was surprised at how large Tokyo Station was and equally at how busy it was at 10pm at night. Checking in was easy and the hotel was explained to us along with a map of where all of the amenities were located. We had pre ordered a wifi device through Global Advanced Communications and it was waiting for us at check-in as well. We were escorted to our room down a series of very long corridors - so much so that a number of coloured lights were pointed out to us as where we should aim for when returning downstairs from our room. All common areas of the hotel were immaculate and all staff that we encountered politely stopped to greet us.We booked a Palace Side Queen room. Size wise it was on par with other rooms we booked for our trip in Japan. Easy enough to move around with a couple of bags. The high ceilings certainly give the room an added spaciousness. The furnishings in the room were incredible with large windows and thick curtains. The bathroom was also huge with a separate rain shower and bath - perfect after a long flight. All other room amenities are as expected - slippers, robes, free wifi, tea/coffee, complimentary water and toiletries. The bed was firm which I later learned was fairly standard in Japan. We didn't hear any noise from the station below. The hotel is located in between Chiyoda and Ginza. We ended up walking around the area that night - nice wide streets and very clean. We took the opportunity to buy a Suica card, JR Pass and reserve our seat on the Shinkansen in the morning. The next morning before checking out we got up early, had breakfast nearby and took a walk over to the Imperial Palace (20 mins each way). Special mention to S Fukunaga who escorted us and our luggage, from the hotel lobby, through the madness of Tokyo station to our car on the Shinkansen platform. Exemplary service. Thank you. I cannot fault the Tokyo Station Hotel. It’s perfect for a stopover hotel on either end of your journey or for a longer, luxurious stay that is easily connected to the rest of Tokyo.

Location is absolutely excellent (above Tokyo station) when travelling in Tokyo. Very easy to get to when arriving with the Narita Express. Restaurants below (-2, -3) are some of the best for a traveller (locals and businessmen also eat there), great shopping.Rooms are spotless and very spacious compared to normal Japanese hotel rooms. Bed was very comfortable and bathroom large and well equipped (from hair dryer to shaving kit and shampoos).

The Tokyo Station Hotel is a must when in Tokyo! First it is full of tradition, however even more outstanding is the service, the location and the rooms. Service is simply unmatched, not that you are supported when selecting restaurants or sightseeing spots, but the friendly staff also guides you the the train you intend to board. I just can recommend it to all travelers

Perfect location inside the Tokyo station and great starting place for sightseeing. Very warm welcome up on arrival and fast check-in. The lady at the concierge (8th October around 10pm, forgot her name) was so lovely and providing me with a lot of information about Tokyo and the tours. She was so helpful and polite. The room was relatively large for Tokyo. The breakfast in the Atrium has a large selection although very Asian oriented and the quality of the Western dishes was not great.Definitely would return to this place.

The Tokyo Station Hotel is an excellent choice, connects directly to Tokyo Station via the South Marunouchi exit, and clearly exceeds what might be expected of a “station” or “airport” hotel. The buildout and furnishings are in traditional European style and the room appointments are very well fitted out with easy-to-use bedside controls, hassle-free wifi and TV, and particularly well stocked bathrooms.Be aware that some rooms overlook the interior of the station and therefore do not receive natural light (this was not a problem for me, but some may want to know about this in advance).The concierge service was excellent and assisted capably with somewhat complex onward travel arrangements.Whether you need an air-to-train location for transit (as was the case for me) or simply want a very nice hotel in an excellent, central location for a multi-day stay, the Tokyo Station Hotel makes for a very good stay.
user_name:
TransConFlyer
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel exceeded my expectations in every way. The convenience of connecting to and from Narita Airport by the express train makes that connection very smooth and shorter than what you experience by taking a bus bus from Narita to your hotel. The service is outstanding. I was unsure of how to find the right track for Narita Express and the staff at the hotel escorted me to the track (5 levels down under the main station). The breakfast was phenomenal, free wifi, and impeccable service. If your plans call for connecting to Narita or if you have business in this area of Tokyo, this hotel is tops.

Loved this hotel. We were a group of ladies traveling together on a five day trip. Even with our luggage it was very easy to get to this hotel from Narita airport on the NEX train. Foreign passport holders pay only 50% of the cost for a one way ticket to Tokyo Station. The hotel also offered a greeting service wherein they meet you on the platform and assist you through the busy station up to the hotel lobby. Just inform them which train you are taking and the car number before you leave Narita. Although the rooms are small they are very well appointed and comfortable...perfect for 2 people. They have larger rooms available if you inquire early enough. We were surprised that we never heard or felt the trains passing through the station throughout the day and night. The previous hotel that I stayed at is just next door to this hotel and I recall hearing the fast trains speeding thru the tracks especially at night. But not at this hotel. Quite amazing considering it's built on top of one of the busiest stations in Japan. There are lots of restaurants, cafes and convenience stores within the station as well as in the nearby buildings. We had the breakfast buffet on the 4th floor on our last day and it was excellent. Wish we had done it sooner. The Concierge, particularly Marie Antoinette Mori was very helpful with every issue that I had. Also, Aya Nakashima of reservations was wonderful at assisting me in booking rooms. Kudos to the Tokyo Station Hotel team. Beautiful property in a great location with wonderful service.

The Tokyo Station has exceeded our expectations, especially that we were able obtain rates that were considerably lower than other 5 star hotels in the city. It is a gem in the heart of Tokyo (near the Imperial Palace and the Central station) and a stone's throw away from the very posh shopping district of Ginza.It is worth mentioning that you can access the High Speed Shinkansen train platforms from the backdoor of the hotel directly, which was a big plus as we were to take it. The service is impeccable as everyone is very kind from the moment you chcek-in to checking out. The chief Concierge (Marie Antoinette) in particular is highly knowledgeable and affably helpful, which made our stay in Tokyo all the more enjoyable.The breakfast is spectacular, hosting a wide selection of western as well as Japanese delicacies. The room amenities were top end and considerably more sophisticated than other 5 star hotels in the US or Europe. For a one of a kind experience, I recommend the "Dome Rooms" as they overlook the hustle and bustle of one of the busiest train stations in the world (while obviously keeping the noise out!). All in all, it is a very highly recommended hotel for those who seek luxury and practicality in equal parts! :)

My wife and I had a two night stay at the end of our recent 10 day visit to Japan (Tokyo and Kyoto). The Tokyo Station hotel was an excellent stay - service was first class in all respects and the buffet breakfast in the Atrium restaurant each morning was very pleasant, with Western and Japanese food available. Our room on the third floor was most comfortable (excellent bed) and bathroom was great. Room looked out onto Maranouchi building. The other key plus is the location right next door to Tokyo station - very handy for Shinkansen and plenty of restaurants for reasonable meals. We were also provided with a porter (young lady) to walk us to the Airport Limousine bus stop. All in all a wonderful and pleasant stay.

In the main station of Tokyo - this hotel is perfect for sightseeing Tokyo. The trains lead from the nearby station to all aereas of the town and further. The quality of the rooms, the breakfast are one of the best I have ever seen. The staff is friendly and helpful, allthough most of them do not understand english well.

The staff was incredibly helpful and friendly. For example, we wanted to attend the Sumo matches but the venue wasn't answering their phones to sell tickets. The only other way to buy them off-site was through a vending machine at 7-11, but it was in Japanese. I was very surprised when the bell-lady offered to go to the store with us to help buy tickets. This was just one example of the kindness and helpfulness they showed us!

Yes, it is true. They go above and beyond to make your stay the best ever! Yoshiki Kamata the duty manager spent time looking for camera cords and directing me around Marunouchi and my welcoming guest relations gentleman, Koji Hamazaki helped me acclimate to the hotel. A beautiful, restored traditional building in an area of some of the finest new architecture. Enjoy!

Stayed one night. It exceeded expectations. The hotel is of a high class, overall and right down to the smallest things. Room fit out is very stylish. I have not come across a higher standard of service. Very personalised attention, nothing is too much. Hotel location is great. The bell hop even took me to the station to help me buy a ticket for the airport and escorted me to the platform next day. Breakfast was also excellent. Don't take any criticisms of this hotel seriously. I'll be back for sure.

The service is where this hotel truly shines. I can't begin to say enough about how well they take care of you at the Tokyo Station Hotel. From check-in to check-out, they go out of their way to attend to your every need.I would quickly add the rooms themselves are worth the stay. They are small by American standards but average by Japan, but very well appointed. The rainshower is something you must experience!The hotel is extremely convenient to the Tokyo train station and Narita Express. It's also convenient to many parts of Tokyo via cab or subway.

My stay with the Tokyo Station Hotel was a real enjoyment. My trip was planned just for dining at SUKIYABASHI Jiro, the most famous sushi bar. Contacted few hotels but only the Tokyo Station Hotel managed to secure me a seat for dinner. Ms Mori, the chief concierge, impressed me from the very beginning with her professionalism and perfect English (which is not very common among hotel staffs in Japan) Prior to my trip, we have already exchanged quite a few number of emails regarding my restaurant reservation. Her prompt responses and professional assistance made me really looked forwards to staying at their hotel.When checking in, I was warmly greeted by Ms Mori at the reception. She is such a cheerful lady and we had a pleasant conversation. The hotel itself is quite new as was renovated only a year ago but has a history of nearly 100 years. The design is quite comfortable and cannot really complaint in every aspect. Clean and enjoyable. Not to mention the great location, easily accessible to major attractions or anywhere in Japan.When I checked out, there was still some time left before taking a train to the airport so I left my luggage at the concierge for last minute shopping nearby. When I came back with few shopping bags, I asked one of their staffs if they could show me where the toilet is at the lobby so that I could pack those things in. The staff took me to a private dressing room at their ballroom. This was really thoughtful as some hotels would just ask you to pack at a corner (including some five stars hotels!) I would definitely recommend it to my friends and revisit in my next trip to Tokyo.

As many others have written, a first class hotel right above Tokyo Station - a real home to return to after a day exploring Tokyo. Also, a perfect base from which to explore Japan as so convenient for Shinkansen and local trains. Area is a little quiet, however, only 15mins walk or JPY 1,000 for a taxi to livelier areas.However, what really stood out for us was the warmth of the welcome and the amazing service provided by one of the guest relations staff (Negishi-san). At 5:30pm on the day of our arrival I realised that I had forgotten to pack my contact lenses. Negishi-san telephoned various opticians to see who had my prescription, he then took us to the opticians, translated for the eye exam and then escorted us back to the hotel - all of which would have been pretty baffling for two people on their first ever day in Tokyo. The service went above and beyond our expectations.We stayed at the hotel three times as we traveled through Tokyo on our way to visit other parts of Japan, and each time we looked forward to returning to the Station Hotel - not cheap, but highly recommended

Tokyo Station Hotel is a first class hotel right in Tokyo Station. Even though it is in the station, there is no noise from the trains, traffic, and crowds. The staff is very good and all I encountered could speak English. The rooms are large and very comfortable. The breakfast buffet was included in my room rate and was very enjoyable with both European and Japanese selections and a hot grill for fresh-cooked eggs.Tokyo Station is the terminus of the Narita (Airport) Express Train. It is also connected into the extensive Tokyo subway and regional trains as well as the bullet trains. The station/hotel is only a block away from the Imperial Palace, which you can see from most rooms, and only a few blocks from the Ginza shopping district.
nice cozy hotel, location is great. super!! many trains and subway meet in here, is very convenient to everywhere!And breakfast is quit good too.I will back again!
As far as my family is concerned, this is the BEST hotel in Tokyo. Top-notch!The landmark building, meticulious organisation, friendly staff...the hotel is simply in a league of its own.

Big luxurious rooms, great location, and incredible staff. Rooms are large with opulent bathrooms that include a rain shower. Perfect location inside Tokyo Central Station is easily accessible by bullet train from the airport, easy access to the rest of the city, and a great starting point to explore the rest of Japan. Staff was unbelievably friendly and accommodating. I can’t say enough good things about the service/staff. One of the finest hotels I’ve ever had the pleasure to stay at. Highly recommended!

Top class hotel, best of all is convenient location and its staff (exceptional even for japanese standarts which are already very good). Breakfast is superb. They gladly helped with takyubin services,arranged restaurant reservations and got us regional train tickets which helped a lot.

I spent 7 nights at Tokyo Station Hotel for work trip. This hotel was a historical building that was renovated in the center of Tokyo station. Location is second to none, at Marunouchi exit of Tokyo station making travel around so easy.The room is spacious and beautiful! Beautifully designed, blend of modern Japanese and classic architecture. Staffs are attentive and service is world class. I sent my clothes for laundry and they did a very good job with it! I didn't try the restaurants in the hotel as there are so many good restaurants out there in Tokyo but they look good.Highly recommended for anyone traveling on leisure or business.

Five Start Hotel!!!If they are not ranked as a five star hotel, they should be!Location: Conveniently located adjacent to the Tokyo station, you never have to leave the Tokyo Station building. How good is that? You get off Shinkansen, a few mins later, you are in your room. The room itself is very quiet, I anticipated some noise from the train station but I almost forgot where I was as my room was so quiet.Service: Check in staff was so friendly, they truly understand what good service is supposed to be. What I noticed in Japan while I was there for about a week, most people won't look at my eyes when they talk. Most people talks very politely but I could tell they are just following the procedure. The front desk clerks looked at my eyes and smiled as they welcomed me to the hotel. After the check in process, a nice lady offered to take my bag (which I refused as she as such a tiny lady and I thought I had more muscle to carry heavy stuff), and showed me to my room. As we walked, she explained to me about the hotel history and safety of the hotel. The way she explained to me shows she cares about hotel guests, and was proud to work for the hotel.Room: Standard size, not too large and less counter space but it was enough to get what I needed to get done. They had three outlet plugs on the work desk, I was able to charge my electronics, and with a very stable free wifi, I was able to get a lot of work done. The bed they had in my room was very nice too. Mattress they had was what I felt comfortable. Not too hard, soft enough, I was able to sleep very well. I like the bathroom too. Although the counter space was on a smaller side but still had just enough space to put everything I needed in the bathroom. I enjoyed a nice bath and loved the fluffy bathrobe. Just what I needed after two weeks of business trip in Asia. At the check out, since I was traveling by Narita Express, they offered to carry my suitcase to the train platform. ( I declined but it was such a nice gesture that they offered)Unfortunately I didn't have time to enjoy any of their restaurant facility, I definitely would love to come back to try them. When I started traveling to Tokyo for business frequently, the Tokyo Station was always under construction. When I came to Japan last year, I finally saw the construction finished and remodel for the hotel was completed. I told myself, the next chance I get, I am going to stay at this hotel. I am glad I was able to stay at this hotel finally.If you are looking for a nice comfortable stay with excellent service, this is the hotel for you. Traveling could be tiring, there are here to make sure your stay is as comfortable as possible. I rested very well and got a lot of work done.

Service:Rainy at arrival and taxi stop at North exit of station. When my family was close to the hotel entrance, staff noticed and helped us outside the entrance. Service team was caring and while one staff helped us carry our luggage, another one was wipping our soaked belongings and others were helping us checked in. My family was just so hurry a few seconds ago and it's like magic. My family was leaded to our room and responsible staff took initiative to carry my wife's shopping trophies (paper and plastic bags) and explained to us our questions regarding locations, directions and reminded us free Wifi.Food:My son loves the omelette at breakfast and he had 2 omelettes per breakfast in our 2-night stay. There might not be a lot of choices as in some hotels in other countries we had stayed but the quality was no question.Staff:Very polite and very kindly declined tipping when I tried that to housekeeping staff when she's cleaning my room. Rare but precious quality behind magnificent training.When we have checked out, luggage had already been in our big taxi and at a rainy day, staff with umbrella accompanied my family to the van.My family and I are touched by the Japanese hospitality.
user_name:
Matthew Cheuk M... L
Hong Kong, China

review_body: Pros: Service was excellent (as in everybody: from the Concierge who helped us get advanced dinner reservations at Sukiyabashi Jiro Roppongi, Guest Relations, Reception, Housekeeping, etc). The hotel was very very clean at all times, always looked and smelled great. Despite the size of the bedroom, it had everything you would need and more. Loved that they would give you a fresh set of pajamas every day. Shower with tub on the side was great. Furnishings were very pretty. This would have been the perfect hotel if the rooms were bigger.Location wise, thought it was perfect for getting around to Anywhere. Hotel has an entrance to the JR station (sorry I forgot if it was the North or South side), and just outside that would lead to the other trains (there is an elevator if you have huge luggage). Very convenient to go to and from the airport especially since they also had a free Meet and Greet service, and Send off service (when we checked out, I asked Guest Relations what would be the best way to get to Narita Express, and he said he will have someone bring us there and even help with our luggage, which was very convenient).:) Ginza is relatively near, either you walk there, but we preferred taking the train. Lastly, it was great that Kitchen Street and Ramen Street were very near as this hotel was also at Tokyo Station.:) Lastly, forgot to mention that it is quite convenient that there are 3 possible entrances to the hotel.Cons: Just the room size, but everything else made up for it. We stayed at a Dome King (which had a view of the Dome of the station which was interesting, though you cannot really keep the curtains wide open, hehe) for 2 nights and at a Queen room for 3 nights. Rooms were around the same size, the Dome King just had a bigger bed and different view (Queen room had a street view, could see Kitte across the street). Some people might complain about how far some of the rooms are from the elevators, but really, what do you expect from the architecture of the building, it's not a high rise structure.

My husband and I recently stayed for one night here, at the back end of a long drive-around trip in other areas. What a lovely way to end the trip! Apart from the very convenient location and modern (and tasteful) decor (which, to us, still retains a quintessentially understated Japanese touch), what really touched us was the staff. Not only were they obviously extremely well-trained and professional, everyone we met was really warm and friendly! Allow me to give a couple of illustrations:- While still planning for the trip, we were looking to make a reservation at a popular restaurant for our final night in Tokyo. We therefore took a chance and wrote to the hotel to see if they may be able to help us make the reservation. Even though we would only be staying in the absolute cheapest room(!), the staff that communicated with us (Ms Marie Antoinette Mori, who, we found out later, happened to be the Chief Concierge!) was so friendly, professional and efficient. We have never come across any other member of hotel staff that even came close.- Shortly after checking in, a very friendly lady showed us to our room. Having heard our questions earlier at the reception desk regarding the location of various restaurants, she took the time to explain to us (in very good English) the lay of the land and the best way to walk through the labyrinth that is Tokyo Station to where we wanted to go. She really could just have shown us to the room, said a polite good-bye and walked away, yet she chose to stay and made an effort to help us.What can we say! A hotel with staff like this just can't go wrong!

Very convenient location for using the subway and train systems. Friendly and helpful staff, superb breakfast buffet and very clean rooms with large bathrooms, brilliant shower and large range of toiletries. Amazing building beautifully restored to a luxury hotel with a wonderful large atrium breakfast room. Considering where the location is it is also very quiet.

I've been to Tokyo many times - first time I've stayed here. It is now my hotel of choice. Amazing building from the outside with lots of history (see pictures). Restored and upgraded to a luxury hotel (see pictures). Very quiet at night. Great location.

An amazing building located right next to the main train station in central Tokyo. My friendly guide walked me through the long, winding corridors on arrival, pointing out the dining options and useful little features here and there along the way.The room is very well appointed, with all the modern conveniences you'd expect from a hotel of this quality. An air purifier and heated toilet seats will be out of the ordinary for western travellers, but these are standard at this level of luxury in Japan.Of course all the luxury, convenience and great service comes at a price, so be prepared to pay above the odds for your stay here.

I missed the last shinkansen for Kyoto. So i had to find an hotel for the night.I found this hotel. I told myself, it looks expensive. And i was right. Almost 40k for a night, the most expensive night of my life (and the cheapest of that place).But the room was great, very big, like the whole hotel. The staff is very polite.
This is a beautiful and fantastic place to stay in the middle of Tokyo!!!!Very convenient coming from the airport or simply visiting Tokyo.Excellent staff, very kind and helpful !!!!Recommend it!!!!!

My new favorite hotel in Tokyo. The location is super convenient, right next to (and above) Tokyo Station. There is excellent food in the Marunouchi area and the Kitte shopping mall next door has a great selection of shops with interesting things to buy. I just completed by third stay at this hotel. The service is top-notch and the staff speak good English. The rooms are new and luxurious with premium toiletries. The beds are comfortable and I did not notice any noise from the train station (I have stayed at both the Classic and Palace Side rooms). Complimentary bottled water is in the fridge, which is perfect as I don't like drinking water at room temperature.During this stay, I hiked up Mt. Fuji, with a stay at the Tokyo Station Hotel before and after my hike. Marie Antoinette Mori, Chief Concierge, helped book my stay at the Gouraikoukan (mountain hut near the summit of Mt. Fuji). Gouraikoukan is very difficult to book as it is the hut closest to the summit, but Ms. Mori managed to book us 3 places at the hut and also arranged our dinner/breakfast choices. She is super efficient and friendly. The price of this hotel is very reasonable and much lower than hotels in the same category. The prime location makes this hotel even a better deal as you will save time to and from the hotel. I have previously stayed at the Conrad, Park Hyatt and Four Seasons Marunouchi - but my new favorite is the Tokyo Station Hotel. Being able to get off the train/subway and straight into your hotel is great! I will be staying again in several months' time - and will be paying a little more for the Dome Side Room with views of the dome ceiling of the train station.

Was visiting friends in Tokyo and took the Nozomi Shinkansen from Osaka. I heard alot of the Tokyo Station Hotel and decided to stay here.The room was expensive but the service you get and the quality of the accommodation is 5 star all the way.Staying here was really a grand experience.Most of the staff I met spoke English and were very polite.The room is very big and very very comfortable with complete amenities that you would expect for a 5 star hotel.

We stayed here as our first stop on a nearly 3 week trip to Japan. This hotel is very nice and our room was very nice. Decorated to a high standard definitely. We stayed on the Palace side to help lower the noise of the very active train station. Although we could still hear/feel the trains it wasn't so loud that it interfered with our sleep although total exhaustion from the very long flight was probably very influential in our ability to sleep.Although the room was a bit small per our "Western" standards, we still had plenty of room for our suitcases and moving about the room. It was very nicely appointed, I believe it was remodeled not long ago. Extremely clean as were all the hotels we stayed in while in Japan. The bathroom had all the amenities, toothbrush, toothpaste, blowdryer, hair brush, Q-tips all that kinda thing as do many hotels in Japan, a wonderful touch actually. Very nice towels, wonderful bathtub and shower, all stone and glass, lovely for sure.I didn't attach any pictures of the room because there are plenty already available on TA and the hotel website. I did add some pictures of the breakfast area (The Atrium I believe) which was beautiful and the breakfast spread from traditional Japanese to Western breakfast was wonderful. Tremendous selection and everything was top notch, totally loved it!Although we stayed only one night we were treated to a wonderful staff and many spoke English. My wife was born in Japan and thankfully speaks wonderful Japanese but it was nice that the staff spoke English to me.Be prepared to walk through very long halls, remember this is a train station... train stations are often quite large and LONG, this one's no exception, but the halls are nicely decorated and patrolled (thankfully) by security guards, nice touch, felt very secure.Be aware that if you only speak English you'll probably do OK in large cities like Tokyo but know that once you get away from cities of that size you'll have issues if you don't know a little Japanese. The train schedules are subtitled in English....to a degree, you have to pay very close attention and allow time to connect and even get lost from time to time.....also know that when they say the train doors close in one minute they are NOT kidding, do not ignore the schedule because the trains run on time, unless there's some off the wall emergency, truly the trains are on time so keep out of the doorway when the train is getting ready to leave, trust me on this point!Also, if you're going to spend a lot of time traveling by train, purchase the rail pass, it's great and most of your travels will be via Japan Rail (JR), your pass will apply for most trains but on occasion you'll need to take a local train that your pass will not cover and you'll have to pay for that portion of your travels. You must exit through a gate manned by JR employees, often times a sign at their window will read "Fare Adjustment", always show them your pass, they will nicely bow and thank you, you must do this, your pass will not work in any automated machine. But the train system is fantastic, subway included, just pay attention and allow proper time to make connections etc...Carry coins with you, you'll need these for the train and bus which you'll need to take on occasion unless your not concerned about the cost of taxis, you can really expend some funds if you take taxis all the time, on occasion you just may have to but do try to avoid the cost. Taxis are great in Japan, always very clean although you may run into more than one that has been smoked in, smokers are still a problem in Japan, no where near what it used to be and it is getting better all the time, still you'll need to be aware of hotel rooms that say its a non smoking room, but check it right when you check in, if it stinks of smoke you can try to get another room right then, don't wait.....give it a try anyway, they may not be able to accommodate you but perhaps they can as well, ask nicely.Always carry a cotton handkerchief with you, not all bathrooms have any kind of towels or hand dryers provided, it's the only way you can dry your hands after using the bathroom. Also know that you may not always be using Western style toilets...do yourself a favor, research this on the internet, be prepared to utilize "different" style of toilets....all very interesting.Sorry to rattle on but these are several little tips that really make traveling in Japan, or many parts of the world for that matter, a LOT more comfortable.Avoid being rude and stupid.......be polite and respectful and thats' exactly what you'll get in return.

The old but recently refurbished Tokyo Station Hotel is a fantastic hotel in central Tokyo Chiyoda Ward. JR-trains and the Tokyo subway are found just under the hotel building and the Imperial Palace with it's beautiful gardens is just a few blocks away. On the other side of the tracks is Ginza located within a walking distance. Even though this is in central Tokyo the atmoshere is very calm an quiet. The architecture is well preserved and the rooms have a high standard with wonderful bathrooms. If you are fed up with the Tokyo skyline this is the place to stay in Tokyo.

I stayed here with my husband earlier this year. I must say, my expectations were not only met, but defied! Despite the hotel being in the busy location of Tokyo, we found it a very pleasant and quiet escape from the daily grind. We stayed here for 4 nights. The rooms were clean with an openly bright atmosphere. I felt truly at home. The staff were friendly and always willing to cater to my every need. I would definitely recommend that you stay here! 10/10 would revisit!

My husband and I stayed at this hotel last month during a holiday to Japan. The location of this hotel is excellent and the rooms are very quiet, no noise from trains! The hotel has been renovated to a very high standard and the hotel rooms are very comfortable, clean and the staff are very nice. Staying at this hotel made it easy to travel by train around Tokyo and Japan. I would stay here again.

We just spent four nights in this hotel which has the best location. We stayed in the Dome Room overlooking the train station. It is very surprising quiet considering the location is in one of busiest traffic in Tokyo. The security is tight. Before access to our room we need to access the floor first. There are so many shopping malls within walking distance through underground paths. Also the Tokyo First Avenue is in walking distance where has characters street, ramen street and others. The breakfast in Atrium (only for guests) is very good. We enjoyed both western pastries and Japanese food ($40 per person if breakfast is not included in the package). This will be the only place we will stay in Tokyo if we visit Tokyo again. One thing needs to be aware that we took Narita Express to Tokyo Station, it took us a while to find the entrance of the hotel in the station. There is a small entrance right next to the JR ticket office in the south side of marunouchi exit. The hotel entrance is outside of station facing the marunouchi buildings.

Yes, the hotel is lovely, the furnishings are of high quality and the location is brilliant but it didn't quite work for us as well as we had hoped. The rooms appear to have everything - desk, chair, coffee table, lounge chair, shoe horn, ice bucket etc but there was barely any space to move around and there was virtually no drawer space to place our belongings (half of one shallow drawer); most surfaces and cupboards were filled with hotel paraphernalia which we didn't use or need. We had a dome room then a queen room later; both were similar. The staff obligingly provided us with plastic drawers to place within the cupboard and removed the coffee table and this did make the room usable for us over our 4 day visit. Also it was very hard to find a bar in the evening; we were never able to have a pre dinner drink because the bars were either closed or full (or was this a dress code euphorism?). We were quite well dressed, but I feel the hotel was catering more for wedding parties and the fashion conscious rather than the guests.

Japan ROCKS those train station hotels! The Tokyo Station is so close to the mayhem that is the actual station... yet once you are ensconced in a room, you feel like the Queen in London! Impeccable service: the manager was upset he couldnt find us when we arrived at the station but made sure to make up for it with a gorgeous room...the bell hop girl immediately noticed my kid would need smaller pjs, and brought her these with matching slippers and a small gift. The staff at breakfast noticed my kid didnt eat much, and gave us a discount on her buffet. Another bell hop girl took us through the station the next morning, waited outside a bento shop with our luggage while we selected our lunch, and saw us safely on our shinkansen.I only wished we could have stayed longer. Wow!

Was on the way to Narita and did a one night stay in Tokyo Station Hotel.The interior of the hotel was impressive and certainly recalls the past glamour of travel. Check in was smooth and was pleasantly surprised to be upgraded to a king sized bed room. The bathroom was huge and the rain shower was really refreshing.The Hotel Concierge helped me pre-book a sushi dinner nearby, which was really enjoyable.Had a good night sleep in a room overlooking the city. Service was impeccable. Would choose it again for its convenient location by the main Tokyo Station.

We booked into this hotel for one night before heading to Kyoto for a week. I was booking from Canada and had a number of questions and all were answered via email promptly. We booked a classic room which was small but gorgeous. The rain shower and heated toilets were worth the price alone. But what set this place apart was the assistance from the train station, at check in, escorting you to your room, explaining how things worked in the room and then escorting you back to the train station on your way out of Tokyo. Unbelievable service. Canadian hotels should take note!! We enjoyed it so much that we rebooked a room again the night before we were to fly out to New Zealand. There were no Classic rooms left so we did have to pay extra, but the room was twice the size and both times we were upgraded to a view of the city. Again impeccable service. Oh... and be sure to indulge yourselves with the buffet breakfast at least once. Delicious!! The whole experience was fit for a king! Thank you Tokyo Station staff for giving us such fond memories on our arrival and departure. Your hotel will be one of our fondest memories.

We found our way easily on Narita Express train to hotel and cost only about $30. Japanese people are lovely and go out if their way to help. Hotel is first rate with courteous staff and beautiful (small by US standard but expected) rooms and facilities.

I stayed for two nights and had a single room - not huge but well-designed and luxurious. A fisheye mirror created a sense of extra space. The bathroom was particularly nice, and provisioned with good quality toiletries. Enjoyed seeing the historical photographs in my room and the corridors, and staying in such an interesting place. I just had a nearby Tokyo street view from bedroom and bathroom but it included a street crossing so could observe people going back and forth. The bedroom window was very close to the bed so needed to get on the bed to operate the blind. The location is great being at Tokyo station with easy access to all forms of transport and many sights, and many many shops and restaurants/cafes, within walking distance. The staff were very courteous and helpful, with quick attention to requests and efficient carriage of tasks such as luggage forwarding. Would stay again.

This was an absolute treat to stay at this hotel. It has been rebuilt and refurbished in the last five years and is just spectacular. It is right at the station, so very handy. It is also right across the road from all the designer shops and a quick walk to the Ginza area where there is also great shopping. The rooms a very decadent and comfortable. We were treating like royalty while we were there. Everything was just perfect.

Comfort, quality, great service, historic presence, and LOCATION make this hotel the only place to stay in Tokyo. This is one of the few hotels that has a great first night bed - no getting used to it, just fall right in for a comfortable sleep. The luxurious bath, robes, and sleep wear add to the pampered experience. Oh, and please DO have the breakfast in the atrium, serving both traditional Japanese and Western food. Great food, and a great value in a city that doesn't have as many breakfast options. Preservation buffs, check the archives for the story of this incredible restoration and preservation project. On levels below, or just adjacent to, the hotel are a primary subway line and the train station. In most other cities this would not be desirable, however, here it is one of the best amenities. If you do nothing else, eat a few meals here - there are dozens of restaurants, take-out, and bento (basement shops have the best bento), and shop the train station, both levels. especially easy to do with a rail pass. Do as the residents do - travel, eat and shop the station!

Stayed for one night only (wished it was for longer) staff excellent, birthday gift in room and staff taking photos for my birthday.Room was special, dome room with a view over the station concourse.Would definitely use again when staying in Tokyo

A lovely old building which has been transformed inside by delightful and extremely tasteful interior design. Wonderful. Excellent location despite being above a major railway station(you never notice this aspect anyway) - with a lot of major attractions, inc the Imperial Palace & Gardens, within walking distance.Great service, and lovely food, the breakfasts especially being superb. Very spacious bedrooms with a great en-suite bathroom.Expensive but then if you want Tip Top quality then this is what you pay and this is it !

We checked ourselves in at the last minute having been stranded by the insane travel chaos caused by snow storms in February. It was expensive but completely worth it, with pitch-perfect service. It's located right by Tokyo station so very handy for popping down to check whether the Shinkansen lines were up and running again. It's also well-appointed, quiet and huge by any standards, not least to say Tokyo's. We enjoyed the (artificial onsen) and spa facilities in the morning before heading off.

One of the 'four wonders of Tokyo' on our 'must do' list. My wife and I were visiting the city this Spring to see the glorious Cherry Blossom emerge, to see distant snow-capped Mount Fuji gleam in the morning sun, to ride on the latest N700 Bullet Train and to stay at this magnificent hotel. What a treat! Arriving at dawn from London we were ushered into the Atrium which is reserved exclusively for hotel guests to enjoy breakfast. The British designers have converted this vast and impressive roof space into a supremely comfortable room. The breakfast buffet offers every kind of indulgence you could wish for; to be enjoyed at dining tables or in the comfortable lounge seating areas surrounded with books and bookshelves. On the ground floor you will find the Lobby Café where even a simple request for a pot of tea will receive impressive attention from the courteous staff. Our bedroom in one of the corner towers was an oasis of comfort with faultless technology, the bathroom so perfectly designed and equipped that I actually photographed it. As always with a great hotel, the quality of the staff is key, and the Station Hotel understands this as well as anyone. Natural Japanese courtesy is matched with a Japanese belief that serving your guests with perfection is an honour.

All combined, if you're staying one/two nights then it's definitely worth it! Location is great. Rooms are excellent - quite spacious, modern and in fantastic condition. And service is great as well. Lounge is a bit too expensive - over USD 10 for a coffee!!!

A stay in this hotel made for a great start to our trip. The rooms are described as European style, with good quality furnishings, generous bathrooms (ours had a separate rainfall shower and bath tub) and European toiletries. Our Queen room overlooked the station entrance and was quiet, apart from the occasional rumble from trains below. As others mention - the corridors seem to go on forever and the lovely lady who showed us to our room must surely walk miles every day! Once you've checked-in, guests staying at the far end of the corridor are shown a "guests only" entrance which offers a quicker route into/out of the building. Our flight arrived early morning. Arriving at the hotel, staff stowed our luggage until the 3pm check-in (I understand early check-in is not done in Japan, which is fair enough). Upon checking-in, our luggage was waiting in our room. This hotel is not cheap but we felt the quality justified the cost. We tried the breakfast buffet in the Atrium once - a very good selection of Western & Asian items but quite expensive (around UK£25/person). Tokyo Station makes a good place from which to explore the city on foot or by metro/JR rail lines. It is also convenient for catching a Shinkansen out of Tokyo.

My family and I were extremely satisfied with our recent stay at Tokyo Station Hotel. The facilities were truly state of the art. My son especially loved their ultra modern water closet. I appreciated the stool in the shower area which was beside the bathtub. They were in one enclosure. The location was superb-within walking distance of the Imperial Palace and Ginza. Upon exiting the hotel, the entrance to Tokyo Station is just a few meters away. Tokyo Station, a historical landmark in Japan, is the main subway hub of Tokyo, its nearby districts and also of the Narita Express ( train to and from Narita Airport) and the Shinkansen (bullet trains) trains, which service the distant provinces of Japan. There are restaurants galore within the Tokyo Station complex. The service of the staff was likewise commendable. Also, in terms of security of hotel guests, outsiders are unable to gain entry into the hotel room lobby and elevators without a room card. My family's consensus is that upon our return to Tokyo, our only choice of a hotel will be the Tokyo Station Hotel-superb in every aspect!

I was in the hotel 10 years ago when it was a run down old hotel with everything falling apart , and nothing seems to be right. Had a drink at the Bar and Left.This year , I came to stay and found it to be beautifully restored and my stay was very enjoyable. The rooms are nicely done and so are the public places.

This is a gorgeous, luxurious and wonderful hotel. It is conveniently located in Tokyo Station, a major hub for several subway lines and train lines. The rooms are small by North American standards, but very functional. The amenities will make you feel pampered: from the huge bathtub, separate shower space, and separate toilet that features a high-tech console that far exceeded my personal needs (I did, however, use the buttons to make the seats go up and down). The staff provide amazing service. As we checked out, they accompanied us to the ticket counter of the train station and helped us purchase our tickets home. I would love to stay there again.
user_name:
Josh M
Redwood City, California, United States

review_body: The rebuild of this has brought a nice looking building to an area which surrounds it with glass and metal, the outside of the building looks good but there is a car entrance which is nothing short of a maze, my taxi driver was confused how to get near.I was expecting a resplendent reception on arrival and quite honestly it was a let down, it felt like the spare bedroom had been converted, it was rather pokey and not grand as expected.The room was excellent though, the fittings were perfect, I opted for a view of the station, I ended up on the third floor overlooking the south entrance and although an inside view it was interesting.The room was comfortable with free mineral water and wifi and a good selection of toiletries. I had a very relaxing shower and I was quite humoured to find the toilet open close and flush without me needing to do anything.I never ate in the hotel unfortunately so I never had a chance to try anything, but maybe next time.

We came to Tokyo for my 30th birthday and intended to stay at the Park Hyatt. Unfortunately, because of the Tokyo marathon there were no rooms there (or nearly anywhere) during the first part of our stay, and we randomly ended up booking a room at this hotel - we were pleasantly surprised. Though our room was upgraded to a rather lovely suite, we had a view of a brick wall from our window, not a big deal as we were just there the one night until our flat in Ebisu was ready - and surprisingly, despite being in the train station, essentially - it was very quiet.(I will note that the -tiny- door to the hotel was a bit difficult to locate (especially after a long flight and then Narita Express ride) though we did eventually find it (Marunouchi North Exit on the right after the ticket machines).The staff exemplified typical Japanese hospitality, and the room service was relatively good, though as is typical in these hotels - pricey. The bathroom was the nicest of any hotel we stayed in in Japan - with a massive shower and bath. Upon checkout they presented me with a lovely notebook as they'd noted it was my birthday from my passport (I'd not told them directly) which I found very kind of them!I'd not hesitate to stay here again when we next visit Tokyo, though I'd perhaps ask for a different view.

my partner and I spent one night in this hotel while we were travelling around Japan and it showed incredibly exceptional quality. We stayed here on my 21st birthday and the staff went to incredible lengths to ensure that I had the best experience, from helping my partner book the restaurant to delivering flowers to my room and even presenting me with a gift at the end of our stay.The rooms here are not large but they are so beautiful they have a bit of a classic french theme and were definitely large enough so that we could spread our luggage out and be comfortable (not true of all the hotels we had stayed in before now). The bathroom was large with areas separated by glass for the toilet, sink and shower/bath sections. The shower was a large, overhead shower with a large floor space next to the bath.The location of this hotel could not be better. Less than 1 minutes walk to Tokyo station and has 2 shopping centres in its surroundings. For us this was really the perfect place to stay and well worth the price. I will never forget my first experience staying at this hotel and I will definitely be back!

Great location and easy access to Tokyo station makes the splurge worthwhile. We loved the historic hotel. The hotel staff were able to speak English. They were extremely polite and helpful. The Chinese restaurant in the basement was excellent and vegetarian friendly!

Tokyo station hotel is the top hotel I have stayed in so far ( in the city of Tokyo )I have tried few more 5 star hotels in the same area but this one is the best 1. Right in the middle of Tokyo ,attached to Central Tokyo station . 2 excellent French Classic style decoration with high ceilings . The hotel is very clean 3. Beautiful breakfast area with a good selection of food .4. Very helpful staff 5. Good money value for what you get 6. Direct access to Narita airport express .In arrival ,ask the staff to help you to buy the prepaid public transportation card ( minimum charge is 2000 ¥- 20 $ . )it takes less than a minute , literally in the station entrance of the hotel . I was there for a week ,using the metro and train and the 20$ Covered me for this period of time . You can use the same card to purchase some snacks or drinks . For sure I will stay there in my next trip to Tokyo
user_name:
Melina B
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: I was sad when Seiyo Ginza Hotel closed in April 2013, as I've been staying at that hotel since 1997. So I was glad to find a hotel in the vicinity that matches Seiyo Ginza's qualities. One of the charms of Seiyo Ginza was its clientele: the hotel catered mainly to Japanese clients and one rarely ran into business travelers (until Rosewood acquired the property in the late 90s). And this is what Tokyo Station Hotel is like. The hotel has a lot of Western sensibilities: ample size rooms, high ceiling, iron and ironing board in the wardrobe, chandelier in the bedroom. The decor is classic European.Buffet breakfast, served in the 4th floor atrium, is one of the best I've had in Tokyo and is reasonably priced. Service overall is excellent. A bonus is direct access to Tokyo station, so if you're traveling to/from Narita/Haneda airports in the winter, you don't have to put your coat on.BTW, I know another regular Seiyo Ginza client who now stays at Tokyo Station hotel when he visits Japan.

We arrived Tokyo station by airport limousine which stopped at the Yaesu side, and it took quite a long time for us to find the hotel on the marunouchi side. But it was well worth the search, the hotel was so delightful with friendly staff, well appointed rooms and nice ambience. It was a long walk from the hotel reception side to our room on the another end but the long corridor is like a gallery lined with nice historic pictures of Tokyo station and the hotel. The room is on the small side but with every details taken care of. The bathroom was especially impressive with a big deep bathtub and a huge rainforest shower. The view from the window was perhaps the only slight disappointment but not surprising with the hotel rooms above the station on low levels in the midst of the tall office buildings around the station. There are plenty of eating places and shopping within the station and in the vicinity. We found the location most convenient for traveling by trains and subway. This is our favorite hotel in Tokyo and we will certainly want to stay there again on our next trip to Japan!

Friendly, warm, comfortable,convenient. My wife and I stayed for one night for our eight-year anniversary I can't say enough about this hotel!The Hotel is a very nice bed and breakfast. A breakfast of Coffee, served at 9-10:30Am in the parlor. Cookie, the Golden Retriever, will come over and join you for breakfast,all in one:the food and coffee in the morning are amazing!

It is my favourite hotel in Tokyo as its location is very convenient for subway, JR and NEX. The most lovely area for me is its bathroom. Although the room rate is a bit expensive, we will come back again next time.

While we don't normally stay at hotels this far up the food chain, the decision to stay here was relatively easy. A direct train ride from the airport, porter meeting us at the train to help with luggage and escort us through the Tokyo Station to our hotel, a well-appointed room, and a staff that defines customer service.

I was recommended this hotel by a friend in Tokyo, it would appear that it had just opened and the owner has not wasted any money at all. It was nice to see a well built and well finished hotel. The staff were very friendly and couldn't try harder to help customer. The location is great especially if you have to catch the bullet train or metro. Despite being in a huge station the hotel is quiet and serene.The breakfast buffet was a good mixture of western and Japanese.The location is walkable to the imperial Palace (don't run on the gravel they don't like it), walk in the Ginza district which was great.The only downside if I could find one was that the rooms could be a long walk from reception due to the design of the building, it was quicker to take the nearest exit and walk around the building than internally. Another interesting feature was the use of the 24 hour clock that went passed 2400 hours, so 0100 becomes 2500 and 0200 becomes 2600 which was amusing.Anyway back to the hotel, I will definitely be back when I next stay in Tokyo.

Very impressive decoration, nice hotel lobby and room. Although the size of the room is not very big, and have to walk through a very long corridor from lift lobby to room. it is still very nice, the bed is comfortable and the bathroom is unexpectedly spacious. All staffs are good and helpful, especially the house keeping is super tidy! Don't miss the breakfast, although it is quite expensive cost more than 4000 Yen per person. The restaurant is just gorgeous and foods are nice too. Most of the occupants of the hotel were Japanese, the atmosphere is calm, quiet and decent.Only one thing that annoyed me, when we got off from the Airport Limousin, it's so hard to find the way form the North to South, as the Tokyo station totally block the way between Hotel gate and bus stop, also without any clear guidance. I just think if the hotel can give their occupants an E-pass to use within Tokyo station which allow us to walk through every entry, then it'd be more than perfect!

Here for a week, we are just so delighted by our hotel pick (Thanks, Expedia!). Every amenity n the room, extremely gracious service, and of course right at the station for access to everywhere. Close to, and perhaps, the nicest hotel we've ever stayed at. Memorable in the extreme.
user_name:
Michael K
Six Mile, South Carolina

review_body: Excellent service. Exceptionally helpful concierges. Friendly and attentive lobby staff. Love the female bellhops! Room was large, clean, comfortable, quiet and well appointed. Huge bathroom with great tub and shower, and of course, one of those amazing full-service Japanese toilets in it's own little room. The location is perfect, so convenient, right there at the busiest train station in Japan and within walking distance to Ginza and the Imperial Palace. Shopping and restaurants nearby and in the train station. You never hear the trains even though they are right there. Amazing breakfast buffet in a beautiful room upstairs, Asian food on one side and European/Western food on the other. Nice spa and fabulous restaurants in the hotel. I can't wait to stay there again. I definitely recommend this hotel.

This is my second time here. I choose the room facing the business district. Room size is much bigger in comparison to other hotel in Japan. Hotel maintains its good service and standard. As I cannot speak japanese, hotel helps me to preorder a night bus ticket in Tokyo a month before I arrived. They have also translated all the japnese details to english to ensure I can take the bus before I left, of course without extra charge. Excellent service.

So convenient. I like the renovation that was just completed. Yes the rooms are long and narrow but the ceilings are high. Nice mix of colonial and modern. We got connecting rooms, the weird thing was in one room you can leave the door open but in the other you can't.Anyway we didn't have much interaction with the staff but the ones that did provided good service you would typically expect.They have a valuable service of meeting you at the arrival of your train from narita, if you ask in advance. They will also bring you to your train upon check out. This is useful as the train system and station takes a while to understand.Tips usually are not necessar and are refused. But I guess the younger ones living in the cities are changing. It's not usually done but I offered those that pulled by suitcase from the train to the room. I was surprised that they accepted but hey I did offer. But for those that brought me to the train refused, so I hope I did not insult them.We only spent one night so we did not try any of the restaurants. No noise whatsoever from the trains, cars, busees or people around the station.

The Tokyo Station hotel feels like an institution.
