It's difficult to understand how such a stunningly beautiful hotel just happens to co-exist inside a crowded public subway but there it is and is equally right up there with the best hotels I have ever stayed at. If you want class with a quiet English understatedness you can do no better than the Tokyo Station.Housed in an old historic redbrick building located right inside Tokyo station the rooms are large and beautifully decorated in a classic English manor style with its high ceilings, tall windows, and chandelier overhanging the bed, all carried over from a period gone by. Recently refurbished the rooms were spotless and odour free and the A/C quiet. The bathroom was almost as large as the room and equally as beautifully decorated.All the staff at the hotel spoke good English and always eager to assist. Internet was free. Getting there from the airport you just take the Narita Express to Tokyo station.

I stayed for three days at the Tokyo Station Hotel and loved my stay. The hotel looks brand new, is super clean and feels very quiet and exclusive even though it is located right at Tokyo station. The location of the hotel is amazing and everything is very close. I was on a business trip and rarely needed to get on a train as most of my meetings were only a short walking distance away. I was spoilt for choice in terms of eating options as there are literally hundreds at various price points in the area.I arrived early so could not check into my room before 1 PM. I instead used the spa (for a charge of US$20). The spa was a great experience with a carbonate pool and a artificial hot spring. I freshened up and could go off to my meeting.I highly recommend the hotel!

Tokyo Station Hotel is a lovely hotel conveniently located. The high ceilings in the rooms give it a big spacious feel. The staff is accommodating, caring and aiming to please. The restaurants were all good in the hotel. Would recommend it without hesitation

There are so many hotels in so many different locations in Tokyo it was hard to decide on one for our trip. In the end we decided to go with Tokyo Station Hotel after reading reviews about this place. Did we regret our decision, absolutely not! You may not usually pick a hotel located right next to a busy train station, but believe it or not you do not hear a thing when you are inside this hotel. This hotel has been beautifully decorated and the staff are very very polite and helpful. It is in a great location, easy access to the train lines, subways and Shinkansen.

Tokyo Station Hotel is one of the best hotel I've stayed so far.It is without a doubt a destination in itself!!It was one of the most memorable valentines getaway.It's European décor matched with the rich history of the Tokyo Station will provide you with a unique memorable experience as if you're in Japan but not!Spa Tokione is a must for spa lovers. (I've reserved a couples room package, where couples could receive treatments at the same time. We both chose different aromatic massage oils which surprisingly merged really well creating a new and unique scent, well balanced and strictly reserved for our special memories together there. Afterwards she had purchase the one she had chosen, I didn't buy mine, so at home it just feels different. Definately recommending buying both to recreate that moment!!!)We had dinner at Sushi Aoyagi (a traditional Japanese) and enjoyed it very much as everything is superb and everything I've tasted (I've ordered the omakase) it is something that I could not ever imagine tasting! (we originally wanted to have dinner at Blanc Rouge....but we didn't know most reservations were made 3-4month prior and therefore unable to get any seat....SO!! lesson: to dine at the luxury restaurant of desire in Japan, make sure you reserve ASAP!!)Morning brunch at the Atrium.....WOW!!!! All I can say is that it is WONDERFUL!!! Amazing beyond words!!!No words nor pictures will be able to describe that breakfast experience!!!Don't even think about considering another place for breakfast if you are staying there!!! Please! You'll be missing out!!Afternoon tea/snack at Toraya (yes...still in the hotel~) is Amazing as well!!! I don't usually give out complements, but the limited time special pudding was just too amazing to describe! In fact, tears of happiness is the only thing stopping me from enjoying that amazing pudding!!I could go on and on about how amazing this place is. Instead of reading about it more, I would recommend just go and experience it yourself!!!

I found their home page often shows as it they are fully booked, but do try calling or e-mailing – as apparently the webpage is not 100 pct. functional.We stayed here the last night of our Tokyo trip. Very convenient for catching the Nartia express return to airport the following morning. We arrived early and stored our luggage, when we returned to check-in luggage was already in the room, very convenient. There were small slippers for my daughter, and a child toothbrush – she noticed it straight away.Very big spacious room, huge bathroom, everything was beautiful and well functional. Nice big closet with iron and iron board.Do not get a room facing the station, as there was noise all night from the station (not at all loud) but you could hear it, sounded like an elevator arriving (ding dong) every minute all night long – so do get a room facing the street.Will recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to Tokyo, we were traveling with a lot of luggage and it was so nice and easy just going down 3 or 4 sets of escalators to be at the train.

We stayed here for one night for Valentine's day. We had dinner reservations nearby and just loved the location. Service was amazing and each staff member that we encountered spoke excellent English. We had a room with breakfast, and it was easily the best breakfast buffet I have had at a hotel anywhere. The room was impeccably clean and had every amenity we needed. We were upgraded to a Maisonette room and the view was unbelievable. The bed was very comfortable; a pleasant change from many we've slept in here in Japan. (They tend to be very hard.) We will definitely stay here again.

I loved this hotel. Our room was spacious and beautifully decorated. The location is perfect right in the train station. Staff was amazing and very helpful. We have stayed at other hotels in Tokyo but this will be our go to place for our next trips.

We stayed here for three nights after doing a lot of research! Location is incredible. If you have a limited amount of time to explore, this is definitely your best bet. Service was excellent and staff was very helpful at all hours. Only downside was that our room was small and had a limited amount of natural light. Still though, overall a great experience!

We booked this hotel based on the reviews . We stayed for three nights. The room we were allocated is OK but a little small. The room has a bath and a shower. It also has plenty of power points for the traveller with many electronic devices. The rooms are extremely quiet and although they provide you with a map of the hotel I had no problems in navigating the maze. We were going to the lobby bar for a quick bite until we saw the smokers. There are plenty of other options just outside the hotel. I was impressed by the quality and friendly staff, most speak good understandable English. Would I come back to this hotel. Yes base on quality and location

In 15 minutes we managed to get from the bullet train to reception, drop our bags and get out again. Just as quick at the end of our trip back to the airport train and they carried our bags to the train door. The room was small but comfortable. The bathroom was just as big and absolute luxury. Not cheap but very convenient and real luxury.

Elegance and style epitomise this establishment. On every level, you are treated to a first class experience. The staff are knowledgable and very helpful. Nothing is too much trouble.The rooms are appointed with almost everything that you can think of and the beds are extremely comfortable to sleep in.Location wise, you couldn't be in a better place; above a very central station (though you cannot hear a sound) and in a very affluent part of town. I can't recommend this hotel highly enough.

We could not fault the cheerful, efficient bell girls at the Tokyo Station Hotel who met us at the platform after our Shinkansen from Nagano and guided us through the maze of Tokyo Station to the hotel within the restored Victorian station building. They stored our luggage for us all afternoon as our flight home from Narita after midday checkout was not until 8 in the evening and then escorted us and carried our luggage to the Narita express platform. The concierge service was friendly, prompt and well oiled, as one would expect in a station hotel but it is always admirable to see these systems working at their best. As others have noted, the hotel itself is a bit of a maze with multiple elevators serving selected floors only, and some significant distances to cover for some rooms but it is wonderfully quiet/ soundproofed, and the rooms have beautiful high ceilings, full windows, comfy beds/pillows and well appointed bathrooms. We didn't eat in the hotel but had a drink in the lobby cafe: however it's those cheerful, smiling, efficient bell girls ( and boys) we'll remember.

Wonderful transit location or perfect for Tokyo visit. Easiest place for airport arrival/departure and access to trains, etc. Rooms very well appointed and extremely QUIET - great for weary travelers. My new favorite hotel in Tokyo!

It is a very nice hotel....grand and vintage...excellent customer service...right at Tokyo Station which is like a maze. The room is small but very comfortable...amenities are definitely well...actually no complaints. However, other travellers are right, the layout of the hotel is really weired. To get to the lobby you need to change two elevators and the public areas are really somehow tiny. Since the station is so busy, I don't get to feel like I am "resting" although you don't hear much noise from the station. But this hotel will work great for the first time visitor as it is right at the central location which connects everywhere else in tokyo and you will get great help if you need.

I have stayed the night here in tokyo, and found the tokyo station hotel to be a great location for my two day lay over. You are right near everything, plenty of shopping, restaurants and sight seeing. And you are on top of a train station, so airport access is direct, as are most parts of Honshu. The room was very comfortable, although the view was of train tracks, but the noise was barely noticeable, and as I was not going to sit in my room and stare out a window, I did not mind. It is worth looking around the hotel for half an hour as it was recently refurbished and is within an historical building. I will stay again when next in tokyo.

Great position and very nice hotel which has all the facilities you would requireThe location is perfect for overnight stays as it is above the station for the Shinkansen and the Narita ExpressAlso very

We stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel on our first night in Japan. It was phenomenally convenient to the Narita Express Train (direct from the airport), restaurants, the Imperial Palace, and Ginza. My wife and I were thrilled by the elegant appointments and hospitable staff. We can't recommend this place enough.

Located right beside the Tokyo Train station, this hotel offers a great stay though at a fairly high price. The Hotel has an old place charm to it and spreads over the pretty large area. We had booked the palace side room and found the rooms exceptionally well-furnished and neat. Since the Hotel wasn’t a cheap deal, we opted out at loads of nearby restaurants and bars for our square meals. Being situated within the station complex, it’s very easy to access regular shops and eateries spread all across the locality. Though the per-night- charges are steep, the hotel is a convenient option, especially for folks in transit and the ones who have an early train to catch.

We had one night in Tokyo after a long trip in Hokkaido, and decided to try the new Tokyo Station Hotel after seeing the outside of it earlier last year. The short answer - I was totally blown away by the experience. (As a benchmark, I have stayed in top hotels and ryokans in Japan, so I know the level of hospitality the Japanese can go to!) First impressions: There are two entrances to the hotel; the main one is from the street or taxi drop-off area, and the other one is from the JR station. We entered from the latter, and were greeted by many bellboys (or bellgirls! They look really cute with their little hats) which made us feel very welcomed. The concierge was courteous, warm and friendly, and promptly showed us where we were with maps of the area. Check-in was 3pm and since we arrived earlier they took our suitcases and stored them. By the time we came back at 3:30pm, all the suitcases were in the room waiting for us! We had someone to show us to the room (typical in Japan), and he even gave us a little history of the place. Room:Our room was the dome room which is slightly larger than the others along the corridor. However this doesn't mean that there is a dome in the room - it just means that the window looks out to the great dome in the Tokyo Station. It was pretty cool watching the people walking about below, some of them gawking at the dome above. If you like natural light filtering into your window then don't choose the dome room; however I have to admit that looking over one of the busiest stations in the world from your hotel room is pretty hard to beat.The room was smaller than I expected, but the very high ceilings made up for it. It has everything I need and wanted, and then some. There is a JBL iPod speaker but it works only with the older iPods and iPhones. Everything looks spanking new and polished, as if you are the very first guest there. Bathroom:The bathroom really shines here. The shower area is right next to the bathtub, onsen style, so it's a very, very large "wet area" - a treat in Tokyo when bathrooms are usually small. Water pressure is strong, toiletries from Gilchrist & Soames, plenty of other toiletries provided. Toilet was the typical Japanese ones which means you have a warm seat every time you use the loo. Location: What can one say about the location except that it is perfect? Even the Mandarin Oriental doens't have a location as good as this. The Imperial Palace is right across the road (some rooms have views of the Palace), and you are at the station which goes to Narita airport on the NEX line. Daimaru (at Gran Tokyo) is also a 5-minute walk away (this can be confusing as you have to navigate the passageways through Tokyo Station, but once you get it, it's easy), and there are so many shops and restaurants at Tokyo Station, you will never be bored or go hungry. Roppongi and Asakusa is just around the corner. Tsukiji Fish Market is a 5-minute taxi ride away (about JPY1200) or 30 minutes on foot. Service:Flawless. I think the only few places which beat this is Ugenta ryokan in Kyoto, and the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo.Cons:The room may feel small for some people. There are some rooms which can be very far from the elevators so be prepared for a long walk. That said, it does make the corridor look really impressive!I am a very light sleeper so even though the soundproofing is top-notch, I can still pick up a bit of noise.

We stayed at the tokyo station hotel for one night as we had a 24 hour stopover in the city, and it was excellent for that purpose. Being able to get the Narita Express from the airport direct to the station and then go upstairs to the hotel is a big bonus. Plus, it is very easy to get everywhere in Central Tokyo from here; we walked to Ginza which is an easy stroll, and the imperial palace is very close also.Service was impeccable - fairly good English was spoken (though not great) and nothing was too much trouble for the staff. In fact, a month before our trip I was having difficulty getting a booking at a restaurant in Tokyo, so I emailed the hotel to see if they could provide some assistance. I was emailed back a signed letter in PDF which confirmed that the booking had been made in my name and to let them know if any other further reservations were required. Upon check-in, another letter waited for me in the room confirming this again. Very thorough service.The room was on the small side and had no view, but it was very reasonable priced so we had no quibbles. All in all, an excellent choice for the city.

I am now back to Hong Kong with a lot of treasurable memories of Tokyo and this beloved heritage hotel, and in particular, the wonderful hospitality that have been given to us so generously by the team there. We stayed here for four nights druing the Christmas time. Marie Antoinette Mori san who's the Chief Concierge of the Hotel has been leading her team to the highest standard on earth. She speak excellent English and her team as well so no worries on communiation in Tokyo nowadays. Whatever you can think of, whether it is before the trip of druing the trip or even after the trip, they will do their best to help you. Words just can’t express how we appreciated and how we were touched towards all that have been given to us by the team. We asked for a lot during and well before the trip happens back in summer this year. We asked them to helped us to pre-book quite a number of restaurants during Christmas time and they did exactly what we wanted (of course with some limtiation due to the restaurant themselves that can't promise a window seat during the peak Christmas season), and all those restaurants offer fantastic view over all the different illumination druing Christmas time in Tokyo. Also a big thanks to the team in helping us to pre-arranging the skytree packages for us which allow us to go up to the top in the very morning without queuing up at the ticket counter, and so lucky we also have a fine weather that day morning, and we, as the early bird, did get the worm to have the luck to see the Mt. Fuji on the skytree top, with excellent visibility. It was really our luck to have them to arrange all these for us. We also purchased a total of six packages of different products from the amazon.co.jp and asked them to deliever to the Hotel before we check in. The team in the Hotel just followed very closely on all my purchase ordered and inform me promptly whenever any one of them has arrived, giving me the greatest level of peace of mind. And of course I have to mention the Strawberry Cake, and top grade fresh strawberry and the Champagne that have been pre-arranged at our request were all wonderfully prepared, and the team was so thoughtful that they included a molten chocolate bath for our strawberry without us asking for such in advance! We did have a very joyful and excited Christmas Eve that night, thanks to all of their hard work in getting us to this point. The hotel itself was the best heritage hotel that I have stayed in so far, though the room is of a smaller size but with the limitation of the heritage building itself these are surely one of its own characteristic. The shower and the water pressure were both excellent and very comfortable, the rain shower was the best that I have used ever, with the powerful waterfall engulfing your whole body, and you never want to get out of that rain shower for sure once you are in. The temperature control of the shower was as precise as you want, with every little turn of the temperature knob it gives you a very precise change in temperature, it was so comfortable. Our last minute (really a last mintue as I only asked for that the day before our departure to Tokyo) request for a hotel transfer was also arranged flawlessly and that have enabled us to reach to Tokyo downtown much earlier than planned and allowed some free time for us to have a drink on the 7/F of New 丸の内 building before coming back for the in-room Christmas Eve celebration. You won't be disappointed with all these and I would highly recommend anyone travelling to Tokyo to consdier this Hotel. They are located right on top of the Tokyo Station, a station that could lead you to anywhere in Japan as it is the mecca of all trains in Japan. The sound proof of the room was really good given the proximity of the heavy train traffic just downstair and I can tell you that you won't feel or hear the train noise at all. The bed sheet was smooth enough, the bed was about right (though not the best that I have tried before), and there was free wi-fi, an i-phone dock (for those who use galaxy, you can jsut purchase a samdock, which I did, from amazon which will give you the access capability to use the i-phone dock same as if you have an iphone), the temperature control was excellent as well. There is also a humidity control unit which you can use to add on some humidity to the room as it would be dry in Japan during winter time. There were two bottles of chilled complimentary water in the fridge for you to use. There are just so many that I can't list them out one by one and you have to try this and experince this wonderful experience while you are in Tokyo. I didn't use the spa and fiteness facilities so I cannot comment on those but I have taken a quick view of the site which is very good indeed. There are also a lot of restaurant of the Hotel in B1F that you can try. For sure I am totally satisfied with this Hotel and next time if I am in Tokyo for an overnight stay, this one would be my top choice.

On a recent trip to Tokyo, I was fortunate to have the choice of staying in top hotels in the city. Tokyo probably has more luxury hotels than any other city in the world and any of the top level hotels would have been great. Plus, this being Japan, the level of service is unrivalled. No other country comes close.However, I didn't want to stay in yet another generic 5 star hotel in a shiny gleaming skyscraper (not that there's anything wrong with that) but I wanted somewhere with character.And so I booked into The Tokyo Station Hotel.Believe the hype, believe the reviews, believe the ads - it really is truly amazing, extraordinary and an experience to remember.The interior design looks like a classier, more understated Gatsby aesthetic of Art Deco mixed with modern sensibilities. I had the Palace side Queen sized bedroom on level 3 and it was beautifully and stylishly furnished. And the bathroom - the most amazing bathroom I have seen, with a huge bath separate to the shower area (the wet section of the bathroom is enclosed in clear glass). Toiletries are Gilchrist and Soames, like Shangri-la.Located directly above the Tokyo Station, a stone's throw from the Imperial Palace and the Marunouchi district, ten minutes walking distance to Ginza and 50 minutes from Narita - no other hotel has the perfect location for the leisure traveller or the busy businessman. As one of the major stops on the JR Yamanote line, as well as the hub for the shinkansen and the Narita Express (NEX), Tokyo literally is at your doorstep.There's countless bars and restaurants in the station (this being Japan, there's an extensive network of underground shopping centres within the station) and they stay open til late!But if you are a romantic tragic, you cannot miss the chance to see a living legend in action - head to the hotel's Oak Bar and experience the legendary bartender, Mr Hisashi Sugimoto, work the bar like it's 1959. The Oak Bar is furnished very much like a private club but its surprisingly not an intimidating place - I went by myself and there were two other groups of females all kicking back with a drink. As an aside, if you're a cocktail afficionado, Tokyo is the city to be. The city is full of passionate bartenders of the old school variety who have dedicated their lives to perfecting the art of the martini. The highlight of the hotel was definitely the customer service - I could tell that all staff were drilled to the highest standards and no request was impossible. Efficient, courteous, friendly and impeccable - to the Tokyo Station staff (especially the fabulous concierge staff), I truly loved you all.The buffet breakfast at the atrium is exclusivity defined - only hotel guests can access this - and it was one of the best breakfasts I have ever had. As always, my general rule is to eat the local cuisine of the country you're visiting, so I skipped the western bacon-and-eggs-and-hot-meal part of the buffet and went straight to the Japanese side. And was promptly in heaven.The hotel has a spa and fitness complex but due to time constraints I was unable to try them out. There are a number of cheap and cheerful reflexology and massage places in the underground shopping centre and I highly recommend them. Note that the Imperial Palace is closed on Mondays! I forgot to read the fine print in my Lonely Planet and turned up at the gates bright and early on a Monday - and walked away empty handed. Here's some practical information:1) The Tokyo Station is on the Yamanote Line. Because the Yamanote Line is a circle, it takes just over an hour to do a full loop. And the Yamanote Line leaves Tokyo Station (and any other station on the line) every 2-3 minutes.2) Tokyo Station is at 4 o-clock. This means Shibuya (where Hachiko statue and the dance clubs are located) is at the 8 o-clock mark. Which means that it takes approximately 20 minutes to travel between Tokyo Station and Shibuya. Shinjuku is at 10 o'clock which means it takes approximately 30 minutes to travel from Tokyo to Shinjuku.3) If you're a fashion and shopping tragic, the best places to hit shopping are Ginza (for the usual luxury offerings) and Shinjuku (where the grand department stores are located). But I highly recommend Shinjuku particularly the little side streets and alleys just outside the train station. Oh my God - ever wanted to buy a Birkin, or Louis Vuitton for a fraction of the price - then hit the Duty Free Stores. Don't be shy, just go inside - all the staff are nice and friendly - and shop how the pros shop. Don't ever pay retail again. Some of the stuff are second hand, some are brand new - but all of them are authentic. And again, this being Japan, the second had stuff still look almost brand new. This is even better than ebay. 4) It makes life so much easier if your hotel is situated on one of the Yamanote line stops. However, note that many train stations in Tokyo are interconnected - for example, JR Yurakucho station is a stop on the JR Yamanote line, but what most travellers don't realise is that Yurakucho is just a 5 minutes walk to Ginza and Hibiya! This means that if your hotel is in Hibiya (literally on the other side of the tracks from Ginza) then you don't have to change trains if you're on the Ginza line - just walk to the Yurakucho station and you're on the Yamanote line straight away! Same thing for Shiodome station - it is not on the Yamanote line but it is connected to JR Shimbashi which is on the Yamanote line, just walk 5-10 minutes underground through a shopping centre.To the JR East Company and the Tokyo governor/mayor who had a vision of restoring this grand hotel to this former glory, and to the current staff and management who make the dream a reality, I salute you.

This is the second time I've stayed in this hotel, and it didn't just meet my expectations, it exceeded them. I had asked for a dome room with a view overlooking the concourse of the train station, and I was assigned just the room I wanted. I've probably described this in an earlier review, but this one was slightly different than the other one, in that it seemed a little larger. Other than that, though, it was just what I wanted it to be. It had an extremely high ceiling, bathroom amenities including a Toto "Washlet" toilet that does just about everything for you, including raising the lids, flushing automatically and "cleaning you off" when you're through. The only thing different from the one I have at home (it's hard to imagine life without one when you've first enjoyed it) was that there was no "dryer." The bed was huge, soft and with a huge amount of pillows that made you feel as if you were an oriental potentate. Despite being right at the largest train station in Tokyo, you never heard a sound, even though announcements are going on literally right outside your window, and screaming kids are running around all over the place, not to mention the huge holiday crowds. I forgot to mention that the bathtub/shower area is just special. The tub is large and deep, so you have an almost "onsen" like experience. Then there is the shower, which is right next door to the tub, and it has an elegant "rain" shower head. It's hard to decide which is the more decadent.The hotel itself is "old-time" luxurious, with high ceilings, deep carpets, long hallways, and it takes you back to an era of (I almost hate to say it again) luxury that is sadly lacking in most hotels.I opted for the "breakfast package" which included a daily trip to their fantastic "atrium" where a huge and lavish array of wonderful foods was in evidence. Everything you could possibly want or need (and a few things you probably wouldn't) was there: meats, pastries, salads, soups, etc. (I don't want to take the space talking about all of them) and an on-site chef who whipped up tasty omelets. In short, it would be hard to find another breakfast as super as this!All in all, it was a welcome return for me, and I vowed I would always stay here when I return to Tokyo for at least part of my trip. Anyone who wants a perfect stay in Tokyo need head no farther (if one is arriving by train) than this sensational hotel.

Not inexpensive, but $523 for a large room, with twin beds on the palace side of the hotel, actually with a small glimpse of some of the castle buildings including a more than excellent breakfast buffet in Tokyo is a steal.In 2005 as I recall my wife and I walked through this hotel, we had been to the Luminaria light display in Marunouchi and were walking back to Tokyo Station from Yurakucho. It was cold and had started to rain so we cut through the building to get to the train station. It was an old, old barn with the widest hall on the 2nd floor I have ever seen in any hotel anywhere.Since then JR East has spent a large fortune restoring the hotel, adding a 3rd and 4th floor which we burned out in 1945 in the fire raids and restored the original two domes. The central hall was reduced in width allowing the palace side rooms to be enlarged to rather long rectangular shape, new everything, beautifully "restored" and refurbished. It is a joy to see what can be done with an old building and lots and lots of money.We stayed in room 3066, a superior twin room with a bare view of the palace grounds. My only complaint is that the wing chair was not comfortable for reading, the sofa was fine. Beds were great, quiet despite overlooking the very busy front taxi arrival area. We ate a light dinner at the Toraya Resturant on the 2nd floor, had a vegetarian dinner assorted steamed vegetables over rice with a ponzu sauce which to my surprise was excellent. My only criticism is that the green tea which I ordered with the after dinner sweet was not of the same quality as was served at the Toraya shop in the basement of Mid-Town Center. That was tea to go back for again and again. We went out walking afterwards to see the lights in Marunouchi 2 blocks west of the hotel. On our return we had a beer and an apple soda in the 1st floor lounge. Good service, not inexpensive, but it is Tokyo.The breakfast is an additional fee of 2,000 yen per person, but it is a very elaborate buffet of western and Japanese dishes of which I ate more than I should have. Excellent food and excellent service in a nice setting.Note, this hotel is built along side of the railroad tracks and stretches for about 300 yards, so you may wind up with quite a bit of a hike from one of the two elevators to your room. Such is life. The building dates to about 1906 was completed in 1914, burned out in 1945, closed in 2007 for a 6 year revovation/restoration. There are newer western style hotels in the city generally more expensive, but for a trip back in time at the most central location in all of Tokyo this is the place to stay.Oh, for giggles, go to the 2nd floor where you can overlook the rotundas at the North and South Marunouchi entrances to the station. Better than the scramble across the intersection at Shibuya, trust me.

My family of 4 (2 boys 9,7) stayed total 6 nights in Tokyo Station Hotel. From reservations, pre-stay assistance until departure, everything was perfect! I would like to thank Marie Antoinette Mori (Chief Concierge) for her personal attention to every of our enquiries. We were thankful that she speaks English and was able to answer to all our needs. She had arranged for porter services to meet us at the NEX platform in TYO station and bring us right to the hotel door step. On our departure days, the other concierge staff proactively brought us to the Shinkansen tracks as well as to the NEX platform in the station, otherwise we might get lost!The property is newly furnised and re-opened in Oct 2012. Rooms are decent size per JP standard and the bathrooms are fantastic, especially the rain bath and the auto toilet! My boys were give some souveniors and they were thrilled!Location is extremely convenient. You can get to practically anywhere easily from all the JR lines. There is a direct access path from the South Exit of the train station to the Hotel. The JR travel service center is located at the North Exit of the train stationl; you can reserve your Shinkansen tickets etc with the assistance of the agents who speaks very good English. Lots of restaurants within walking distance of the hotel at the surrounding buildings or within the train station.Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our stay and would definitely be back.

My wife and I and 2 kids (4, 3) stayed in Tokyo Station Hotel for 12 nights at the end of October/beginning of November. This review can not possibly express the pleasure of our stay. I can't imagine our vacation being better had we stayed elsewhere. Getting to Tokyo Station from Narita is simple. Once you get into Tokyo station, it does take a little work to find the hotel. Following signs and asking, as others has posted, helps. Still, with no need to drag luggage into a cab, you can't beat the convenience, especially once you start to use the metro/trains for sightseeing. The station has everything you need, though it takes a little work to navigate your way around (which can be frustrating). Tokyo Station Ramen Street was an especially convenient place to go coming back to the hotel after sightseeing. Also, about a block away, are many high rises with dozens of shops, restaurants, coffee shops, and small grocery stores on the basement floor. With kids, this provided us with every convenience we might need, often without ever needing to go outside (there are tunnels from the Tokyo station underground that lead into these buildings). On to the hotel. I don't know where to start....The staff is remarkable. Let's start there. The staff could not have been more gracious during our entire stay. We felt so welcomed from the start and by the end of our trip we felt like the staff was family. I must also recognize Ms. Mori. Even before we arrived, she helped to not only secure me Pocket WIFI (which I highly recommend) but several restaurant reservations. Then, during our stay, she helped us with other reservations, sightseeing suggestions, and friendly conversation. Additionally, she has the insight to provide the kids little gifts upon our arrival back 'home' several times, making it far easier to 'parent' after a long day of sightseeing. The hotel provides PJs for all guests. Every night, the entire family would come home to pressed Pajama shirts. The kids' shirts had Shinkansen bullet trains embroidered, and our kids couldn't wait to get into them each night. It was very hard not to steal them at the end of our trip! The hotel also provided, in addition to all the great toiletries, toothbrushes, toothpaste, and shinkensen cups for the kids.The Hotel. It is beautiful. Obviously, the facade is a landmark. Inside, the hotel is flawless. Everything has been redone to perfection. It is very modern and remarkably well designed and exceptionally clean. I agree with others, there are some long, long hallways, but this is a minor criticism. The Room. We stayed in a Dome King. It is sound proof. We opted for this because we wanted to see the station below us, a unique experience. Watching all the salary men and women going to work each morning and leaving each evening served as bonus entertainment. One night, with the kids asleep, we were entertained by a young man trying to coerce a women to join him on a train ride home, while the rest of the station was empty (he failed). For some, the rooms may be small. For us, the Dome King was great. We are used to sleeping with our kids in a King Bed on vacation. There was plenty of room for the kids to play in front of the bed on the floor with toys. The bathroom is great. The shower is huge and has an amazing rainfall shower head in the middle, along with an adjacent tub. The toilet has all the expected Japanese features, including a heated seat. Our kids were disappointed to leave the Tokyo toilets.Restaurants: We were never disappointed in the restaurants (sorry, forget the names, but you'll know what I mean). We ate in the sushi restaurant with my wife's aunt, who lives in Tokyo. Since we had the kids, we secured a private room. The sushi was wonderful, and the service was outstanding. Next, we ate at the Irish restaurant. I had the Shepard's Pie, fantastic, along with a Guinness Draft,while my wife raved about the fish and 'crisps.' The staff mentioned that they brought members of the Irish Consulate in to try the food before the restaurant launched. During that dinner, our waitress from the sushi restaurant from the night before came over to say hello and wanted to take pictures with our kids. As a parent, this sort of thing really makes you feel welcome. The atrium breakfast is not to be missed. It has a phenomenal selection, ranging from traditional Japanese fare to omelets, meats, pastry, and fruits. And the brioche french toast was amazing. It is a high end breakfast in, though and amazing space, a surprisingly relaxed environment.Also, I should mention the Oak Bar, where I stopped, unfortunately, oncet. Great little bar...intimate, with a Japanese Whiskey, along with a surprisingly good selection of international whiskey and US bourbon. Well, that is my take. Sorry for the delay getting it out. I guess I'll conclude by saying that when I come back to Tokyo, I'll stay at Tokyo Station Hotel. I had a long stay there with my family and at the end of the trip I felt really sad to leave the hotel and the people who worked there

We stayed here for 2 nights as part of our 8 days 7 nights Japan trips. The rooms are very decent in size per Japanese standard. I didn't feel cramped. The bathrooms are amazing where the amenities are aplenty. The housekeeping did an amazing job! i spilled some tea on the bed and the HK replaced everything including a new blanket. I say this this because in some US major chains, they do not replace blankets. There is also free wifi which is hard to come by in many Japanese hotels without a fee. The staff was wonderful. The location is connected to the major Tokyo Station and its by the Marounouchi South exit (South Passage pass the South Court where there are some food shops) and connects to 2 side entrances to the hotel. the train station is majorly huge! i took my parents to Shibuya and Shinjuku. The staff gave us a station map to help us navigate and escorted us to the station where to get on. They also took us to the Shinkansen on the day we checked out and brought us there to board our train to Kyoto. There is a major shopping mall attached to the station where foods are aplenty. One thing for sure, you'll never go hungry. Like other reviewers said, the hotel restaurants are on the expensive side(would you expect less?). You do have to pay for the health club and the spa (saunas and hot springs) separately. Tokyo Station is a major station to connect to practically everywhere. It's so convenient and quiet. The beds are heavenly. They did a great job on renovation. its beautiful lobby with a fireplace. I will be back to stay here again no doubt!

Fantastic property! It's exceptionally clean, and luxe. Room sizes are great and the bathrooms are heavenly. Great restaurants below the hotel, and the location is extremely convenient! Would definitely return!

We have just completed two stays within a short period at the Station Hotel and we can not wait for the opportunity to return. The standard of service is outstanding and the quality of the fittings and furnishings gives one the feeling of being on one of the great transatlantic liners of the last century. The attentiveness of every member of staff was exceptional even down to the bell-boy who bravely took our two exceedingly heavy suitcases all the way to the platform of the Narita Express in the station below - through rush-hour crowds. A wonderful hotel, one of the greats.

I stayed here several years ago before the recent major renovation. It had the feel of a quaint luxury hotel from days past with its dark hardwood furnishings and old fashioned steam radiator heating. I was looking forward to staying again after the renovation.I was not disappointed at all. The hotel exterior, which is part of Tokyo Station, was restored to its original appearance. The interior was completely remodeled to current luxury standards with extensive use of marble and fine hardwood.The rooms are beautiful and have all the amenities expected at luxury hotels anywhere, but also have those Japanese touches such as toilets with heated seats and lids that raise automatically when you approach.The staff is very helpful and efficiently sees to your needs and requests without fuss or complaint.There is fine dining in the hotel, but being in Tokyo Station, you can conveniently make your way to any area in the city to eat.If you stay here, get a room facing the Imperial Palace. Spend the little extra to stay in a room above the lowest priced rooms. It is worth it. I only wish I had more time than the two nights I stayed on this trip.

Having stay in the hotel for the last ten days, I had nothing to complaint.Small as expected but the room layout is good. Rooms are tidy and quiet even facing the business district outside. Services are exceptionally good. All staffs are very polite and highly trained and I will definitely come back next time.

The Tokyo Station historical building made of red bricks in the very heart of Tokyo has been turned last year into a luxury hotel with marble floors and elegant setting. The basic rooms are rather small but acceptable, and are equipped with quality furnishings. However, make sure you'll have a room facing the Imperial Palace, the rear rooms give onto a rather oppressing steel wall. Perfect service. Elegant tea room and restaurant.

I stayed here because of its unbeatable location but it is so much more than a convenient hotel to stay in. From the moment my husband and I stepped off the Narita Express train, two of the hotel's staff members were waiting for us outside of the train car (a free service which they provide if you request it). They took our luggage right away and began to guide us through the labyrinth that is the massive Tokyo Station. The staff's English was very good and they were friendly and helpful. Once we checked in without a hitch one of the nice ladies who met us at the station escorted us up to our room and gave us a complete tour of the room's amenities as well as directions to best navigate our way in, out, and around the hotel. Honestly, service from a hotel doesn't get better than this.The room itself is gorgeous. The space is generally what you would expect in Tokyo, a bit small but not at all cramped or uncomfortable. The room (as well as the halls, lobby, Atrium, etc.) is tastefully decorated. Everything from the marble floors, wainscoting, molding, color scheme, artwork, was thoughtfully arranged. The style is kept true to the era of the original hotel but remodeled with all the comforts of modern living. They did an impeccable job of combining style and function and packing it all into a small hotel room. The queen size bed was comfortable, pillows were nice and the space was very clean. The bathroom is similarly pleasing to the eye and very functional. We had breakfast buffet at the Atrium (pricey, $32 per person). The atmosphere of the Atrium is simply beautiful. The food is tasty and the spread is quite respectable for both the western and Japanese cuisine selections. While quite expensive for breakfast, I recommend trying it if you have some spare coin and time. It's a very enjoyable meal and a lovely, calm, satisfying way to begin a day in Tokyo. You must reserve the buffet in advance or reserve it when you check in. The Atrium buffet is for staying guests only.

the euro appearance of the hotel really make the hotel feel fancy. it's nicer than a nice business hotel (marble floors in guestroom, solid furnishings, fancier toiletries) but not quite same as the top luxury hotels. booked a basic room which was kind of small-ish but sufficient, and i think would be kind of tight squeeze for a couple for more than a couple nights. my room had a view directly into the shinkansen tracks, like a little gnome nesting in the train track cracks. the window soundproofing was pretty good and it helps that the trains stop running shortly after midnight so the noise isn't bothersome while sleeping. since the building is shaped like a train station, the hallways are very long, like a train platform. "dome" rooms face the interior of the train station and i don't believe get natural daylight. of course service and staff are very friendly and helpful as expected in japan. love all the old photos of tokyo station in the hallways. fitness and spa have fee for regular guests.

We spent three delightful nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel. It is located adjacent to the Tokyo Station making it very convenient for transit from Narita Airport and by trains to other areas. The rooms were exceptionally clean and well-appointed. The staff provided excellent service--meeting us and accompanying us to and from the train station platform. The location is in the center financial district close to the Imperial Palace and wonderful eating areas. The only drawback was the layout of our room--narrow and difficult to move around, which is probably typical for a Japanese room in Tokyo.

Good size room with excellent bathroom. Good wifi and tv included. Lots of dining options around the area and many metro stations a very short walk away. Not cheap but good value for japan.Only issue is that there is not a lot of room for large suitcases but this is a Japan-wide issue. Pack smart!

The hotel is elegant and sumptuous and worth the expense for a few days as it's so convenient. Easily accessible from the train station (despite what others have said you do not need to go outside if you take the right exit from the station). The room was modest in size but perfectly appointed and had a fabulous bathroom. Major sites in the city are within easy reach and great shopping and dining nearby.

This historical old pile of brick that spans a full city block has been very well renovated with excellent accommodations. There are so many good things about this place but they can easily be overshadowed by the flaws. Arriving in pouring rain one fends for one's self. There does not seem to be any bellmen to assist arriving guests. The small lobby is crowded most of the time. The corridors defy imagination as they extend for hundreds of meters and a long brisk walk only brings one into the next and yet the next. Rooms with 00 in them require the ultimate trek. Staying here can only be described as a bizarre experience as one is at once awed by great bathrooms and vexed by no evening service, poor breakfast buffet and very spotty internet. It is not unusual to see hoards of visitors gawking at the historical portraits on the walls of the long corridors or even wedding pictures being taken in the hallways. Would I stay again? No. However it was a very unique experience to stay there for 6 nights riding out an earthquake and a typhoon. The area is not exciting being a fairly long hike to the Ginza but if you like train stations and goofy hotels this is your place.

This newly renovated upscale hotel is beautiful, very comfortable, conveniently located, and offers top-notch service. The historic hotel is located right next to Tokyo Station and is therefore extremely convenient when taking the Narita Express (NEX) to and from the airport, the Shinkansen bullet train to Kyoto, and the subway to any other part of the vast city. It is also within walking distance to the Imperial Palace and to the trendy & fashionable Marunouchi and Ginza shopping areas. The rooms are clean, modern and elegantly furnished. They are also quite spacious by Tokyo standards. It's also worth mentioning that we never heard any outside noise despite being right above one of the busiest train stations in the world! Last but certainly not least, the fantastic concierge team (headed up by Marie-Antoinette) provided us with unbelievable service during our stay, including a complimentary "Meet & Greet Service" where they picked us up from our train and escorted us right up to the hotel. This hotel is a real gem and we would not hesitate to stay here again on our next trip to Tokyo.

We recently stayed at the Tokyo Station Hotel for two nights. This grand dame went under extensive renovation and reopened last year 2012 with all the modern comforts. It's location is very convenient, accessible by foot, train or underground. The hotel sits on the site of the Tokyo Station where the JR trains arrive. We were greeted by a bell person upon disembarking our JR train and were helped to steer through the mess of the station's Friday afternoon frenzy. The decor is classic opulent reflecting the hotel's history. The service was nothing less than excellent. Our room was very big by any standard, equipped with high end bathroom fittings by Toto, an air purifier, a makeup mirror, HD TV and wifi to name a few. Our breakfast was part of the room rate, and we enjoyed a lovely breakfast in the spacious atrium of the hotel. Our flight leaving Tokyo was through Haneda but I think Narita is equally accessible via its express service. No regrets, I will definitely love to stay there on my next visit to Tokyo.

This hotel went through extensive renovation and was reopened in 2012. They did a very good job in preserving the elegant old world charm but with the addition of new technology such as a toilet that flushes itself when you get off the seat, dimmer for all the lights, wi-fi. The bedding was comfortable. The rooms are standard size for Tokyo. Their service was top notch. We had left a bag at the hotel before traveling around Japan. When we checked in we were told the bag was already in the room. The hotel cannot be more convenient. It is at the Marunouchi N Exist of the Tokyo Station. It was raining hard yesterday so we spent the afternoon shopping and eating at the station's hundreds of restaurants without seeing the sky.

We booked in at the Tokyo Station Hotel for our last two nights in Japan and we really enjoyed it. The two reasons we stayed here were that we had a relatively early flight when we came back to the UK and wanted to be conveniently located for the Narita Express and that we wanted to end on a high with a great hotel.The hotel itself is stunning and very comfortable. There are a few reasons though that I haven't awarded them an excellent rating. Firstly, the layout is not great and we were in a room that was a very long walk from the elevators and reception. Secondly, the atmosphere is very elegant but almost too elegant. The lobby bar was dead by 8:30pm and trying to get a drink proved almost impossible in the hotel. We had one evening where we went to one of the bars and despite seeing 6 people leave they refused to let us in, claiming they were full!The staff are very nice and English is widely spoken (if that's important to you) but I don't know if I'd stay here again as it was very staid and I felt as if I was 40 years to young to be there. It's also very expensive (although we got a very good deal through Expedia) and I think for the amount of money that you need to stay there I'd have been disappointed if we hadn't managed to get a discount.Overall it was good and a lovely end to our vacation. The location is second to none if you need to leave early but be prepared to feel like you need to whisper at all times and be in bed by 10pm.

Service, Accomodations, Public rooms, staff, convenience, VALUE. STYLE. This grand hotel had it all. A perfect oasis with easy access to everything via JR and metro within 3 mins. Taxi too. Breakfast bountiful (less good value, maybe) but setting and service outweighed. Great value for elegance, historically significant surroundings and very attentive, professional and solicitous staff. Comfortable.
user_name:
Joanna M
New York City, New York

review_body: I am a regular traveler to Tokyo for business, onto which I always affix a short period of vacation. It's a terrific city and I look forward to each trip there, even though it entails very long flights. Usually, my hotel of choice is the decidedly ordinary Excel Shibuya, only because it is near my work, located at the buzzy Shibuya crossroads/Mark City Building, and close to the utterly cool Aoyama-Omotesando neighborhoods. This time I also booked three nights at the Tokyo Station Hotel in eager anticipation of checking into the newly opened (since 2012), totally renovated, low-rise old station in and amidst the high rises of post-war central Tokyo. It's a very beautiful architecture and has indeed been attentively restored and outfitted. The neighborhood is quiet and well-situated for the Museum of Modern Art and the Imperial Palace compound. But I wouldn't call the hotel wonderful by any means. Service is delivered in a nervous and awkward manner by the numerous bellhop-clad greeters stationed about. (If the one person on duty who speaks English happens to be taking a tea break, good luck getting a map of the area from the others.) The room on the 2nd floor was long-ish, narrow, and over furnished for the space. Out the beautiful French window was the entrance to the hotel below, and that meant looking upon a truly ugly arrangement of taxis wound around and around to serve the entire train station; in other words, no grand or green entrance to match a grand hotel. Japanese friends were also surprised by the unsightly taxi arrangement, as well as the small and undistinguished reception area of the hotel. It's quite a hike from the elevator to most of the rooms, and if you want to access the numerous restaurants attached to the hotel, hike back to another elevator and descend to the dreary basement, or hike to the access door to more restaurants from the second floor (and then possibly get stuck outside if the keycard fails to let you in again.) The massage I booked in the room via reception --in order to avoid the long trek to the basement facility --was quite good when it finally happened: the masseuse was nearly a half hour late, and only after I phoned the front desk to inquire did she appear. Another inconvenience: to enter the main station from the hotel for a little bite to eat or to check train schedules is no easy matter: one must walk out the front entrance and around the length of the building (in the rain, in this case) to enter via the one hallway available without buying a train or subway ticket first. Finally, Tokyo is more than a little pricey, as everyone knows. In this case, the room was $500 and the one room-service breakfast I shared with my husband (one order between us) was more than $40. Yes, the Marunouchi Building shopping is great, and yes, the grand Ginza area is in walking distance; and there is a wonderful array of traditional Japanese eating places lining the street in-between. But will I return to the Tokyo Station Hotel for these, or just hop the Yamanote line to get there for an afternoon of shopping and eating? You guess.

Location beside Tokyo station is excellent. Room was luxurious and clean. King bed was so comfortable! Upon checking out a member of staff accompanied us to one level above the platform for the Narita Express in order to make sure that we did not get lost. Lovely touch. The hotel is not cheap but we found it worth the extra bit for the convenience and comfort on offer!

We throughly enjoyed our 4 night stay at the beautiful, Tokyo Station Hotel. If you want an outstanding location and fine service in a Colonial style hotel, this is it. We were graciously greeted by the GM and Chief Concierge at arrival. Prior to that the bell staff awaited our arrival at the Train Station and literally carted our bags for what seemed like a mile. Top notch!The room was beautifully decorated and looking outside in towards the Imperial Palace, what a view! The staff was routinely great and the Concierge, Mari Antoinette was wonderful. She gave us a complimentary tour of the Louis Vuitton show at the hotel which was excellent.The renovation is outstanding and the overall product, great. I recommend this hotel and would happily stay again.

I had a very brief stay here (check-in at 10:30pm, check-out at 6am next morning to catch a train) and did not get to experience the hotel facilities and breakfast, but I was very happy with the room and overall service. I had the view of Marunouchi/ post office on the third floor. I liked the beautifully appointed bedroom and the large bathroom. Above all this hotel is extremely convenient if you are doing a rail trip out of Tokyo station as you do not need to drag your suitcases and deal with taxis (I also like Kyoto Granvia hotel for the same reason). There are also good shops and restaurants in Marunouchi office buildings across the street.

I was truly amazed at how well preserved and how tastefully done this renovated hotel looks. It truly is brought back to its glory days. Very clean, elegant, and the service is amazing! It's hard to book a room as it is now the hotel to go to, and I was just very happy to be able to experience this.You cannot tell that just steps away is the main tokyo station with millions of commuters traveling. There are endless taxis and people walking. But inside its so quiet and serene.Highly recommended. I had an amazing time.

The breakfast offerings at the Atrium could be better. Compared to my experience at Shangrila Hotel Tokyo the breakfast quality and range of food offered needs improvement. The staff service quality is par excellence and specific staff members took that extra effort to assist me on my needs eg logistics of sending my bags ahead to my next destination, information on restaurant for dinner etc

This is a perfect hotel for anyone who wants to stay in Tokyo.Check in - very quick, staff is incredibly helpful and polite.Location - this is an amazing location. It took us under an hour to get here from Narita airport by train. It has lot of JR lines and subways lines very convenient. Also, if you are planning to travel around Japan, this is a perfect location as all the bullet trains leave from Tokyo station.Room - very stylish room, comfortable bed, it has everything you can possibly need, very quiet and peaceful, you don't hear the trains at all.Food - there are many restaurants in the hotel and around the hotel, really incredible choice. We ordered room service and it was delicious!Value - comparing to hotels like Park Hyatt and Penninsula, this hotel is half the price but much better location and just as good, so this is an amazing value! You get a 5 star service and luxury for half the price, incredible!WiFi - free wifi, very fast, we connected 2 ipads and 2 iphones, all worked very well.Spa - we didn't try the spa, but it looks wonderfulI would also like to add that Tokyo Station Hotel is recently renovated so everything is brand new. The building itself is really stunning, it's like staying in the most beautiful building in Tokyo!Even though the hotel is a part of the busy station, this is a very clean area, and the rooms are quiet. Across the street from the hotel is luxury shopping mall KITTE, which has a lot of interesting stores with Japanese produce, it also has Muji, lot of restaurants and cafes and very nice roof garden. It's not a mall like you know but cool glass and steel architectural delight that is a unique experience. This is an AMAZING hotel.
user_name:
luciabrooklyn
New York City, New York

review_body: Tokyo Station Hotel is chic, charming and an incredible value. You could opt for one of the glass high rises like Park Hyatt but in my opinion this is a far more unique experience. The hotel was rebuilt from the ground up a few years back but somehow has maintained old world charm combined with sleek japanese amenities. All of Tokyo is super clean and safe and yet somehow this area seems even more!

Perfect Hotel in Tokyo for, ambience, location, service and value. One the best Hotels in which we've stayed in our many travels.Could not have chosen a more convenient hotel in Tokyo given it's location at the Tokyo Station, on the JR line directly from the airport, convenience to subway lines and bullet trains and central location in Tokyo. Additionally, the accommodations, friendly staff and value, were outstanding. Not cheap, but for Tokyo and the quality of the hotel,not expensive.I'd definitely recommend the Dome Rooms My wife was particularly pleased that the bathrooms, equipped with the latest automatic toilets, toiletry's and makeup mirrors, were designed for a women's use.Also, the Hotel on our departure to the airport had two young lady's porters transport our bags and us directly to the Narita Express train, at no cost. Never had this level of service anywhere. I would definitely stay here again and recommend this Hotel to anyone wanting a first class experience in Tokyo.

We found this place a little by accident. Didn't seem to attract such glowing reviews as some hotels, but found out it only re-opened recently after a six-year renovation, and maybe hasn't seen enough Trip-Advisor traffic. Absolutely amazing place and will stay again for sure.Pluses: 1. Location, location, location. Off the Narita Express and straight into the hotel.2. Beautiful building with a lovely, gentle ambience. The style is different from much of Tokyo, with quite a 'colonial' feel, but done in a beautiful, slightly austere Japanese manner. Not classic hi-tech.3. The atrium, where breakfast is served is especially amazing (as is breakfast itself- one of my most memorable meals amongst of a week of foodie heaven)4. Room (a dome room facing into station) was small but beautifully appointed and lovely bathroom, with separate partitioned wet room.5. The staff were especially helpful, even by the amazing standards of Japanese hospitality. On our departure, the bellboy (actually, a tiny bellgirl) led us out of the hotel, through the web of the station and delivered us to the exact spot for our train. Once you've been in Tokyo station, you'll know how much trouble this saved us!!!Minuses:1. Having real trouble here. Worse I can say is it's a long walk from one end to the other end of the hotel..

So proud of staffsEven frontline or back of house have do the best.Staffs polite, attentive,Place clean & tidy,Design fitted for user.......Can keep the condition good, Eng. dept also do a good job.Very good experience & memory on my life, special on my birthday trip on 2013Everyone Move on !

What a wonderful find! This hotel is not only historic and beautifully restored but it is perfectly situated right beside the Tokyo Station and accessible from within. Yet, once inside the hotel, you would never know you were at such a busy location - it is so peaceful and quiet. We couldn't even hear much noise in the corridor. It was fantastic to catch the train from the airport right to the hotel and much cheaper and quicker than a taxi or shuttle bus.The staff are perhaps the most polite I have ever met and could not have been more helpful and courteous. Yes, our room at the back was a little small but we were not bothered by this as it was really well decorated, recently refurbished and it had some character about it. We don't tend to spend much time in the room during city breaks as we are out and about exploring so it suited us just fine. In future, if we returned, we'd love to stay in one of the rooms in the dome.All in all, a faultless experience. It wasn't even that pricey - we got a great deal on Expedia and booked well in advance

But splash out and get a larger room.. the smallest ones face the tracks in the back. It's a pleasure to see the station restored to its former glory. The Marunouchi area is not as windswept as it used to be now that the "Kitte" (former Central Post Office, just over the road) has also been restored and converted to shops and restaurants.

My first impression of the Hotel is undoubtedly fantastic. Not the cheapest hotel in Tokyo, but the service was immaculate and given it only recently opened, the quality of the rooms and the finnish on the material was first class. The staff were all very helpful and my entire family want to come back to this hotel on our next trip to this great city. People often have the impression that Tokyo is an expensive city, but if you check out the prices of the restaurants and stores for general items like non designer clothing and regular Japanese food, the location of this hotel is perfect in terms of access to all kinds of culinary outlets....for all types of budgets. The history of this hotel is charming and I would recommend my friends to stay here.

Stayed for one night in a palace side room room, which was beautifully furnished and exceptionally well-equipped. The room wasn't ready when we tried to check in at about 11am, but when we returned at 4pm, our bags had already been taken to the room and after check-in the receptionist showed us to the room. The layout of the hotel is initially confusing, but it's worth spending time visiting the displays which give a little of the history of the building. We visited both bars and found the prices of drinks to be reasonable (given the standard of the hotel and its location). The room was quiet and breakfast was very good. The hotel's location is superb with easy access to most parts of the city. Whilst the hotel was not cheap, it felt special and I'd be very happy to return.

Picked this hotel party due to location. Attached to Tokyo Station it made it easy to get around, using subway, express trains and reserved trains. Also very handy for buying drinks and snacks to avoid mini bar costs as there are many many shops and eating options within the station. Also simple to catch NEX to and from Narita.The hotel itself was recently refurbished. Had a Palace side room which was beautifully furnished with a large TV with a few English language options. Bathroom was large with an enormous deep tub and the most amazing shower. Plenty of nice quality bathroom amenities.Service at the Hotel was excellent. They had my room ready by 1pm even thought check in was officially 3pm which was much appreciated after a long flight. When I had a problem with a tour company the desk spoke to them on the phone on my behalf and sorted out the arrangements. All of the staff I met were very helpful, seemed rightly very proud of their beautiful hotel and genuinely pleased to welcome you. Housekeeping was excellent. Room was alway immaculate. Bedding was clean and comfortable. Really enjoyed my stay and especially liked he character of the hotel. They had prints on the walls of the hotel and station from time gone by and it really did feel like being part of history. Do take the time to go and look at the domes of Tokyo Station from the viewing deck. It's a unique vantage point.

We stayed here in the heart of Tokyo for 3 nights. Brilliant location as part of Tokyo railway station so getting around this crazy city is made a lot easier. The refurb has created a truly beautiful hotel mixing he old and the new in a glamorous and luxurious fashion. The room was small but had everything you need and more - I've never stayed anywhere that provided so many toiletries and items you might need (when was the last time you used a shoe horn!). Would thorough recommend this hotel as a base for a stay in Tokyo.

Pricey, but perfect in every way. The level of service was the best I've ever experienced. I would compare this hotel to the Taj Palace in Mumbai - truly wonderful! The bathroom was superb, best bath soak I've had in a long time! Breakfast was pricey but outstanding and the staff recommended a good local restaurant for me to enjoy my evening meal. I will return!

First off its really difficult to find the entrance, it looks like a small side entrance to a huge impressive building.Interiors are nice with the high ceilings and up market finishes, very similar fixtures fitting, and colours of the Singapore St.Regis hotel. Check in was smooth, the bathroom was great, western style and yet you can flood the place. I can't quite put my finger on it but the place seems more like a japanese old boys club. Lots of elderly wealthy japanese ladies and gents roaming around the place. It ticked all the right boxes and it's nice to stay in a place with a local flavour rather the usual global brands. But something was missing? Maybe it's the hushed tones of the Japanese clientele that threw me a bit. Location superb all the main line and underground station right underneath you. Though the secret side entrance leads you to the east station lobby, actually the West station lobby has the English speaking JR trains help desk. If you have an early start on the bullet trains, then you cant beat the place.

The location and exterior of this landmark property are truly extraordinary. Finally, a central Tokyo hotel that is not a generic steel and glass tower. Newly refurbished, the hotel still has some bugs to work out. Rooms are new and nice, but cheaper ones will have views of walls and pillars. Ours had a partial view of the Yamanote line platform. Fortunately, the soundproofing was effective. From the Tokyo station JR entrance, where most will arrive, you are on your own with your luggage for the long and confusing walk to the reception desk. What others have said about getting to one's room is true: It can take five minutes of walking, if you don't get lost; and it is easy to get lost. Better signage would help.Certainly convenient for rail travelers, but take care not to arrive on a late train if you are staying here. Most of the station concessions will be closed; and there is nothing in the way of food on the streets within walking distance to the hotel, as the surrounding area is the financial district, which closes tightly at night. We arrived at JR station at 10:00 p.m. and ended up dining in the hotel bar, which had a rudimentary and outrageously priced menu of what turned out to be frozen/microwaved western fare.Overall, it was a good stay for the money, and perfect for JR/Narita Express travelers, provided that you do not arrive too late.

Brand new hotel, with great location in central Tokyo, best choice both for business and leisure.Extremely convenient for moving around with metro and trains of JR as well for reaching by foot main attractions of downtown Tokyo.The Hotel is very stylish, room comfortable, management and staff very helpful and with great knowledge of what are travelers' needs. The breakfast is both Japanese and continental and it is very good for variety and quality of the food.We would like to thank specially the two attendants Mrs L. and Mr. S. for having shown our way to the Narita express for the airport accompanying us to the exact track of the train when we left in big hurry.I strongly recommend this Hotel to everyone is traveling to Tokyo.

The hotel, occupying the heritage building atop JR Tokyo Station, has just been renovated recently and reopened to the public. The location is definitely a plus for business and leisure travelers alike, particularly for those who are very much obsessed with the plethora of dining and shopping within the station below. You don't have to go back to the street from JR to access the hotel as the entrance (as a glazed sliding door) is right next to the exit of Marunouchi (south) in the station.Given the layout of the heritage building, you might have to go a long way from the reception to your room, but in the corridor you can enjoy many photos of the old Tokyo Station and the neighborhood taken in the early and mid 20th centuries, a treat to those who have an appetite for the history of the area. Also, the long corridors on the 2nd or 3rd floors (where most guest rooms are) are punctuated by some exhibition areas, where you can enjoy the exclusive interior view of the dome overlooking the entrance to JR.Guests can enjoy utmost privacy when returning to the hotel as there are some secondary entrances (very far from the lobby yet much closer to your room) where only those with room keys can tap on some sensor to unlock the doors to the elevators. The rooms are spacious with European decor and high ceilings. The bed is firm yet comfortable with large bedside tables. The bathroom is large with the toilet in its own cubicle separate from the bathtub or shower. Unlike the dim rooms in many other hotels, these rooms are amply lit. The only downside is that even though there are excellent soundproof walls blocking the noise from the traffic outside the hotel, you might hear the noise from the approach and departure of trains in the station below.

Perfectly located near the station. The building extraordinary and monumential. Just renovated to fantastic standard. Not many Europeans have yet found this pearl which I strongly recommend. Friendly staff.

One of the best hotels I've stayed at. Excellent efficient staff and service, beautiful room, awesome location. If you're fortunate to stay here, do. Get a room facing the street-- view is lovely. (I faced the Shin-Marounochi building and pedestrian traffic in front of the hotel. View was nice enough that I bought a few excellent bentos from the nearby Daimaru food hall and enjoyed them looking out the windows.) Otherwise, you'll be facing inwards which, I think, is just a wall.

This place is expensive let me just get that out of the way we had flown into japan realised we couldn't get our JR rail passes yet and had to find a room to sleep, walked into the closets place (Tokyo Station Hotel) the building is gorgeous, we could only get a superior King, cost us about 500AUD, WORTH it, Bed so comfortable you'll never want to leave. amazing shower facilities so much space. best sleep I had in the entire month

This completely renovated Taisho Period Hotel means a lot to the people of Tokyo.It is a Landmark with a lot of memories.The renovation was nicely done with attention to minute details.The ceiling is high ( over 3 meters), and the rooms size is generous for Tokyo,around 22 sq meters.

Absolutely no complaints about our two night stay at the end of our three week trip in Japan. The location in the station (we had a dome room overlooking the activity) was terrific for last minute shopping around Tokyo as well as departing on the Narita Express when it was time to go. Concierge was extremely helpful. Room was perfect, great amenities/facilities, including state of the art keys, lighting in the room etc. The hotel was generally very quiet and enjoyable. Loved it.

We stayed for just night at the end of our stay in Japan, mainly for ease of transportation. The hotel building is stunning, you will find many Japanese outside taking photos. The reception staff are very efficient and helpful. The room was miles away from the reception and took 5 minutes to walk to. The room was small with very high ceilings which helped. The view was of a station platform. The bathroom was small but well equipped. The location is very good. All transport links are obviously literally on your door step. Get the metro about. VERY EASY. There is a shopping centre directly opposite hotel with some cool shops and places to eat. Walk to Ginza from hotel only 5 -10 minutes. One slight annoyance with the hotel was that on returning from dinner at a local restaurant my husband and I fancied a night cap, it was about 11pm, the lobby bar was shut and the other bar on the 2nd floor (i think) is very small and they had no room for us. For such a large hotel you would expect to be able to get a drink or coffee etc before midnight.

Stayed here for one night as it was the last hotel in Tokyo with any rooms during golden week. £200 a night exc breakfast.The propertyVery smart shiny newly done up old station hotel next to the main station. The décor is first class – deep carpets, new paint, shiny brass, great marble. The hotel has small public areas (one lounge, which was so full there was a queue to enter), small reception. Right next to the station so great for train travellers.The roomThe rooms are in two lines – one line looks out over the plaza in front of the hotel (and has large rooms), the other looks out onto the wall of the station six feet away, and so is dark and pokey. We were in the dark rooms. The room was barely 100 feet (cats quite safe). Apart from size and the lack of light and outlook, the room was smart. The window was sealed, making the room feel very stuffy.The bathroomGood sized bath with a power shower over. Not huge but large enough, good smellies.The bedVery comfortable queen sized bed, nice cottons, good bedside lighting.Ambient noise and lightGood curtains closed out the light, but some piece of electrical gear whined outside all night in a maddening falling and rising tone.Other commentsTokyo is expensive, so maybe my frame of reference is not great, but while I would not have minded paying £200 to look out upon a view with 200 feet, I objected to paying £200 to look out on a whiny wall, so this was not a great experience.

As first time visitors to Tokyo, we chose this hotel for the central location, and from recommendations on this site (especially regarding the English speaking concierge). We could not have been happier with our choice. We stayed in a palace side king room for 4 nights. The room, though not overly spacious, was luxurious, the bed wonderful, the decor elegant, and everything new and fresh with every gadget you could need - and free very fast wi-fi. The renovation of this historic building is superb. The concierge explained the history of the building as he escorted us to our room and his pride was evident. Our room was so quiet you could hear a pin drop (amazing considering it's proximity to one of the busiest railway stations in the world). Previous reviewers have mentioned the wonderful bathrooms and the very special Toto washlet toilet. I could go on and on - highly recommend this hotel! Also highly recommend Tokyo as a fabulous holiday destination.
