The rooms are spacious, the beds comfortable, the staff very friendly and helpful, just cannot fault it, I enquired about where I could purchase one of the long shoe horns you find in the rooms, the staff said they would make enquiries and get bacK to me. When they rang back they said they were very expensive, so they would send one up to my room, what great service!

It was a very nice experience for the first 3 nights in Japan. I am so happy that we chose this one as I heard of the new renovated hotel. It uses the latest, state of the art technology every part of the room and building, yet it has good taste and classic atmosphere. You cannot beat the location especially if you use Narita Express and Shinkansen bullet trains. Employees are so nice, professional, and helpful. They gave us the warm, welcoming feelings. Breakfast was superb. We will be repeating customers and will recommend to anyone who is visiting Japan.

I had been waiting and hoping patiently for this place to open, having stayed across the street at the very nice Marunouchi hotel. How happy I was to see what a sterling job they did of bringing back the luxury hotels of yesteryear. Equal in all respects to those great dames of the past, just meandering around the huge property made you feel as if a duke, duchess or emperor might appear just around the corner!I read many of the other reviews for this hotel and have trouble understanding any of the negative remarks. Of course I understand that people have different tastes and experiences, but in all ways I found my experience here to be top rate.I think I must have stayed in the same "Dome" room as some of the other reviewers, because I found the same amenities and furnishings, including the crystal chandeliers, the huge and wonder "rain" shower and the separate "personal" room with the porcelain "throne." No one mentioned, though, that this "throne" was one of the technical marvels of the bathroom age, a Toto "Washlet" that does everything for you when you "use" the facility except powder your bottom. No need to even touch the thing! From raising the lid to flushing and lowering it, and everything in between, this is truly a marvel of the age, and something really special. I would like the "not so" Grand Hyatt hotel in New York to come and learn something about great hotel bathrooms!I didn't notice anyone's commenting on the lovely spa downstairs. I didn't use all their services, but just visiting the Japanese style bath (I was told you can't call it an onsen because they don't have natural mineral water being piped up from under the ground) made for a very relaxing experience. As I'm sitting in my room right now, I believe I'll be making a quick trip down there for an invigorating soak when I finish this.So I basically have to agree with all the good comments that were made about this hotel, from the "surprisingly quiet" comment to "Great Hotel in the heart of the city." I definitely will stay here when I visit Japan again, because it's worth every penny you have to spend on it. A wonderful time here!

This is the first time I stay in this hotel， experience is not good at all except the breakfast is good but expensive， still i think the breakfast is worth cos i can see the chef has the heart to make such delicious breakfast buffet. The service there are not good at all. Conceige are so slow and impatience。a google map print need to stand more than 10 min. The conceige staff are not friendly at all！ everythime i call for the message， they transfer and transfer and end up they cant find my message. Waste me another 5-8 miins waiting for the transfer。 i m a international traveller and always stay at 5 stars for more than 30 years. My comments is I will not pay 530USD per nite for this kind of service standard . I will never go back and refer this hotel to anybody.

Situated above/next to rail lines and the bullet train, the room was surprisingly quiet. The room that we stayed in was in the dome section where the view was not only the beautifully restored dome with its interesting artwork but the coming and going of the commuters. Although the trains do stop running by midnight and start by 5:30 next morning, I could not tell that at least ten different lines were running next door. The room is luxurious starting with the chandelier hanging from the high ceiling. Although the room was a bit tight due to the big comfortable bed and chair with glass side table, it was furnished with two crystal night lamps. It had an iron and ironing board in the closet. Wifi is available. The bathroom has a very nice, deep tub with separate room for toilet. The outside corridor is elegantly decorated using white as the color theme which I am not sure how long that can be maintain. The only drawback for me about this place is the lobby. The lobby is too small to accommodate not just the hotel guests, but the many users of the hotel restaurants. In addition, unlike the other luxury hotels in the area, there is no doorman to greet you as you get off the taxi. We had to drag our luggages from cab to the hotel lobby. The location is obviously convenient being so close to the trains, shopping areas, and plenty of restaurants. However, have to learn to work the underground passage way to the other side of station without going through the JR turnstiles. And being Tokyo Station, the place is crowded.

Great location right downtown! Walking distance to many areas and the train right at your feet. Stayed here just one night on a business trip but had a great experience. Staff were very friendly and helpful. We caught the Nozomi (bullet train) to Kyoto and you can just walk right out of the hotel in to the station. Very convenient! I highly recommend this hotel.

Stayed for few nights in mid Dec 2012, whilst they had a superb offer so value for the buck was great for the superb service and facility this newly restored Tokyo Station Hotel have to offer. Amazing layout and they have done a fantastic job in restoring the place to a top notch scale but keeping the pre-existing features throughout the building. Really enjoyed the stay and would definitely like to come back again.

We stayed at the Tokyo station hotel for a occasion of our anniversary. 我們決定入住東京車站飯店是為了慶祝週年紀念日As we asked the hotel to help us to reserve two ticket of the NHK symphony orchestra, because the overseas online booking of their performances is not allowed, we explained this request is for our anniv day. 為了慶祝這個特別日子，我們想要到NHK音樂廳去聽一場由NHK交響樂團演出的音樂會，但是我們發現海外聽眾無法在網站上先行預定音樂會的票，於是我們決定試著請飯店協助我們預訂這場音樂會的席位。為了讓這個請求實現的可能性提高，我們在發信給飯店時，解釋了這個特殊日子以及我們的需求。The hotel did not only booked the seats for us, but also arranged souvenir photo taking in our room, and there was a welcoming and wishes card on the room table congratulating us. We felt very warm with their arrangements and kind help. The room we stayed was in the dome, with a perfect view of the Tokyo Station entrance, and so close to the dome top so that we can appreciate the decoration closely. The room was small but very comfortable, with well chosen furniture and tableware, and a very nice bath room. The reconstruction project kept the decoration of the building and the room meets the Taisho style when the hotel first established. This created an atmosphere of european nostalgia.The buffet breakfast in the Atrium level was another highlight of this stay. The sunlight came from the glass window. With a 9 meter high ceiling, the restaurant provided a spacious comfortable environment for their guests. Food was great. Just 1 lowlight that we found a small litter under the room desk. But this dose not diminish what wonderful experience Tokyo Station Hotel had brought us!Special thanks to the Chief Guest Relations, Ms. Mori and her team members. Her professional help and arrangements has made this stay an incredible memory.

Just returned from Tokyo and a great stay at the newly refurbished Tokyo Station Hotel. After six years of renovation, the hotel that sits atop Tokyo's busiest train station has reopened and sets new standards for elegance and comfort. The staff is wildly accommodating, the public spaces of the hotel are beautiful and comfortable, and the rooms are absolutely ideal. My room, in the cupola of the station's dome, felt like a magical little hideway ensconced high atop the station. The room had sweeping ceilings graced with a crystal chandelier, beautifully appointed furnishings, an incredibly comfortable bed and a great bathroom (check out the ceiling mounted falling water shower head). The breakfast atrium is particularly lovely and comfortable. Every minute spend inside the hotel feels cosseted and graceful ... a stark contrast to the hustle and bustle of the train station just outside the doors. Check out the beautiful and discreet bars, Camellia and Oak Bar, for a chic midnight drink. A very special place!

this hotel underwent a recent remodel/restoration which is a great improvement on the old Tokyo station hotel; very convenient location in the west side of the Tokyo Station building; rooms are beautiful, quiet; breakfast is expensive

The hotel is ideally located right outside Tokyo Station, which means there is no need to change trains after taking the train from Narita airport into Central Tokyo. This makes things very handy, not just for international comings and going, but also for domestic train journeys as Tokyo station is a main hub. As for the hotel, rooms are brand new and, while not huge, the height of the ceilings make the room feel very spacious. For us, one particularly memorable plus was the concierge desk. As well as being completely fluent in English (not a given), one gentleman on the desk was kind enough upon seeing me walk into the hotel to hand me a print out of a map showing me the directions of how to get to a restaurant I had asked him to book earlier that morning. I've never had this kind of thoughtful service, even at some of the most famous hotels who are supposedly known for their service. That aside, the hotel is also convenient if on business as it's in the business district and also next to Ginza if you want some high end shopping. If you want hip and happening (like my last visit), try Shinjuku. If you want something more refined, try here.

Impreccably clean. Recently renovated. Excellent staff service. You need a train pass to conveniently walk to the main underground mall which is connected to it. If you dont have a train pass, you can purchase one. Not expensive, but a weird arrangement. The hotel rooms are not large, but they had to fit in the existing historical building, so can't really complain. Beds and linen excellent. The huge rain shower in the bathroom is reason enough to stay there. Location is within Tokyo Station. Surroundings mostly office buildings so not much touristy things to do there, but go underground and there are countless shops and restaurants. Ginza is 10 minutes walk away, Imperial Palace 8 minutes walk.

If you're expecting American-size rooms, you're going to be disappointed. This is not only Japan, it's Marunouchi after all. But the tall ceilings mitigate any sense of oppression and the gorgeous appointments in the room quickly transport you to a state of luxury and refinement. The artwork hanging in the corridors is a nice touch reminding guests of the historical significance of the place. Even if you're not splurging on one of their DOME rooms, you can stroll over to one of the little observation areas (I think there are 3 on each floor). Here you can enjoy the view down into the station rotunda that would otherwise cost you an extra Y10,000. Squint hard and you might even be able to see the markers indicating the spots where 2 prime ministers were assassinated. Service in Japanese hotels is consistently top-notch, but here it is elevated to an exceptional level. One feels compelled to tip, but Japan has done just fine without that custom. Let's not corrupt them. By Japanese standards, I would give this hotel perfect scores across the board, but international guests might not consider it an excellent value and the rooms might feel a bit cramped and thus the deducted points.

Coming in late from Narita, this hotel was a pleasant place to land. The rooms are spacious and well appointed. The staff impecable. We definately will stay here again. The location is also the best jumping off point for train travel from Tokyo.
user_name:
Elizabeth T
Los Angeles, California, United States

review_body: Perhaps because it is recently reopened or possibly the Frank Lloyd Wright background, the Tokyo Station Hotel is one of long lines. It doesn't matter whether it is the restrooms, elevators or certainly the lounges, don't plan to get in and out in a hurry or even slowly.Though everything was new and shiny, our room was slightly larger than a closet at many of the grand old hotels. For what it is worth, the ceilings were very high. I kept picturing being in an experiment to see if vertical height made up for floor space, and for me it didn't. I like to be able to open a suitcase without forcing the other person to climb on the bed or stand in the bathroom. Detracting further from the overall experience was the view was of a side of a building. Perhaps we were just unlucky and got the only really lousy room, but we did not experience the truly minimal size elsewhere in Japan or even at the other Tokyo hotels and ryokans I stayed at during other trips. The good news is we were happy to stay there one night and now can choose not to stay there again.
